headline: CONTEMPORARY ART:A SPECIAL REPORT : A young artist in Umbria re-examines contours of Photorealism
abstract: TODI, Italy—  Of all recent art movements, few were execrated by the modernists so virulently as Photorealism. The painters and sculptors of this school, which emerged in the United States in the mid-1960s, produced more or less exact copies of photographs (or in the case of sculptures, often direct body casts), recording seemingly banal city scenes, suburban streets, storefronts, diners, consumer goods, automobiles and motorcycles, with phenomenal adeptness, but with a disconcerting level of emotional detachment.

headline: Seoul moves to avert UN battle over North Korea
abstract: SEOUL:—  South Korea has opened a diplomatic offensive to avert a bitter battle in the United Nations Security Council when members meet Wednesday to debate the North Korean nuclear program.

headline: This Time, Bonds and Stocks May Prosper Together
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column on improved outlook for bonds; holds Federal Reserve's plan to keep interest rates low even in face of economic recovery suggests bonds can perform well for longer than had been expected, even if stock market rallies in tandem with economy; graph of total bond and stock returns (M)

headline: Battle at Karbala, Key City South of Capital
abstract: American forces attacked a Republican Guard division in what officials said was the beginning of a drive to push through the outer defenses of the Iraqi capital.

type: Money and Business/Financial DeskMoney and Bus
headline: Charity in Cyberspace
abstract: Graphs and other data profiling operations of Goodwill Industries, charitable organization that now runs Internet auction site

headline: Hewlett Says Plan for PC's Is Corporate Money-Saver
abstract: Hewlett-Packard plans to announce a technology initiative today that it says can reduce a corporation's cost of owning and managing personal computers at least 45 percent, by shifting processing power to a central bank of shared computers.    The new effort, to be discussed at a meeting with industry analysts in New York, is part of Hewlett-Packard's drive to use its sizable investments in research and software to gain an edge on its chief rival in the personal computer business, Dell Computer.

headline: Frontier of Military Technology Is the Size of a Molecule
abstract: Nanotechnology is being used to detect presence of chemical or biological weapons; nanotechnology is field of intense interest to Defense Department; department has supported research into it for more than two decades and expects to spend about $243 million in current fiscal year; total federal budget of nanotechnology research and development is $774 million; nanotechnology's power lies in fact that common materials like carbon, when reduced to nanoscale, often exhibit unexpected traits like surprising strength; US Army has committed $50 million work with Massachusetts Institute of Technology over five years, which will be matched by cash and other contributions from MIT and other industrial partners; MIT director Dr Edwin L Thomas comments; some start-up companies like Arryx Inc are trying to build nanoscale products directly; photo (M)

headline: From China's Provinces, a Crafty Germ Breaks Out
abstract: Article traces rise of corona virus that causes severe acute respiratory syndrome in Guangdong, China, province known for exotic cuisine prepared from freshly killed beasts; unusually high percentage of early SARS victims were in catering profession, offering possible clue to how germ that most resembles chicken and rodent viruses gained ability to infect humans; first victims became ill in Dec; alarmed health departments in three Guangdong cities reported strange pneumonia clusters in early Jan to provincial authorities, who concluded that they were facing highly infectious pneumonia caused by previously unknown agent; disease spread until mid-Mar before Italian doctor working in Hanoi, Vietnam, alerted World Health Organization; doctors were placing SARS patients during period in ordinary wards, exposing health workers and others; map; chronology of events; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Computer Network Agrees To Buy Inrange
abstract: Computer Network Technology Corp acquires Inrange Technologies Corp, unit of SPX Corp, for $190 million in cash; plans to cut undisclosed number of sales, information technology and administrative jobs as part of purchase; graph (S)

headline: Internet Is Losing Ground in Battle Against Spam
abstract: Alyx Sachs is no longer sending people e-mail offering to ''fix your credit risk free.''    Confronted by an increasing number of individuals, businesses and Internet service providers using software meant to identify and discard unwanted junk e-mail -- commonly known as spam -- Ms. Sachs has been forced to become more creative in her marketing pitches. The subject line on her credit e-mail, for example, now reads ''get a fresh start.''

headline: Boeing and Air Force Agree To $16 Billion Tanker Deal
abstract: Defense Dept says Boeing Co has agreed to lease 100 fuel-tanker planes to Air Force for about $16 billion over six years, ending year and half of price haggling; Air Force will have option after lease to buy 767's for $4 billion; Rep Norm Dicks comments (M)

headline: U.S. Acts to Limit Influence Of Iran in Iraq's Politics
abstract: American military in Iraq reports capture of fighters from Badr Brigade, Iraqi exiles backed by Iran; plans to station military forces along major routes from Iran to try to stop further infiltration by Iranian-backed forces; White House has warned Iran not to capitalize on power vacuum and confusion after ouster of Saddam Hussein's government to interfere in Iraq's affairs; there has been steady trickle of intelligence reports in recent weeks about efforts by Iran to influence and shape events inside Iraq (M)

headline: Another Ex-HealthSouth Executive Charged With Fraud
abstract: Federal prosecutors filed criminal charges against Michael Martin, a former chief financial officer, alleging conspiracy to commit wire and securities fraud.

headline: Baghdad Air War Shifts With G.I.'s in the City
abstract: US fighter-bombers begin 24-hour combat patrols over Baghdad to support allied ground forces now encircling Iraqi capital and to prepare for possible block-by-block fighting (S)

headline: A Convoy Of Russians Is Attacked Near Baghdad
abstract: Nearly two dozen Russian diplomats and journalists comes under attack twice as they are leaving Baghdad in automobile convoy; at least five are wounded, reportedly including Russian Ambassador Vladimir Titorenko; officials and witnesses disagree as to whether attacks came from Iraqi or American-led forces (M)

headline: Prices That Are All Over the Map
abstract: Annual AAA survey finds that travelers heading to domestic destinations this summer can find some good deals, especially in nation's heartland; tables show most expensive, and least expensive, places to stay; charts (M)

headline: Managing Editors Are Named At 3 Magazines in People Group
abstract: Three magazines in People group of Time Inc have new editors; Barbara O'Dair, managing editor of Teen People, is being succeeded by Amy DuBois Barnett, editor in chief of Honey, magazine aimed at young black women; O'Dair will stay with company and move to Time Inc Interactive and develop content for AOL's teenage channel; Kristin van Ogtrop is named managing editor of Real Simple magazine, succeeding Carrie Tuhy; Richard Perez-Feria will become managing editor of People en Espanol (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Firefighters Settle Dispute
abstract: British firefighters and government reach agreement and rank and file vote to accept 16% pay increase over next two and half years and to streamline service; agreement ends nine months of conflict and strikes that caused military on several occasions to assume firefighting duties (S)

headline: Cut From Another Cookie
abstract: Dan Dillon, chief executive of Welch's, juice maker in Concord, Mass, comments on his life and career; photo (M)

headline: Drug Maker's Vow to Donate Cancer Medicine Falls Short
abstract: Novartis promised two years ago to give away revolutionary cancer drug Glivec to people around world who could not afford it, but pharmaceutical company's ambitious pledge has been only partially fulfilled; 2,000 patients in United States have gotten free medication, but effort has fallen short elsewhere, with drug being given to just 1,500 patients outside US; critics say Novartis is using donations as marketing strategy with goal of building Glivec sales to $1 billion annually; in India, for example, Novartis halted program after government let local companies eat into profits by selling generic version of drug; in wealthier countries like South Korea, Hong Kong and New Zealand, Novartis has encouraged patients who received free drugs to become advocates, pressing public health systems to buy Glivec; Novartis chose tiny nonprofit group Max Foundation to run international patient assistance program after established charities turned down job, but there have been complaints over effectiveness of foundation's functioning; photos (M)

headline: AstraZeneca Pleads Guilty In Cancer Medicine Scheme
abstract: British pharmaceutical maker AstraZeneca pleads guilty to health care fraud in case involving prostate cancer drug Zoladex; will pay total of $355 million, which includes $64 million criminal fine, $291 million to settle most civil accusations and $25 million to settle accusations of fraud against Medicare; company admits it gave doctors free samples of Zoladex knowing that government would be billed, but disputes charge that it inflated price of Zoladex reported for Medicare reimbursement; chart; photo (M)

headline: Why So Cheery About I.B.M.?
abstract: Market Watch column on cheer among some analysts, though not all, about prospects for IBM; stock price graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Negotiation Over Journalist
abstract: Sen Richard G Lugar, chairman of Foreign Relations Committee, asks Indonesian government to ensure safety of journalist William Nessen if he leaves rebel area in Aceh province; Nessen has expressed fears that military will kill or arrest him (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Inquiry Into Files On Nazis
abstract: Argentine government orders investigation into disappearance of entry documents issued by Juan Peron's administration, which was in power between 1946-1955, to more than 300 fugitive World War II war criminals and Nazis (S)

headline: Sniper Fire Greets G.I.'s in Big City in North
abstract: American Special Forces troops enter Mosul, Iraq, after organized Iraqi resistance flees, finding city engulfed by anarchy; quickly retreat; incursion followed talks with tribal and Baath Party leaders intended to bring about peaceful surrender of city, homeland of Sunni Arab nationalism; armed Kurds in civilian clothes drive around city flying flag of Kurdish Democratic Party; thousands of Kurdish troops remain outside city; Kurds in city stage small-scale uprising; city's Arabs begin attacking Americans; Arabs and Kurds blame US for not moving soldiers into Mosul quickly enough to stop looting; photo (M)

headline: Delta Gets Some Stiff Competition on a Key Route
abstract: Delta Air Lines is scrambling to cope with competition that has spread as quickly here as a California wildfire: two low-cost airlines are challenging it for passengers between this city and Atlanta, on what until now was the country's biggest nonstop route with no rivalry.    The entrance of JetBlue Airways and AirTran Airways into the market is forcing Delta to increase by about 50 percent the number of daily flights and to offer triple miles to frequent fliers on that route. Most noticeably, it has also drastically cut fares -- from at least $1,151 for a one-way walk-up ticket in March to $249 for a nonrefundable one-way walk-up fare in June.

headline: Tape Shows Hussein But Resolves Nothing
abstract: As the Bush administration continued efforts to find whether President Saddam Hussein of Iraq was alive or dead, an Abu Dhabi television station broadcast a videotape showing Mr. Hussein greeting well-wishers in a Baghdad neighborhood. The station said it was told the tape was made on April 9, the day Mr. Hussein's statue in a central Baghdad square was pulled down. American intelligence officials expressed doubt about the date of the tape.

headline: MOODY'S CUTS RATING ON TENET DEBT TO JUNK STATUS
abstract: Tenet Healthcare Corp's debt is cut to junk, or below investment grade, by Moody's Investors Service (S)

headline: TiVo Exceeds Estimates as Loss Narrows
abstract: TiVo Inc reports net loss of $7.88 million in its fiscal first quarter ended April 30 compared with loss of $35.2 million year ago; revenue rose to $28.5 million from $13 million (S)

headline: Suit Over Sale of Clayton Homes to Buffett
abstract: Orbis Investment Management Ltd asks Delaware court to help it block Warren E Buffett's $1.7 billion purchase of Clayton Homes Inc, mobile-home maker in which Orbis has 5 percent stake; Orbis says price is too low (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Stitches Out; NORTHERN IRELAND: Charges In Lawyer'S Killing; ITALY: Mcdonald'S Sues Food Critic;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat Sells Unit
abstract: Fiat enters into exclusive talks to sell aerospace unit FiatAvio for 1.6 billion euros ($1.7 billion) to combination of Carlyle Group and Finmeccanica (S)

headline: National Do-Not-Call Registry Overwhelmed by Eager Public
abstract: Federal do-not-call registry web site is overwhelmed by consumers wishing to be protected from phone-based marketing soliciations; Federal Trade Commission reports that 735,000 consumer telephone numbers were registered on-line and via toll-free phone service on first day of availability; is adding capacity to handle heavy demand (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As Prices Fall For Crude Oil, OPEC Leader Calls for Talks
abstract: OPEC's president Abdullah al-Attiyah calls for special meeting April 24 to discuss recent slide in oil prices, which have fallen almost 20 percent since before war with Iraq began; says market is full of oil and is facing glut, not shortage; price of crude oil for May delivery closes at $27.96, down 66 cents; Energy Department says average price at pump for regular unleaded gasoline fell 1.9 cents, to $1.63 per gallon, in week ended April 7; Petroleum Industry Research Foundation president Lawrence J Goldstein says any change in output will probably not take effect until June or July mainly because OPEC members already have contracts with buyers for next month's oil sales; graph (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Mazda Reports Profit Surge; INDIA: Industrial Growth; MALAYSIA: Bank Merger Advances; SOUTH KOREA: Truckers On Strike; SOUTH KOREA: An Sk Warning;.

headline: Colombia's Long Civil War Spreads Turmoil to Venezuela
abstract: Colombia's 39-year-old civil war is spreading armed leftist rebels, right-wing death squads, drugs and refugees to neighboring Ecuador, Panama, Brazil and, especially, Venezuela, where 1,400-mile border has become flash point between left-leaning government of Pres Hugo Chavez and its ideological opposite in Colombia under Pres Alvaro Uribe; photo; map (M)

headline: U.S. Seeks Solid Core to Fix Iraq's Broken Legal System
abstract: US military and civilian teams face complex task of rebuilding legal and justice apparatus that has brutalized Iraqis for decades, trying to separate those who brutalized populace from those who felt compelled to join Baath Party to work or stay alive; questioning by Army lawyer Major Charlotte R Herring of Iraqi lawyer, Fatima Suaad Ibrahim, described; Ibrahim explains Iraq's system of matrimonial, civil and criminal courts, as well as political tribunals run directly under Saddam Hussein; photos (M)

headline: British Court Orders Extradition in French Bombing Case
abstract: A British court ordered today the extradition of an Algerian man accused of participation in a series of bombings in the Paris subway and commuter train system in 1995.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TIFFANY, New York, the retailer of luxury jewelry, increased its quarterly dividend to 5 cents from 4 cents a share, the first increase in three years.    BBA GROUP, London, a plane repairer and provider of airport services, said it would buy the Midcoast Aviation Fixed Base Operation at Lambert-St. Louis International Airport for $9.5 million.

headline: Azteca in Debt Deal
abstract: Azteca Holdings negotiates exchange with holders of slightly more than half of $150 million in bonds maturing in July; company is short of cash and has been seeking to negotiate exchange since March (S)

headline: Remarks by Iran's President Indicate No Sign of Thaw With U.S.
abstract: Pres Mohammad Khatami of Iran, on final day of visit to Lebanon, dampens any notion that relations between Iran and United States might be warming; heaps praise on Lebanon-based militant Islamic movement Hezbollah, which Washington considers terrorist organization backed by Iran and Syria and wants disarmed; denies that Iran supplies or directs it; his three-day visit to Lebanon is closely watched for his response to American concerns; relatively moderate tone he takes is no surprise, given his position in Iran as reformist counter to supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who has ruled out restoring diplomatic ties with US; Khatami says series of quiet contacts between Iranian and American officials during past year are not leading to diplomatic relations, which were severed after 1979 Islamic revolution in Iran; Bush administration also has discounted that idea (M)

headline: OPEC Production Cut Is Less Than Expected
abstract: OPEC surprises oil market by announcing smaller-than-expected production cut; will reduce production to termporary limit of 25.4 million barrel per day starting June 1; will remove 2 million barrels per day from market; estimate of current output of 27.4 million barrels is higher than outside experts' calculations; OPEC was expected to abide by its previous quota of 24.5 million barrels, set in January; OPEC secretary general Alvaro Silva and president Abdullah al-Attiyah comment; crude oil for June delivery falls 1 cent, to $26.64 per barrel; graph; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- Buenos Aires; Where Glamour and Chaos Merge
abstract: Travel article on Buenos Aires as business destination; photo (M)p

headline: Investing; A Rally for Funds, and Their Families
abstract: THE rally in stocks since mid-March has been welcomed by most investors, but those who hold shares in companies whose primary business is managing mutual funds and other financial assets have had even more reason to celebrate. From March 10 through Thursday, the Lipper management company index, a group of asset managers, gained 35.5 percent, compared with 23.2 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.     ''When the stock markets go up, the stocks of the asset managers go up even more,'' said George A. Roche, the chairman of T. Rowe Price, one of the companies in the group.

headline: Life of Privilege Is Now a Boozy Miasma
abstract: Twenty-seven-year-old man, son of family once favored by Saddam Hussein's government, says now that Hussein is gone, his life has become blur of booze and bordeom; since the war started, his father, who held high-level civilian job in Basra, has been arrested by allied forces; his pregnant wife left him, saying she feared for her life; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Grocer Selects Executives
abstract: Royal Ahold discloses several management changes, including appointment of Dick Anbeek as new chief financial officer for Ahold Europe (S)

headline: Gauging Ticket Demand
abstract: To the Editor:    If teams are varying their ticket pricing to make the most of games against stellar teams, why not go further? How about considering other factors: charging less, for example, when a star player is out of the lineup (a k a the use of an understudy) or when you have to sit next to a rowdy drunk? Pricing could also consider an opponent's winning percentage, over the last 10 games, as well as factors like the weather and the last time the team's owner made a trip to the clubhouse.     As the joke goes, an economics professor who is grading exams is visited by a former student. The former student remarks that the questions were the same as when he took the test. To which the professor responds, ''But I've changed the answers.''    MICHAEL BOGNER  Wall Township, N.J., June 10

headline: Popeyes Ends Ties With Hill, Holliday
abstract: Popeyes Chicken and Biscuits is parting ways with New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos (S),

headline: G.M.'s Quarterly Earnings Beat Forecasts
abstract: First-quarter earnings at General Motors beat Wall Street's expectaitons, but they are viewed skeptically because gains in company's financing operation offset weakness in its automotive operations; net income was $1.48 billion, up from $228 million year earlier; revenue rose to $49.37 billion from $46.21 billion year ago; North American automotive profits fell to $548 million from $654 million, while earnings at General Motors Acceptance Corp rose to $699 million from $439 million; GM's market share fell to 26.6 percent from 28.2 percent in first quarter from year ago; chief financial officer John M Devine comments (M)

headline: Syria Is Forced to Adapt To a New Power Next Door
abstract: Riad al-Turk, Syria's most outspoken dissident, ticks off the roughly one-third of his life spent as a political prisoner: 13 months under the current president, Bashar al-Assad, a whopping 18 years in solitary confinement under Mr. Assad's late father and sundry years or months stretching almost back to independence in 1946.     Now, like everyone in the Middle East, he has a new political factor to consider: the United States military, setting up next door in Iraq as the latest occupying power.

headline: KEMPER SAYS TALKS TO SELL BUSINESSES HAVE COLLAPSED
abstract: KA

headline: Lehman Aided in Loan Fraud, Jury Says
abstract: Federal jury finds bankrupt First Alliance Corp defrauded over 7,500 homeowners who got high-cost home equity loans from it and that Lehman Brothers knowingly assisted in fraud by providing financial backing to company despite warnings about its questionable business practices; awards plaintiffs $50.9 million in damages; holds Lehman responsible for 10 percent of amount, company, its founder, Brian Chisick, and other company executives and directors liable for 85 percent of damages and MBIA Inc, which insured some of mortgage-backed securities, liable for 5 percent (M)

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: Bush Says Hussein's Regime is 'No More'
abstract: The president said the U.S. would now shift its focus from combat to the search for weapons of mass destruction and the conversion of Iraq into a democracy.

headline: British Regulator Gives Edge To Small Bidder for Safeway
abstract: British regulators weigh in on battle for Safeway, indicating in letter to bidders that combination with William Morris Supermarkets stands best chance of winning approval; William Morrison agreed in January to buy Safeway for 2.9 billion pounds ($4.8 billion); Tesco, J Sainsbury and Asda, which is owned by Wal-Mart Stores, as well as entrepreneur Philip Green have made bids (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: HONG KONG: New Chief At Telecom Company; HONG KONG: Unemployment Rises;.

headline: In Hamas Message of Defiance, Gunmen Kill Israeli Settler in West Bank
abstract: Given how methodical Hamas is, the attack could only be interpreted as a message that the organization remains strong and very much active.

headline: Market Place; The American Exchange is being sold as NASD focuses on being a regulatory organization.
abstract: AS Henny Youngman might have said, ''Take my exchange, please.''    For the second time in four years, the American Stock Exchange is being sold, this time to a private equity firm that has agreed to invest $110 million in what was once known as the Curb Exchange because it operated out of doors.

headline: Dollar's Neighbors Feeling Uneasy
abstract: Canadian dollar has risen smartly in value this year, reaching 72.12 cents, its highest level in more than five years; Canadian exporters get 14 percent less of their own money for every American dollar they earn; exporters are feeling pain with 85 percent of Canada's exports going to US; Canadian Manufacturers and Exporters says jump in Canadian dollar is threatening profit margins across Canadian industry and will be significant drag on economic and employment growth this year; graph (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Texas Instruments Lowers Forecasts
abstract: Texas Instruments, world's largest maker of cellular phone chips, cuts second-quarter sales and profit forecasts as demand in Asia fell short of its expectations (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: France needs a new law to keep religion and racism out of state schools, Education Minister Luc Ferry told Europe 1 radio.

headline: Customers Tire of Excuses for Rebates That Never Arrive
abstract: Some companies are rethinking rebates as sales incentives; neither manufacturers nor retailers are accelerating processing, which leaves consumers dissatisfied, in many cases as they await checks that never arrive, and can lead to scrutiny by Federal Trade Commission; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Asylum Seekers Leave
abstract: Great Britain deports first Afghan asylum seekers since 1995; large number of Afghans wishing asylum in Great Britain has caused country to offer $4,000 dollars to any persons willing to return home and to make cuts in number of new arrivals (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: A chart on March 16 with an article about investing in venture capital funds overstated the levels in Europe. The data included private equity investments incorrectly. A corrected chart appears today, on Page 7.

headline: 3 Israelis and 2 Palestinians Are Killed in Separate Shootings
abstract: Two Palestinian gunmen, two Israeli civilians and one Israeli officer are killed in separate shootouts in West Bank city of Nablus and at crossing point to Gaza Strip; Yasir Arafat meets with top members of his Fatah movement to discuss deepening impass over proposed government of new Palestinian Prime Minister Mahmoud Abbas, who has angered Arafat by proposing to promote some of Arafat's critics at expense of his longtime allies; confirmation of new government is Pres Bush's condition for moving ahead with new peace plan (M)

headline: GOODRICH LOWERS FORECAST AND CUTS 1,700 JOBS
abstract: Goodrich Corp plans to lay off 1,700 workers in next two years and slashes its 2003 profit forecast amid falling demand from plane makers; company gets third of sales from Boeing Co and Airbus Industrie, which have cut production; reports first-quarter net income rose to $29.4 million from $14.3 million year earlier; sales rose 23 percent, to $1.1 billion from $896 million (S)

headline: Viacom Reports a Profit; Radio Unit Is Still Troubled
abstract: Viacom Inc posts solid first-quarter results on strong performance from its cable networks, television and video businesses; poor performance at radio business continues to concern investors and management; company reports net income of $443.1 million, reversing loss of $1.1 billion in year earlier; revenue rose 6.7 percent, to $6.05 billion from $5.67 billion; cable network division reports 13 percent increase in revenue, to $1.16 billion, while operating income rose 21 percent, to $432.2 million; Blockbuster Entertainment unit reports 14 percent rise in revenue, to $1.5 billion, and 25 percent rise in operating income, to $148.7 million; operating income in television unit jumped 13 percent, to $242 million, while revenue rose 4 percent, to $1.92 billion; revenue at radio business fell 2 percent, to $443.8 million, while profit was flat at $190.6 million; Viacom confirms it has agreed to acquire 50 percent of Comedy Central that it does not already own from AOL Time Warner for $1.2 billion (M)

headline: American Air Pulls Back Bonus Plans
abstract: American Airlines drops plans to pay large bonuses to seven top executives if they stayed with company until January 2005; says it will keep money in much-criticized trust fund set up to protect pensions of 45 executives in case it files bankruptcy protection; flight attendants' union says it will vote again soon on $340 million in critical concessions its members narrowly agreed to give company on April 16; American announcement comes after union leaders denounced AMR Corp chief executive Donald J Carty and other officials for agreeing to take compensation packages while they were seeking annual labor concessions worth $1.8 billion and for not disclosing them during negotiations; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Party Lagging In Rome Race
abstract: Some analysts contend local Italian elections reflect mixed feelings about Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's government as early results predict his party losing Province of Rome to center-left opposition; Berlusconi has been embroiled in corruption trial (S)

headline: Coca-Cola Reports a Profit, But Fails to Sway Investors
abstract: Coca-Cola Co reports net income in first quarter rose to $835 million compared with net loss of $194 million year earlier; revenue increased 10 percent, to $4.5 billion from $4.1 billion; president-chief operating officer Steven J Heyer comments; Coca-Cola's shares fall $2.63, or 6.2 percent, to $39.90 (M)

headline: COURT DISMISSES SUIT AGAINST BANK OF NEW YORK
abstract: Bank of New York Co wins dismissal of lawsuit that accused it of defrauding three offshore trusts of $40 million they invested in Inkombank, Russian bank that lost its license in 1999; trusts claimed that Bank of New York, which was correspondent for Inkombank, knew Russian bank laundered money and had ties to organize crime when they tried to withdraw their money in 1996; they accused Bank of New York of hiding wrongdoing and of persuading them not to withdraw funds (S)

headline: U.S., in Assessment, Terms Trailers Germ Laboratories
abstract: Bush administration says two mysterious trailers found in Iraq in last two months are mobile units to produce deadly germs and strongest evidence yet that Saddam Hussein was hiding program to prepare for biological warfare; American intelligence official says administration's strong conviction about trailers is based mainly on similarity between testimony of Iraqi sources and evidence found on ground; report posted by Central Intelligence Agency offers six-page analysis done in collaboration with Defense Intelligence Agency; report, with unusual frankness, lists four Iraqi sources it says had given West its insights into alleged mobile germ factories; Matthew S Meselson, expert on biological weapons, offers skeptical view of evidence presented by CIA, noting agency has made technical errors in past; calls on government to turn over its Iraqi evidence to independent panel (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chip Investments
abstract: The Sony Corporation and its video game subsidiary, Sony Computer Entertainment Inc., will team with the Toshiba Corporation to build semiconductors for devices that work on high-speed networks. The companies will invest about 200 billion yen ($1.7 billion) during the next three years and start production in Japan of the large-scale integrated circuits by the second half of 2004. The chips will be code-named Cell and be integrated into the successor to the popular PlayStation 2 game consoles. The companies have worked with I.B.M. on developing the technology for the chips since 2001.   Ken Belson (NYT)

headline: Revamped S.U.V. Found To Cause Worse Injuries
abstract: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says crash test of 2003 Lincoln Navigator sport utility vehicle indicates that it has become more harmful to people riding in passenger cars than 1999 model; finding is significant because Navigator has been marketed by Ford Motor Co as vehicle redesigned in ways that made it less dangerous to passenger car occupants in two-vehicle collisions; agency researcher Stephen M Summers comments (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Names Executive
abstract: BNP Paribas names Baudouin Prot, joint

headline: Once-Weakening Peso Rebounds, Creating Economic Commotion
abstract: Once-weakening Mexican peso has rebounded, creating economic problems; peso hit low of 11.2300 to dollar on March 10, and has risen in value by 10 percent since then, reaching 10.1125 to dollar; higher peso rises in value against dollar, more expensive and less competitive Mexican exports become in US, country's most important market; Mexico's foreign-currency reserves, important bulwark against financial crises, stand at healthy $53.7 billion; graph (M)

headline: Powell Says U.S. Is Studying North Korean Nuclear Offer
abstract: North Korea has given the United States a plan that could lead to the Koreans dismantling their nuclear weapons program, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today.

headline: Menem Takes Early Lead in Argentine Presidential Election
abstract: Former Pres Carlos Saul Menem is running neck and neck with fellow Peronist Nestor Kirchner, first-time candidate for national office, with 90 percent of vote counted in Argentina's presidential election; country appears headed for first runoff vote in its history; Menem, whose many critics contended was washed up, leads pack of 18 candidates with 24 percent of vote to 22 percent of vote for Kirchner, self-styled reform candidate who accuses Menem of corruption and betraying Peronist ideals; opinion polls indicate that Kirchner is favorite in runoff on May 18; Menem has highest rate of rejection of any political figure in country; photo (M)

headline: VIVENDI IS SELLING SPENCER GIFTS TO REDUCE DEBT
abstract: Vivendi Universal SA agrees to sell its Spencer Gifts United States retail chain to investors led by Gordon Brothers Group LLC (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: MGM Mirage Will Close Online Gambling Unit
abstract: MGM Mirage will close its online casino division at end of month because of 'unclear' legal and political climate with regard to online gambling (S)

headline: 2 PC Makers Given Credit And Blame In Recycling
abstract: Silicon Valley Toxics Coalition and Computer Take Back Campaign release study on different ways Dell Computer and Hewlett-Packard handle recycling of waste from computer products; commends Hewlett-Packard for using 'state of the art' practices in partnership with expanding commercial recycling industry, while criticizing Dell for using low-cost prison labor in association with Unicor, industrial prison system within Justice Department; photo (M)

headline: New Economy; New efforts are being made to keep online merchants from collecting personal information from children.
abstract: Privacy-rights groups are trying to expand number and kinds of commercial Web sites that must comply with federal law meant to protect children's privacy online; want Federal Trade Commission to weigh Amazon.com claim that it does not come under law because its site is not aimed at children; law bars children's Web sites from letting children reveal data about themselves without parental approval; drawing (M)

headline: Intuit's Earnings More Than Double in Quarter
abstract: Intuit Inc reports net income increased to $294 million in its fiscal third quarter April 30 from $144.5 million year earlier; sales rose to $634.7 million from $491.2 million, higher than analysts expected (M)

headline: Art Directors Club Announces Awards
abstract: Art Directors Club announces winners of its annual awards; Chicago office of DDB Worldwide wins most awards, followed by Wieden & Kennedy (S)

headline: In Afghanistan, Helping Can Be Deadly
abstract: Killing of Ricardo Munguia, Red Cross water engineer in Afghanistan, by suspected Taliban members underscores increasingly dire circumstances around delivering aid to southern Afghanistan, where US military continues to wage war against Taliban militants, and reveals deep unease among aid workers about dangers they face and their fear that aid programs will be cut or curtailed because of such killings; some aid workers accuse United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistn of playing down gravity of their predicament; Munguia's killing is described as both random and calcuated (M)

headline: After the Pitch, Life Became A New Game
abstract: Profile of Floyd Hall, owner of New Jersey Jackals minor league baseball team; photo (special section, Small Business)

headline: The Question in Cairo: Will Soap Prices Fall And Democracy Rise?
abstract: Fall of Saddam Hussein is having profound psychological and political implications in Egypt, and rebuilding will be judged there on its effect upon issues at home; main concerns are fragile economy and political liberalization (M)

headline: Wholesale Inventories Rise, Perhaps Threatening Growth
abstract: Commerce Department repor

headline: A Bit of Ingenuity in Your Ear Makes Phone Dialing Effortless
abstract: BlueSpoon Digital cellphone headset fits in user's ear and acts as earpiece and microphone for compatible cellphones; photo (M)

headline: LABRANCHE SAYS EARNINGS TO FALL BELOW EXPECTATIONS
abstract: LaBranche & Co, leading specialist on New York Stock Exchange, expects its first-quarter profit to fall short of Wall Street's expectations (S)

headline: If Only Wall Street Had Listened at the Time
abstract: Hunter College and Franklin and E

headline: Feeding Frenzy Under Way, as Companies From All Over Seek a Piece of the Action
abstract: Companies from around the world and their governments are besieging Washington to get piece of reconstruction action in Iraq, rushing to compete for contracts in what could be biggest reconstruction effort since Marshall Plan in postwar Europe; pleas are lavished mostly on Bechtel Corp, lead contractor; British Trade Minister Lady Symons visits to make point that Britain is excellent partner in both war and peace; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Andreotti Cleared Of Mafia Charge
abstract: Former seven-time Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti is once again cleared of connections with Italian mafia by Sicilian appeals court; Andreotti's sentence of 24 years in prison for his involvement in 1979 murder of Italian journalist is being appealed; photo (S)

headline: Reported SARS Cases in Beijing Take Sharp 2-Day Jump
abstract: Reported cases in Beijing of SARS climbed by 249 to 588 as the government continued its belated campaign to give honest figures.

headline: Draft of European Union's Constitution Wins General Support
abstract: European leaders broadly endorsed the draft of a first-ever constitution for the European Union at a summit meeting here today.

headline: Zeal for Suicide Bombing Reaches British Midlands
abstract: British government identifies suicide bomber who killed three people in Tel Aviv nightclub and his alleged accomplice as British citizens; says Asif Hanif, who died in attack, and Omar Khan Sharif, who reportedly escaped after failing to detonate his bomb, are first Britons known to be prepared to kill themselves in militant Islamic cause; two grew up in Britain in middle-class or blue-collar environments; this seems to set them apart from more typical image of suicide bombers molded by hardships of Gaza or West Bank; Hanif's brother says he traveled to Damascus, Syria, to study Arabic; Hamas, which has headquarters in Damascus, has taken responsibility for suicide bombing, as has Aksa Martyrs Brigades, group connected to Yasir Arafat's Fatah movement (M)

headline: Bond Sale Schedule For the Week Ahead
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes the regular auction of new three-  and six-month bills today and a four-week bill tomorrow.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.84 percent, the rate on the six-month issue was 0.92 percent and the rate on the four-week bill was 0.80 percent.

headline: HERSHEY REPLACES 1936 WRAPPER ON ITS CHOCOLATE BARS
abstract: Hershey chocolate bars have new look for first time since 1936 as Hershey Foods Corp replaces traditional wrapper with sealed, one-piece wrapper (S)

headline: Derivatives: Corporate Financial Leverage Wrapped in Enigma
abstract: Analysis: Financial problems at Freddie Mac seems to be centered on confusion on part of directors, managers, auditors, creditors or shareholders about how to deal with complex financial instruments known as derivatives; Freddie Mac's auditor PricewaterhouseCoopers disclosed in January that Freddie Mac might have misreported some of its derivatives trades (M)

headline: Case Could Redefine Board Members' Liability
abstract: Recent ruling by Delaware Chancery Court Judge William B Chandler III allowing shareholder suit against Walt Disney Co and its board of directors to proceed may have broad implications for liability of corporate directors in business decisions; at issue in five-year-old suit is hiring and termination of Michael Ovitz as Disney president; Ovitz served for fourteen months, leaving with $38 million in cash and estimated $100 million in stock options; some lawyers hold that victory by Disney shareholders could make being corporate director too risky; photo (M)

headline: DataBank; Investors Ignore News of Weak Economy
abstract: Performance of financial markets in week ended Apr 4 noted; stock price graphs and tables (S)

headline: OPPOSITION GROUPS TO HELP TO CREATE ASSEMBLY IN IRAQ
abstract: Main Iraqi opposition groups agree to help put together national assembly of more than 350 deputies that would meet this month to name interim executive council or prime minister to run country; Jay Garner, charged with administering Iraq, confirms significant progress on political front; goal of former opposition groups is to create provisional national assembly with two-thirds of delegates chosen from inside Iraq; exiles and their allies among country's Kurdish minority are organizing selection process; Ahmad Chalabi, leader of one opposition coalition who has garnered strongest support from Washington, says his supporters seized tons of documents from Baath Party and Iraqi secret police and intelligence services; says files document Saddam Hussein's relationships with Arab leaders and foreign governments; sends out pointed warnings to those Arab leaders who have dismissed him as lackey, and to Al Jazeera television, which reported that he was under arrest for embezzlement; says he has intelligence reports showing that several Al Jazeera reporters worked for Iraqi intelligence; Chalabi's aides say files show how royal household in Jordan profited secretly and handsomely on transactions with Hussein and his family members; Chalabi has not made any files public, but is allowing Defense Intelligence Agency officers to examine them; discussing their existence and their potential for scandal in dozens of capitals is seen as Chalabi's way of flexing political muscles as he edges closer to power in Iraq; photo (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: McCORMICK & CO. INC., Sparks, Md., said it would sell its packaging business to Kerr Group Inc., Lancaster, Pa., a maker of plastic containers and vials, for $142.5 million, including trade liabilities.    COLONIAL BANCGROUP INC., Montgomery, Ala., operator of 270 branches in six states, said it would buy closely held Sarasota BanCorporation, Sarasota, Fla., parent of Sarasota Bank, for about $40.5 million in stock to expand in Florida.

headline: A Muslim in the Middle in France
abstract: Dr Dali Boubakeur, director of Paris Mosque, France's main mosque, is to become president of new council that will represent country's Muslim population before the government; has already incurred wrath of two major Muslim groups on council, National Federation of the Muslims of France and Union of Islamic Organizations in France, which he has called 'hotheads' and accused of promoting 'militant fundamentalist Islam'; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Getronics To Cut Jobs
abstract: Dutch information technology company Getronics will close 20 offices and eliminate 1,000 to 1,200 jobs as part of reorganization that could cost up to 60 million euros ($66 million) (S)

headline: Indonesia Wants to Acquit General in Human Rights Case
abstract: Indonesian prosecutors tell human rights court that Maj Gen Adam Damiri was not guilty of crimes against humanity when he commanded forces during military-backed rampage in East Timor four years ago; asks aquittal (S)

headline: Ex-Official of HealthSouth Refuses to Answer Questions
abstract: Lawyers for ousted HealthSouth Corp chief executive Richard M Scrushy try to assign blame for multibillion-dollar acounting scandal to former chief financial officer William T Owens, Federal court hearing on whether to continue temporary freeze on Scrushy's assets; Owens repeatedly refuses to answer their questions; Securities and Exchange Commission agrees to give Crushy access to $17 million to pay his taxes; photo (M)

headline: Appointment at Times Co.
abstract: Philip A Ciuffo, executive director of internal audit at New York Times Co, is appointed vice president for internal audit (S)

headline: G.M. Board Set to Sell Control Of Hughes Unit to News Corp.
abstract: General Motors Corp's board is planning to meet to approve deal worth $7 billion that would give control of its Hughes Electronics unit and DirecTV satellite operation to News Corp; deal would end three-year effort by News Corp chairman Rupert Murdoch to take over DirecTV and its 11 million subscribers and add US outlet to his global satellite empire (M)

headline: Crispin, Porter Gets Campaign for Pony
abstract: Pony International, majority owned by Global Brand Marketing Inc, names Crispin, Porter & Bogusky to handle ad account of Pony brand of athletic shoes and apparel, which had been handled internally; spending estimated at $5 million to $7 million (S)

headline: CONTEMPORARY ART:A SPECIAL REPORT : A young artist in Umbria re-examines contours of Photorealism
abstract: TODI, Italy—  Of all recent art movements, few were execrated by the modernists so virulently as Photorealism. The painters and sculptors of this school, which emerged in the United States in the mid-1960s, produced more or less exact copies of photographs (or in the case of sculptures, often direct body casts), recording seemingly banal city scenes, suburban streets, storefronts, diners, consumer goods, automobiles and motorcycles, with phenomenal adeptness, but with a disconcerting level of emotional detachment.

headline: Seoul moves to avert UN battle over North Korea
abstract: SEOUL:—  South Korea has opened a diplomatic offensive to avert a bitter battle in the United Nations Security Council when members meet Wednesday to debate the North Korean nuclear program.

headline: This Time, Bonds and Stocks May Prosper Together
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column on improved outlook for bonds; holds Federal Reserve's plan to keep interest rates low even in face of economic recovery suggests bonds can perform well for longer than had been expected, even if stock market rallies in tandem with economy; graph of total bond and stock returns (M)

headline: Battle at Karbala, Key City South of Capital
abstract: American forces attacked a Republican Guard division in what officials said was the beginning of a drive to push through the outer defenses of the Iraqi capital.

type: Money and Business/Financial DeskMoney and Bus
headline: Charity in Cyberspace
abstract: Graphs and other data profiling operations of Goodwill Industries, charitable organization that now runs Internet auction site

headline: Hewlett Says Plan for PC's Is Corporate Money-Saver
abstract: Hewlett-Packard plans to announce a technology initiative today that it says can reduce a corporation's cost of owning and managing personal computers at least 45 percent, by shifting processing power to a central bank of shared computers.    The new effort, to be discussed at a meeting with industry analysts in New York, is part of Hewlett-Packard's drive to use its sizable investments in research and software to gain an edge on its chief rival in the personal computer business, Dell Computer.

headline: Frontier of Military Technology Is the Size of a Molecule
abstract: Nanotechnology is being used to detect presence of chemical or biological weapons; nanotechnology is field of intense interest to Defense Department; department has supported research into it for more than two decades and expects to spend about $243 million in current fiscal year; total federal budget of nanotechnology research and development is $774 million; nanotechnology's power lies in fact that common materials like carbon, when reduced to nanoscale, often exhibit unexpected traits like surprising strength; US Army has committed $50 million work with Massachusetts Institute of Technology over five years, which will be matched by cash and other contributions from MIT and other industrial partners; MIT director Dr Edwin L Thomas comments; some start-up companies like Arryx Inc are trying to build nanoscale products directly; photo (M)

headline: From China's Provinces, a Crafty Germ Breaks Out
abstract: Article traces rise of corona virus that causes severe acute respiratory syndrome in Guangdong, China, province known for exotic cuisine prepared from freshly killed beasts; unusually high percentage of early SARS victims were in catering profession, offering possible clue to how germ that most resembles chicken and rodent viruses gained ability to infect humans; first victims became ill in Dec; alarmed health departments in three Guangdong cities reported strange pneumonia clusters in early Jan to provincial authorities, who concluded that they were facing highly infectious pneumonia caused by previously unknown agent; disease spread until mid-Mar before Italian doctor working in Hanoi, Vietnam, alerted World Health Organization; doctors were placing SARS patients during period in ordinary wards, exposing health workers and others; map; chronology of events; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Computer Network Agrees To Buy Inrange
abstract: Computer Network Technology Corp acquires Inrange Technologies Corp, unit of SPX Corp, for $190 million in cash; plans to cut undisclosed number of sales, information technology and administrative jobs as part of purchase; graph (S)

headline: Internet Is Losing Ground in Battle Against Spam
abstract: Alyx Sachs is no longer sending people e-mail offering to ''fix your credit risk free.''    Confronted by an increasing number of individuals, businesses and Internet service providers using software meant to identify and discard unwanted junk e-mail -- commonly known as spam -- Ms. Sachs has been forced to become more creative in her marketing pitches. The subject line on her credit e-mail, for example, now reads ''get a fresh start.''

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ad Agency's Profit Slips
abstract: Dentsu Inc, Japan's largest advertising agency, says that it earned 23 billion yen ($198 million) in year ended March 31, decline of 16 percent from year before (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat's Loss Grows
abstract: Fiat SpA reports larger first-quarter loss and says rest of 2003 will be difficult and challenging; lost 681 million euros ($787 million) in quarter compared with loss of 529 million euros year earlier; revenue fell 15 percent, to 12.3 billion euros ($14.2 billion); car unit posts drop in sales and operating loss of 334 million euros (S)

headline: In Baghdad's Anarchy, the Insane Went Free
abstract: Iraq's only hospital providing long-term care for chronic schizophrenia and other serious mental disorders was all but destroyed during war, leaving patients to wander off; some got shot and killed, others got raped by looters; of more than 1,400 Iraqis institutionalized at Al Rashad state hospital in Baghdad, 300 remain; Iraqi psychiatric staff accuses marines of standing by as looters carried away everything within hospital; staff says marines then broke door down on maximum security wing and patients fled, untethered from antipsychotic drugs that stabilized many of them; Red Cross has spent $1.5 million over last three years bringing facility almost to Western standards for compassionate care to mentally ill; Dr Olaf Rosset, Norwegian who has overseen project, says he asked US military commanders to send troops to provide security, but they did so only after hospital was all but destroyed; psychiatrists at hospital meet with desperate Iraqis who plead for help in handling disturbed family members who returned home after escaping from hospital; photo (L)

headline: Saudis Arrest 8 in Deadly Riyadh Bombing
abstract: Saudi Interior Min Prince Nayef announces capture of eight suspected militants wanted in connection with bombing attacks on residential compounds in Riyadh; says police raids around holy city of Medina led to total of 11 arrests, including foreign-born wives of three of suspects; American Amb Robert W Jordan says United States believes chances are high that another attack will take place despite arrests; Prince Nayef says those arrested include three radical clerics known for their support of militant causes; Saudi and American officials say Al Qaeda remains prime suspect (M)

headline: Cloaked in Green, But Pushing Trucks
abstract: Toyota Motor Co is introducing its latest Prius, which will get about 55 miles per gallon and be first midsize vehicle with hybrid technology as Ford Motor Co scales back expectations for its first hybrid-powered vehicle and backpedals on pledge to improve fuel economy of its sport utility vehicles; situation is complicated and bleak from perspective of reducing oil consumption; Toyota, Honda Motor and Nissan Motor are flooding American market with SUV's of all sizes; Toyota and Nissan are redoubling efforts to take on last largely unchallenged stronghold of Detroit automakers: pickup truck; sales of new-model SUV's from Japan far outnumber gas-sipping hybrids; graph; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Accountability Is Focus of Rule Aimed at Chiefs Of Wall Street
abstract: Rule proposed by nation's largest securities regulator NASD is expected to require chief executives of brokerage houses to certify that supervision at their firms is adequate to protect investors; is intended to force brokerage executives to make compliance with securities laws and regulations as consequential to executives as pursuit of profit; investigations by NASD and Securities and Exchange Commission into violations perpetrated by Wall Street firms continue (M)

headline: Britain Keeps Its Distance From the Euro, at Least for the Time Being
abstract: Chancel

headline: Delta Air Reports Wider Loss And Plans to Cut More Pilots
abstract: Delta Air Lines says first-quarter widened to $466 million compared with $397 million loss year earlier; sales rose 1.7 percent, to $3.16 billion; says it will lay off 200 pilots by end of May because of lower travel demand; chief executive Leo Mullin comments (M)

headline: Plans for Policing a Postwar Iraq
abstract: Pentagon turns its attention to how to police cities of Iraq and deal with looting, lawlessness and crippled government now that American forces are pushing toward military victory; wants to enlist other allied nations to help secure country and eventually turn security responsibilities over to newly formed Iraqi government; Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz says it may take US more than six months to cede power to Iraqi-led civilian authority; Gen Eric K Shinseki, Army chief of staff, who has clashed with Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, says it will take several hundred thousand troops to keep peace in postwar Iraq, estimate dismissed by Wolfowitz as wildly off the mark; Pentagon officials put figure closer to 100,000 troops; photos (M)

headline: Word for Word on the Web, Isaac Newton's Secret Musings
abstract: Newton Project, joint effort based at University of London, aims to gradually post all of Sir Isaac Newton's previously unpublished work on Web site, including thousands of pages of alchemical and theological writings; material, which may take 15 to 20 years to finish transcribing, will be accompanied by high-resolution images of manuscripts; science historian Mordechai Feingold says even though Newton is famous for his work in math and physics, he did not compartmentalize himself and having complete works available is best way to understand him; photos (M)

headline: Changing Patients' Sexes, and Korean Mores
abstract: Profile of and interview with Dr Kim Seok Kwan, 52, who pioneered sex-change surgery in South Korea in 1986; Kim comments on social changes that have taken place in country and reasons why he decided to undertake transgender surgeries; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: STMicroelectronics Says Income More Than Doubled
abstract: STMicroelectÿ

headline: A Reticent China Undercuts Its Milder New Image
abstract: News analysis on how China's reluctance to reveal data on SARS has undermined five years of diplomacy intended to alter country's image and improve relations with other Asian nations; secrectiveness also reflects China's emphasis on social stability above individuals' well-being; leaders have now pledged to tackle severe new respiratory disease, but still insist China should not be treated as source of SARS; photo (M)

headline: In a Low Key, New E.D.S. Chief Hopes to Regain Skeptics' Trust
abstract: Article on corporate style of Electronic Data Systems' new chief executive Michael H Jordan, who succeeded Richard H Brown; Jordan dismisses speculation that he was brought in to prepare company for merger, as he did turning Westinghouse into candidate for takeover by Viacom, media giant that owns CBS; says strategic alliances, not mergers and acquisitions, will come to define way technology companies like EDS evolve in years ahead; many experts say there is not much fundamentally wrong with EDS; photo (M)

headline: BIG HOSPITAL CHAIN REDUCES PROFIT FORECAST
abstract: HCA Inc says second-quarter pretax profit will be reduced by $110 million to $130 million as company abandons work on new billing system (S)

headline: U.S. May Let Kurds Keep Arms, Angering Shiites
abstract: American occupation authority in Iraq plans to let Kurdish fighters keep their assault rifles and heavy arms, but require Shiite Muslim and other militias to surrender theirs; Shiite leaders of heavily armed political groups that have moved into power vacuum in Iraq strongly oppose plan in private in talks with American and British officials; Lt Gen David D McKiernan says plan will bar militias inside Iraq, news conference; says Kurdish forces are exception because they fought as part of coalition and will keep some forces in self-governing enclaves in north; says Iraqi National Congress militia under Ahmad Chalabi is being 'demilitarized;' plan would let ordinary Iraqis retain some arms, including rifles; L Paul Bremer III, top civilian administrator, formally dissolves Iraq's armed forces as they existed under Saddam Hussein; abolishes Defense and Information Ministries, Republican Guard and other security institutions involved in Hussein regime's most repressive activities; map; photo (M)

headline: Barrels Looted From Nuclear Site Raise Fears for Villagers in Iraq
abstract: Hundreds of Iraqis in village adjacent to nuclear complex in Tuwaitha have been bathing in and drinking water from contaminated barrels stolen from site during war; photos; experts say barrels had held radioactive contaminants and some villagers are suffering from ailments they now attribute to radiation poisoning; US military forces have since sealed off complex but question is why looters were allowed to roam freely for days, ransacking vaults and warehouses that contained material for making 'dirty bombs'; Tuwaitha was most conspicuous element of Iraqi nuclear program, bombed by Israel 22 years ago; IAEA inspectors are now at site, which was bypassed by military in drive toward Baghdad (M)

headline: Mine Owner In Australia Being Bought
abstract: British-Swiss mining company Xstrata agrees to acquire MIM Holdings, Australian miner of coal and base metals, for $2.04 billion in cash; deal would expand Xstrata's principal operations beyond South Africa, where it is one of largest exporters of coal (M)

headline: 3 U.S. Health Workers Said to Be Infected
abstract: Officials of Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report three health care workers in US have caught mysterious respiratary disease SARS while caring for patients in this country; will not disclose where cases occurred; CDC has previously reported separate instances in which patients with disease have transmitted it to six household members in this country (M)

headline: Forsaking the Laptop for a Can-Do Palmtop
abstract: Ian Austen article assesses several programs that allow handheld organizer to fill in for a laptop on word processing and other computer tasks; photos (M)

headline: A Radio Bulletin Worried Family Members
abstract: Clifford Lawson, retired Army sergeant who worked at Northrop Grumman unit in Saudi Arabia for six years, is one of eight Americans killed in terrorist attacks in Riyadh on May 12; his wife and son, who live in Snellville, Ga, talk about hearing news of attack on television; photos (M)

headline: Ex-Employee Sues Medical Gear Maker
abstract: Vital Signs, maker of medical equipment, is sued by former chief financial officer Joseph Bourgart, who quit in January amid accusations that he passed confidential data to investor (S)

headline: Citigroup's Chairman Is Barred From Direct Talks With Analysts
abstract: Regulatory settlement reached with 10 Wall Street firms bars Citigroup chairman Sanford I Weill and other senior officers from talking to Citigroup's research analysts on investment banking matters without company lawyer present; restrictions are legacy of unorthodox campaign by Weill to persuade Jack B Grubman, his star analyst, to change his rating on AT&T's stock from neutral to positive; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Considers Indicting Terrorist Arrested in Iraq On Achille Lauro Murder
abstract: Bush administration is exploring ways of bringing charges against Palestinian terrorist Abu Abbas, who was captured in Iraq, withholding judgment about whether to turn him over to Italy and rejecting Palestinian demands for his release; he faces life sentence in Italy for his role in 1985 hijacking of Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro in which American passenger Leon Klinghoffer was killed; some American officials are leaning toward trying to indict Abbas in American courts and bringing him to US to face conspiracy charges; Klinghoffer's family and Anti-Defamation League want to see him tried in US; Palestine Liberation Organization officials say US has no legal right to hold him or extradite him to Italy, contending his detention violates 1995 peace agreement that ensured amnesty to PLO members for acts committed before Oslo accords of 1993 and 1995; US says Abbas's capture lends credence to argument that Saddam Hussein harbored terrorists; photo (M)

headline: War Protests In India Aim At Bottlers
abstract: Radical groups in India are staging armed raids of some of most visible symbols of America: Coke and Pepsi warehouses as protest to American-led invasion of Iraq; 10 members of People's War Group, outlawed militant Maoist faction that has clashed with local authorities in southern India for two decades, storm Pepsi-Cola warehouse in Guntur district of Andhar Pradesh; management of warehouse belongs to local franchise bottler and not PepsiCo; several soft drink distribution centers were attacked last week, including apparent bombing at Coca-Cola operation in Andhra Pradesh that destroyed hundreds of cases of drinks (M)

headline: Free to Protest, Iraqis Complain About the U.S.
abstract: Iraqis are exercising their new right to complain, which was denied them during Pres Saddam Hussein's rule, and are directing those complaints against Americans; blame Americans for looting and ongoing lack of everything from electricity to firm sense of order, and they say they do not want long-term US military occupation; there is no sense that complaints are degenerating into violence or unwillingness to cooperate with Americans; right to complain is accompanied by other rights long suppressed under Hussein, particularly rights of Shiites, who are increasingly active, some demanding Islamic state and providing civilian militias to keep order; photos; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Parties Near Agreement On Creating Asbestos Trust  Companies, insurers, unions and Democratic and Republican senators are nearing an agreement to end all asbestos lawsuits and instead pay people with asbestos-related diseases from a national, privately financed trust, people who have participated in the talks said.    The trust, which would have to be approved by Congress and President Bush, would pay more than $100 billion to hundreds of thousands of asbestos victims over the next 30 years. [Page A1.]

headline: Senate Votes Unanimously to Approve Expansion of NATO
abstract: President Bush met with the foreign ministers of the seven East European countries and thanked them for their support of American policy on Iraq.

headline: The Memories of a Jew, Now Honored by Vienna
abstract: Profile of and interview with Frederic Morton, 79, historian, novelist and New Yorker who fled with his family from Vienna, Austria, in March 1938; Morton, who has been lionized by Vienna in years since war, has returned to his birthplace to be awarded Cross of Honor for Arts and Sciences and because his book A Nervous Splendor, account of single year of life of 19th-century Vienna, is being turned into musical; Morton offers glimpses of his early life, his Jewish family and comments on his awards and his ambivalence about Vienna; photo (M)

headline: Hotels Doing Well, Despite Slump
abstract: Hotels Do4

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Sale
abstract: Group of investors led by Wilbur Ross will sell substa2

headline: Flight Attendants Approve Concessions at American
abstract: Flight attendants at American Airlines narrowly approve $340 milion in annual wage and benefit cuts, giving carrier more room to avert bankruptcy filing; flight attendants will take 15.6 percent pay cut, starting May 1, and about 2,000 will be laid off; acccept changes to benefits and work rules; AMR chief executive Donald J Carty thanks union leadership and employees for recognizing urgency of company's financial crisis; Carty agreed last month to take 33 percent cut in base salary and forgo bonus this year; graphs; charts; photos (M)

headline: A Web Site Ready-Made For the Phone-In Diarist
abstract: TypePad, new blog service, is going after those who want to be Web publishers but would rather not bother with nuts and bolts of building and maintaining Web site; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Brewer Maintains Forecast
abstract: The Belgian brewer Interbrew stuck to its earlier forecast of organic sales and profit growth this year. Sales during the first half of this year have been strong, especially in Russia, Ukraine and Central Europe, the company said, while market share in France and exports to the United States declined. Analysts said that after a profit warning on Monday from a rival Dutch brewer, Heineken, the market had expected similar pessimism from Interbrew.   Paul Meller (NYT)

headline: U.S. to Form New Iraqi Army and Pay Soldiers of Old One
abstract: The aim is to build a force of 40,000 soldiers over two years, which is far smaller than Saddam Hussein's military.

headline: Ex-Freeman Executive at Saatchi & Saatchi
abstract: Ex-Freeman Executive At Saatchi & Saatchi Eric Silver, a top creative executive who abruptly left Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York two weeks ago, has been named to the new post of executive vice president and group creative director at Saatchi & Saatchi in New York.

headline: Toulouse Journal; Sinister Tales From a Sleepy Town Grip France
abstract: All of France is spellbound by tales of rape and murder emanating from quiet city of Toulouse, where two unidentified prostitutes say that former Mayor Dominique Baudis joined in sadomasochistic orgies at lake house in nearby Noe and ordered murder of transvestite who secretly videotaped proceedings; Baudis denies charges and suggests that people he has alienated in pornography industry are out to detroy him, or that local newspaper is bent on revenge; detectives learned about prostitutes by questioning Patrice Alegre, psychopath who was sentenced to life in prison for five killings year ago; media frenzy surrounding story includes articles by staid daily Le Monde, which ran detailed but thinly sourced article with lurid charges for which there is no hard evidence; photos (M)

headline: Carrier in the Gulf Gets More Striking Power, and Maybe the Hint of a Return Home
abstract: Navy increases its airstrike capability in Iraq with arrival aboard USS Abraham Lincoln of four additional F/A-18 Super Hornet jets, on loan from aircraft carrier Nimitz, which has not yet reached Persian Gulf; additional air power will enable 10 to 20 additional flights a day and provide more support to ground troops; illustration of new jet shows tactical capabilities and munitions (M)

headline: In Warlord Land, Democracy Tries Baby Steps
abstract: Letter From Asia on crisis of confidence in Afghanistan amid fears of rise of regional warlords and faltering efforts to ensure security and foster democracy; photo (M)

headline: Israel Presses Assault on Hamas With Gaza Missile Strikes
abstract: Israeli attack helicopters delivered two more missile strikes in Gaza, a day before U.S. monitors are scheduled to arrive to prop up a new peace plan.

headline: HASBRO MAKES ITS PRESIDENT ITS CHIEF EXECUTIVE, TOO
abstract: Hasbro Inc promotes its president-chief executive officer Alfred Verrecchia to chief executive to succeed Alan Hasenfeld, who will remain chairman (S)

headline: How to Unclog the Information Artery
abstract: Calls for greater steps to curb spam intensify, as quantity of spam rises to drown out other e-mail; there are wide range of proposals for taming spam; most of bills in Congress are built around imposing penalties for sending deceptive e-mail; volunteer spam fighters are creating lists of Internet addresses of spammers to boycott; Internet service providers boast of their spam-fighting tools, and some are preparing to dig even strong barriers around people's in-boxes, blocking mail from anyone that recipient does not already know; excerpts from conversations with seven people who have some ideas for a solution; photos (L)

headline: In Baghdad, Free of Hussein, a Day of Mayhem
abstract: American troops clear Iraqi forces from wide swaths of Baghdad, but seem powerless before fresh wave of frenzied looting and mayhem that follows retreat of Saddam Hussein loyalists; mobs set fire to virtually all government ministries and begin ransacking private homes for first time; city and virtually all of Iraq are operating essentially without government, services or police protection; Bush administration apparently is unprepared to respond quickly to breakdown; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld calls freedom 'untidy' and instantaneous response impossible; State Department says it will send 26 police and judicial officers to Iraq as advance team for contingent of what might eventually be over 1,150 people to help restore law and order; they will be part of group led by Lt Gen Jay Garner, who will run initial Iraqi civil administration under US occupation; military officials in Baghdad say American troops will try to keep religious centers open and public services functioning; begin enlisting local Iraqi officials to help rebuild police forces; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank's Rating Lowered
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp cuts from stable to negative long-term rating outlook on Kookmin Bank, South Korea's larges financial institution (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil prices rise after Royal Dutch/Shell says shipments from Nigeria will be disrupted because of political unrest; graphs (S)

headline: Special (and Mundane) Effects of the Movies, on TV
abstract: Computer-generated effects have become one of most cost-effective tools of contemporary television, allowing series to shoot scenes in studio and add much of scenery digitally in post-production; many post-production companies offer special effects as just one part of their services; some companies, like Stargate Digital, also create effects for epic productions; photos (M)

abstract: J. D. EDWARDS POSTS 2ND-QUARTER LOSS; TAKE-TWO REPORTS 58% INCREASE IN PROFIT; VIDEO GAME COMPANY FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY;.

headline: Bill Reduces Blue-Collar Obligations For Pensions
abstract: Bill pending in House of Representatives would allow businesses with union workers to reduce their company pension obligations by billions of dollars, because statistics show that most blue-collar workers do not live as long as other Americans; provision is being supported by United Auto Workers and manufacturing companies whose pension funds now have assets far short of what they are projected to need under previous assumptions about worker longevity; measure would allow companies to assume that their blue-collar workers will on average die sooner than pension plans now assume they will; companies would not be required to put aside as much pension money as government regulations now require them to do; Edwin C Hustead, chairman of actuarial panel that developed data on which new provision is based, says he has written to Treasury Department, which regulates pension funds, to express concern that data were being misapplied; says white-collar workers are shown by statistics to live longer, but bill would not require companies to factor that into their pension calculations; adds if it were included, unionized companies with largely white-collar workers would have to set aside more to fulfill their promises to retirees in future; hodls workers' pay has been shown to be more powerful predictor of life expentancy than whether worker is blue collar or white collar, but bill does not recognize that higher-paid workers live longer and therefore require longer pension payouts; aides to bill's sponsors say they are unaware that measure has overlooked these other significant mortaility factors; spokeswoman for Rep Benjamin L Cardin says congressman's goal is to help preserve system of traditional pensions; spokesman for Rep Rob Portman says bill is intended to make sure companies are not forced to overpay into their pension systems; UAW supports provision because it hopes money the companies save from pensions can be used for higher wages; chart; photo (M)

headline: WESTPOINT STEVENS FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
abstract: WestPoint Stevens Inc, maker of towels and bedding, files for bankruptcy protection; chief executive Holcombe T Green Jr resigns (S)

headline: Prudential Buys Skandia Unit
abstract: Prudential Financial buys American Skandia, provider of mutual funds and variable annuities, from Sweden's Skandia Insurance, for about $1.2 billion; unit will become part of Prudential Investments asset management business; Prudential says it will eliminate unspecified number of jobs because of purchase over next 18 months (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Broker Posts Profit
abstract: Merrill Lynch posts its first profit in Japan in three years; estimates it earned net income of 973 million yen ($8.2 million) in year ending March 31, compared with 59.9 billion yen loss year earlier (S)

headline: Decoding the Shorthand For Better Music Files
abstract: Q. What is MP3 V.B.R.?    A. The abbreviation MP3 V.B.R. stands for MPEG Audio Layer 3, Variable Bit Rate.     MP3 is the common file format used for encoding and compressing audio files for use on computers and portable digital music players. Variable bit rate is a type of encoding that is used with MP3 files to make them sound better than standard audio files.

headline: Iran Is Said to Send Agents Into Southern Iraq
abstract: Iranian-trained agents have crossed into Iraq and are working to advance Iranian interests, according to U.S. officials.

abstract: ITALY: Berlusconi Party Lagging In Rome Race; FRANCE: Strikes To Hit Flights; RUSSIA: Hu Arrives; SERBIA: 23 Held In 1991 Massacre;.

headline: Finding Opportunity in Baggage Woes
abstract: The airline service cutbacks and the airport security delays are bad enough. But what really maddens many business travelers is the knowledge that security guards are pawing through their checked bags, and airlines are increasingly acting as if a checked bag is nothing more than another brick on their load.    And therein lies a business opportunity that a handful of companies are hoping to seize. Promoting themselves essentially as long-haul bellhops -- one, in fact, calls itself Virtual Bellhop -- they show up at your house or office, take your bags and ship them to the hotel or wherever else you will be staying, before you get there. Then, at the end of your stay, they ship them back home.

headline: A Hunger Strike Puts Spotlight on British Asylum Policy
abstract: Iranian refugee Abas Amini is on hunger strike and has crudely stitched up his eyes, mouth and ears with green thread to protest how he, and other Iranians seeking asylum in Britain, have been treated; he is poet and political dissident who says he was tortured frequently during six years he spent in Iranian prisons; British government is not sure he is telling truth; government is under relentless political pressure to reduce number of immigrants streaming into country each year; Amini has been seeking asylum since his arrival two years ago; from 2000 to 2002, 300,000 people applied for asylum in Britain, more than in any other industrialized country; photo (M)

headline: Affirmative Action: A Corporate Diary; From Coffee to Keynote
