headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Move To Oust Justice
abstract: Argentina's lower house judicial affairs committee unanimously approves 15 counts of wrongdoing levied against Supreme Court Chief Justice Julio Nazareno; charges could be first step toward his impeachment; concurrently President Nestor Kirchner allows civic groups to file objections to judicial candidates; photo (S)

headline: On a Friday in Baghdad, Shiites Gather for Prayer for First Time in Four Years
abstract: Thousands of Shiite Muslims, some sobbing with emotion, prostrate themselves in prayer before largest mosque in Baghdad's main Shiite neighborhood as part of Shiites' first mass prayer meeting in city in four years; estimated 8,000 people crowd around Al Mohsen Mosque; photo (M)

headline: Masterpiece or Empire, It's All Up to the Player
abstract: From the paper-and-dice days of early Dungeons and Dragons to the fluid graphics of The Sims Online, role-playing games have offered a chance to shed your skin and become somebody new, even if for just a few hours. Second Life, a new online game from Linden Labs that made its official debut this week, combines Internet socializing with rambles in its 3-D virtual society. Players can roam through the game with an onscreen body that looks as much (or as little) like themselves as desired.     Not strictly an adventure or strategy game, Second Life is a vast playground of pixels where the players use the game's tools to build houses, cities and businesses for other players to visit. Players can buy and sell virtual commodities like art or weapons, dance together in exotic nightclubs or just hang out and chat. Unlike simulation games that rely on specific rules, Second Life takes a rather free-form approach. While the game was in development, ambitious players testing it created realistic representations of castles, Japanese houses and even a city that mimics the urban landscape of the film ''Blade Runner.''

headline: Player in Cellular Phone Market In Europe Predicts Consolidation
abstract: Marco De Benedetti, head of Telecom Italia Mobile, says consolidation is inevitable in European cellphone industry; says most European countries can support only three mobile phone companies; four of Europe's five biggest mobile phone markets have more than three operators, and some have as many as six; DeBenedetti says even though Telecom Italia Mobile is almost debt-free, he does not plan to play further role in any consolidation; sees Germany as most likely country for consolidation to begin; photo (M)

headline: Dying Man's Suit Tests A Drug's Availability
abstract: Joseph L Stendig, California man dying of ideopathic pulmonary fibrosis, is suing to force InterMune to give him pirfenidone, experimental drug for disease, on 'campassionate use' basis; accuses company of stifling drug's development to maintain sales of another of its drugs, Actimmune; InterMune says it is considering large clinical trial to accelerate approval of pirfenidone (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Paul Moore Jr, retired Episcopal bishop of New York who for more than decade was most formidable liberal Christian voice in city, dies at age 83; photos (M)

headline: The Lure of the (Nearby) Open Road
abstract: Travel Association of America survey finds Florida and California are top destination states on American travelers' wish lists this summer; tables of preferred travel destinations and activities (S)

headline: Holder Raises Cordiant Stake To Level Needed to Block Deal
abstract: Active Value, the largest shareholder in the Cordiant Communications Group, the British advertising agency company, said today that it had increased its stake. The purchase gives it enough shares to block a buyout of the company by the WPP Group.    Active Value, a London-based fund manager, said it bought 2.5 million more shares of Cordiant, bringing its total stake to 25.13 percent. According to British regulations, a valid vote on a WPP takeover offer would require that at least 75 percent of shares be voted, with approval requiring a majority of those votes.

headline: In Britain, Encouraging Words on Euro
abstract: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown said this week that, while British economy has flunked most of his five tests of euro membership, there could still be referendum on question next year or thereafter; many British business leaders believe their government must act now on its intention to remove economic obstacles between British economy and euro membership; photo (M)

headline: Following the Military's Hunt For Most-Wanted Iraqi Officials
abstract: Photos of playing cards showing Iraq's most-wanted officials; cards are distributed to American forces to help in their searches

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Airport Contract Voided
abstract: Philippine Supreme Court invalidates contract awarded to group of investors, including Germany's Fraport, to build new international air terminal in Manila; court says partners did not have 'requisite financial capacity' to complete project when contract was awarded in 1997; Fraport will appeal (S)

headline: Turks Wonder Whether U.S. Will Share Some of the Spoils of Rebuilding
abstract: Many Turkish businessmen wonder whether their companies will have opportunity to bid on lucrative rebuilding contracts in Iraq; question is complicated by Parliament's refusal to allow American troops to open northern front during war; Public Works Min Zeki Ergezen is pessimistic about contracts coming to Turkey, and some businessmen believe US has forbidden American companies to use Turkish subcontractors; photo (M)

abstract: Excerpts from statements by Federal Communications Commission members Michael K Powell, Kathleen Q Abernathy, Michael J Copps and Jonathan S Adelstein about rules changes enacted by Commission (M)

headline: Second Thoughts and Very Long Hours
abstract: Second article about Col Steven Boltz in series Tours of Duty, which is revisiting him and other service members periodically; Boltz is intelligence officer for V Corps and veteran of 27 years in Army; describes long, hard hours at Tactical Operations Center in northern Kuwait; is optimistic about military campaign in Iraq, despite some unanticipated setbacks; photo (M)

headline: Market Place; A Drug Giant Thinks It Can Grow Still Bigger
abstract: Pfizer Inc is making Wall Street promise that it will get bigger; chairman-chief executive Henry A McKinnell Jr promises revenue growth of at least 10 percent this year and next, 'with continued strong revenue growth' beyond 2004; fans of company's stock tend to focus on uncommon resources that are likely to allow Pfizer's earnings to incresase for at least five years; company has cash to buy drugs, even if its research apparatus fails to produce blockbusters; has army of sales representatives that dwarfs those of competitors, and should sales lag, its sheer size means that it can keep profits growing by dispensing with some of those researchers and sales representatives (Market Place column) (M)

headline: AIRCRAFT COMPONENTS SUPPLIER TO BUY BRITISH UNIT
abstract: Esterline Technologies Corp, maker of electronic components for Boeing Co, acquires Roxboro Group's Weston aerospace-sensors unit for $88 million to expand in Britain (S)

abstract: Chief executive Patricia Russo tells analysts that

headline: U.S. Economic Penalties Against Iraq Are Ended
abstract: Bush administration ends many of sanctions United States placed on Iraq before Persian Gulf war, easing job of contractors rebuilding Iraq; move lets American companies begin exporting many goods to Iraq, and allows people who live in US to send money into country, up to limit of $500 a month per Iraqi household; penalties being suspended are separate from United Nations' strict sanctions against Iraq, which remain in effect; Pres Bush has called for those to be removed as well (M)

headline: Dim Whispers Of the Missing
abstract: Scores of desperate Iraqis gather outside state security complex in Baghdad, begging American troops guarding its gates to help them find relatives whom they believe to be trapped in prison beneath sprawling grounds; Iraqis call out names and dates of arrest, hoping their missing loved ones will be resurrected along with past; many have more than one relative supposedly in the jail; marines say they have searched complex thoroughly and discovered nothing; say there is no secret prison; say Iraqis refuse to believe them and keep coming back day after day, reflecting heartbreaking optimism of those who believe that, with government dismantled, their missing relatives will reappear; photo (M)

headline: Trying to Escape From Custody, Iraqi Prisoner Is Shot to Death
abstract: United States Central Command says Iraqi prisoner died of gunshot wounds suffered when he tried to escape from coalition-run camp in Baghdad, and that another prisoner who tried to escape was recaptured; attempted escapes come day after military investigators announce inquiry into whether US forces are responsible for death of another Iraqi prisoner at different camp (M)

headline: Tyco Investors Sue Merrill Over Research
abstract: Tyco International shareholders sue Merrill Lynch & Co for securities fraud; suit charges former Merrill managing director Phua Young issued biased research reports on Tyco (S)

headline: What Would Happen If Mom Ran the Show?
abstract: Ajilon Office survey of employed American adults finds majority believe their mothers would perform better than or about same as their current chief executives in number of areas, including resolving employee disputes, communicating with employees and handling company finances (M)

headline: Spokeswoman in '91 War To Help U.S. Leader in Iraq
abstract: Margaret Tutwiler leaves post as ambasador to Morocco to assume temporary position overseeing all public relations and information operations in postwar Iraq; was State Department spokeswoman during Persian Gulf war in 1991; photo (S)

headline: Accused of Hiding War Crimes Suspect, Liberia Says It Killed Him
abstract: Liberian government of Pres Charles Taylor, which has been accused by United Nations investigators of harboring accused war criminal Sam Bockarie, says its forces shot and killed him today as he tried to enter nation from Ivory Coast; body of Bockarie, warlord who led campaign of rape and mutilation in his native Sierra Leone and more recently aided Ivory Coast rebels, reportedly is taken to Monrovia and inspected by Sierra Leone officials; news of death comes as noose tightens around Taylor government; United Nations Security Council renews sanctions barring Liberia from selling diamonds and buying arms; threatens to add timber, key export, to list of prohibited goods (M)

headline: Citing Illness, China Decides To Postpone Soccer Season
abstract: China postpones start of season for its men's and women's professional soccer leagues as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) continues to disrupt international sports; delay cast further uncertainty on largest international sporting event for women, soccer World Cup, which is scheduled from Sept 23 to Oct 11 in four cities of east-central China; Major League Baseball's executive vice president Sandy Alderson says he would travel to Toronto to signal confidence in decision to continue playing games there despite death of 16 people from SARS; says his organization is comfortable about teams going to Toronto without great risk, in spite of WHO travel advisory (M)

headline: FLEMING WINS APPROVAL TO HOLD AUCTION FOR FOOD STORES
abstract: Fleming Companies wins bankruptcy court permission to seek higher bids for its 31 Rainbow Foods stores, which are subject of $85 million offer from Roundy's Inc; Roundy's offer will become opening bid at June 3 auction (S)

headline: U.S. WILL ASK U.N. TO BACK CONTROL BY ALLIES IN IRAQ
abstract: Draft resolution to be introduced by United States, Britain and Spain lifting economic sanctions against Iraq calls for Security Council to endorse American and British control of Iraq's political development and financial resources for at last 12 months; under resolution, new Iraqi oil revenues and at least $3 billion in current United Nations-controlled escrow fund would be transferred to new Iraqi Assistance Fund to be 'disbursed at the direction of' US and GB, in consultation with interim government to be formed in Iraq; advisory board would include representatives from International Monetary Fund, World Bank and UN; it would have right to appoint auditors to examine accounts of fund; American officials say giving UN important supervisory role in Iraq's oil industry is concession to Security Council members that opposed war in Iraq and are skeptical of lifting sanctions on country under military occupation; resolution says new UN special coordinator would work with US and GB--referred to as 'provisional authority'--and people of Iraq in restoration and establishment of national and local institutions for representative governance; there is no mention in resolution of UN weapons inspection team led by Hans Blix; France reportedly signals that it will not veto resolution and may even vote yes (M)

headline: U.S. Officials See Signs of a Revived Al Qaeda
abstract: Senior counterrorism officials say that leaders and operatives of Al Qaeda have reorganized bases of operations in at least half-dozen locations, including Kenya, Sudan, Pakistan and Chechnya; say leaders have begun to recruit new members, train new followers and plan new attacks on Western targets in earnest; cite secret arrests in United States in last two months of two Arab men suspected of having been sent by senior leaders of Al Qaeda to scout targets for new terror attacks; men were part of larger group of about six Qaeda followers arrested in recent months whose presence in United States has led authorities to conclude that terrorist group remains determined to carry out attacks on American soil; photo of Fazul Abdullah Muhammad, a leader of Al Qaeda, who has been seen in Somalia; global map shows sites of Qaeda captures, escapes or failed raids, trials or indictment or attacks (L)

headline: Fed Statement On Decision About Rates
abstract: Text of statement released by Federal Reserve after its monetary policy panel Federal Open Market Committee decides to leave interest rates unchanged (S)

headline: BOEING TO ADD BROADBAND SERVICE TO LUFTHANSA
abstract: Lufthansa reaches deal with Boeing Co to have broadband Internet service installed on its entire long-haul fleet, first airline to make such move (S)

headline: U.S. May Have to Allow Others to Inspect Iraqi Arms
abstract: Bush administration is studying its obligations to work with independent inspectors under arms control treaties that govern chemical, biologial and nuclear arms; Pentagon, however, has indicated that it wants no outside help; nongovernmental weapons experts argue that US should allow international inspectors to help identify and destroy unconventional weapons, saying that independent confirmation would help convince skeptics that war was just; say that US is obligated to work with international agencies because it signed treaties and conventions governing disposal of unconventional materiel (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Lexmark's Profits Rise On Sales Of Ink Cartridges
abstract: Lexmark International Inc., the second-biggest maker of computer printers in the United States after the Hewlett-Packard Company, said yesterday that first-quarter net income increased 32 percent as rising sales of ink cartridges offset a drop in machine sales. Net income rose to $94.6 million, or 73 cents a share, from $71.5 million, or 53 cents a share. Sales increased 5.7 percent to $1.11 billion from $1.05 billion, Lexmark said. Supplies like ink cartridges rose 18 percent, while sales of hardware like printers fell 7.7 percent. Hardware sales fell because of a transition to a new product line, the loss of Compaq Computer as a reseller and not being able to satisfy demand for all-in-one printers, the chief financial officer, Gary Morin, said. ''It was a relief to see them meet the high end of their guidance,'' said Tim Jossart, co-manager of the Touchstone Value Plus Fund, which manages $40 million in assets and holds 26,430 Lexmark shares. In January, the company had given a first-quarter forecast of 62 cents to 72 cents a share and analysts had expected 72 cents, according to a survey of nine analysts by Thomson First Call. Shares of Lexmark rose 31 cents, to $69.50 yesterday. They have gained 16 percent this year.

headline: A Serbian Mystery Unravels With a Crackdown on Gangsters
abstract: Serb crackdown on underworld and former security figures who served Slobodan Milosevic solves mystery of murder of former President Ivan Stambolic six weeks before Milosevic's ouster; body of Stambolic, former Milosevic patron who had become eloquent critic of hard-line rule, is found in grave north of Belgrade; police say he was killed by government-sanctioned paramilitary group implicated in recent assassination of Prime Min Zoran Djindjic (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Associates Will Combine 2 Units
abstract: Computer Associates International will combine two units to cut jobs and expenses while improving customer service; about 450 jobs will be cut, or 2.8 percent of work force; company says it granted chief executive Sanjay Kumar options to buy 700,000 shares as stock dropped 36 percent in last year (S)

headline: OBITUARY : John Mowinckel, diplomat
abstract: John W. Mowinckel, 82, a staff officer of the Office of Strategic Services during World War II, and later a journalist and diplomat, has died in West Palm Beach, Florida.

headline: Chief Resigns at Paxar
abstract: Paul J. Griswold, the chief executive of the Paxar Corporation, a maker of electronic bar-code printers and labeling devices, has resigned to ''pursue other business interests,'' according to the company.    The chairman, Arthur Hershaft, who preceded Mr. Griswold as chief executive, will assume the roles of president and chief executive, the company said. Mr. Griswold notified the board on Monday of his resignation, Bob Powers, Paxar's vice president for investor relations, said.

headline: A Poor Man's Air Force
abstract: The Iraqi missile strike last March at the Marine headquarters in Kuwait is one of the most intriguing aspects of the war.

headline: Headphones With a Twist Make the World Go Away
abstract: Bose introduces headphones with circuitry that cancels out low-frequency noises and hard-shell ear cups lined with cushions that block higher frequencies; photo (S)

headline: Paratroopers Find Suspicious Warheads and Rocket Parts in Kirkuk
abstract: American paratroopers discover what they describe as suspicious warheads and rocket components outside former Iraqi governor's office in Kirkuk, tantalizing but inconclusive find on first day of large-scale American presence in Kirkuk, oil capital of northern Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Divining Dividend Benefits
abstract: Fidelity Investments survey finds nearly 80 perent of respondents say that eliminating taxes on some dividends will help them personally; forty-eight percent believe Pres Bush's dividend-tax proposal will benefit only extremely wealthy, while 33 percent disagree (S)

headline: Central Bank Cuts Outlook For Growth In Europe
abstract: European Central Bank expects economic growth in 2003 and 2004 to be slow in 12 nations using euro currency, and that inflation in 2004 might be lowest since 1990; lowers its growth forecast for 2003 to range of 0.4 percent to 1 percent; sees growth at 1.6 percent for 2004, down from earlier forecast of 2.4 percent; expects inflation to be 1.8 percent to 2.2 percent this year and to fall to range of 0.7 percent to 1.9 percent in 2004 (M)

headline: Poles Remain Divided After Endorsing Union
abstract: Prime Min Leszek Miller of Poland moves to shore up support for his struggling leftist minority government; offers to submit to vote of confidence, and promises fiscal reform as well as radical flat tax on personal and corporate income; vote of confidence could come as early as June 11, but Pres Aleksander Kwasniewski, speaking on Polish television, hints that Miller may have to go; notes issues that must be addressed in next 11 months to prepare for membership in European Union; Miller's government has been dogged by corruption scandals (M)

headline: A Star Is Born (and Swimming in Singapore)
abstract: Luohan, also known as flowerhorn fish, has become wildly popular as symbol of good luck among Singapore's ethnic Chinese majority since its introduction from Malaysia in 2001; shops dedicated to selling fish, their food and tanks have proliferated and fish prices have soared; prices are falling as too many sellers take advantage of fish's prolific breeding habits, creating glut; photos (M)

headline: Inflation Eases, But Other Worries Build Up in Brazil
abstract: Social unrest is growing in Brazil in face of austere monetary and fiscal measures undertaken by President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva; increase in public spending anticipated by many has not occurred; Government instead has taken tough anti-inflation stance by raising overnight interest rate to 26.5 percent and committing to creating budget surplus equaling 4.25 percent of GDP; measures thus far appear to be restraining price increases but pressures are building to stimulate growth and job creation; photo (M)

headline: Recording, In Flavors Of DVD
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column examines format battle in DVD industry; early on, DVD's were playback-only and format was devised by DVD Forum, consortium of 230 electronics makers; but when recordable DVD's were introduced, eight companies, including Sony, broke away because of what they perceived as technical limitations and devised rival, but incompatible, format; Sony remained member of both groups, and developed recorder capable of burning both formats; photo; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: A Profit At SK Telecom
abstract: SK Telecom Co reports profit of 449 billion won ($373.3 million) in first quarter compared with 444 billion won year earlier and 163 billion won in fourth quarter; sales gained 16 percent, to 2.2 trillion won from 1.9 trillion won year ago (S)8

headline: A New Tool for Translating Ancient, Flowing Script
abstract: Script-recognition software, developed by Center of Excellence in Document Analysis and Recognition at State University of New York at Buffalo, should accelerate development of optical character recognition software for Devenagari, script used for Sanskrit and other South Asian languages; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Gold's Gym International delegates advertising duties for company and its franchises to Henderson Advertising (S)

headline: Miscellany

headline: Nasdaq Decides to Split Job Once Chief Retires in May
abstract: Nasdaq's stock market hires Robert Greifeld to be chief executive and president and H Furlong Baldwin, outside director, to be chairman, succeeding Hardwick Simmons, who is retiring as chairman and chief executive; president Richard Ketchum will become vice chairman and remain on board (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Truckmaker's Loss Triples
abstract: Truck maker Isuzu Motors reports record loss of $973 million in year ended March 31 (S)

headline: U.S. WARNS IRAQIS AGAINST CLAIMING AUTHORITY IN VOID
abstract: United States military moves to strip Baghdad's self-appointed administrator Muhammad Mohsen Zobeidi of his authority and warns Iraqi factions not to take advantage of confusion and political void by trying to grab power; Lt Gen David McKiernan, commander of ground forces, issues proclamation warning that 'coalition alone retains absolute authority within Iraq' and saying that anyone challenging that authority will be subject to arrest; but military presence is sparse in many areas of city, and various groups ranging from Shiite radicals to communists are seizing villas and adorning them with their respective emblems; military is keeping close eye on activities of Ahmad Chalabi, leader of Iraqi National Congress who has ensconced himself in Baghdad club and is seeking to play important role in effort to restore civil authority; Jay Garner, retired lieutenant who will lead reconstruction effort and who is traveling in Kurdish-held northern region, says anti-American sentiment will subside when people realize Americans are only going to stay long enough to establish democratic government and get econmy going; American military forces continue to round up members of old government, and are still being killed and wounded as they try to establish order; three marines and one Army soldier are killed in accidents; map shows population distribution and density in Iraq; photos (M)

headline: Winthrop Baker Jr., 71, Dies; Broadcaster Turned Innkeeper
abstract: Winthrop Patterson Baker Jr, who went from Westinghouse Broadcasting television executive to running deluxe New England bed-and-breakfasts, dies at age 71; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Loss For Chip Maker
abstract: Germany's Infineon Technologies reports loss for three months through March widened to 328 million euros ($357 million) from loss of 108 million euros year earlier; chief executive Ulrich Schumacher comments; photo (S)

headline: By Any Other Name, It's Usually a Rosa
abstract: Agriculture Department reports nearly 90 percent of so-called traditional flowers sold in United States in 2002 came from Colombia and Ecuador; American flower growers have been shifting to more exotic breeds; graphs (S)

headline: Hussein Is Probably Alive in Iraq, U.S. Experts Say, Citing Intercepts
abstract: American intelligence analysts now believe that Saddam Hussein is more likely alive than dead, view reinforced in recent weeks by intercepted communications among some of his fugitive supporters; new hunt for Hussein is being led by Task Force 20, secret military organization that includes members of Army's highly specialized Delta Force and Navy's elite counterterrorism squads, with support from Central Intelligence Agency; prevailing belief is that Hussein is still in Iraq; arrest of Abid Hamid Mahmoud al-Tikriti, Hussein's closest confidant, has raised some hope of obtaining more conclusive information; but Mahmoud's success in eluding capture for nearly two months in country occupied by nearly 150,000 troops underscores reality that Iraq still offers many hiding places; chronology of developments since March 20 in trying to determine Hussein's fate; photos (M)

headline: Frank P. Smeal -- Municipal Bond Expert, 84
abstract: Frank P Smeal, municipal bond expert, dies at age 84 (S)

headline: E-Mail Swindle Uses False Report About a Swindle
abstract: Recent e-mail fraud puts new twist on time-honored ruse by claiming to warn against credit card misuse involving purchases from Best Buy Co; electronics retailer acted quickly to reassure customers but as many as one million fraudulent messages may have been mailed before scheme was detected and shut down; photo (M)

headline: Cambodian Pique at Thais Lingers
abstract: Cambodians continue to harbor resentment of all things Thai more than two months after anti-Thai rioting in Phnom Penh set off by alleged claim by popular Thai actress that Angkor Wat temple, Cambodia's national symbol, actually belongs to Thailand; continue to voice anti-Thai sentiments in public and seem to be informally boycotting Thai goods; map; photo (M)

headline: A Famed Philippine Family's Bubbly Maverick
abstract: Profile of and interview with Kris Aquino, 32-year-old bubbly talk show hostess and youngest daughter of Corazon Aquino, former Philippine president; photo (M)

headline: U.S., Angry at French Stance on War, Considers Punishment
abstract: Bush administration is pursuing ways to punish France for opposing United States on war in Iraq, including possibility of limiting French participation in American meetings with European allies; anger at France is so deeply felt within administration that even Sec of State Colin L Powell warns that it will be punished; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: LIECHTENSTEIN: Democracy Or Monarchy?; GERMANY: Treaty With Jewish Group; BULGARIA: An Amphibious Assault;.

headline: More Detailed Reports Are Urged to Show Source And Location of Cases
abstract: World Health Organization will broaden its reporting standards for SARS, calling on all countries to report not just number of suspected or confirmed cases but also where they were occurring and from whom they were contracted; countries are supposed to have been reporting such information to WHO all along, but many have not, in part because their health workers have been swamped with reporting other details in epidemic; 29 countries and Hong Kong have reported 6,054 SARS cases, including 417 deaths; China and Hong Kong have reported vast majority of cases (M)

headline: Court Acquits Informant Facing Charges In Rabin Killing
abstract: Informant for Israel's security service is acquitted of charges that he failed to report acquaintance who was plotting to assassinate Prime Min Yitzhak Rabin in 1995; three-judge panel agrees there is no proof that informant, Avishai Raviv, knew that Yigal Amir, right-wing radical, was planning to kill Rabin; Amir is serving life sentence for killing Rabin (M)

headline: More Cases of SARS, but No New Deaths
abstract: No new SARS deaths were reported on Saturday, but China, Hong Kong and Taiwan all announced new cases.

headline: Israel Agrees With End But Not Means Of Peace Plan
abstract: Israeli Foreign Min Silvan Shalom says Israel's experience with more than two years of conflict with Palestinians and failure of Oslo peace accords mandates some changes in new US-backed peace initiative, but adds that criticisms should not be construed as opposition to talks; interview; photo (M)

headline: Iraqis Race To Fill Void In Journalism
abstract: Dozens of new newspapers start up in Iraq to fill void left by demise of old state-run news outlets; new ventures represent spectrum of religious groups and political parties, as well as some projects planned by Americans; Iraqi journalists savor their newfound freedom, but old habits persist; some reporters praise boss without prompting, substituting returned Iraqi exile for Saddam Hussein; politics still shapes mission of most newspapers emerging in Iraq; photo (M)

headline: US Airways Narrowed Loss in February
abstract: US A

headline: Senate Begins Process to Reverse New F.C.C. Rules on Media
abstract: A broadly bipartisan group of the Senate Commerce Committee today approved legislation by voice vote to restore the limits on media ownership.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Medicare Legislation Goes To Conference Committee  Congressional leaders rejoiced over the passage of legislation to help elderly people purchase prescription drugs, but they said they would need weeks and perhaps months to work out differences between the two versions approved by the Senate and the House.     The task of achieving a compromise was complicated by an extremely close vote in the House, where conservatives said they feared that Medicare costs might explode with the addition of new drug benefits. [Page A1.]

headline: A new museum on the Hudson fosters a local cultural renaissance
abstract: NEW YORK—  More than a century after the American landscape painters Thomas Cole, Frederick Church and Albert Bierstadt immortalized the rural beauty of the Hudson River Valley in their art, this scenic region of New York State is enjoying a cultural renaissance. And Beacon, a former hat factory town 60 miles north of Manhattan with a population of 13,000, stands at its epicenter.

headline: SARS Precautions Spread Into Toronto Church Services
abstract: The people of Toronto filled their churches over the Easter weekend in an expression of faith over fear despite the spread of a mysterious respiratory disease.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Summit Meeting Charges; CHINA: New Sars Case;.

headline: Interplanetary Warfare, On the Installment Plan
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews computer games Xenosaga Episode 1: Der Wille Zur Macht and Zone of the Enders: The 2nd Runner; photos (M)

headline: BEAR STEARNS AND TRIMARAN AGREE TO BUY PACKAGED ICE
abstract: Bear Stearns & Co's private equity unit and Trimaran Capital Partners agree to buy Packaged Ice Inc, largest ice maker in nation, for about $450 million (S)

headline: United Chief Takes Pay Cut But Retains Other Payments
abstract: United Airlines says chief executive Glenn F Tilton will take 14 percent cut in his base salary this year, but Tilton's stock and cash bonuses and other compensation, worth millions, will remain intact; Tilton is now expected to earn $712,500 in salary this year; UAL agrees to pay $4.5 million into three trusts set up for Tilton's pension, with first installment to come on Jan 1, 2004 (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bus Hijacking
abstract: Seventeen-year-old who hijacked bus in Bremen (Germany) is captured by police after he holds several people hostage and demands release of four arrested Al Qaeda members; police do not believe Lebanese-born teen has any connection with terrorist group (S)

headline: U.S. Warns Botox Maker About Its Ads
abstract: Food and Drug Administration warns Allergan Inc that its advertisements for Botox are illegal because they minimize drug's risks and promote it for uses beyond those government has approved; Allergan general counsel Douglas S Ingram says FDA is raising 'minor issues' that comapny will worth with agency to correct; is second warning Allergan has received from regulators regarding marketing of Botox (M)

headline: Protests in India Deplore Soda Makers' Water Use
abstract: Coca-Cola Co and PepsiCo are caught in controversy in India over water consumed by their bottling plants in southern India; village government of Pudussery, rural community in Palghat district of Kerala state, has revoked water-use license of Pepsi bottling plant there because plant depleted community's groundwater to point of causing shortage; license is not due to expire until 2005; plant belonging to Hindustan Coca-Cola Beverages in nearby Perumatty was denied license renewal last month on similar grounds; company appealed to Kerala High Court, which reversed village's decision; Coke and Pepsi dominate country's $1.2 billion market for soft drinks; both companies insist they have not overused water resources (M)

headline: U.S. Students Rebel At a Harsh Academy
abstract: In a torrent of rage, teenagers at the troubled Academy at Dundee Ranch in Costa Rica rose up over the weekend and overthrew their masters, walking off the ranch that was set up 19 months ago as a behavior modification program for troubled youths. Most of the children are going home, many to an uncertain future.    Article, Page A6.

headline: Protest Strike in France Interrupts Travel
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of government employees in France, with backing of some workers in private sector, stage one-day strike to protest government plans to reform state penion system; central issue is Prime Min Jean-Pierre Raffarin's intention to bring government finances in line with fiscal pact underpinning euro; Raffarin's government is under fire from European Union, which has begun action to censure France for exceeding limits to public deficits imposed by rules governing fiscal policy of 12 countries that use euro as their currency; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway Posts Wider First-Quarter Loss
abstract: Gateway Inc says net loss widened to $197.7 million in first quarter from $123.2 million year earlier; sales declined $844.5 million from $992.2 million; sold 506,000 personal computers in quarter, down 30 percent from fourth quarter and 22 percent from year-earlier period (S)0

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: AFGHANISTAN: Entering Cyberspace; CHINA: Milk Kills 3 Children; PHILIPPINES: 2 Held In Bombings; INDONESIA: Visa-Free Entries Cut; TAIWAN: 40 Indicted In Election Scandal;.

headline: Smokers Denied Class Action in Boston
abstract: Massachusetts Appeals Court Judge Janis Barry rules that claims by thousand of 'light' cigarette buyers against Philip Morris USA cannot be brought at single trial; ruling means suits must be brought individually and not as class action (S)

headline: Rules Proposed to Prevent Cronyism in Stock Offerings
abstract: Advisory committee of business and academic leaders submits report to New York Stock Exchange and NASD that recommends 20 new guidelines for ensuring fairness in market for initial public offerings; recommendations come at time when regulators and investment banks are struggling to level playing field in market for initial public offerings as part of effort to regain public confidence after concluding $1.4 billion settlement over banks' flawed research practices; report was comissioned by Securities and Exchange Commission in October (M)

headline: Bush Rebukes Israel for Attack in Gaza
abstract: Pres Bush rebukes Prime Min Ariel Sharon's government after Israel's failed attempt to kill Hamas leader Abdel Aziz Rantisi, saying action undermines latest Mideast peace efforts; US officials convey displeasure, but also press Palestinian Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas to rein in violence; Bush comments at meeting with Ugandan Pres Yoweri Museveni, several hours after Israeli helicopter gunships carry out missile attacks in Gaza; photo (M)

headline: Bush Offers Optimism to Cheering Marines; Rumsfeld Warns of Dangers
abstract: Pres Bush, addressing 12,000 marines at Camp Lejeune, NC, delivers optimistic assessment of war in Iraq in subdued and somber speech as forces close in on Baghdad; says Iraqi commanders have committed war crimes, including executing prisoners of war; spends time with families of five marines killed in action; at Pentagon briefing, Gen Richard B Myers says forces will isolate Baghdad, secure its large population, establish interim government and eliminate resistance from south, leaving remnants of Saddam Hussein's government unable to communicate with Iraqi people; senior administration officials say only after Baghdad is under American control will White House begin to create Iraqi Interim Authority; Iraqi exiles who want prominent roles in that government are pressuring White House to declare government-in-waiting immediately, but Bush's aides are reluctant to do so until other Iraqis can compete for top posts; Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld and Gen Myers issue warnings that risk of Iraqi chemical or biological attack increases as forces close in on Baghdad; Pentagon officials are hoping ground assault on Baghdad, combined with psychological operations might encourage more Iraqis to surrender; Rumsfeld also vows that soldiers engaging in guerrilla tactics will be hunted down after conflict; photos (M)

headline: At $10 a Year, Automated Buddy Loses Laughs
abstract: SmarterChild, an automated buddy, or bot, is programmed to respond to instant messages; interest in product has waned since creator began charging annual subscription fee; nine million people have chatted with SmarterChild since its inception in June 2001; Stephen D Klein, chief executive of ActiveBuddy, company that created and maintains service, will not mind if interest continues to decrease, saying it was demo project for corporate market that 'got out of hand'; drawing (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Gambles for Investors With Perfect Clocks
abstract: Investing in leveraged index funds offere

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of May 25 article on Detroit charity event, which misstated career path of co-chairman Robert A Lutz; he did not join General Motors directly from Chrysler

headline: Marines Steam to Liberia
abstract: More than 2,000 United States marines aboard amphibious assault ship Kearsarge steam toward west coast of Africa to prepare for possible evacuation of American citizens from strife-torn Liberia; more than 500 foreigners are evacuated in week from Monrovia (S)

headline: Most Corporate Ethics Officials Are Critical of Top Officers' Pay
abstract: Conference Board survey of corporate executives responsible for setting ethical standards finds most say pay of their companies' senior executives is 'out of control;' finds executives involved in serious ethical and compliance violations are paid severance in most cases (M)

headline: FINLAND APPROVES A LILLY DRUG TO FIGHT BREAST CANCER
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co says its Gemzar, its treatment for pancreatic cancer, is approved by Finland for use against breat cancer; company is talking with Food and Drug Administration about approving medicine for breast cancer in US (S)

headline: Security Cutbacks Worry Airport Officials
abstract: Transportation Security Administration is planning to reduce by 15 percent number of security workers it uses to screen airplane passengers as summer vacation season approaches; intends to make half of its cuts, about 6,000 of 55,600 full-time screeners, by end of May and rest by end of September; some smaller airports will get extra screeners as jobs are shifted from city to city; agency is cutting work force to meet hiring cap set by Congress; staffing cuts weigh heavily on minds of airport operators; chart; photos (M)

headline: Bayer's Annual Earnings Jump as Costs Are Cut
abstract: Bayer AG expects operating profit to risemore than 10 percent this year after cutting costs; chief executive Werner Wenning comments (M)

headline: COMPUTER HORIZONS SAYS AQUENT'S OFFER IS INADEQUATE
abstract: Computer Horizons Corp says that unsolicited takeover offer of $5 a share from Aquent LLC is 'grossly inadequate' (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Iraqi Held In Refugee Case
abstract: Swedish authorities hold Iraqi Khaleed Shnayf Daoed while formal extradition request is being drawn up in Australia; Daoed is believed to be involved in 2001 doomed voyage of SIEV-X, which left Indonesia and sank en route to Australia killing 353 Middle Eastern and Afghan migrants (S)

headline: Last, Desperate Days of a Brutal Reign
abstract: John F Burns article reports that Saddam Hussein's last week in power in Iraq was true to form of his entire regime: a chronicle of terror, greed and delusion; describes his own experience with Iraqi officials who arrested him on April 1 in apparent effort to shake him down; photos (M)

headline: Former D'Arcy Client Moves to New Agency
abstract: Capital One Financial names McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising as creative agency of record on its account; account had been held by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Philippine Company To Sell Pagers
abstract: Smart Communications, unit of Philippine Long Distance Telephone Co, enters agreement with Research in Motion, becoming third Asian telephone operator to sell Black-Berry hand-held computer, product of Research in Motion (S)

headline: Bush to Back Measures on Generic Drugs
abstract: Pres Bush plans to announce measures intended to speed introduction of generic versions of brand-name drugs; measures include rule limiting number of regulatory delays that manufacturers can impose on companies hoping to introduce competing versions of their drugs; would also add $13 million to Food and Drug Administration's budget so it can hire more employees and approve generic drug applications more quickly; Senate health committee unanimously approves bill that would also limit regulatory delays of generic drug applications; bill would penalize companies that reach agreements with makers of brand-name drugs to delay introduction of generic versions, deals that have attracted attention of regulators; Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America president Alan F Holmer says current law works well for patients and that further legislation is unnecessary; Generic Pharmaceutical Association president Kathleen D Jaeger lauds Senate billl and Bush's coming proposals (M)

headline: XO MAY CHANGE BID FOR GLOBAL CROSSING TO CASH
abstract: XO Communications says it may offer $700 million in cash for Global Crossing after initial offer is spurned by Global Crossing's creditors; XO, controlled by financier Carl C Icahn, says it may also offer $472.5 million for company's bank debt, on condition that Global Crossing cancels agreement to sell control to Singapore Technologies Telemedia (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of May 4 article: interest due on late income tax payments accrues until taxpayer's full liability has been paid; 25 percent cap is for late-filing penalty

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Matsushita Expects A Loss
abstract: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co says it probably lost 23.5 billion yen ($196 million) in fiscal year ended March 31 (S)

headline: FLEMING RECEIVES BANKRUPTCY COURT APPROVAL OF LOAN
abstract: Fleming Companies wins final court approval of $150 million loan and vendor lien program, clearing major hurdle in its bankruptcy case (S)

headline: Life Makes You Move
abstract: The Boss column on Queens, NY-based Nu-Old

headline: From Cable Star to Face in the Crowd
abstract: Ashleigh Banfield's sudden fading into background at NBC News surprises many in news media industry; article explores her apparent demotion from anchoring her own prime-time MSNBC news program to reassignment as NBC correspondent covering less-important issues; renewal of her NBC contract in uncertain; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Forces Fire Missiles at House Believed to Hide Afghan Rebels
abstract: American helicopters and fighter jets fire missiles into house in eastern Afghanistan after American soldier is wounded and Afghan soldier killed in an ambush; local officials say men who carried out ambush are thought to have taken refuge in house; ambush is latest in series of attacks by presumed Taliban supporters who are opposed to American military presence in Afghanistan (M)

headline: Tensions Mount in Nigeria's Presidential Campaign
abstract: Nigerians brace for possibility of violent clashes during elections for governorships and presidency; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Bank'S Profit Falls; SOUTH KOREA: Internet Bankruptcy; HONG KONG: Cost Cuts At Airline; JAPAN: Mcdonald'S Names Executive;.

headline: It May Once Have Been the Cradle of Humanity, but It's Far From Eden Today
abstract: Qurna, where local legend has it that Garden of Eden once bloomed, is one of many historical sites across Iraq that fail to live up to stories that surround them; neglect under Saddam Hussein's government, war between Iran and Iraq, then recent American-led war cited as causes for city's suffering (M)

headline: North Korea Cancels Talks With the South
abstract: North Korea canceled talks today with South Korea two days before a debate that opens at the U.N. on the nuclear crisis.

headline: KRISPY KREME TO OPEN STORES IN MEXICO IN JOINT VENTURE
abstract: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts Inc plans to open 20 doughnut shops in Mexico in next six years in joint venture with Grupo Axo of Mexico City; will have 30 percent interest in partnership (S)

headline: An Italian Traveler Is Slain By Taliban in Afghanistan
abstract: Italian tourist is shot and killed in taxi on main road in southern Afghanistan, apparently by Taliban gunmen; this is second such killing of foreign civilian in region in two weeks (M)

headline: Midas Begins Review of Its Creative Work
abstract: Midas Begins Review Of Its Creative Work Midas Inc. has begun a review for the creative part of its account, which has been handled since October 2001 by Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York. Though billings were not disclosed, Midas spent $40.6 million to advertise in major media last year, according to CMR, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

headline: What Rift? Top Aides Deny State Dept.-Pentagon Chasm
abstract: Chasm between Pentagon and State Depts seems so wide that it appears they are conducting two different foreign policies but top deputies, Paul D Wolfowitz at Defense and Richard L Armitage at State, downplay split and deny any animosity, interviews; some tensions are inevitable and healthy, because missions are different, with State Dept focusing on negotiation and Defense Dept taking tougher stance; Sec of State Colin Powell and Sec of Defense Donald Rumsfeld are widely seen as rival jousters, contest where Pentagon seems to have upper hand; some see Powell as marginalized figure since wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, but Armitage rejects generalization that Bush administration sees war as primary means to solve problems; similar tensions in prior administrations recalled (M)

headline: U.S. Youths Rebel at Harsh School in Costa Rica and Many Head for Home
abstract: Students at Academy at Dundee Ranch in Costa Rica rise up in revolt after Costa Rican officials visit ranch and tell them of their rights after complaints about program from former director; school is latest foreign outpost of World Wide Assn of Specialty Programs and Schools, far-flung affiliation of behavior modification programs that promises to convert troubled American teenagers into straight arrows; it lasted 19 months before students revolted; six people present claim adults beat some of children to quell uprising; academy's owner Narvin Lichfield is jailed for 30 hours, and may face criminal charges; four staff members feared by children are being deported to Jamaica; most of children are going home, many to an uncertain future; about 30 youths remain at academy; photo; map (M)

headline: Blasts at Philippine Mosques Follow Bombing at Terminal
abstract: Bombs explode outside three mosques in Davao, Philippines, in what police say may have been retaliation for recent bombing near ferry terminal that killed 16 people and injured 50; no one is killed in mosque explosions, which occur hours before Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo's arrival to meet with authorities about terminal bombing; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Borland Shares Rise On Strong Forecast
abstract: Borland Software Corp shares rise after company predicts improved operating margin; stock price graph (S)

headline: Azerbaijan's Leader Collapses While Delivering TV Speech
abstract: The 79-year-old president of Azerbaijan, Heydar A. Aliyev, collapsed twice during a nationally televised speech there today, prompting fresh questions about the health of a leader considered integral to the stability of his oil-producing country.    Mr. Aliyev, who has a history of heart and other health problems, was addressing a military audience in Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, when he gasped, clutched his heart, complained of pain and fell. The live television broadcast of his remarks was interrupted while bodyguards rushed over to support him.

headline: Men Are Much in the Sights Of Recruiters in Nursing
abstract: Nursing industry has stepped up efforts to recruit men; nurses in New York metropolitan area start at $50,000 to $70,000 kper year, and in specialties they make up to $100,000; nurses can pick and choose their place of employment because virtually every hospital, nursing home and home-health agency in greater New York area has shortage; Gary Liu, who switched to nursing from career in computer industry for pay and personal satisfaction, comments; photo (M)

headline: Text of Bush's Speech
abstract: Following is the text of remarks by President George W. Bush to the nation on Thursday announcing the end of major combat operations in Iraq:

headline: INDICTMENT SEEN IN STEWART CASE
abstract: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia says Martha Stewart faces likely criminal indictment related to her personal trading in Imclone stock just before FDA turned down Erbitux drug application and stock price plunged; photos; graph; disclosure, raising possibility that Stewart may have to step down from company posts, comes before tense annual meeting, at which she speaks by video; Stewart's lawyers have apparently failed to win agreement with federal prosecutors after months of negotiations (M)

headline: Young Iranians Are Chafing Under Aging Clerics' Edicts
abstract: Continuing protests by students in Tehran highlight question of how long Iran's aging clerics can impose their vision of Islamic state on nation 70 percent of whose people are under 30; majority of Iranians want sweeping transformation of theocracy that now tells them what to think, what to wear, what to read, what to watch and how to behave, and they are frustrated at glacial pace of change; demonstrations do not really pose serious challenge to mullahs because opponents of system lack unifying figure or organization that can translate their demands into public pressure; those who voted for Pres Mohammed Khatami, hoping for reform, have grown disillusioned; photos (M)

headline: Iraqi Says Hussein Planned to Revive the Nuclear Program Dismantled in 1991
abstract: White House says Iraqi scientist Dr Mahdi Obeidi claims Saddam Hussein intended to revive his nuclear program as soon as United Nations lifted sanctions against Iraq; Obeidi led Americans to barrel filled with nuclear blueprints and equipment that could be used to enrich uranium; he says he was ordered in 1991 to bury plans and equipment under garden of his house in Baghdad; International Atomic Energy Agency says fact that stash remained untouched is evidence that Iraq had not resumed its nuclear program since inspections began after Persian Gulf war; administration officials familiar with what Obeidi uncovered for Central Intelligence Agency say he came forward in May, and was taken out of Iraq to prevent reprisals against him; he has said there may be three or more other sets of similar parts, hidden by other scientists who have not yet come forward; photo (M)

headline: Travelers Feel New Isolation on a Russian Island
abstract: Foreigners and 'mainland' Russians on Sakhalin Island now need permits for most travel outside capital, Yuzhno Sakhalinsk, under new government campaign against gangster activities related to illegal export to Japan of about $1.3 billion worth of crab and seafood fished every year from waters around Sakhalin; new permit system is shaping up as epic clash between Russia's traditional love for controls and demands of free market; photo; map (L)

headline: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Montreal; Camaraderie Crowds Out Culture Wars
abstract: Travel article on Montreal as business travel destination; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Irish Schools To Get Broadband Connections
abstract: Ireland's Communications Min Dermot Ahern says he will provide broadband Internet connections for every school, library and community center in Ireland; says connections should not cost more than 30 million euros ($35.4 million), and could be financed by new tax on telecommunications companies (S)

headline: Seoul Tries to Thwart Takeover of Big Korean Oil Refiner
abstract: A little-known overseas investment fund collided with a government that is determined to keep it from gaining control of the SK Corporation, Korea's largest oil refiner.

headline: AOL's First-Quarter Results Surpass Chief's Forecast
abstract: AOL Time Warner reports larger-than-expected quarterly profit; net income was $396 million comapred to net loss of $54.2 billion year earlier; earnings rose 14 percent, to $2 billion; revenue increased by 6 percent, to $10 billion; total debt rose to $26.3 billion, from $25.8 billion, about $2 billion lower than some analysts' expectations; chief executive Richard D Parsons comments; photo (M)

headline: Editor Is Leaving Meredith to Finish a Book
abstract: Myrna Blyth, former Ladies' Home Journal editor, to retire from Meredith Corp, magazine's publisher, where she is now vice president and editorial director of More magazine and editorial director of new-product development (M)

headline: Stocks Rise in Asia on Hopes That Worst of SARS Is Over
abstract: Stock markets rise sharply across East Asia amid hopes that SARS outbreak can be controlled; photo of Hong Kong traders wearing face masks, which are becoming less common on floor of exchange and in streets in city hardest hit by disease; 12 more deaths reported there, bringing total to 150, but there are just 15 new cases (M)

headline: Already Battered, Tenet Reduces Earnings Forecast For Rest of Year
abstract: Tenet Healthcare tells investors to expect significantly lower profits this year than anticipated; company, which is under regulatory scrutiny for its Medicare billing practices, blames higher costs and its limited success in negotiating more favorable prices with private health plans for care; also expects lower reimbursements from Medicare and state governments under Medicaid; acting chief executive Trevor Fetter comments; graph; photo (M)

headline: Nigerian Elections Seen as Test for Civilian Rule
abstract: Nigeria is set to hold legislative elections in key test of whether it can move from one democratically elected civilian government to another without military interference;real battle will be week later, with presidential race and gubernatorial contests in 36 states; some 30 parties are running; vote comes amid widespread logistical snags and violence; photo (M)2

headline: In Cambodian Forest, Battling Besieging Spirits
abstract: Villagers in Ping, Cambodia, and its mountain neighbor, Bornhok, use tribal rituals to battle nameless disease that has sickened more than 30 of them and killed 7 in an agony of coughing, choking and delirium; none of villagers seem to know just what spirits turned against them or what transgressions they were punishing in northwest mountains of Ratanakiri Province; doctors of Western medicine are also baffled by mystery pulmonary disease, which closely mimicks SARS but, unlike SARS, seems to respond to antibiotics; photos; map (L)

headline: Bush Braces for Meeting With French and German Leaders
abstract: The meeting in the French Alps will focus on the Middle East, the reconstruction of Baghdad and the growing crisis over Iran.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: An SK Warning
abstract: Sovereign Asset Management threatens to sell its 14.99 percent stake in SK Corp if company keeps up 'unconditional support' for SK Global (S)

headline: Short Supply of Natural Gas Is Raising Economic Worries
abstract: United States faces its most severe shortage of natural gas in quarter-century; industries that use gas to produce their goods are already laying off workers; experts warn that warming trend, in economy or weather, could send prices spiking for electricity that cools homes and runs every sort of business; most analysts agree that basic law of supply and demand is at work; nearly all electric plants built since 1998 are designed to be fired mainly by gas, which has been promoted as cleaner-burning fuel than oil or coal; drilling has increased about 25 percent in last year, but supplies have not kept up with demand because much of drilling has been confined to old, overworked basins that are not as productive as they once were; analysts say failure to guage supply needs and weather patterns accurately in up-and-down economy has added to squeeze on supplies; prices for natural gas have risen sharply in last year as stored supplies fall to lowest level since federal government began keeping records in 1976; latest surge in prices has led to renewed calls from gas industry for loosening of environmental restrictions on drilling and pipeline construction in US; Energy Sec Spencer Abraham and National Petroleum Council are convening meeting later this month to discuss shortage and propose solutions; photo; graphs (L)

headline: Opposition Candidate in Nigeria Urges New Vote
abstract: He also rejected redress through legal channels, and appealed to world powers to refuse to recognize a government that he said had rigged its return to rule.

abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Bank Posts Loss; SOUTH KOREA: A Profit At Sk Telecom;.

abstract: List of soldiers killed in Iraq (S)

headline: British Muslims Are Seen Moving Into Mideast Terrorism
abstract: After two suicide bombers in Israel were found to be British citizens, Britain faced suggestions today that young British Muslims had shifted their focus to terrorism in the Middle East.

headline: Newspaper Surfing
abstract: Nielsen/NetRatings reports most of nation's major newspaper Web sites had significant traffic gains in Mar from Mar 2002; table; graph; photo (S)

headline: In the Heart of Baghdad
abstract: Map showing advances of American forces in and around Baghdad (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sharp Cuts Forecast
abstract: Sharp Corp says profit nearly tripled to 32 billion yen ($267 million) for year ended March 31; earnings were 13.5 percent below forecasts (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Military Breaks Silence
abstract: Mexican military, fulfilling new freedom of information law, discloses to El Universal Mexico City newspaper that 299 soldiers have been court-martialed since December 2000; 210 of those tried were convicted on variety of charges (S)

abstract: Advertisin

headline: Belgian War Crimes Law Used Against Foreigners Hits Home
abstract: Belgium's outspoken foreign minister, Louis Michel, has become the latest politician to be the target of a lawsuit filed under his country's international war crimes law.

headline: Lawyer Faults Officers at HealthSouth
abstract: Donald V Watkins, new lawyer for former HealthSouth Corp chief executive Richard M Scrushy, says officers who pleaded builty to fraud are responsible for company's accounting scandal, not his client; Frederick G Helmsing, lawyer for former HealthSouth chief financial officer William T Owens, who pleaded guilty last month to charges of securities fraud, says Watkins's contention is not true (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Defamation Appeal Lost
abstract: Opposition party leader Chee Soon Juan's conviction for defamation against Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong and Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew is upheld by High Court; fine has not been determined (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Restructuring Planned
abstract: Engage Inc, which makes software for online advertisers, is negotiating financial restructuring that might lead to filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection; Engage is majority owned by CMGI Inc (S)

headline: LOEWS TO BUY NATURAL GAS PIPELINE FOR $795 MILLION
abstract: Loews To Buy Natural Gas Pipeline For $795 Mil

headline: Compressed Data; Apple Tweaks Microsoft Over a New Computer
abstract: Computer industry veterans say futuristic new office computer planned by Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard Co leans too heavily on industrial design ideas introduced by Apple; Apple executives note new graphics software Microsoft plans for 2005 version of its Windows operating system apes features that have been in Apple operating system since 2001; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Applied Materials Posts $62 Million Loss
abstract: Applied Materials Inc reports net loss of $62 million in fiscal second quarter, down from net profit of $52 million year earlier; net sales for quarter ended April 27 were $1.11 billion, down 4 percent from $1.16 billion year ago (S)

headline: Illness Brings Subdued May Day in Beijing
abstract: May Day revelries in Beijing are sharply curbed by pervasive fear of SARS infection; to discourage travel that might spread disease, government officially shortens national holiday to five days from planned seven; photo of Tiananmen Square, deserted on day when thousands would normally gather to mark most hallowed of Communist holidays (M)

headline: Blair Says Ulster Peace Hinges on I.R.A.
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair publicly challenges Irish Republican Army, saying its refusal to break with its violent past is sole remaining obstacle to lasting peace in Northern Ireland; says break in current stalemate is 'frustratingly close' and that time has come for IRA to clearly pledge to give up its arms, halt its paramilitary activities and declare its long war with Britain ended; photo (M)

headline: Chronicles of War
abstract: Glimpses of the conflict, from disturbing tales to a lighter moment. PAGE B10

headline: Market Place; NASD Says Invemed Inflated Commissions on Trades
abstract: NASD files suit against Invemed Associates run by Kenneth G Langone, director of New York Stock Exchange and founder of Home Depot, charging firm illegally shared in customer profits by overcharging them to trade in hot new stock offerings during 1999 and 2000; says Invemed charged some of its institutional customers inflated commissions--as high as $8 per share--when they wanted to 'flip,' or quickly sell, initially public offering shares they purchased; NASD rules bar securities firms from sharing in their customers' profits; NASD also claims that some of Invemed's customers paid commission of $2 per share when trading in established companies; such inflated commission--institutional customers typically pay 6 cents per share to trade--allowed Invemed to share in its customers' profits; case against Invemed grew out of NASD investigation into new stock allocations at Credit Suisse First Boston (M)

headline: New increases expected as vacations begins : Still paying a high price for a 'roaming' cell phone
abstract: PARIS:—  Ted Matheny, a lawyer based in Paris, travels about one week a month for business, racking up mobile phone charges of about €400 a month.

headline: Battle for Baghdad Like War Plan: Kill Enemy, Limit Damage, Provide Aid
abstract: Objectives of battle of Baghdad, like those of entire war, are to destroy forces that support Pres Saddam Hussein, avoid civilian casualties, limit damage to civilian infrastructure, and provide aid; it does not appear that battle for city itself will occur for at least few days, and it will be approached in stages; Joint Chiefs of Staff chairman Gen Richard B Myers, after putting premium on speed in campaign's first two weeks, now counsels more deliberate pace; comments appear intended to prepare American public for possibility of prolonged contact, next phase of which will entail detailed reconnaissance missions into city, clandestine commando raids and pinpoint airstrikes intended to bring about collapse of government and prevent protracted urban fighting; any Republican Guard soldiers now ringing city who retreat inside will join more than 20,000 members of Special Republican Guard and other forces, and are expected to wage guerrilla warfare to thwart larger allied force; battle is fraught with other perils, including possibility that Iraq will use chemical or biological weapons; as ground forces close in on Baghdad, air campaign has shifted focus to Republican Guard, particularly four divisions near capital, and begun targeting system of command, control and communications that Iraqi leadership uses to send orders to field commanders; as Republican Guard continues to sustain damage, US military faces three likely battle options: push ahead to Baghdad through defeated Guard divisions south of city, destroy other Guard divisions that could attack allies' flanks, or hold off until long-awaited Fourth Infrantry Division and its 21,000 soldiers arrive later this month; map shows US troops' advances toward Baghdad; diagram shows how typical mechanized engagement is coordinated; photos (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WELLS FARGO & CO., San Francisco, said it planned to sell $3 billion in 30-year convertible bonds and use the money for general corporate purposes and to buy back debt and shares.    QUANTUM FUEL SYSTEMS TECHNOLOGIES WORLDWIDE, Irvine, Calif., a supplier of fuel tanks for General Motors' natural gas vehicles, plans to buy Global Thermoelectric, Calgary, Alberta, a maker of power equipment, for about $75 million in stock.

headline: Rumsfeld Echoes Notion That Iraq Destroyed Arms
abstract: Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, responding to questions after speech to Council on Foreign Relations, New York City, suggests publicly for first time that Iraq might have destroyed chemical and biological weapons before war; again holds it is just matter of time before military teams uncover illicit arms Pres Bush cited as major reason for war; seeks to counter critics who have accused administration of bungling post-war campaign in Iraq; appeals for patience for reconstruction effort that will be difficult and bumpy at times; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft Ends Dispute With AOL Time Warner  Microsoft agreed to pay AOL Time Warner $750 million in a settlement that ends a bitter dispute and commits the two companies to a sweeping program of business cooperation.    Under the terms of the agreement, Microsoft will grant AOL a seven-year royalty-free license to its Internet browsing software, and faster and greater access to Microsoft's Windows operating system. [Page A1.]

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Telecom Stake Sold; GERMANY: Bank Purchase Considered; BRITAIN: Grocer Rejects Bid; GERMANY: Media Stake Acquired; BOOK DEAL INVESTIGATED;.

headline: Iraqi elite division 'destroyed,' U.S. says
abstract: U.S. forces were within artillery range of Baghdad on Wednesday after they "destroyed" one of the six Republican Guard divisions defending the capital, according to the chief spokesman for the U.S. Central Command.

headline: Full Text of Brokaw's Interview With Bush
abstract: An interview of President Bush by Tom Brokaw of NBC News aboard Air Force One:

headline: Wall St. Settlement Plan May Take Years
abstract: Wall Street settlement will not prevent thousands of investors from also suing their investment firms, but it may take years for money to become available; Securities and Exchange Commission officials say first step for restitution fund is to appoint administrator who will set up plan to repay investors who bought certain stocks through 10 firms that reached settlement and who have filed claims with government; $387.5 million has been appropriated for fund; photo of SEC chairman William H Donaldson (M)

headline: African AIDS, and Helping Orphans Remember
abstract: Health workers in Uganda encourage dying AIDS patients to preserve memories for their children, who are often left orphaned, with shaky cultural roots; photo of Rebecca Nakabazzi with her son and memory book she is compiling, which includes advice she hopes he will remember (M)

headline: In Britain, Rivals Uneasily Share Stage to Discuss the Euro
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair and the chancellor of the exchequer began a campaign to promote a new consensus on Europe.

headline: The Military in Transition: From Combat to Containment
abstract: Photos and diagrams explaining how US military in Iraq is shifting tactics from large-scale hostilities to establishing street-level security and containing civil disorder

headline: South Korean President Blocks Extension of Bribe Probe
abstract: President Roh Moo Hyun rejected a special prosecutor's request for a one-month extension of the investigation, but left open the possibility of a fresh investigation in the future.

headline: E-Commerce Report; As Blockbuster moseys online, two competitors are already running hard. But will that matter?
abstract: Blockbuster's plan to introduce online movie rental service in 2004 to compete with Walmart.com and Netflix discussed; its delayed arrival in business, while risky, reflects current light demand; photo (M)

headline: On Television; CBS Is Planning To Stress Golf, Not Protests
abstract: CBS Sports television coverage of 2003 Masters golf tournament at Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia will remain basically unchanged despite picketing by demonstrators against club's men-only membership policy; broadcast will have no sponsors; demonstration, led by National Council of Women's Organizations, is likely to be televised only if it affects tournament play; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Growth Estimate Cut
abstract: Italian government cuts its 2003 growth forecast in half, to 1.1 percent, but some economists say figure is still too optimistic (S)

headline: SEMCO ENERGY CUTS DIVIDEND AND ISSUES PROFIT WARNING
abstract: Natural gas distributor Semco Energy Inc forecasts net loss for 2003; reduces quarterly dividend to 7.5 cents per share from 12.5 cents (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Filling cracks in e-tailing's promise to protect privacy.
abstract: Federal Trade Commission acts more aggressively against Internet retailers who fail to comply with their own stated policies for protecting consumers' privacy; photo (M)

headline: Pixar Executives Not Quite Ready To Forsake Others For Disney Alone
abstract: Pixar Animation Studios chief executive Steven P Jobs is working to renegotiate marketing and distribution deal with Walt Disney Co, set to expire in 2005; seeks to keep much greater share of profits; survival of partnership is in doubt; table of most popular animated films; photos (M)

headline: Enlisting the Young As White-Hat Hackers
abstract: Tiger Team, program started by Andrew Robinson, teaches young hackers that their skills can be used for good and can be road to good job in computer security; uses virtual game of capture the flag, trying to crack other team's network and do damage while defending their own; photos (M)

headline: Epidemic Spurs Plan To Revive Hong Kong
abstract: Hong Kong officials address economic fallout of SARS epidemic, announcing $1.5 billion package of tax breaks, loan guarantees for businesses and creation of 21,500 short term jobs, half of which will involve cleaning and disinfection effort to combat disease; plan calls for government spending and tax cuts concentrated in next four months that will equal one percent of territory's annual economic output; measure comes just seven weeks afer government announced higher taxes and deep spending cuts to reduce enormous budget deficit (M)

headline: HUDSON TECHNOLOGIES PLANS TO TRIM STAFF BY 20 PERCENT
abstract: Hudson Technologies Inc, which sells refrigerants, is cutting about 20 percent of its work force and closing six service depots to reduce costs; company has 85 employees (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: HONG KONG: Sars Pushes Up Unemployment; JAPAN: Toyota To Increase Output; INDONESIA: Economy Slows A Bit;.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP., Portland, Ore., said it had sold 53,000 acres of forest near Cleveland, Tex., to Cleveland Properties, for $35.3 million, and 27,000 acres of forest in and around San Augustine County, Tex., to San Augustine Properties of Texas for $18.2 million.    GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., said its GE Medical Systems unit would market a prostate cancer imaging system that incorporates its Infinia Hawkeye system with the ProstaScint imaging agent of Cytogen Corp., Princeton, N.J., a maker of biopharmaceutical products used in diagnosing and treating cancer.

headline: Music Industry Sends a Message To PC Screens: Sharing Is Theft
abstract: Recording Industry Association of America starts another cammpaign aimed at making life more uncomfortable for online music-swapping fans; thousands of people trading copyrighted music online see messages not to steal music; messages reflect latest effort among record executives to limit digital copying of their products; association plans to send at least million warnings each week to people offering popular songs for others to copy; association president Cary Sherman comments (M)

headline: Predicting the Path of a Submarine (or a Mutual Fund)
abstract: Strategies column on method devised by Yale researchers for rating mutual funds; graph (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Treasury Prices Mixe

headline: Blair, Bolstered by the War, Is Facing Challenges at Home
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair's standing has risen at home with fall of Saddam Hussein regime, but he faces challenge of pulling his own government and country together to 'make the peace worth the war'; biggest challenge for Blair now is to bring about public service reforms and establish clarity and decisiveness that seem to come easily to him on international stage; New Labor party came into power in 1997 on promise of overhauling dilapidated public services and public has been disappointed by lack of visible progress; Blair's loyalty to Pres Bush over Iraq issue is widely seen as costing him leadership role he has long sought in Europe (M)

headline: 'Missile Man' Surrender May Lead to Weapons
abstract: DOHA, Qatar -- He was one-half of Iraq's weapons couple, "the Missile Man" married to "Dr. Germ," a former general who human rights groups allege helped gas Kurds.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Draft For Europe
abstract: British brewer SABMiller will begin sales of Miller Genuine Draft beer in Hungary, Romania, Slovakia, Czech Republic, Poland and Italy; photo (S)

headline: Crushing Iraqi Units, Daring Rescue and the Saddam Hussein Mystery
abstract: As the war in Iraq entered its 14th day, U.S. forces continued their march toward Baghdad, encountering little resistance, but bracing for tough battles to come.

headline: TRANSITION PLANS
abstract: Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz says it may take United States more than six months to cede power in postwar Iraq to Iraqi-led civilian authority that would pave way for representative government; recalls that after Persian Gulf war in 1991 it took six months for Kurdish forces in northern Iraq to establish effective self-governance; envisions no central postwar role for United Nations in political administration, as many European countries want; Gen Peter Pace, vice chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, tells reporters that American and British forces or 'those who might volunteer to join us' could provide 'secure environment' so that new Iraqi government could build its police force and its armed forces up to internal defense-type capability; Pres Bush prepares to head to Belfast, Northern Ireland, on Apr 7 for his third meeting in three weeks with Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain, who has pushed for deeper UN involvement in postwar Iraq; UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan calls Security Council meeting to discuss Iraq; photo (M)

headline: A Network TV Executive Skips to a Particularly Menacing Rival
abstract: A Network TV Executive Skips To a Particularly Menacing Rival.

headline: Safeco Reports Earnings Are Up 42%
abstract: Safeco says fiï

headline: France Says It Was Victim of Lies Fed by White House
abstract: Officials in France complain formally that their country is victim of 'repeated disinformation' being fed by Bush administration officials who accuse France of having provided military and diplomatic aid to Saddam Hussein's government; White House denies assertion; still, some experts are surprised by anti-French virulence that has come, if not directly from Bush administration, then from some of its supporters or sympathizers in news media; French complaint is made in form of letter sent by Amb Jean-David Levitte to White House, State Dept and Congress (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Electrolux Lowers Outlook
abstract: World Business Briefing: Sw

headline: Security Council Votes to Extend Oil-for-Food Plan in Iraq
