abstract: The Security Council voted unanimously today to extend the United Nations oil-for-food program in Iraq for an extra three weeks, until June 3. But diplomats made it clear that this action does not preclude the adoption of new proposals to further alter or eliminate the program before that date.    The oil-for-food program began in 1996 as a way to ease the impact of United Nations sanctions on Iraq's civilian population. No oil has been sold since the war in Iraq began on March 19 because there has not been a recognized Iraqi government to sign contracts.

headline: U.N. Inspectors Say Baghdad Never Resolved Arms Issues
abstract: The United Nations weapons inspection office provided a postscript to its truncated mission today, suggesting in a new report that many open questions remain about whether and when Saddam Hussein's government destroyed its chemical and biological agents.    The report by the office of Hans Blix, the executive chairman of the United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission, also noted that none of the vehicles on Iraqis' prewar list of ''legitimate vehicles'' that could be mistaken for mobile biological weapons labs bore any resemblance to the two mobile facilities found recently in Iraq.

headline: Some Skeptics Say Arms Hunt Is Fruitless
abstract: Scott Ritter, former UN weapons inspector, is among small but vocal group of skeptics who doubt that stores of unconventional weapons will be found in Iraq; Ritter argues that weapons Iraq once had have been destroyed or degraded (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Land Speculation Discouraged
abstract: South Korean Finance Minister Kim Jin Pyo announces government will take measures to discourage loans to real estate investors and encourage them to invest in stock market; government is seeking to halt skyrocketing prices of apartments and other real estate; photo (S)

headline: Support for Britain's Labor Party Eroding, Poll Says
abstract: As a poll showed public disenchantment with the Labor Party, Foreign Secretary Jack Straw said today that he stood by the accuracy of British government intelligence on Iraqi weapons.

headline: Tough Economic Reform Plan Gains Momentum in Germany
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's politically divisive plan to overhaul Germany's paralyzed economy, including proposals to shake up country's labor market and scale back its generous pension benefits, wins support from top party officials; plan would make it easier for companies to lay off workers and reduce amount of time unemployed people can receive benefits (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Profit Up 18%
abstract: Adobe Systems says earnings rose 18 percent in its fiscal second quarter ended May 30; net income rose to $64.2 million from $54.3 million year earlier; sales rose less than 1 percent, to $320.1 million (S)

headline: Company Has Ties in Washington, and to Iraq
abstract: Bechtel, company that will lead reconstruction of Iraq, has long history of doing business there, including unsuccessful pipeline deal that involved meeting between Donald H Rumsfeld and Saddam Hussein; project later drew scrutiny from special prosecutor looking into allegations of impropriety involving Edwin A Meese III, former White House counsel and attorney general in Reagan administration; Bechtel has about 1,000 people on projects in Middle East and Persian Gulf region where it has five offices; selection causes disappointment for Parsons Corp, second finalist in bidding; Parsons identified unit of Halliburton as subcontractor, which, because of Vice Pres Dick Cheney's prior involvement as chief executive, may have caused its elimination from bidding; General Accounting Office has opened inquiry on Halliburton involvement in postwar Iraq; Bechtel's history, which includes ties to Washington via men who have served as executives, noted; chart details five contracts for reconstruction of Iraq that have been announced so far (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Advertiser's Sales Fall
abstract: WPP Group says revenue fell to 908.5 million pounds ($1.45 billion) in first quarter, down from 945.8 million pounds ($1.51 million) year ago (S)4

headline: Korean Diplomacy Enters a New Era
abstract: Han Sung Joo, South Korea's new ambassador to US, discusses his country's quest for better balance in relations with US and for reversal of American decision to remove its 14,000 infantrymen from positions along demilitarized zone that separates North and South Korea; experts say Han, former foreign minister and university president, can take initiative on complicated and sensitive diplomacy rather than merely try to burnish image of Pres Roh Moo Hyun; photo (M)

headline: London Journal; Sidle Up to the Bar, but Don't Shimmy or Shake
abstract: Westminster City Council in London is sensitive to criticism it receives for forbidding dancing in bars that do not hold public entertainment licenses; one bar in London has paid more than $25,000 in fines and legal costs; council says licensing laws are intended to help control noise generated by dance-inducing music; deputy manager of one bar says it is his job to decide if customer is really dancing, or only swaying; photos (M)

headline: A Tabloid King Looks Beyond Elvis
abstract: American Media Inc chief executive David J Pecker, who persuaded former US Weekly editor Bonnie Fuller to join company, strives to implement ambitious plan to turn company into profitable billion-dollar venture that he may take public; photo (M)

headline: Iraqis Were Set to Vote, But U.S. Wielded a Veto
abstract: One uncomfortable truth of American occupation of Iraq is that US officials, for now, are barring direct elections and limiting free speech, two of very ideals that have been promised to Iraqis; officials say it may take up to two years for elected Iraqi government to take over country; week ago in Najaf, American military units helped set up voting system and candidates blanketed city with fliers outlining their platforms, when L Paul Bremer III stepped in and unilaterally canceled election; several days later, American marines stormed offices of obscure local political party and jailed four members for violating new edict by Bremer that makes it illegal to incite violence against occupying forces; events expose tightrope Bremer is walking as he struggles to help build friendly and stable Iraqi government; some American officials say they believe Iraq is not ready for elections, and voting could inflame tensions; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Reverse Split For Priceline
abstract: Priceline. com, seller of discount travel services, completes 1-for-6 reverse stock split (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Loss At Resort Operator
abstract: French resort operator Club Mediterranee reports loss of 29 million euros ($34.4 million) in first six months of its fiscal year as sales fell 4 percent; posts operating income of 12 million euros, up from operating loss of 4 million euros year earlier (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Help For Credit Unit
abstract: Hyundai Automotive Group is coming to rescue of Hyundai Card, one of South Korea's troubled credit card companies; Hyundai Automotive units are buying shares valued at 454.7 billion won ($381 million) in Hyundai Capital Services, motor vehicle financing company that owns Hyundai Card (S)

headline: Private Sector; A Large Chunk of Green From an Old Orangeman
abstract: Syracuse University renames its mana

headline: Site of Egypt Summit Prospers During Peace
abstract: Sharm el Sheik, Egypt, where main road runs between ridges of Sinai Peninsula and depths of Red Sea, prospers during times of relative Mideast peace and suffers when hostilities keep away tourists; Pres Hosni Mubarak has turned place into favored retreat for gatherings such as Pres Bush's meeting with Arab leaders in search of peace (M)

headline: Plenty of Confusion On Bonds and Rates
abstract: plenty of co

headline: U.S. Adds Basque Group in Spain to Its Terrorist List
abstract: The announcement came a few hours before President Bush was to meet at the White House with Prime Minister José María Aznar of Spain, a strong political ally in the war against Iraq.

headline: Will New Rules On Wall Street Matter Much To Investors?
abstract: Experts doubt new practices mandated by settlement in which big Wall Street firms agreed to pay $1.4 billion for their role in stock market bubble will matter much to small investors; say $7 trillion in stock losses since broad averages peaked in Mar 2000 have long since taught investors not to rely on Wall Street analyst's research; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: SOUTH AFRICA: State Funeral Ordered For Sisulu; CONGO: Key Rebel Joins Government;.

headline: Hotel Cuts Still Under Review, Owner Says
abstract: Six Continents PLC is not yet certain how many jobs it will eliminate at its InterContinental hotel division by end of May (S)

headline: Family Dreads Telling Father That Three Daughters Are Dead
abstract: Family and friends of Saad Abbas are reluctant to tell him his three beloved daughters did not survive missile attack that hit their Baghdad apartment on third night of American airstrikes; while American military officials say efforts were made to avoid civilian casualties, there were still many; initial estimates are that several hundred died and many more were wounded; photos (M)

headline: NORTHWEST FLIGHT ATTENDANTS TO SWITCH UNIONS
abstract: Flight attendants at Northwest Airlines vote to oust Teamsters, their union representative for 26 years, in favor of Professional Flight Attendants Association; vote comes as Northwest seeks pay and benefit concessions from unions to stem losses; Teamsters refused to enter those talks (S)

headline: Most Taiwan SARS Cases Spread by One Misdiagnosis
abstract: Director general of Taiwan's Center for Disease Control says most of Taiwan's SARS cases can be traced to one man whose lung ailment was misdiagnosed for five days; says that patient caused rapid growth in cases that began on Apr 21 and forced closing of four hospitals; says hospital will be fined for misdiagnosing patient's disease and failing to report its error for two days longer; says health authorities think they have traced sources of infection for all but 6 of island's 116 probable cases; in Hong Kong, 11 more people are reported to have died of SARS, bringing death toll to 204; on mainland China, there are 159 new cases, for total of 4,560; 219 people have died; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Will Move Air Operations To Qatar Base
abstract: United States is shifting its major air operations center for Middle East, including day-to-day responsibility for overseeing hundreds of air missions in Iraq, from Saudi Arabia to Qatar, first step in what is likely to be significant reduction of American forces in Saudi Arabia and realignment of American military presence in region; formal decision about whether to make new arrangement permanent will be made by Pres Bush and Defense Sec Rumsfeld; move is prompted by continued unease in Saudi Arabia about large American military presence in kingdom, and fact that war in Iraq is winding down; Rumsfeld visits United Arab Emirates and Qatar as part of trip to discuss with regional allies shape and size of American military commitment in region after fall of Saddam Hussein's government; United States commanders have chafed at restrictions Saudis placed on American-led wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and Air Force officials in particular have long favored moving air command post to base in Qatar; senior Bush administration officials stress that America's military relationship with Saudi Arabia will continue, including efforts to train Saudi forces as well as use of Saudi air bases (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Soldiers Charge Abuse
abstract: Russian military prosecutors begin criminal investigation into 2 sergeants accused of physical abuse by 14 soldiers who deserted base near Vladikavkaz (S)

headline: Parents Divided Over Jamaica Disciplinary Academy
abstract: Tranquility Bay in St Elizabeth, Jamaica, is oldest foreign outpost in booming network of behavior-modification programs for American teenagers; it has reputation as harshest of them all; many who have been there describe life of pain and fear; others say program saved their lives; school's methods have spawned fierce supporters and critics; it is becoming battleground for warring camps of parents and children, growing number of whom oppose program; fight may shape future of parent organization, Utah-based World Wide Assn of Specialty Programs and Schools, known as Wwasps, one of biggest and most lucrative businesses of its kind; some students describe being restrained by staff members who twisted their arms behind their backs until their hands touched their heads, inflicting intense pain without bruises; no long-term studies of 1,500 youths who have been to Tranquility Bay, or 300 who have graduated, have been done; photos; map (L)

headline: Italian Leader, in a First, Testifies at His Own Bribery Trial
abstract: Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi of Italy appears at his own bribery trial; says he entered into business deal in question because Bettino Craxi, prime minister at time, urged him to do so for good of country; this is first time sitting Italian prime minister has ever given testimony as criminal defendant; Berlusconi is accused of bribing judges in mid-1980's to try to influence sale of state-controlled food company to him and not to competitors; if convicted, he would probably file appeal and ask for new parliamentary elections to be held, essentially seeking verdict's repudiation by voters; voters first elected him after bribery charge had already been filed and despite long history of criminal proceedings against him; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Caliper To Acquire Zymark
abstract: Caliper Technologies Corp, which makes devices and systems for laboratory experiments, acquires Zymark Corp for $72.7 million in cash and stock; Caliper plans to move headquarters to Zymark's hometown of Hopkinton, Mass, from Mountain View, Calif, after transaction is completed; Zymark's chief executive Kevin Hrusovsky will become Caliper's chief executive; Caliper's chief executive-founder Michael Knapp will become chief technical officer; graph (S)

headline: San Diego's Spreading Biotechnology Colony
abstract: IDEC Pharmaceuticals Corp's $85 million headquarters is latest outcropping of biotechnology-related construction in hills of San Diego County, Calif; IDEC broke ground in February on 350,000-square-foot complex east of University of California at San Diego in area known as University Town Center; complex is expected to be completed in fall of 2004; biotechnology companies have clustered near area's research institutes; map; drawing (M)

headline: POWELL IN MIDEAST ASKING QUICK STEPS FOR CONCILIATION
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell, in Jerusalem for first American engagement in Israeli-Palestinian dispute in year, calls on both sides to take quick military steps and not get bogged down in arguing over long-term peace plan drafted by United States and others; specifically rejects Prime Min Ariel Sharon's appeal to revise so-called road map to accommodate certain Israeli objections to granting Palestinians who left Israel when it was founded 'right of return' to their native areas as part of any final settlement; notes right of return was major stumbling block when Israeli-Palestinian talks broke off two and half years ago; he will meet with Israeli Foreign Min Silvan Shalom and new Palestinian Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas, but not with Yasir Arafat; US has refused to deal with him since last summer; photos (M)

headline: Music Songs à la Carte
abstract: Apple Computer says that its Internet download service Music Store has sold over two million songs at 99 cents apiece since its April 28 debut; photo; tables of music sales (S)

headline: Arts Groups Fight Upstarts to Keep Their Buildings
abstract: Postwar Baghdad is site of scramble for buildings; artists seeking to reclaim Iraqi Artists Society building meet resistance from religious and political groups wanting building themselves; many other cultural groups say they are under intense pressure from scores of Islamic groups and political parties that have sprouted around capital since Saddam Hussein's government fell; for new entities, land grab is both blunt expression of power in power vacuum as well as crafty positioning for whatever comes next; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Black Box Posts Declines In Revenue And Income
abstract: Black Box Corp, provider of computer-networking products, says net income fell 68 percent in its fiscal fourth quarter ended March 31 as revenue dropped 16 percent; net income was $4.21 million compared with $12.9 million year earlier; revenue fell to $134.8 million; graph (S)

headline: New Magazine Has the Sound, Not the Budget, Of the Late Talk
abstract: Radar, general-interest magazine with specific interest in pop culture, is set to hit newsstands, and financial backers hope that young, urban readers will be attracted to its cheeky hodgepodge of humor, current events and aggressive, and not always friendly, coverage of celebrities; Radar has been been compared with Talk, Tina Brown's much-ballyhooed magazine, but Radar's management is keeping much tighter rein on spending in hopes that it will last longer than Talk; Maer Roshan, publisher and editor, comments; photo (M)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for MARK LUSCOMBE; Who Wins, and Who Is Skipped, in the Tax Cut
abstract: Interview with tax analyst Mark Luscombe on how various taxpayers will benefit differently from new tax cut; he notes law is heavily tilted toward higher-income taxpayers; photo (M)

headline: Arabs and Kurds Clash in Kirkuk, and at Least 5 Are Killed
abstract: Ethnic tensions between Kurds and Arabs explode into violence in northern Iraq city of Kirkuk, leaving at least five dead; witnesses say armed Arabs drove into Kirkuk from town of Hawija, provoking gunfights in two neighborhoods; wounded are predominantly Kurds; violence apparently began when Kurds harassed Arabs in outdoor market; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- Minneapolis-St. Paul; A Good Place to Do Business With an Easy Airport to Boot
abstract: Travel on Minneapolis-St Paul as business destination; photo (M)

headline: Deal Reunites Early Makers Of Hand-Helds
abstract: Palm Inc agrees to acquire Handspring; stock deal will reunite Donna Dubinsky and Jeff Hawkins, pioneers who created first successful hand-held computing device, with Palm, company they left in anger to start Handspring; photos; graphs of hand-held industry data (M)

headline: W.H.O. Lifts Vietnam Advisory
abstract: The World Health Organization said that SARS infections appeared to be dwindling in 3 other nations, but still rising in China.

headline: Unemployment Rate Rises to 9-Year High
abstract: The unemployment rate climbed from 6.0 percent in April to 6.1 percent in May, but the economy lost fewer jobs than expected.

headline: MediaTalk; No Big Deal. Dave Just Wants the Day Off.
abstract: On the fifth day, Dave rested.    But, as often happens with the Dave in question, no one knew quite what to make of David Letterman's sudden decision last week to take Friday off. And no one -- either at the show or at CBS -- is quite sure if he plans to make the last day of the workweek a Letterman-free zone.

headline: Innovation at Hewlett Tries to Evade the Ax
abstract: Hewlett-Packard's $3 billion cost-cutting effort, critical to company's success, poses serious challenge to its ability to innovate and invent in fast-consolidating computer industry; researcher layoffs and development budget cuts threaten success of crucial cooperation among company's engineers and scientists to restore HP's ability to compete; chief executive Carleton S Fiorina reiterates company's dedication to innovation; photo; table of leading technology companies' research and development spending (M)

headline: Success for Brazil Despite Naysayers
abstract: Many analysts expected economic turmoil when Luiz Inacio da Silva won election as president of Brazil, but he has steered cautious economic course that is pointing in positive directions in his first 100 days in office; Brazilian currency, the real, has recovered and government bonds are trading at their highest prices; da Silva comments; graph; photos (M)

headline: Iraqis Struggling to Reclaim A Land Literally Awash in Oil
abstract: Reconstruction of Iraq's sprawling oil industry could take longer than Iraqis and American and British forcers hoped; oil will be motor that powers Iraq's reconstruction and determine future well-being of its people; American officials say country could be pumping 3 million barrels a day by year end; photo (M)

headline: DUKE ENERGY TO SHUT A TRADING BUSINESS
abstract: Duke Energy Corp to close its speculative energy-trading business in North America to reduce collateral payments and preserve its credit rating; will cut about dozen trading jobs and transfer about eight workers within company (S)

headline: Arab Street Shifting Its Gaze to Iraq After Hussein
abstract: Arab diplomatic efforts to stabilize Iraq began in earnest today as President Hosni Mubarak called for the speedy installation of a transitional government.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Hadhrat Mirza Tahir Ahmad, spiritual leader of Ahmadiyya Muslim sect, which seeks to reinterpret Islamic doctrine in light of modern age, dies at age 74 (M)

headline: Iraqi Pipeline Blast Is Laid To Sabotage
abstract: Adel Qazzaz, director general of Iraq's Northern Oil Co, says explosion along major oil pipeline route in north-central Iraq appears to have been act of sabotage; incident comes as State Oil Marketing Organization, which oversees export of Iraqi oil, announces companies that will buy Iraq's first oil exports since war (M)

headline: Factory Orders Fall; Military Sales Rise
abstract: Commerce Department reports factory orders dropped 1.5 percent in February compared with 1.7 percent gain in January; factory inventories expanded 0.4 percent in February after 0.1 percent gain in January; decrease in orders was led by 1.6 percent drop in bookings for durable goods; orders for commercial aircraft fell 27 percent; military capital goods were 23.3 percent higher in February than year earlier; Raytheon says it will accelerate production of new version of its Tomahawk cruise missile; bookings for military communications equipment surged 14 percent after 10.3 percent rise; industrial machinery orders plummeted 29 percent, to $2.8 billion; orders for computers dropped 17 percent, to $3.9 billion; photo (M)

headline: New Economy; The legal waters grow muddy in a dispute over a company's rights to Unix.
abstract: Fears for future of free software are raised by lawsuit in which SCO Group, which acquired Unix operating system and its source code in 1995, accuses IBM of breaching its contract with SCO by taking code covered by Unix contract and putting it into Linux, leading example of open-source software development; SCO has sent warning letters to 1,500 large corporations saying that Linux is unauthorized derivative of Unix and that Linux infringes on its Unix intellectual property and other rights; photos (M)

headline: A Strong Push
abstract: Graphs of gains in Nasdaq Composite and Dow Jones Industrial indexes

headline: For Inmates Who Have Everything
abstract: H2

headline: U.S. General Unsure When or if Weapons Were Destroyed
abstract: Gen David H Petraeus says Iraqi chemical weapons stocks may have been destroyed before US attack, or may still be hidden (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Power Contract Error
abstract: Canada's biggest publicly traded power generator, the TransAlta Corporation, said a clerical error in contract bidding cost it $24 million this quarter, setting off a sharp decline in its stock price. The company submitted an erroneous bid to the New York Independent System Operator, which runs the state's power grid, for May 2003 transmission congestion contracts, the company said after North American markets closed on Tuesday. The mistake will reduce earnings by the equivalent of 11 Canadian cents a share. TransAlta's shares fell 77 Canadian cents, to 17.98 Canadian dollars ($13.16) a share, on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

headline: U.S. Tells Iran Not to Interfere In Iraq Efforts
abstract: Bush administration, facing mounting resistance from militant Islamic clerics and Arab nationalists in Iraq, says it is determined to see establishment of 'Islamic democracy' and that it recently warned Iran against interfering; warning comes amid growing concern about instability still evident in Baghdad, competition among Kurds and Arabs for power in north and outpouring of anti-American sentiment from Shiites in south; officials say US is redoubling efforts to promote pro-American clerics even as Iranian agents who have crossed into Iraq are trying to court Shiite clerics sympathetic to Iran's fundamentalist government; team of American officials is preparing to convene second meeting of Iraqi leaders in Baghdad, step toward formation of interim Iraqi authority; map of Sunni and Shiite regions of Iraq; chart of Shiite leaders and their political positions; photo (M)

headline: For Arabs, New Jihad Is in Iraq
abstract: Men from across Arab world, driven by combination of religious zeal and Arab nationalism, are volunteering for jihad against United States presence in Iraq; hundreds are waiting in Damascus, hoping for seat on one of free buses provided by Iraqi interests or other transportation to war zone; Baghdad issues daily exhortations for faithful to join the fray, and boasts of arrival of thousands of volunteers; Vice Pres Taha Yassin Ramadan, in latest news conference, claims count stands at 6,000, with half of them willing to be suicide bombers; Syria, like most Arab governments, officially discourages anyone from going, but it has long borders with Iraq and anyone holding passport from an Arab country can enter or leave with few questions asked; rulings from Muslim religious institutions on issue of jihad have been mixed; many volunteers waiting in Damascus speak only of importance of jihad to defend any Islamic land, whether their religious elders support it or not; others say they are going because they are outraged that United States claims it is bringing deomcracy to Iraq while killing civilians daily; photo (M)

headline: In Surprise, Parenting Wins Top Award for Magazines
abstract: Time Inc's Parenting magazine wins most prominent award for general excellance for magazines with circulation of more than two million at National Magazine Awards, sponsored by American Society of Magazine Editors; magazine's editor in chief Janet Chan comments; The Nation wins for columns and commentary, Architectural Record for general excellance for magazines with circulation of 100,000 to 250,000, Scientific American for single topic, The American Scholar for essays and Foreign Policy for general excellance for magazines with circulation under 100,000; Texas Monthly is recognized for general excellance for magazine with circulation of 250,000 to 500,000; The New Yorker wins two awards for reporting and fiction and The Atlantic Monthly wins in public interest category and general excellance for magazines with circulation of 500,000 to one million; chart (M)

headline: Ringing In With Hip-Hop Beats
abstract: Hip-hop tunes dominate market for movie or pop themes that can be downloaded in computerized form to replace standardized ring of cellphone; photo (S)

headline: Ex-Korean Finance Official Is Held in Bribery Accusations
abstract: Former South Korean Finance official Lee Keun Young is first official to be jailed in scandal involving alleged payoffs to induce North Korea to summit meeting with South Korea in 2000 on reconciliation; is accused of authorizing more than $500 million in loans to two companies within Hyundai Group, through which payments to North Korea were allegedly made (M)

headline: What Hope Now for Mideast Peace?
abstract: JERUSALEM (CNN) -- As the U.S.-led military campaign against Iraq nears an end, a common refrain on the streets from Tel Aviv to Ramallah is what will the Iraqi war mean for Middle East peace and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: G.M. AND BMW TO ANNOUNCE JOINT VENTURE ON FUEL CELLS
abstract: General Motors and BMW plan to announce joint venture to deelop liquid hydrogen as fuel for cars; hydrogen is used to power fuel cells, clean power system that Pres Bush has envisioned as replacing gasoline-powered cars in future generations; two companies say they plan to start selling affordable vehicles powered by fuel cells by 2010 (S)

headline: 2 Journalists and U.S. Clergyman Are Reported Held in Laos
abstract: Laotian authorities detain Thierry Falise and Vincent Reynaud, European journalists, and Naw Karl Mua, American of Laotian origin, who is believed to have been acting as interpreter for them in covering Hmong insurgency; say men may be charged in connected with killing of village security guard by local fighters; international journalist organizations urge their release (M)

headline: DVR Myths and Facts
abstract: If you hadn’t guessed from my coverage in Circuits (like today’s column) or in this newsletter, I’m a huge, raving, tentacle-waving fan of digital video recorders like TiVo and ReplayTV.

headline: Arab Leaders Vow to Fight Terror During Talks With Bush in Egypt
abstract: Five Arab leaders pledged to President Bush today that they would actively fight "the culture of extremism and violence" that has undercut Mideast peace efforts.

headline: China and Hong Kong Investigate a Well-Connected Real Estate Tycoon
abstract: Chinese and Hong Kong authorities have begun a broad investigation of the real estate and livestock empire of Zhou Zhengyi, a Chinese businessman whose high-level political and financial ties helped him become Shanghai's wealthiest deal maker.    Mr. Zhou, 42, was detained in Shanghai and his wife and business partner, Mao Yuping, was arrested in Hong Kong on suspicion of obtaining loans from mainland Chinese banks through fraudulent means, including a $200 million loan from the Bank of China, Chinese government media and Hong Kong officials said.

headline: Mortgage Requests Drop
abstract: Mortgage Bankers Association of America says its index of mortgage applications decreased 9.3 percent, to 1,684.6 last week from 1,856.7 previous week; refinancing index also fell 9.3 percent, to 9,046.9 from record 9,977.8 (S)

headline: Briefly Noted
abstract: AMERICAS PANAMA: STOLEN TREASURES RECOVERED The police said they had recovered Panama's most important collection of pre-Columbian gold artifacts, stolen from the Reina Torres de Arauz Museum in Panama City in February. Undercover agents tracked down the 292 gold relics on Monday afternoon by posing as black-market buyers, the police said. A Panamanian man, whom the police arrested but declined to identify, tried to sell the officers the relics for $10 million. Thirteen people suspected of collaborating in the robbery, including eight culture institute employees, were in custody, the police said. The items date from 500 to 1000 A.D.    (Reuters) ASIA INDIA: NEW AMBASSADOR TO PAKISTAN India has appointed Shiv Shankar Menon, currently ambassador to China, as its next ambassador to Pakistan, the Foreign Ministry said. Mr. Memo, 53, is a career diplomat. Press Trust of India said Mr. Menon had been accepted by Pakistan, clearing the way for his move to Islamabad. As part of fresh peace initiatives, India and Pakistan recently announced steps to restore full diplomatic relations. Diplomatic links were broken after an attack on Parliament in 2001. India blamed Pakistan for the attack, and recalled its ambassador. A few months later, it asked Pakistan to do the same.    (AP) EUROPE GERMANY: NEO-NAZI CRIME UP Right-wing extremist groups have become more violent, even as their overall numbers have declined, the country's domestic intelligence agency said in a report. The report, released by Interior Minister Otto Schily, said that while membership in right-wing organizations had declined by 10 percent at the end of 2002, to around 45,000, the number of acts of violence they motivated increased by 8 percent, to 772. The report also noted a rise in the number of foreign organizations based in Germany that are believed to present a security threat. Radical Islamic groups make up a large part of them, with about 30,000 members.    Hu

headline: Aegis Combines Media-Agency Units
abstract: Aegis Combines Media-Agency Units The Aegis Group in London is revamping by placing its two media-agency networks, Carat and Vizeum, in a new division intended to increase their buying power and consolidate back-office operations.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Conviction Appealed
abstract: Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's former Deputy Prime Minister, begins appeal of sodomy and corruption conviction; many feel conviction is primarily political retribution for conflict with Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Lawyer Urges Bail
abstract: Lawyer George Bizos urges Harare judge to release his client Morgan Tsvangirai, claiming his arrest for treason is to silence his political views not because of criminal actions; Tsvangirai was arrested after Movement of Democratic Change party he leads organized continued protests against Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe government, demanding Mugabe's resignation (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Three-Way Extradition
abstract: Mexican Supreme Court upholds extradition request by Spain and will send former Argentine navy officer Ricardo Miguel Cavallo to Spain to face charges of torture, genocide and terrorism for participation in Argentina's 1976-1983 dictatorship; this type of cooperation between countries, in hopes of international justice, is first ever of its kind (S)

headline: Private Sector; English Major Makes Good on Wall Street
abstract: Harvard Business School Club of Greater New York honors Henry M Paulson Jr and Donna E Shalala; he comments, interview (S)

headline: As U.S. Agents Begin to Investigate Riyadh Attacks, Saudis Move to Limit Their Role
abstract: American investigators scour three blast sites in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, where terrorists detonated car bombs; hunt for forensic evidence is noteworthy because Saudi authorities have severely limited American access in terrorism investigations in past; Interior Min Prince Nayef bin Abdul Aziz says Americans are only there to inspect incidents and will not conduct detailed probes; senior American officials dismiss comments as signal to Saudi people, who might be distrustful of having large American law enforcement presence there; recap of bombing and investigation; photo (M)

headline: J.P. MORGAN FORMS PARTNERSHIP WITH INTRAWEST
abstract: J P Morgan Chase & Co and Intrawest Corp forms partnership Leisura Developments US to finance and develop residences at resorts in US (S)

headline: Has Oracle's Chief Disarmed a Rival?
abstract: Hostile takeover of PeopleSoft by Oracle is viewed as remote because of possible antitrust objections and litigation begun by PeopleSoft board, but bid is already paying off for Oracle by sowing doubts in minds of potential clients' about future of PeopleSoft and J D Edward & Co, software company that PeopleSoft has agreed to acquire; Lawrence J Ellison, Oracle chairman and chief executive, insists that bid is for real; whether Oracle becomes main beneficiary if bid paralyzes two competitors remains to be seen; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: BORLAND SHARES RISE ON STRONG FORECAST; NANTERO CREATES DEVICE FOR CHIP MAKING;.

headline: Federal Judge Unfreezes Assets Of Former HealthSouth Chief
abstract: Federal Judge Inge P Johnson lifts freeze on assets of Richard M Scrushy, former chief executive of HealthSouth Corp, denying government motion to block use of his money and property pending his trial for fraud; Scrushy has been accused by Securities and Exchange Commission of inflating earnings by $1.4 billion since 1999; Scrushy will have millions of dollars at his disposal to defend against SEC fraud suit and criminal probe of him by federal prosecutors (M)

headline: S.E.C. Picks A Fed Banker To Lead Panel
abstract: William J McDonough, longtime president of Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is named chairman of new Public Company Accounting Oversight Board by Securities and Exchange Commission; McDonough comments (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: $350 Billion Tax Cut Plan Is Approved by Congress  The $350 billion tax cut package, which is less than half the size the president requested in January, was approved in the House by 231 to 200 and in the Senate by 51 to 50, with Vice President Dick Cheney breaking the tie.    While the bill was still being printed, Republican leaders vowed to bring up more tax cut proposals this year and extend the current measure for years to come. [Page A12.]

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: COMPUTER HORIZONS SHARES SOAR; ADTRAN SAYS INCOME MORE THAN DOUBLED;.

headline: Accounts Suggest 6 Massacred British Soldiers Were Fleeing an Angry Crowd
abstract: Details begin to emerge about fighting that led to deaths of six Brish soldiers and four Iraqis at Majar al Kabir in southern Iraq; accounts suggest that British soldiers were trapped by angry mob and tried to retreat into police station, but were shot there; tensions had apparently risen when patrols began searching houses for weapons, drawing complaints that soldiers had pawed through women's underwear, brought police dogs into homes and even stolen money; map; photos (M)

headline: Cellphones Ring Out With the Help of a Steeple
abstract: Church steeples and crosses are proving to be ideal places for cellular telephone antennas, especially in small towns that lack other tall structures; churches can earn average of $1,000 to $3,000 a month in fees for renting out steeples; Bell Atlantic (now part of Verizon) rebuilt lightning-damaged steeple of United Methodist Church in Ipswich, Mass, in exchange for permission to put antenna in it; photos (M)

headline: Crime Reports Defy Russian Claims of Greater Calm in Chechnya
abstract: Statistics reports about crime and violence in Russian republic of Chechnya run contrary to Russian government assertions that life in Chechnya is slowly returning to normal; reports detail parade of disappearances, killings and beatings; civilian murder rate in Chechnya is at least two to three times as high as in Moscow; abduction rate is almost double murder rate; statistics do not include deaths in region's low-level guerrilla war, in which roughly dozen to two dozen Russian fighters and unknown nunmber of antigovernment guerrillas die each week; crime statistics, ostensibly public information but never formally released, are provided by person close to pro-Moscow government who disagrees with government's assertions (M)

headline: Experts Say European Central Bank Is Ready to Cut Rates
abstract: Given the recent surge in the euro and the tide of grim economic news in Europe, some experts predict interest rates will cut by a half a point.

headline: France Calls for Suspending U.N. Sanctions on Iraq
abstract: France's ambassador to the U.N. proposed today immediately suspending sanctions on Iraq and phasing out the U.N. oil-for-food program.

headline: U.S. Sets Date For a Decision On Chip Tariff
abstract: Sec Donald L Evans says Commerce Department will decide June 16 whether to approve 57 percent tariff on memory chips made by Hynix Semiconductor; at issue is whether South Korea unfairly subsidizes Hynix (M)

headline: Owners of Hyatt Chain Must Reveal Breakup Plan, Judge Says
abstract: Owners of Hyatt Chain Mu

headline: Patents; Before Shock and Awe can go from battlefield to lunch box, there is a stop at the trademark office.
abstract: 'Shock and awe,' phrase coined by United States military forces to describe their battle plan for war against Iraq, is on trademark applications filed by Americans for wide range of products including foods, toys, fireworks displays and eyeglasses; interest in such phrases usually wanes before Patent and Trademark Office rules (M)

headline: For Some, Tobacco Debt May Now Be Worth the Risk
abstract: For Some, Tobacco Debt Ma

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Stake In Gas Project
abstract: China's top offshore oil producer, CNOOC Ltd, will pay $348 million for 5.3 percent stake in North West Shelf project, Australia's largest oil and gas venture, to meet growing gas demand in China (S)

headline: Virtual Travel Gives the Airlines Real Heartburn
abstract: Entire travel industry is coping with corporate America's growing love affair with teleconferencing; new technology is making it easier and cheaper than ever, meaning that it will probably continue to eat into revenues of airlines, hotels, car rental companies and other segments of travel industry even if all other problems industry has gone through fade away; photo (M)/

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Gunman Kills Mayor
abstract: Aci Castello (Sicily) Mayor Michele Toscano and four others are shot and killed by disgruntled government employee Guiseppe Leotta, who later shoots himself in Vittoria church (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Software Profit Rises
abstract: britain: sof

headline: BAUSCH & LOMB MAY DELAY REQUEST FOR IMPLANT APPROVAL
abstract: Bausch & Lomb Inc might delay seeking approval for eye implant to treat diabetes-related vision problem by as much as three years; Food and Drug Administration wants more information about safety of implant Retisert in patients with macular edema (S)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: More than 50 bodies were recovered after two ferries sank in Bangladesh rivers during a storm, witnesses said.

headline: U.S. Captures A Half Brother Of Iraqi Chief
abstract: US Special Forces in Baghdad capture Saddam Hussein's half-brother Barzan Ibrahim al-Tikriti, former intelligence chief on list of 55 Iraqis wanted by US authorities; ghosts of old regime emerge as relatives of some 700 Iraqi soldiers pick through shallow graves at military hospital in capital, 1,600 unmarked graves are found in Kirkuk and British find mass grave near Basra; nascent Iraqi leadership jockeys for power under eye of US authority; Muhammad Zobeidi, representative of long-exiled Ahmad Chalabi, declares himself governor of Baghdad, holds news conference at Palestine Hotel and tours city; US military trains Chalabi's 'Iraqi Freedom Fighters' in Mosul; Baghdad streets continue returning to life, although looting continues, including incident in which US troops break up bank robbery; photos, including one of US marines getting haircuts on street (M)

headline: With the War Largely Over, OPEC Fears Oil Price Drop
abstract: OPEC members see need to cut back on extra oil output to keep prices in favored range once renewed supplies flow from Iraq; United States forecasts that Iraqi exports will soon resume because war is largely concluded lead oil traders to anticipate glut; uncertainty about stability of authority in Iraq and amount of oil country will pump make it hard to forecast future oil supplies and prices; photo (M)

headline: Fire at a Russian School Kills 28 Deaf Boys
abstract: Fire at boarding school for deaf in Makhachkala in Russian republic of Dagestan kills 28 boys asleep and unable to hear frantic shouts of adults; at least 106 other boys are injured, 22 critically; this is second major school fire in four days, coming after blaze in Siberia that killed 22 children in gymnasium dressing room; latest disaster leaves average Russians stunned and enraged over perilous state of poorly maintained school buildings; map (M)

headline: Dear Customer, G.M. Says, We've Improved
abstract: General Motors Corp will begin print ad campaign that it says it has improved its product and will ask customer to give it another chance; ads are by McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising; photo (M)

headline: Editor of US Weekly Resigns From Magazine
abstract: Bonnie Fuller, the editor of US Weekly who has raised the celebrity magazine's circulation and profits during her 16-month tenure, resigned today from Wenner Media, the magazine's publisher.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Stockholm: A Market Merger
abstract: OM AB, owner of Sweden's m

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: BRAZIL: Trade Surplus Rises; CANADA: Steel Maker In Bankruptcy; MEXICO: Seed Unit Sold;.

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Bank Results Decline; INDIA: Interest Rate Lowered;.

headline: Text: At the Pentagon
abstract: At a news conference yesterday at the Pentagon, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld and Gen. Richard B. Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, discussed the collapse of Saddam Hussein's government, the remaining resistance in Iraq and other subjects. Following is a transcript from the session as recorded by Federal Document Clearing House Inc.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trade Surplus Rises
abstract: Canada's trade surplus widened to 5.9 billion Canadian dollars ($4.2 billion) in March from 4.8 billion Canadian dollars in February; surplus, which accounts for more than 75 percent of Canada's foreign trade, grew by 16 percent, more than offsetting deficit with rest of world (S)0

headline: European Nations to Buy Airbus Planes in $24 Billion Deal
abstract: The deal comes as a welcome lift for Airbus and its principal shareholder, the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company.

headline: Honors
abstract: American Advertising Federation names Carla Michelotti chairwoman; she succeeds Mark Dacey (S)

headline: War Plan Works, Pentagon Says, but Surprises Abound
abstract: War plans are often said to go out the window when the first shot is fired. But not, it seems, this time.

headline: People
abstract: * Cheryl Van Ooyen is named to new post of senior vice president and creative director for Visa account at BBDO Worldwide; Nicholas Paul is named vice president and management director of Three Sixty-One Degree Events and Sports Marketing; Greg Lucia is named vice president and general manager at Source Marketing branch office; Aaron Adler and Ari Weiss join Saatchi & Saatchi as an art director and copywriter, respectively (S)

headline: As Iraqi Clerics Go Home, Talk of Schism With Shiite Hard-Liners in Iran
abstract: Many Shiite clerics from Iraq who have lived in exile in Iran for many years are planning to return home; their departure from Iran, and revival of Iraq's historically holy city of Najaf, may pose serious threat to rule of hard-line ayatollahs in Iran; Najaf, center of Shiite world for more than 1,300 years, is expected to regain that position when influential clerics return and begin teaching at its seminaries; some high-ranking Iranian clerics who believe in freer religious studies have said they would go to Najaf when stability returns; Iraqi clerics who are returning to Iraq say they are tired of seeing their faith dominated by Iran; photos (M)

headline: Buca, a restaurant chain, doesn't want to be known as one, so it takes a local approach.
abstract: Advertising: Buca, a restaurant chain, doesn't want to be known as one, so it takes a local approac7

headline: A Wayward Youth? No, It Was a Prince of the Realm
abstract: England's Prince William, turning 21, visits Wales, where he is sung chorus of Happy Birthday in Welsh and visits arts center for homeless; William, who has invited friends rather than notables to birthday party at Windsor Castle, apologizes for recent speeding incident on Lord Bathurst's estate in Gloucestershire; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Arrest In Legislator's Killing
abstract: Russian authorities hold Artyom Stefanov as prime suspect in last Thursday's assassination of liberal legislator Sergei N Yushenkov; prosecutors suggest suspect sought revenge for father's imprisonment (S)

headline: AOL Founder Is Said to Be Open to a Spinoff
abstract: Stephen M Case, mastermind of America Online's record-breaking acquisition of Time Warner, has begun to talk favorably of undoing deal by spinning off AOL; Case's opinions may have little effect on AOL Time Warner's future because his waning power at company; his views may even reflect his own frustration with his changing status; Case declines comment; photo (M)

headline: Lagos Journal; Oil, Oil Everywhere, Except at the Gas Pumps
abstract: Severe gasoline shortages in Lagos, Nigeria, which has some of world's most ample oil reserves, speaks loudly about all that ails country; shortages are not new in Nigeria, but immediate cause of current one is murky, like so much tied to politics and money there; conspiracy-minded Nigerians theorize that crisis is contrived to embarrass Pres Olusegun Obasanjo as he seeks re-election to second term; shortage struck right after he reminded country that under his leadership, gas lines had disappeared; state-owned Nigerian National Petroleum Corp blames its foreign suppliers; because Nigeria lacks refining capacity, it must import half the gasoline its citzens need; photo; map (M)

headline: India Pressed on Kashmir Attacks
abstract: Domestic pressure on Indian government to respond to Muslim terrorist attacks in Kashmir increases with massacre of 24 Hindus and reports of militants massing in Pakistan; Min Yaswant Sinha observes that India has 'better case' for pre-emptive strike than US had against Iraq, drawing quick US response emphasizing differences; India also lacks military superiority; Pres Bush and Prime Min Tony Blair, meeting on Iraq, approve joint statement urging cease-fire and calling on Pakistan to discourage militancy (M)

headline: Toll in Saudi Arabia Rises to at Least 20, U.S. Official Says
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the attacks aimed at Westerners have the "fingerprints of Al Qaeda."

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Aid For Economy Urged
abstract: Bank of Japan's governor Toshihiko Fukui says government should take steps to head off financial crisis (S)

headline: Bush Defends the Progress of the War
abstract: President Bush mounted a vigorous defense on Monday of the progress made in the war against Iraq, seeking to rebut concerns in the military.

headline: Eying Postwar Iraq, Chirac to Meet With Putin and Schröder
abstract: President Jacques Chirac suggested that the situation in postwar Iraq would top the agenda at the meeting in St. Petersburg this weekend.

headline: Jordan's King Urges All Sides In Mideast to Press for Peace
abstract: King Abdullah of Jordan appeals to international negotiators to 'stay the course' as continued violence between Palestinians and Israelis threatens Washington's latest drive for peace; remarks are made in Shuneh, Jordan, at unusual session of World Economic Forum; they reflect concern of many in region that newest Middle East peace effort will go way of many others unless main players and their backers show new resolve (M)

headline: EMC Posts Profit but Says Its Customers Remain Wary
abstract: EMC says it returned to profitability in first quarter; revenues rose to $1.38 billion, up 6 percent from first quarter of 2002; net earnings were $35.2 million compared with loss of $76.9 million year ago; chief financial officer Bill Teuber and president-chief executive Joseph M Tucci comment (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: QUALCOMM FACES CHALLENGE ON CHIPS; REGULATORS SEEK E.D.S. PAPERS ON NAVY DEAL;.

headline: Hot Seat's New Occupant at Philadelphia Inquirer
abstract: New Philadelphia Inquirer editor Amanda Bennett faces daunting tasks at newspaper; will be focus of news publishing industry's attention as it tries understanding conundrum of whether good journalism and good business practices are compatible; photo; table of circulation of nation's top weekday papers (M)

headline: 3 Racy Men's Magazines Are Banned by Wal-Mart
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc halts sales of Maxim, Stuff and FHM, men's magazines that feature mix of scantily clad starlets and bawdy humor but go to some lengths to avoid being labeled as pornography; Wal-Mart has been under pressure from Christian groups in past over its distribution of various magazines; spokeswoman Melissa Berryhill comments; Stephen Colvin, president of Dennis Publishing USA, which owns Maxim and Stuff, says Wal-Mart accounts for less than 3 percent of copies company sells at newsstands; Maxim, Stuff and FHM have combined circulation of almost five million; officials at FHM, which is owned by Emap PLC, says Wal-Mart has right to make product decision, but disagrees with decision; photo (M)

headline: Critic of Burmese Junta Not Hurt, Envoy Says
abstract: UN envoy Razali Ismail reports that pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi detained by Myanmar authorities, shows no sign of having been injured in attack on her supporters that killed and injured scores of people; says military junta has promised her release (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Colonel Freed In Activist's Death
abstract: Col Juan Valencia Osorio, former commander of Guatemala's presidential guard, has 30-year sentence for ordering 1990 murder of activist Myrna Mack overturned on appeal and is freed; judge cites contradictions in trial; photo (S)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: Air Transport Association president James C May says airline industry is 'beginning to buckle' from effect of war in Iraq and continuing high-level security alert; domestic advance bookings are down 20 percent compared with year ago; bookings for trans-Atlantic travel are off 40 percent, and have fallen 30 percent for trans-Pacific trips; Travel Industry Association of America estimates show Americans this spring will take 52.6 million business-travel trips over all, down 2.5 percent from last spring and down 13 percent from spring 2001; survey by Customer Respect Group shows Alaska Airlines is best in online booking among airlines while Travelocity comes in first among travel companies; members of United Airlines Mileage Plus frequent-flier program get bonus of 500 miles first time they use EasyCheck-in kiosks that airline is rolling out at its hubs (M)

headline: Briton Awaits Ride Home After Hike to Pole
abstract: Pen Hadow, 41-year-old Briton, waits in tiny tent at North Pole for ride home to Dartmoor after reaching pole on foot and alone in grueling 64-day crossing from Canada's northernmost shore; map; professional guide left Ward Hunt Island, world's northernmost human settlement, March 17, skiing, swimming and finally walking 478 miles on his third such attempt; map (M)

headline: On Gaza's Main Road, a Wary Return to Honks and Hope
abstract: Israel today released direct control of almost all of Gaza's main north-south artery for the first time in 33 months of fighting.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Conviction In Theater Hostage-Taking
abstract: Chechen Zaurbek Talkhigov is convicted and sentenced to eight and half years in prison for telephoning information into rebel-held moscow theater where 800 hostages were held for more than two days in September 2002 (S)

headline: In HBO, AOL Sees a Sibling And, Crucially, A Role Model
abstract: Jonathan Miller, chief executive of America Online division of AOL Time Warner Inc, sees company's cable television channel, HBO, as model for reviving shrinking AOL service; stresses sales of access to panoply of add-on programming and communication tools in search for own counterpart to HBO programming hit; photo (M)

headline: Land-Rich Museums Find New Income Source
abstract: Land-rich outdoor history museums are finding new income sources; Colonial Williamsburg Foundation is building additional 34,000 square feet of shops and offices in its Merchants Square complex; shops bring in annual sales of $500 to $600 per square foot; office building is being developed on grounds of Hagley Museum and Library, industrial history museum in Wilmington, Del; photos (M)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Manhattan; Cooling the Empire State Building on the Cheap
abstract: Consolidated Edison is recommending that some office buildings, including Empire State Building, cut energy costs for air-conditioning by switching between steam and electricity to supply chilled water throughout buildings' air-conditioning system; Empire State Building in August and September 2002 saved $48,000 in air-conditioning costs by using system and could have saved about $200,000 over course of summer if technique was used earlier; Rockefeller Group, which operates four buildings in Manhattan, uses technique in two of its office buildings (M)

headline: WELLS FARGO WINS COURT RULING IN CALIFORNIA DISPUTE
abstract: wells f

headline: LANDLORD TERMINATES WYNDHAM LEASE ON 15 HOTELS
abstract: Hospitality Properties Trust terminates lease on 15 hotels held by Wyndham International Inc after Wyndham fails to pay rent on properties; Hospitality says hotels will be managed by Candlewood Hotel Co (S)

headline: After Cease-Fire Talks Stall, Israelis Kill a Hamas Leader
abstract: Israeli undercover troops in volatile West Bank city of Hebron shoot and kill Abdullah Qawasmeh, senior leader of Hamas movement who was suspected of organizing several recent suicide bombings; Israeli operation comes day after Secretary of State Colin L Powell meets with Israeli and Palestinian leaders in attempt to conclude cease-fire agreement that has been under negotiation for weeks; Palestinian witnesses and journalists in Hebron say Israeli troops made no attempt to detain Qawasmeh; such Israeli operations are central issue in current efforts to negotiate ceasefire in Middle East; Israel says it will continue to track down Palestinian militants for arrest and to kill those suspected of planning or carrying out violence; says it will stop only when Palestinian security forces begin to act against militant groups; photo (M)

headline: Coca-Cola is taking lines from a classic in its campaign to stimulate a thirst for Diet Coke.
abstract: Coca-Cola Co resumes advertising for Diet Coke with energetic, playfully sexy campaign that seeks to associate brand with youthful joie de vivre; three commericals in campaign, by Foote, Cone & Belding, reintepret Diet Coke theme 'Do what feels good'; spots, to run on TBS and TNT cable networks, are first work from Foote, Cone since being awarded domestic Diet Coke creative assignment, with billings estimated at $40 million, in late December; photo (M)

headline: In a Muslim City in Iraq, a Christian Group Enjoys Its Lively Quarter
abstract: Ankawa neighborhood in Erbil, Iraq, is home to small but lively community of Assyro-Chaldeans, or Assyrian Christians, one of Iraq's smallest, and proudest, ethnic groups; steady stream of slowly cruising cars flows past on main thoroughfare, with young men sitting low behind steering wheel of their cars; women walk arm in arm; liquor stores abound; Ankawa stands in lively contrast to rest of Erbil, Kurdish Muslim city where alcohol is not for sale and most women wear head covering; photo (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Some Web sites are taking their brands from the Internet into some very offline spheres.
abstract: INTERNET companies are starting to think outside the monitor.    Sensing that invaluable exposure and millions of dollars in potential revenue await them offline, online retailers and media companies are finding creative ways to use their brands and expertise beyond the Internet -- whether by producing television shows, forging offline alliances or selling goods wholesale to traditional merchants.

headline: Rice Urges European Union to Classify Hamas as Terrorist
abstract: Pres Bush's national security adviser Condoleezza Rice, in London, says political wing of militant Palestinian group Hamas should be added to European Union's list of terrorist organizations; calls group single biggest threat to peace between Israel and Palestinians; says Europe should join United States in persuading Arab nations to stop supporting Hamas's political arm, which claims money it raises is for charitable causes; US already lists political and military wings of Hamas as terrorist organizations, while EU regards only latter as terrorist group; Rice argues that there should be no distinction; her remarks come on eve of her new role as Bush's 'personal representative' to peace talks in Middle East (M)

headline: Bush Under Fire in Congress for Criticizing Israel
abstract: On a day of new attacks and counterattacks, there was concern in the Bush administration that the peace plan known as the road map could founder.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Dalai Lama's Envoys Arrive For Talks
abstract: Lodi Gyari and Kelsang Gyaltsen, senior envoys representing exiled Dalai Lama, arrive in Beijing for talks with Chinese government for second time in nine months; meetings are first effort between Dalai Lama and Chinese government to address Tibetan concerns in past ten years (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Lower Film Outlook
abstract: Worldo

headline: Under Blizzard of Bullets, a Battle Inches On
abstract: Roads from Najaf toward Baghdad are littered with hulks of pickup trucks and taxicabs that once carried members of paramilitary forces loyal to Pres Saddam Hussein; their bodies are sprawled on ground nearby, shot by American forces; swath of Iraqi countryside along Euphrates River, 60 miles from Baghdad, is all but devoid of ordinary life as American troops hunt down Iraqi soldiers and guerrillas in relentless show of force; American forces are advancing northward, even as battle for Najaf, 85 miles south of Baghdad, is not yet over; Najaf sits along major supply route needed by American and British troops headed to Baghdad; some American officers feel its capture would send message to other Shiite cities that Hussein's government is doomed; fear and uncertainty among Shiite community appears to be leading them to more cautious approach than was expected by United States; Shiites suffered heavily in 1991 when they rebelled against Hussein and US left them to their fate; photo (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose after a government report showed United States payrolls fell less than economists expected last month. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1704, down from $1.1843 on Thursday.

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: Online Diary column; several online discussion groups devoted to Harry Potter books will shut down temporarily when new book Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix is released to give people opportunity to read it; photo blog Hello Natalie is based on photographs found by couple in Brooklyn thrift site; visitors are invited to create life for her; list lovers will enjoy listsofbests.com, site that collects best-of lists and award winners for movies, books and music; other miscellaneous sites noted; drawings (M)

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: Annan Implores Europeans to Forge Pact on Rebuilding Iraq
abstract: European Union leaders issued a joint statement today calling for a "central role" for the U.N. in the future of Iraq.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Northwest Airlines Invokes Emergency Layoff Clause  Citing a decline in Asian traffic because of the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, Northwest Airlines has invoked an emergency clause in its labor contracts that lets it lay off employees without notice.    Northwest is the first airline to invoke the clause in response to the outbreak of the respiratory illness. [Page C4.]

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: I Want My Rebate.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SOUTHERN UNION, Wilkes-Barre, Pa., had its $1.8 billion purchase of Panhandle Eastern Pipeline, part of CMS Energy, approved by the Federal Trade Commission after Southern Union agreed to concessions to ensure competition for the delivery of natural gas to Kansas City, Mo.    VISX, Santa Clara, Calif., the biggest maker of lasers used to correct vision, said the financier Carl C. Icahn had sold his 6.02 million shares in the company to Goldman Sachs, New York, for $17.60 a share. Goldman then sold 3.5 million of the shares to Visx.

headline: 3 E-Mail Giants Will Join In an Effort to Reduce Spam
abstract: America Online, Microsoft and Yahoo, three leading providers of e-mail accounts, report working together to develop ways to reduce unwanted commercial messages, known as 'spam,' that are increasingly clogging their customers' mailboxes; efforts focus on improving methods of establishing actual name and address of senders of e-mails (M)

headline: Iranian Leader Visits Beirut In Show of Shiite Solidarity
abstract: Pres Mohammad Khatami of Iran arrives in Beirut to glowing embrace from Lebanese government and tens of thousands of chanting and cheering Lebanese Shiites; his visit is first by Iranian president since 1979 Islamic revolution; it represents major diplomatic reaction in Islam to United States military action in Iraq; US, which considers Iran leading state sponsor of terrorism, has demanded that Iran stop supporting militant groups like Hezbollah, which is based in Lebanon; Iran and US are thought to be moving toward new phase in their often hostile relationship; Bush administration officials confirm that two countries have been having secret contacts; Khatami will move on to Syria after three-day visit in Lebanon; photo (M)

headline: Museum Pillage Described as Devastating but Not Total
abstract: Donny George, official with Iraqi Board of Antiquities, assesses losses at National Museum of Iraq; says part of collection had been stored or removed prior to war; still, experts believe looting that took place for two days after fall of Saddam Hussein's government may be irrecoverable loss for Islamic cultural heritage; British Museum will send experts to help assess losses; Dr Philippe de Montebello, director of New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, is gaining wide support for proposals that museum looters be offered immunity from prosecution and some compensation if they return what they took; photos (M)

headline: Cuban Dissidents Get Prison Terms as Long as 27 Years
abstract: Cuban courts begin handing out prison terms of up to 27 years to dozens of dissidents, including journalists and libertarians, who have advocated democratic reforms (S)

headline: Bush Aide Meets With Putin in Mission to Repair Ties
abstract: President Bush's national security adviser met with President Vladimir V. Putin and his top aides here today in what a senior American diplomat later called a mission to repair relations badly bruised by divisions over the war in Iraq.

headline: With Peacemakers on Way, Israel Attacks Hamas Again
abstract: Israel presses campaign against Hamas, delivering two missile strikes in Gaza on day before American monitors, Assistant Sec of State John S Wolf, David F Satterfield and unnamned NSC official, are to arrive to prop up new peace plan, which has been badly weakened in week of violence; first assault kills one member of Hamas and injures 22 Palestinians, almost all civilians; second attack hits munitions warehouse located near home of Sheik Ahmed Yassin, spiritual leader of Hamas; events mark fourth straight day that Israeli helicopters target Hamas activists; photos (M)

headline: Former Chief's Protégé Puts His Estate on the Block
abstract: HealthSouth Corp's former chief operating officer Larry House puts his Selby County, Ala, home up for auction; Great Gatsbys, auction house in Atlanta, which is handling sale, estimates value of property and antiques at $27 million, but doubts auction will fetch anywhere near amount; photo (M)

headline: Breaking Monopoly On Excuses
abstract: Humorous article on ways people can recycle for own purposes excuses offered by companies forced to restate earnings because of accounting errors or frauds; drawing (M)2

headline: Changes Requested in Ads for Youths
abstract: Changes Requested In Ads for Youths Activists are pressing for change on two youth-related issues, one involving alcohol advertising on the radio and the other involving marketing of snack foods in schools.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Russian Oil Producers Said to Be Close to Deal  The owners of Russia's largest oil company, Yukos, and the country's No. 5 producer, Sibneft, are close to a deal on a merger, people briefed on the talks said.    If completed, the combination would create one of the world's largest oil companies. It would produce 2.16 million barrels of oil a day, more than the world's fourth-largest publicly held oil company, ChevronTexaco. [Page C2.]    Offer Discussed for Chubb of Britain  United Technologies is in discussions to buy Chubb, a British security systems company, for more than $1.3 billion. [C2.]

headline: BUSH SAYS REGIME IN IRAQ IS NO MORE; SYRIA IS PENALIZED
abstract: Pres Bush declares that regime of Saddam Hussein is no more; administration uses America's rapid success in overthrowing Iraqi dictator to put new pressure on Iran and Syria; Bush says final victory will not be declared until Gen Tommy R Franks, senior commander in war theater, determines that all US military objectives have been met--process that could take months; Pentagon makes arrangements to halt deployment to Iraq of 24,000 troops from Fort Hood, Tex, except for 700 military police and civil affairs specialists; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says US is moving to cut off important oil pipeline running from Iraq into Syria, first major economic penalty against Syria; Sec of State Colin L Powell says US has no plans to make war against Iran and Syria 'right now'; Bush takes telephone call from Pres Jacques Chirac of France, first time two leaders have had extensive conversation since their public breach over France's refusal to back American military action in Iraq; White House says Chirac joined Bush in urging Syria not to harbor former Iraqi leaders (M)

headline: Drop in Foreign Investment Is Greasing Dollar's Slide
abstract: US dollar continues to slide against euro and yen, as new data indicate that foreign appetite for US stocks and bonds is slowing; Treasury Department data show US stocks and bonds by foreigners slowed to $23.8 billion February, third consecutive monthly decline in foreign purchases; euro is valued at $1.1280, up from $1.1231 in New York trading; US dollar trades at 118.63 yen, down from 118.93; graphs (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Bank Indicted
abstract: World Business Briefi

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Telecom Unit Sold
abstract: World Bu

headline: French Threaten Expulsions After Muslim Militants Win
abstract: Union of Islamic Organizations in France, fundamentalist group, unexpectedly wins large number of seats in election for country's first national council of Muslims, prompting Interior Min Nicolas Sarkozy to threaten to expel any Muslim religious leader considered extremist; Sarkozy, who pressed for creation of council, says it will not be used to spread views that run counter to French values, particularly promotion of Islamic law (M)

headline: Prominent Programmer Will Leave Transmeta
abstract: Linus Torvalds, leader of shared software movement, is leaving job with Transmeta, struggling chip maker, to join Open Source Development Lab, nonprofit consortium developing Linux operating system for corporations; has been instrumental in development of freely shared Linus operating system; says he wants to concentrate all his efforts on new version of Linux; Transmeta, early Linux backer, will join consortium (M)

headline: Even With Glut, Shrimp Farmers Want Still More and Others Balk
abstract: Asian shrimp farmers are seeing prices collapse; industry faces criticism from environmentalists for clearing forest and destroying wetlands, and American fishermen accuse Asian producers of illegally dumping shrimp below cost; industry response to glut is prediction that with modern production methods and costs falling, shrimp consumption will soar; optimism is tempered by diseases that have invaded ponds in some areas; Bangkok-based Charoen Pokphand Group's shrimp exports plummeted 25 percent last year; wholesale prices are down nearly 50 percent over past few years, to about $5 per pound; Charoen Pokphand is marketing ready-to-eat shrimp dishes and strengthening its more profitable shrimp feed business; photos (M)

headline: HYDRAULIC EQUIPMENT MAKER TO CUT JOBS AT 5 PLANTS
abstract: Eaton Corp, leading maker of hydraulic equipment, will consolidate five plants and cut unspecified number of jobs (S)4

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Ex-Prime Minister Cleared
abstract: Brian Mulroney, Canadian Prime Minister from 1984 to 1993, is cleared of allegations that he profited from Airbus Industrie purchase of jets from then publicly owned Air Canada; exoneration ends eight-year investigation by Royal Canadian Mounted Police; photo (S)

headline: Survival Of Hussein Still Doubted
abstract: Two videotapes of Saddam Hussein are broadcast on Iraqi television, but American intelligence officials say they still lack conclusive proof that Saddam Hussein is still alive (S)

headline: EarthLink Is Sued by Holder of Anti-Spam Patents
abstract: MailBlocks sues EarthLink saying EarthLink's latest technology to block unwanted e-mail marketing, or spam, violates two of its patents; MailBlocks introduced e-mail service in March that shows users mail only from senders whom they approve or who can show that they are people and not automated senders; MailBlocks was started by Phillip Y Goldman; MailBlocks was granted two patents related to its method of verifying senders, technology called challenge response; company charges $9.95 per year for service; EarthLink has said it will offer its customers free challenge-response system, under name SpamB-locker, at end of May; several other companies are starting to officer similar approaches (M)

headline: British Give Port Control To the Iraqis
abstract: British military hands over major Iraqi port of Umm Qasr to local administrators in symbolic transfer of power intended to show that Iraqis are beginning to take control of major elements of their country; British military prepares to scale back its personnel at port, which is chief gateway for aid agencies bringing supplies into country; new Iraqi Port Authority for Umm Qasr will remain under oversight of American and British administrators now running country (M)

headline: Japanese Pastor Reaches Out With Suicide Line
abstract: Profile of Rev Yukio Saito, Japanese Methodist minister who started Lifeline, suicide hot line, in 1971; through his efforts, it has expanded from single telephone bank to network of 50 call-in centers around Japan, most operating 24 hours a day, and employing more than 7,000 volunteers; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Squeezes Baghdad and Readies Next Step
abstract: United States troops begin gradual encirclement of Baghdad, apparently as part of effort to isolate capital; American tanks reportedly move into city, rolling virtually unopposed along both Tigris and Euphrates; kill hundreds of Iraqis who fire small arms at passing tank columns; it is unclear what has become of Republican Guard divisions that formed what Iraqi government called 'ring of steel' around city; military officials say two of six Guard units were mostly destroyed by allied bombing and artillery; Col Joe Dowdy, First Marine Regiment commander, is summarily relieved of his command; Army infantry division digs in at Baghdad airport; suicide bomber kills three American Special Operations troops near Haditha Dam, which had been captured to prevent Iraqis from blowing it up to disrupt American advance along Euphrates; map; photo (M)

headline: Thriving Kurdish Trade in Fake Passports Slumps as Fewer Choose to Flee the Region
abstract: Smugglers and forgers in Sulaimaniya and other locations in Kurdish-controlled zone of Iraq who used to trade in fake passports are seeing precipitous drop in business as fewer people choose to leave; map; photos (M)

headline: Appetite for War Films Seems Less Hearty
abstract: Hollywood wonders how much Iraq invasion has dimmed public appetite for combat movies, noting that nearly every military-related film to reach theaters this year has been box-office disappointment, including Tears of the Sun, The Hunted and Basic; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Letter To Millions
abstract: French Prime Min Jean-Pierre Raffarin will send letter to all households explaining reasons for pension system overhaul that has provokes wave of strikes (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Construction Spending -- May

headline: Real Estate Industry May Have to Report Suspected Cash Laundering
abstract: Federal government recently served notice on real estate industry that it might soon have to start taking more active role in ferreting out money laundering; USA Patriot Act, signed into law in October 2001, requires wide variety of financial institutions to establish programs to make them more vigilant in detecting and reporting suspicious activity; Treasury Department's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network has sought opinions as to how terrorists and other criminals could be prevented from buying real estate with money that comes from--or is intended to support--illegal activity; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; An Apparent Heir at Xerox
abstract: URSULA M. BURNS doesn't play golf. She doesn't belong to the local country club. Small talk is not her strong suit. And she insists on being home on weekends.    She sounds like an unlikely climber on the Xerox corporate ladder. But up she is going, rung by rung. Since she joined the company two decades ago, Ms. Burns has moved through engineering, manufacturing, various product divisions and a senior vice presidency.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDIA: Hindu Hard-Liner Held; MYANMAR: Harassment Of Dissident Claimed;.

headline: The Last Battle
abstract: As the Americans begin to commit "suicide before the walls of Baghdad," Abu Mush' Republic Guard company is engaged in early morning exercises 180 kilometers north of the Iraqi capital. It is 7:30 a.m. on April 6, and the troops are assembled on the parade grounds of the main barracks at Tikrit, Saddam's and Saladin's home town. The city, built on a flat plain that stretches to the horizon, appears small under a vast sky.

headline: Customer Care, Online
abstract: Customer Respect Group reports that nation's 100 largest companies improved their online customer communication slightly in last year; graph (S)

headline: Rip! Zap! Ding! It's a Classic 6-Minute Pot Roast
abstract: Food companies aÿ

headline: Private Sector; A Good Week for a Hip-Hop Impresario
abstract: Russell Simmons will receive Montblanc Arts Patronage Award (S)

headline: Text of British Prime Minister Tony Blair's Speech on Iraqi TV
abstract: This is the text of a televised message aired on Thursday in Iraq:
