headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Economy Shrinks
abstract: Bank of Korea says South Korea's gross domestic product fell seasonally adjusted 0.4 percent in first quarter from previous quarter, as consumer spending slumped; says spread of SARS in Asia might cause second quarter of contraction (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Google Hiring Engineers For a New York Office
abstract: Google Inc, Internet company, is hiring some 100 engineers for its New York office; senior research scientist Craig Nevill-Manning says he seeks advanced programmers who will be free to develop own projects, interview (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Parliament Backs Reforms
abstract: Turkish Parliament approves series of human rights measures, largely in relation to its Kurdish population, in effort to promote membership in European Union (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: GEAC TO BUY COMSHARE FOR $52 MILLION; VIGNETTE NAMES CHAIRMAN; MICROSOFT INTRODUCES SOFTWARE FOR MOBILE DEVICES;.

headline: Award for Times Reporter
abstract: Elisabeth Rosenthal, Beijing correspondent of New York Times, wins first Osborn Elliott Prize for Excellence in Asian Journalism for her reporting on spread of AIDS in China (S)

headline: In Far East of Many Muslims, Press Is Anti-U.S. but Hardly Pro-Jihad
abstract: Press in Muslim Far East, notably Indonesia and Malaysia, is critical of America's war in Iraq, but without intensity and religious fervor of Arab press in Middle East; tone is much the same in Philippines, nation with close American ties and significant Muslim minority (M)

headline: Business; In a Dull Economy, Avon Finds a Hidden Gloss
abstract: in a dull econom

headline: DoCoMo Is Back, Leading Japan's Cellphone Market
abstract: Japan's NTT DoCoMo, which is due to report earnings on April 8, has written off bulk of its overseas losses, released many new products and finished building most of its new mobile phone network, known as FOMA; president Keiji Tachikawa has steered company back to being dominant cellphone company in Japan; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HEWLETT-PACKARD CO., Palo Alto, Calif., won a seven-year, $600 million contract to run information systems for Bank of Ireland, Dublin.    BLACKROCK, New York, a manager of fixed-income funds for institutional investors, bought a majority stake in HPB Management to bolster its hedge fund offerings.

headline: China Admits Much Higher Number of SARS Cases
abstract: The Chinese government's rare, blunt and very public admission of failure if not deception came as it fired the health minister and the mayor of Beijing.

headline: The 'Matrix' Invented: A World of Special Effects
abstract: The 2,500-acre Alameda Naval Air Station, home to four aircraft carriers in World War II, was abandoned by the Pentagon in 1997. Yet military adventures continue to be planned on these desolate, weed-infested grounds overlooking San Francisco Bay.    Tucked away among the buildings and monumental empty hangars, hundreds of scientists, engineers and graphic artists map out computer-generated battles by Neo and Morpheus, characters played by Keanu Reeves and Laurence Fishburne in ''The Matrix Reloaded.''

headline: NORDSTROM FIRST-QUARTER PROFIT WAS BELOW FORECAST
abstract: Nordstrom Inc says first-quarter profit was 12 cents to 15 cents per share, less than forecast; will report full results on May 19 (S)

headline: HOMETOWN AMERICA IS BUYING CHATEAU FOR $1 BILLION
abstract: Hometown America acquires rival Chateau Communities, largest owner of prefabricated-housing developments, for $1 billion, topping earlier offer from financier Sam Zell's Manufactured Home Communities (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Dept of Defense releases latest list of confirmed deaths of Americans in Iraq (S)

headline: William Gunn, 89; Fostered Wool Symbol
abstract: Sir William Gunn, Australian sheep farmer who spurred wool boom and devised Woolmark symbol, dies at age 89 (S)

headline: International security overshadows economic development : U.S. agenda dominates G-8 talks
abstract: EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France:—  In this spa town sandwiched between snow-covered Alps and placid Lake Geneva, President Jacques Chirac of France, host to the Group of Eight summit meeting, managed to win reconciliation with his nemesis over the Iraq war, President George W. Bush.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDIA: Bus Service To Pakistan To Resume; CHINA: Dalai Lama'S Envoys Arrive For Talks;.

headline: Credit Card Deal Has Initial Approval
abstract: Federal Judge John Gleeson gives MasterCard International Inc and Visa International Inc preliminary approval for $3 billion accord to settle suit by retailers over debit card fees (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Department Store Bid
abstract: Worldo

headline: French Police in Crackdown on Iranian Opposition Group
abstract: French authorities today arrested more than 150 members of a long-established armed Iranian opposition group.

headline: Protesters On the Move, Geneva Shops Board Up
abstract: Luxury shops in downtown Geneva are boarded up in anticipation of possible violence surrounding Group of 8 summit meeting that is set to open in Evian, on French side of Lake Geneva; there have already been isolated incidents of vandalism and skirmishes with police on both sides of border; photo (M)

headline: Executive Life; Portraitist in the Court Of Corporate Kings
abstract: Interview wit

headline: Discovering Doubt and Death On Drive Toward Baghdad
abstract: Steven Lee Myers describes drive by Army's Third Infantry Division from Kuwait to Baghdad's international airport; says that after getting to escarpment north of Najaf in only three days, division spent unanticipated nine days there -- days of numbing tedium, growing frustration, rising fear and mounting casualties -- before renewed advance brought it to Baghdad's international airport; photos (L)

headline: With a Brand Faltering, Prada Designer Returns
abstract: Designer Jil Sander has agreed to six-year contract to return to Prada, Italian maker of luxury goods that acquired her house, Jil Sander AG, in 1999; Sander resigned when relations with Prada soured just months after acquisition, and the brand that bears her name has been unprofitable since 2001; Sander comments; photo (M)

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: U.S.-Led Talks in Iraq End With Pledge to Meet Again in 10 Days
abstract: Iraqi exile leaders, tribal sheiks, ethnic Kurds and Shiite clerics said they would work to create a fully democratic government in Iraq.

headline: Political Foes Of Berlusconi See Red Flag In an Exam
abstract: Political foes of Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi see bias in graduation exams taken by hunrdreds of thousands of Italian high school seniors, saying exam questions and themes appear to emphasize horrors of Communism more than evils of fascism; specter of Communism has long dominated discourse of Berlusconi, who casts himself as Italy's last line of defense against tenacious scourge (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Anger At Broadcast
abstract: Spanish Deputy Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy expresses government's anger over video of ETA, Basque separatist group, in which three hooded members urge viewers to vote for outlawed candidates; video was aired on Basque public television station Euskal Irrati Telebista and is under investigation by state prosecutor (S)

headline: Citigroup Stock Option Dealings
abstract: Citigroup says chairman Sanford I Weill earned $4.3 million by exercising options on 561,760 shares of company two days ago; Weill's gain is almost half of $9.5 million he and group of Citigroup executives earned by exercising options on June 17; other executives include Michael A Carpenter, William R Rhodes and Robert B Willumstad; Weill's stake in Citigroup rose by 58,519 shares to 22.4 million shares exercising options (M)

headline: Syria Calls for Peace Talks, but Israel Voices Skepticism
abstract: Responding to a Syrian call to revive peace talks, Israel said today that it was skeptical of the offer but would be willing to meet as long as Israel was not required to make concessions in advance.

headline: Israel and Arafat Frustrate the New Palestinian Premier
abstract: Palestinian Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas has opponents and doubters on all sides after only three weeks in office; is having hard time being heard and harder time becoming popular; on day of his meeting with Prime Min Ariel Sharon, Palestinian suicide bombers embark on five-attack spree, undercutting his demand that Israel accept new peace plan; his meeting with political leaders of Hamas ends with Hamas members reportedly refusing his request to stop suicide bombings or other violence; Yasir Arafat, who reluctantly appointed him under international pressure, has not rushed to support him, and Palestinian television, controlled by Arafat, has shown little interest in covering his activities; map (M)

headline: Israel Presses Its Assault on Hamas, Killing Leader in Gaza
abstract: The toll from the Israeli attack in Gaza today also included the Hamas militant's wife, 3-year-old daughter and four others.

headline: Oakley Profit Down 42%
abstract: Sunglasses maker Oakley Inc says first-quarter earnings declined 42 percent; net income fell to $3.21 million from $5.56 million year earlier; sales rose 1.5 percent, to $111.2 million from $109.6 million (S)

headline: PRUDENTIAL SELLING TWO INSURANCE UNITS
abstract: Prudential Financial Inc sells its auto and homeowners' insurance businesses to Liberty Mutual Insurance Group and Palisades Safety and Insurance Assocition for $673 million; Palisades is buying Prudential's New Jersey business for $260 million; Liberty Mutual is buying operations in 47 other states and District of Columbia for $413 million in notes (S)

headline: Under Low-Key British Rule, Basra Shows Signs of Coming Back to Life
abstract: British hope Basra will be viewed as model for how to win the peace and get on with business of rebuilding Iraq; when they entered city on Apr 6, they were greeted with mass lawlessness, widespread looting and armed gunmen roaming streets; those early days of chaos created impression among population that British are struggling to counter; they are trying to maintain low profile whenever possible, wearing berets instead of helmets and not setting up checkpoints; strategy is meant to foster climate of trust, counter image of soldiers as occupiers and encourage Iraqis to take over important tasks themselves; they have had mixed results so far; photo (M)

headline: Mixed Views In Pakistan On Amount Of U.S. Aid
abstract: American pledge of $3 billion in aid elicits mixed reaction in Pakistan, reflecting political opposition to Pres Pervez Musharraf and popular view that America should do more; military and economic aid is to be spread out over five years; Islamist parties, which oppose Musharraf's changes to Constitution and his continued role as both military chief and president, hold aid is inadequate and even insulting in view of Pakistan's support of war on terrorism; even Prime Min Zafarullah Khan Jamali, who is loyal to Musharraf, says expectations had been raised about getting $6 billion in aid, plus some debt forgiveness (M)

headline: Bond Sale Schedule For Coming Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and a sale of a two-day cash management bill today and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.08 percent, the rate on the six-month issue was 1.06 percent and the rate on the four-week bill was at 1.14 percent.

headline: European Central Bank Cuts Interest Rate
abstract: Answering the pleas of desperate European exporters and nervous public officials, the European Central Bank today cut its benchmark interest rate by a half point.

headline: Optimism Up; Retail Sales Also Increase
abstract: Commerce Department reports retail sales rose 2.1 percent, Mar, after falling 1.3 percent in Feb; University of Michigan's preliminary index of consumer sentiment jumps to 83.2 from nine-year low of 77.6 in Mar; Labor Department reports producer prices rose 1.5 percent, Mar; graphs of retail sales and producer prices (M)

headline: Hazardous Waste Is Shipped From India to U.S. Recycling Plant
abstract: Hindustan Lever Ltd, Unilever subsidiary, is shipping to United States for recycling about 300 tons of mercury-contaminated material and waste from its closed thermometer plant in Kodaikanal, India; Greenpeace activists, who joined local environmentalist in drive that led to plant's 2001 closing, are closely monitoring hazardous cargo, which is headed to Bethlehem Apparatus Co, Hellertown, Pa, world's largest mercury recycling facility (M)

headline: BAR CODE COMPANY CUTS JOBS AND WARNS ON EARNINGS
abstract: Paxar Corp, maker of bar code printers and labels, is cutting 120 jobs, or 4 percent of its work force in US, and expects first-quarter profit to be lower than forecast (S)

headline: Czech Republic Pays $355 Million to Media Concern
abstract: Czech Republic pays $355 million arbitration award to Central European Media Enterprises, company founded by American cosmetics heir Ronald Lauder, for failing to protect company when its Czech partner squeezed it out of Czech TV station Televize Nova; company, known as CME, was operating partner in Televize Nova; three-judge international arbitration panel ruled in March that Czech broadcast regulators conspired with Czech partner Vladimir Zelezny to wrest control of Televize Nova away from CME and that government owed company compensation; CME chief executive Fred Klinkhammer comments (M)

headline: Iraqi Shiite Group Criticizes U.S. Civilian Administrator
abstract: The group said the administrator, L. Paul Bremer III, has failed to support the rapid creation of an Iraqi-led interim government.

abstract: Adver

headline: Grim Scene for G.I.'s Raiding Iraqi Base
abstract: It took an anti-tank missile to blow a hole through the steel-reinforced wall surrounding the Special Republican Guard's headquarters at the foot of this hill overlooking the capital.

headline: Blair Challenges I.R.A. to End Violence
abstract: The British prime minister said Irish Republican Army's refusal to make a clean break with its violent past was the sole remaining obstacle to a lasting peace in Northern Ireland.

headline: Dell Names Agencies For Marketing
abstract: Dell Computer Corp selects Haggin Marketing, Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos and T3 to handle various direct-marketing duties on its account (S)

headline: Army Defends Soldiers Who Killed Civilians at Checkpoint
abstract: The Army defended the soldiers who opened fire on a vehicle at a checkpoint on Monday, killing at least seven civilians.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Posts Net Loss
abstract: National Semiconductor Corp posts second consecutive quarterly loss as sales increase at slowest pace in more than year; net loss put at $4.4 million, or 2 cents a share, in fourth quarter ended May 25 (S)

headline: Russia-Japan Natural Gas Project Advances
abstract: Oil and gas alliance led by Royal Dutch/Shell Group signs contract for more than $2 billion with Russian-Japanese alliance, clearing way for construction to begin on Russia's first liquified natural gas plant; plant is part of project that will supply Asia Pacific region with Russian gas; World Gas Conferce, Tokyo, draws attention to untapped energy resources of Sakhalin, island just north of Japan; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Climate Rises
abstract: Ifo Institute's survey says Germany's overall business index rose to 88.8 in June from 87.6 in May (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank's Profit Falls
abstract: Korea First Bank, 51 percent owned by Newbridge Capital, reports first-quarter net profit of 12.4 billion won ($10.4 million), down from 26.8 billion won in year-earlier period (S)

headline: In Hometown, Hussein's Glory Is Quickly Gone
abstract: Pres Saddam Hussein's grandest palace, in Tikrit, shows signs of hurried exit; fierce resistance anticipated there quickly gives way to empty streets; American officers set up command post amid mansions and monuments and artificial lakes that Hussein presumably enjoyed only weeks ago; marines spend much of day finishing off their enemies and wondering where rest of them have gone; people of Tikrit take their first steps into new world without man who loomed over them for so long, in city that is inextricably bound up with his vanity, his ambitions and his ability to reward and to punish; looters take carpets, paintings and gilded chairs from Hussein's palace; American military officials say estimated 2,500 Iraqi soldiers in Tikrit have vanished; three men dressed in street clothes identify themselves as members of Republican Guard who took off their uniforms and came home rather than face certain death from American bombs; claim hundreds of Republican Guard soldiers are wandering streets of Tikrit; photo (L)

headline: Economic Scene; Do workers really make hay while the sun shines, or just clock out sooner?
abstract: Alan B Krueger Economic Scene column on conflicting results of studies to determine whether people will work more if their take-home pay rate rises, core tenet of supply-side economics; says there is little reason to believe that recently enacted tax cuts will increase work effort if they are preceived as permanent; photo (M)

headline: BAUSCH & LOMB TO MAKE GENERIC FORM OF GLAUCOMA DRUG
abstract: Bausch & Lomb wins Food and Drug Administration approval to manufacture generic form of glaucoma treatment Alphagan; says it has received approval to market generic drug exclusively until Sept 20; Alphagan is made by Allergan (S)

headline: Stock Offering Scheduled
abstract: The following equity offerings are expected this week:      Martek Biosciences Corp., Columbia, Md., 2.815 million shares. Citigroup Global Markets.    Source: MCM EquityWatch

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: MEXICO: Delinquent Telecom Debt; CANADA: Interest Rate Unchanged; CANADA: Nickel Mine Strike;.

headline: Stocks Are Looking Up. Bonds Look Askance.
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column on conflicting signals being given by rising stock prices, which indicate imminent economic rebound, and collapsing bond yields, which suggest economy is unlikely to improve soon; notes bond market has prove superior indicator; graph of bankruptcy filings (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Economic Aid Plan
abstract: Malaysia cuts its benchmark interest rate by half point, to record 4.5 percent, and announces 7.3 billion ringgit ($1.92 billion) plan for loans and spending to help businesses stalled by SARS outbreak and slowing exports; Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad says workers' contributions to state pensions will be cut to 9 percent from 11 percent of wages, service taxes will be waived for hotels and restaurants, and fund for small businesses will be set up (S)

headline: Aid to Airlines From Europe Is Unlikely
abstract: Association of European Airlines says its members' passenger traffic fell 12 percent on international routes during first week of war in Iraq; estimates conflict in Iraq could add $2.5 billion to their combined losses; financial aid to European carriers is unlikely; KLM says it will lay off several thousand of its 33,000 employees and reduce capacity by 20 percent on routes to US and Middle East and 5 percent within Europe; Lufthansa is talking to its unions about reducing flight attendants' work hours and pay; British Airways will lay off 3,000 workers; Air France plans to cut capacity by 7 percent and has put off buying seven aircraft (M)

headline: CENDANT HIRES FINANCIAL OFFICER FROM DREAMWORKS
abstract: Cï

headline: U.S. Is Now in Battle for Peace After Winning the War in Iraq
abstract: American troops, having won war in Iraq, are straining to manage anger, frustration and competing ambitions of nation long suppressed by Saddam Hussein; new politicial parties, Kurds and Shiite religious groups are asserting virtual governmental authority in cities and villages across nation, sometimes under noses of American soldiers; educated Iraqis eager for American-led transformation fear Americans may be losing initiative; anti-American sentiment remains palpable; photos (M

headline: Top 4 Japan Banks Lost $31 Billion Last Year
abstract: Japan's largest banking companies--Mizuho Financial Group, Mitsui Financial Group, Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group and UFJ Holdings--report combined loss of 3.6 trillion yen, almost $31 billion, for last fiscal year, 28 percent increase, as stock prices declined and stricter accounting methods resulted in more bad loans; Mizuho Financial lost record 2.38 trillion yen, or about $20.3 billion; Sumitomo Mitsui, Mitsubishi Tokyo and UFJ wrote off combined 4.5 trillion yen, or $38.5 billion, in non performing loans; photo (M)

headline: DIAGEO NAMES CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF NORTH AMERICAN UNIT
abstract: Diageo, wine and spirits company, names Ivan Menezes president and chief executive of its North American division to succeed Paul Clinton (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil drops on speculation that return of Iraqi oil to world market will quell concern that inventories are too low; crude oil for July delivery falls 77 cents, or 2.6 percent, to $28.58 per barrel in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Earnings at 3M Are Up 11%
abstract: 3M, the maker of Scotch tape, fiber optic cable and thousands of other products, said yesterday that its first-quarter sales and profit rose 11 percent, helped by a drop in the exchange value of the dollar.    Net income rose to $502 million, or $1.27 a share, from $452 million, or $1.14 a share, in the period a year earlier, the company said. Revenue rose to $4.32 billion from $3.89 billion.

headline: As Qualcomm Plots Future, C.E.O.'s Son Awaits Role
abstract: Paul E Jacobs is considered by many inside Qualcomm and by some outside it to be strong candidate to succeed father Irwin Jacobs as chief executive; younger Jacobs, 40, is generally favorably regarded by board and Wall Street as innovative engineer, but corporate governance watchdogs are often skeptical when successsion turns into family affair; photos; graphs shows gains in market share for CDMA, wireless phone technology Qualcomm developed and wideband version, W-CDMA (M)

headline: U.S. Officials Worried Saudi Attacks Could Be First in Series
abstract: As a team of American investigators landed in Saudi Arabia today, officials said that the bombing attacks of Monday night could be the first in a series of such attacks in Saudi Arabia and the region.

headline: China's Workers Risk Limbs in Export Drive
abstract: Yongkang, China, has 7,000 metal-working factories--all privately owned--that make many items with metallic innards; these goods are exported around world; many of rudimentary machines in Yongkang's factories lack screens or other safety devices; result is that Yongkang is dismemberment capital of country; at least once every day someone is rushed from one of factories to one of dozen clinics that specialize in treating hand, arm and finger injuries; unofficial estimates run as high as 2,500 such accidents each year; lawyers, journalists and doctors say hundreds or thousands of injured workers are left out of official count because boss does not have insurance, or because workers were not hired legally, or because city officials are under perssure to show that they have safety under control; reality, all over China, is that workplace casualties have become endemic; 140,000 people died in work-related accidents in China last year; steps government has taken to address issue have done little to solve fundamental problems; high rates of injury and death are being tolerated in China as price of economic progress; photos; chart; map (M)

headline: Italian Police Arrest 6 Men Suspected of Ties to Al Qaeda
abstract: Italian police arrest six men in Milan and Parma for suspected links to international terrorism and possession of false documents; men are suspected of being connected to Al Qaeda and Ansar al-Islam organizations (M)

headline: Casualties
abstract: Military casualties in Iraq war zone as of Apr 11 are 107 Americans and 31 British killed (S)

headline: Options as Expenses: Different Calculators
abstract: Deane Yang letter on Mar 30 article holds stock option is continuing liability that should be placed on company's balance sheet and 'market to market' every quarter until it is exercised

headline: TBWA/Chiat/Day Wins Nextel Job
abstract: TBWA/Chiat/Day Wins Nextel Job Nextel Communications yesterday chose TBWA/Chiat/Day in New York to handle creative duties on its account, which had been handled by Mullen. Billings were estimated at $150 million.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint's First-Quarter Net Income Rose
abstract: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that first-quarter net income rose to $1.67 billion from $140 million in the year-earlier period on a gain from the sale of its directories business. The directory sale added $1.31 billion to earnings. Total sales fell 4.5 percent, to $6.34 billion from $6.64 billion. Sprint is relying on expense reductions to generate profit amid declining sales at its main phone business and slowing wireless revenue. The new chief executive, Gary Forsee, has less room to slash costs than his predecessor, William Esrey, who eliminated about 15,000 jobs in the last two years, analysts said. The company lowered its forecast for 2003 per-share profits at the local and long-distance phone unit by 10 cents a share, to $1.30 to $1.35. It also expects a sales decline of as much as 7 percent. That compares with a previous sales estimate of a low single-digit-rate decline. Sprint PCS's 2003 loss-forecast range was widened by 5 cents a share to 45 cents to 50 cents a share. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Sprint's main phone unit rose 22 cents, to $11.27 a share. The company released results after the close of regular trading. In after-hours trading, the shares slipped 62 cents, or 5.5 percent, to $10.65.

headline: Aid Groups Urging Military to Protect Essential Services
abstract: International Committee of Red Cross, in unusual move, appeals to American troops to protect hospitals and water supplies in Baghdad; agency, only international relief group now functioning in city, urges troops to bar looting of essential public services; says medical system in city has virtually collapsed, with 39 of 40 hospitals looted or closed; says its aid workers were able to venture outside for only limited time; workers from other aid groups are say Iraq is too dangerous to enter; aid specialists and supplies assembled by United States Agency for International Development are stranded in Kuwait and Jordan because of security concerns; Lt Gen Jay Garner, designated to run Iraq, enters nation but gets only as far as Umm Qasr; photos (M)

headline: Verizon and Union Talks Begin With a Clash on Health Care
abstract: Verizon Communications and Communications Workers of America begin negotiations and immediately clash over company's push to have workers pay more for health coverage and union's push to make it easier to organize workers at Verizon Wireless; CWA president Morton Bahr warns there could be walkout on Aug 2, when Verizon's contract expires, unless company eases way to unionize 20,000 workers at Verizon Wireless; Verizon officials say they take strike threat seriously; assert Verizon Wireless is not part of this round of talks, noting wireless operation is joint venture owned 55 percent by Verizon and 45 percent by Vodafone Group (M)

headline: Casualties
abstract: Daily tally of casualties in war in Iraq (S)

abstract: PROTON ENERGY WILL ACQUIRE NORTHERN POWER; SILICON GRAPHICS TO CUT 400 JOBS;.

headline: Martha Stewart's New Magazine Carries the Taste Of Comfort Food
abstract: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia is happy with performance of Everyday Food, its new magazine focusing on easy-to-prepare meals that use ingredietns found in typical supermarkets, and will expand to 10 issues a year; magazine seems to have attracted audience during its four-issue test run, although its circulation has not bee independently audited and company will not provide figures (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 3 Companies Plan Package Of Calling Minutes
abstract: SBC Communications, BellSouth and their mobile telephone joint venture, Cingular Wireless, plan to sell package of calling minutes that for first time could be used for both mobile and home phone calls (S)

headline: Exxon Backs Groups That Question Global Warming
abstract: Exxon Mobil has publicly softened its stance toward global warming over last year, with pledge of $10 million in annual donations for 10 years to Stanford University for climate research; company has increased donations to Washington-based policy groups that, like itself, question human role in global warming and argue that proposed government policies to limit carbon dioxide emissions associated with global warming are too heavy handed; Exxon gives more than $1 million per year to such organizations, which include Competitive Enterprise Institute, Frontiers of Freedom, George C Marshall Institute, American Council for Capital Formation Center for Policy Research and American Legislative Exchange Council (M)

headline: Powell Begins Diplomatic Trip in Spain
abstract: MADRID, Spain (CNN) -- On the first stop of a three-day jaunt from Spain to Lebanon, U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell arrived Thursday in Madrid, where the city's two largest trade unions have spiced their annual May Day parade with a decided anti-war flavor.

headline: Hints of Upturn Begin to Ease Gloom at Banks And Businesses
abstract: Changes in banks' commercial lending confidence may starting to take hold; overall turned in net lending--new loans minus repayments--has been dipping for more than two years; change in direction in demand for loans seems to be under way; National City Corp executive vice president Todd C Moules says there is cautious optimism; National Bureau of Economic Research says commercial and industrial loans held by biggest banks, those classified by Federal Reserve as those with $300 million or more in assets, have dropped steadily since March 2001, month most recent recession began; graph (M)

headline: Euro Beginning to Flex Its Economic Muscles
abstract: Euro is growing into rival to dollar, making up all ground it lost after its introduction in 1999; more important, it has gained stature as safe haven for investors and governments; with US running up vast deficits, economists say euro has chance to consolidate gains; photo; charts show growth of euro against dollar and as percentage of world's foreign exchange reserves (M)

headline: Venezuelan General to Face Trial in Coup
abstract: Gen. Carlos Alfonzo would be the first military commander to face trial in an April 2002 coup that briefly ousted President Hugo Chávez.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Head of Troubled Food Unit Of Royal Ahold Steps Down  Moving to put an $880 million accounting scandal behind it, the food retailer Royal Ahold said that James L. Miller, left, the chief executive of U.S. Foodservice, the unit where the problems were centered, had resigned.    His departure came just hours before the company's first shareholders' meeting since the scandal surfaced in February. [Page C5.]

headline: Gap Opens Review for 3 Retail Chains
abstract: Gap Opens Review For 3 Retail Chains.

headline: Prosecutors in Bali Bombing Take a Morning to Set Out Case
abstract: A team of prosecutors today read out the 33-page indictment of the first man to go on trial for the bombing of two Bali nightclubs last year that killed more than 200 people.

headline: Despite Shuffle, Stewart Is Still in Charge
abstract: Martha Stewart appears, in stepping down as chairwoman and chief executive of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia to assume diminished role of chief creative officer, to be replicating action of Steve Madden, who took same title at Steve Madden Ltd after pleading guilty to stock manipulation charges; she will, however, most likely continue to micromanage her enterprise and remain its decision maker; graph of company's market capitalization (M)

abstract: QUALCOMM TO INVEST $100 MILLION IN CHINA; AT&T TO SPEND $500 MILLION ON SERVICE IMPROVEMENTS;.

headline: Pope Urges Catholics in Bosnia to Forgive Neighbors
abstract: At an open-ait mass in Bosnia, Pope John Paul II urged Roman Catholics to forgive their neighbors and heal the wounds of a country still carrying the stitches and scars of conflict.

abstract: Mark Cuban increases his investment in cable operator Charter Communications to 6.5 percent (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: Egypt: Food Company Acquired
abstract: Kraft Foods Inc reaches preliminary agreement to acquire Egyptian biscuits and snack producer Family Nutrition Co (S)

headline: Traders Sell Stolen Cars at Give-Away Prices
abstract: US military's effort to restore order at Baghdad's open-air market for stolen government cars results in brief arrest of three suspects and near-riot by angry Kurdish traders; photo; incident is latest sobering lesson in complexity of policing in country with few enforceable laws, expanding criminal gangs and tradition of 'self-help' that includes helping onself to whatever is available (M)

headline: Hong Kong Earmarks $1.5 Billion to Deal With Effects of SARS
abstract: The plan calls for government spending and tax cuts concentrated in the next four months that will equal 1 percent of the territory's entire annual economic output.

headline: COURT APPROVES PLAN BY FLEMING TO SELL STORES
abstract: Grocery distributor Fleming Companies wins permission in bankruptcy court to sell its 31 Rainbow Food stores and 9 remaining Richmar Food stores; Roundy's Inc will buy Rainbow for $86.5 million and assume about $35 million for leases; Save Mart will buy 6 Richmar stores for $41 million, including $15 million in assumed liabilities; Kroger Co unit will buy three for $11 million (S)

headline: Decimalization Under Attack on Wall St.
abstract: Floyd Norris comment holds decimal pricing in stocks is under attack; Securities and Exchange Commission chairman William H Donaldson say liquidity that used to exist has been severely dampened; New York Stock Exchange chairman Richard A Grasso suggests that SEC order experiment in which some stocks be required to trade with prices moving in nickel increments, rather than current penny; individual investors who trade in lots of 100 or 200 shares have benefited from narrower spreads, but institutional investors seemed to have suffered; big trades of thousands of shares are more likely to exceed number of shares offered at best bid or ask price, forcing buyer to pay more; study by Nicolas P B Bollen and Jeffrey A Busse concludes that actively managed mutual funds are incurring greater transaction costs, and that those costs could be reducing annual returns by one percentage point; photo (M)

headline: DaimlerChrysler Stock Declines After Company Forecasts a Loss
abstract: Shares of DaimlerChrysler decline after company said that its Chrysler division will lose about $1.17 billion in second quarter (S)

headline: Gunrunners in Baghdad Take Over Open-Air Food Markets
abstract: Hundreds of guns are being sold openly on streets of Baghdad, increasing fear of residents; they say sharp, sudden bursts of gunfire can be heard during night, and bodies can be found on streets in morning; giant caches of arms, abandoned during war, then presumably looted, are turning up in markets of capital; gun market has sprung up in Shiite slum once known as Saddam City; Baghdad resident gives American soldiers credit for trying to seize guns, but says 'hidden forces' in Iraq are trying to torpedo their efforts; photo (M)

headline: Franks Foresees a Weapons Hunt at 'Several Thousand Sites'
abstract: Gen Tommy R Franks says hunt for unconventional weapons in Iraq will require scouring 'several thousand sites,' process that experts say could take months; failure of military teams to find evidence of illegal chemical, biological or nuclear weapons forces Bush administration to rethink scope of search; administration is tripling number of scientists and engineers assigned to operation, to about 1,500; photo (M)

headline: Liberia Seen as Icon of World's Neglect of Africa
abstract: Letter From Africa on Liberia as portrait of international neglect that stands in sharp contrast to neighboring Sierra Leone, where tens of thousands of foreigners are working to restore peace and donating aid; in Liberia, World Food Program cannot deliver aid because of attacks by thugs, refugees flee and enemy factions make deadly alliances in nearby countries; Liberia, in contrast to former European colonies, was founded by freed American slaves in 1847 and was virtual US colony until end of cold war made it strategically unimportant (M)

headline: Pope Goes to Spain Today, Seemingly Less Feeble Now
abstract: Pope John Paul II is set to go to Spain, resuming foreign trips after more than eight months; is seemingly less feeble than he was; photo of nuns at Cuatro Vientos air base in western Madrid (M)

headline: In Bush's Words: 'Superb' Progress in Iraq
abstract: Excerpts from Pres Bush's speech about Iraq before audience of Iraqi-Americans in Dearborn, Mich (M)

headline: Bush Steps Up Criticism of Europe's Ban on Genetic Foods
abstract: President Bush asserted today that Europe's ban had discouraged Third World countries from using the technology and thus undermined efforts to end hunger in Africa.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Arrests In Lawyer's Killing
abstract: The British police arrested a man and a woman in connection with the killing of a well-known Roman Catholic lawyer in Belfast 13 years ago. There have been allegations that the British authorities colluded with the Protestant paramilitaries who shot the lawyer, Pat Finucane, a prominent legal defender of members of the Irish Republican Army. The male suspect, who has been brought to Northern Ireland for questioning, is thought to be Ken Barrett, a member of the paramilitary group responsible for the killing, the Ulster Freedom Fighters, the Press Association of the United Kingdom reported. Mr. Barrett said last year that the Northern Ireland police had ordered the killing.   Brian Lavery (NYT)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Wella Rejection
abstract: Investors in Wella who own more than third of company's preferred shares reject buyout offer by Procter & Gamble Co, which took control of company with $6.9 billion bid in March; Procter & Gamble owns 78 percent of company's ordinary shares (S)

headline: U.S., Afghan and Pakistan Generals Study Border Incursions
abstract: Senior American, Afghan and Pakistani generals met today to tackle the problems of crossborder incursions.

headline: Rumsfeld and Myers at the Pentagon
abstract: Following is the transcript from a news conference at the Pentagon on Tuesday by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and Gen. Richard B. Myers, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as recorded by eMediaMillWorks.

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Coal Takeover Approved
abstract: Australia-based coal exporter Xstrata wins approval from shareholders of MIM Holdings for takeover that is valued at 3.44 billion Australian dollars ($2.3 billion) (S)

headline: Newer, Smaller, Faster, And Not in Stores Now
abstract: Several retailers are making it easier to purchase and use cutting-edge products from Japan that are not yet available in United States; they are selling never-exported laptop computers, digital cameras and other gadgets through Web; companies mark up prices as much as 30 to 50 percent to pay for express shipping, technical support and one-year warranty; products come modified with English-language software, controls and manual and AC adapters for North American electrical outlets; photos (M)

headline: Meanwhile, Back at the Ranch
abstract: Pres Bush uses invitations to White House and his Texas ranch to reward allies in Iraq war, make clear which foreign leaders are considered part of inner circle and compensate for breaches with traditional allies; Bush invited Japanese Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi and Australian Prime Min John Howard to sit in on briefings at ranch and pulled out all stops at White House for Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyoto to make clear to Filipinos that they will be rewarded for helping US fight terrorists; photos; not likely to enjoy views from ranch anytime soon are French and German leaders who led opposition to Iraq war (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP., Falls Church, Va., the world's third-largest maker of corporate jets, said it would close a Savannah, Ga., plant that makes Gulfstream business jets for four weeks and furlough more than 1,000 workers as it slows production to cope with a drop in demand.    HIGH RIVER L.P., New York, an investment company controlled by Carl Icahn, said it had offered $100 per unit in cash to unit-holders of Hallwood Realty Partners L.P., Dallas, an owner of office and industrial properties.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Barings Auditor Faulted
abstract: World Business Briefin

headline: Decision Seen Soon on Maker Of Calvin Klein Women's Line
abstract: Phillips-Van Heusen, new owner of Calvin Klein business, is expected to announce producer of its new Klein sportswear for women set to appear next year in major department stores; Phillips predicts annual sales will eventually reach $1 billion; retailing executives and analysts following situation say front-runner is Kellwood, with Jones Apparel Group still in running for license; photos of Kellwood chief executive Hal J Upbin and chief financial officer W Lee Capps and Jones chief executive Peter Boneparth (M)

headline: The Saudi Exit: No Sure Cure for Royals' Troubles
abstract: News analysis of US decision to pull out of military bases in Saudi Arabia, and whether departure will be followed by political reforms within Saudi royal family; Crown Prince Abdullah says he wants to drag kingdom into political modernity, but many members of royal household say pressure really stems from restive population of young Saudis without jobs or political participation (M)

headline: New Rules May Drive Push to Privatize . . .
abstract: Grant Thornton reports that 49 public companies have gone private since July, when Sarbanes-Oxley law covering corporate governance was enacted, up 26 percent from previous July-to-April period; suggests greater scrutiny may be disincentive to going or staying public (M)

headline: Fast-food chains are adding premium salads to their menus after the success of a rival.
abstract: Fast-food chains follow Wendy's lead by beginning to offer and advertise premium salads; industry experts wonder whether health-conscious consumers will respond positively to roughage served by fast-food restaurants (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Suspects Deny Killing Girls
abstract: British school caretaker Ian Huntley pleads not guilty to charges he murdered 10-year-olds Jessica Chapman and Holly Wells in summer of 2002; Huntley has admitted that he was guilty of obstructing justice; murder trial is set for October 6 (S)

headline: INSPECTIONS MAY CLEAR WAY FOR APPROVAL OF LILLY DRUG
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co moves closer to approval of new drug for depression after Food and Drug Administration completes reviews of two Indianapolis plants that failed earlier inspections; Federal approvals for drug Cymbalta and for injectable version of schizophrenia drug Zyprexa have been delayed until factories meet FDA manufacturing standards (S)

headline: A Battle Against Vampires With Solar-Powered Weapons
abstract: New Game Boy video game called Boktai: The Sun Is in Your Hand uses natural light as potent weapon against digital bad guys, encouraging players to use system outdoors; photo (M)

headline: U.S., Europe and Canada Investigate Copper Pricing
abstract: Antitrust authorities in US, Europe and Canada are investigating whether several large copper companies colluded to fix prices; Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold confirms it has received grand jury subpoena for documents about its activities in market for copper concentrate, which is later refined by smelters; European antitrust officials conduct raids on offices of BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto in London and Somincor in Portugal; copper prices have increased about 25 percent since 2001 (M)

headline: The Return
abstract: There are two remarkable facts about Col. Martin Stanton. One is that he was in Iraq more than a decade ago. The second is how he got there.

headline: Peenemünde Journal; Where Rocketry Is Honored, Rubble Is Reminder
abstract: German vacationers on island of Usedom visit museum in Peenemunde that once housed power plant for top-secret complex where Nazis developed and tested V-1 missile, or buzz bomb, and V-2 missile, two of most momentous weapons devised during World War II; island was restricted military area in decades when it was part of East Germany; V-2's that struck London from bases in Netherlands reached altitude of 50 miles and reached their target, more than 100 miles away, in just under five minutes; museum lauds technological achievement but makes clear it was pursued on behalf of evil regime; photos; map (M)

headline: Private Concern, Public Consequences
abstract: Marshall S Cogan, prominent New York art collector, restaurateur and magazine publisher, is also subject of stinging ruling by federal Judge Robert Sweet, who found that Cogan drained personal holding company, Trace International Holdings, of tens of millions of dollars while officers and directors did nothing; ruling involving now-bankrupt company could cost Cogan and five associates total of $44 million; photos (M)

headline: From farm to fork, risks persist
abstract: BRUSSELS:—  The dangers lurk in the unlikeliest places.

headline: Finally, a Public Resting Place for History's Motherboards
abstract: Computer History Museum in Mountain View, Calif, contains 5,000 computer artifacts, and will gradually expand; several exhibits described; most of collection has been donated; photos (M)

headline: Military Says It Has Remains Of Last Soldier Missing in Iraq
abstract: Pentagon says it has identified remains of Specialist Edward J Anguiano more than month after he vanished in ambush in Iraq; this ends search for last American soldier missing in war; photo (M)

headline: Thieves Take Cellini Sculpture From Art Museum in Vienna
abstract: Thieves steal 16th-century gold-plated sculpture by Florentine master Benvenuto Cellini from Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna, Austria; alarm is set off when piece is lifted from its case, but it is switched off by guard, believing it to be false alarm; sculpture is worth at least $58 million; Wilfried Seipel, museum director, says he suspects robbery was masterminded by someone who covets piece for private collection; notes it is only object removed from room filled with priceless works; says he has suspended all three guards on duty, but he does not believe any of them were involved in plot; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Bid For Pizza Chain; GERMANY: Unemployment Rises; MEDICAL ACQUISITION INQUIRY; BRITAIN: Reuters Rating Lowered;.

headline: Union Says Airlines Rebuffed Its Request
abstract: Assn of Flight Attendants criticizes airlines' response to threat from SARS, including refusal to allow flight attendants to wear surgical masks and gloves to prevent spread of severe respiratory illness (S)

headline: Iraq's U.S. Overseer Is Praised by Rumsfeld
abstract: Structure of American administration of postwar Iraq remains unresolved, as Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld issues strong endorsement of Jay Garner, retired lieutenant general whose job seemed about to be eclipsed by L Paul Bremer (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Weak Dollar Value Helps McDonald's Return to Profit  McDonald's reported a 29 percent increase in first-quarter earnings based largely upon favorable currency trends. But the company also posted losses in sales at stores open at least a year, a 13-month trend that has been looming over McDonald's business.    Despite a 3.6 percent decline in worldwide sales and a drop in operating income, investors viewed McDonald's report as a sign of improvement after the company posted its first quarterly loss as a publicly traded company in the fourth quarter. [Page C12.]

abstract: INDIA: Pakistani Held In Kashmir Attack; VIETNAM: Soldiers' Remains Repatriated;.

headline: Anti-Americanism in Greece Is Reinvigorated by War
abstract: War in Iraq drives up anti-American feeling in Greece; one poll shows 94 percent of Greeks oppose war against Iraq, and another poll shows that more Greeks have positive view of Saddam Hussein than of Pres Bush and that majority of respondents believe US is as undemocratic at Iraq; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Big Toy Store To Sell
abstract: Britain's Hamleys, 243-year-old emporium that calls itself world's biggest toy store, agrees to be bought for $80 million by its own managers and Baugur Group, leading retailer in Iceland (S)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: CONGO: Accord Signed;.

headline: Hollywood Is Feeling Flush As Blockbuster Season Starts
abstract: Blockbuster summer movies exhibit same release patterns as in recent years: gigantic openings in more than 3,000 theaters followed by steep drop-offs on subsequent weekends (M)

abstract: APPEALS COURT RESCINDS FINE AGAINST AT&T; PANAMSAT AND LEVEL 3 FORM DATA NETWORK;.

headline: Air Canada and Pilots' Union Tentatively Agree on Cuts
abstract: Air Canada reaches tentative agreement with union representing its 3,150 pilots on cutbacks, clearing crucial hurdle in its effort to restructure under bankruptcy protection (M)

headline: Laos Jails 2 Journalists and American Aide
abstract: Three men were sentenced to 15-year prison terms today after they where arrested while reporting on an ethnic insurgency.

headline: Coca-Cola tries selling sexiness in promoting Dasani in the competitive bottled-water market.
abstract: Berlin Cameron/Red Cell agency launches large multimedia advertising campaign to increase share of $2-billion-annually bottled water market held by Coca-Cola Co subsidiary Dasani (M)

headline: Iraq's Slide Into Lawlessness Squanders Good Will for U.S.
abstract: Iraq's descent into lawlessness has stalled its return to normalcy, increased costs of reconstruction and squandered much of good will Iraqis felt for their new American overseers; awe at American power in war has been transformed in just few weeks into anger at American impotence in peace; citizens are in peculiar state of limbo, free yet fearful of crime wave; organized gangs are far better armed than skeleton Iraqi police forces; wholesale plundering of government property, often under eyes of American soldiers in capital, has largely undone good intentions of American military that took such pains to limit damage to country's infrastructure during bombing; military commanders express surprise at scale of initial pillaging, but say they were preoccupied with securing city; in Washington, dismantling of Iraq's government buildings has attracted little interest; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Insurer's Profit Falls
abstract: Dutch insurance company Aegon reports 36 perent decline in first-quarter profit; earned 393 million euros ($449 million) compared with earnings of 617 million euros year earlier; pretax profit was down 47 percent, to 845 million euros; revenue fell 9 percent, to 8.56 billion euros (S)

headline: Case of Mad Cow in Canada Prompts U.S. to Ban Its Beef
abstract: Mad cow disease is diagnosed in cow from unidentified ranch in Alberta, prompting US to ban imports of beef, cattle and animal feed from Canada; trading on Canadian livestock futures is suspended and stock prices of many US and Canadian meat and restaurant companies fall sharply; authorities are not sure if eight-year-old cow was imported or contracted disease in Canada, which is world's tenth largest beef producer; US accounts for 78 percent of Canadian beef exports, but they are only four percent of US beef production; cow was to be slaughtered in January when suspicious veterinarian ordered tests; Min Lyle Vanclief stresses that cow did not go into food chain; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Gas Executive Questioned
abstract: World Business Briefing: South Korea: Gas Executiv

headline: Senator Calls For Reducing Tax Shields For Executives
abstract: Senate Finance Committee chairman Charles E Grassley says Congress should tighten laws that let Enron executives shield their salaries from taxes without risk; Joint Tax Committee report shows top 200 executives of company avoided taxes by deferring $150 million in pay in five years preceding its bankruptcy (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Archer Wins Parole
abstract: Jeffrey Archer, member of British House of Lords and former Conservative party deputy chairman, will be granted parole after serving half of four-year sentence; was convicted of perjury and perverting justice in libel trial against newspaper that reported he had paid hush money to prostitute; photo (S)

headline: From Tourism to High Finance, Mysterious Illness Spreads Havoc
abstract: Highly contagious respiratory disease known as SARS continues to spread; its impact on business activity stretches from Hong Kong around globe, disrupting complex supply chains and forcing industries from airlines to banking to adjust their operations; Swiss bank UBS orders employees returning from business trips to Asia to stay home for 10 days before reporting to work; Intel cancels two major conferences in Asia; KLM Royal Dutch Airlines warns that SARS is hurting international air travel more than war in Iraq; further disruption can be expected; World Health Orgn urges travelers to avoid Hong Kong and Guangdong Province, China; this is first such global warning against travel ever issued by WHO because of infectious disease; health officials do not know if SARS will spread further throughout world or burn out on its own; number of cases is relatively small compared with some other respiratory diseases; health officials' deep concern stems from fact that so little is known about it and because there is no treatment or vaccine; chart lists measures being taken in Hong Kong (M)

headline: European Regulators Seek More Evidence in Microsoft Inquiry
abstract: European competition regulators are seeking more evidence in their investigation of Microsoft, move that is almost certain to delay further five-year-old antitrust inquiry (M)

headline: KEY3MEDIA WINS COURT RULING ON ITS RECOVERY PLAN
abstract: Bankruptcy Judge Jerry Venters rules Key3Media Group, technology trade show company, can line up support of creditors for bankruptcy recovery plan (S)û

headline: A Strong Yen Helps Tokyo Retain Status as Most Costly
abstract: Cost-of-living survey by Mercer Human Resources Consulting and Marsh & McLennan finds Tokyo is again most expensive city in world despite 1 percent annual drop in prices in yen, thanks to yen's rise in value against dollar; Osaka places third and New York 10th; table of world's most expensive cities (M)

headline: What's $400 Million Between Friends?
abstract: Federal investigations of possible financial fraud at AOL Time Warner spur curiosity about dealings and communications between soon-departing company chairman Stephen M Case and Thomas Middelhoff, deposed Bertelsmann chairman; Securities and Exchange Commission contends AOL Time Warner improperly inflated AOL division's sales and earnings by effectively overpaying Bertelsmann in deal constructed to get back $400 million in online advertising sales; photo; timetable of companies' relationship since 1994 (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NAUTICA ENTERPRISES INC., New York, a designer and retailer of casual clothing, said it would license its swimsuits for women and juniors to Warnaco Group Inc., New York, the maker of Speedo sportswear, starting in July. Terms were not disclosed.    HERSHEY FOODS CORP., Hershey, Pa., the confectioner, is selling sugar-free chocolates, including Reese's Sugar Free Peanut Butter Cup Miniatures and Hershey's Sugar Free Dark Chocolate, for the first time in its 109-year history to attract more health-conscious consumers.

headline: Athens Journal; For a Cremation, the Corpse Has to Emigrate
abstract: Greek Orthodox Church dictates that bodies must be buried, not burned, but cemeteries in Athens and elsewhere are so crowded that remains often must be exhumed and moved; current law leaves legal status of cremation ambiguous, but lobbying effort is gaining momentum to get Parliament to pass measure explicitly allowing the practice; photo (Athens Journal) (M)

headline: Argentina, Turning the Corner, Leans to Its Left
abstract: Argentine Pres-elect Nestor Kirchner will inherit economy that is showing signs of bouncing back from worst crisis in country's history; challenges Kirchner will confront are daunting; he must resolve disputes on compensating banks and utilities, force powerful provincial governors to reduce spending and begin negotiations on standby agreement with International Monetary Fund; most pressing concern is country's debt burden, which has risen to nearly 140 percent of gross domestic product since default was announced in Dec 2001; Kirchner has said he wants public works projects to create jobs, but most economists say it would be mistake for new government to try to spend its way back to growth and jeopardize budget surpluses that markets and IMF expect; first signals of his direction will come when he names his cabinet; photos; graph (L)

headline: Deception, or Just Disarray, at Enron?
abstract: Charges that some Enron executives illegally pumped up company's stock price by lying about existence of certain Internet technology discussed as questionable; technology in Enron Broadband Services may have been more developed than indictment suggests; interviews with unit's former customers, suppliers, consultants, personnel and competitors indicate exaggerated claims are typical for computer industry; stock price graph; photos (L)

headline: Sharon and Abbas to Meet, With Quite Different Agendas
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian prime ministers plan to have crucial meeting on May 29; both sides say it is time to move forward on international peace plan, but they have set very different priorities; Palestinians want explicit Israeli statement accepting eventual Palestinian statehood, while Israel wants Palestinians to specify areas where their security forces can take control and crack down on militants, after which Israel would be willing to pull back its troops; outcome of talks between Prime Mins Ariel Sharon and Mahmoud Abbas will set tone for planned summit meeting between them and Pres Bush in Jordan next week; Israeli and Palestinian demands are listed in Middle East peace plan, but parties have not yet agreed on how to get started; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: NEPAL: LIVE FROM EVEREST. CHINA: 150 HELD IN REDEVELOPMENT FIGHT. INDIA: STRIKE CLOSES GOVERNMENT OFFICES.

abstract: Marathon Oil Corp acquires Khanty Mansiysk Oil Corp, which produces oil in Russia, for $275 million (S)

headline: Algerians Begin Burying Dead From Quake; Death Toll Rises
abstract: More than 1,600 were killed in the earthquake that struck Algeria, "and the victim figures are expected to rise," Prime Minister Ahmed Ouyahia said at a news conference today.

headline: A Garage In All Its Glory
abstract: Responsible Party article on Richard Griot and his Griotÿ

headline: Bush Pledges to Help as Ulster Nears a Junction in Peace Path
abstract: Pres Bush gives Northern Ireland peace effort push at key moment, pledging to help local leaders take 'final steps toward a lasting peace'; comments at news conference after meeting with Prime Min Tony Blair on Iraq war; final blueprint for re-establishing home rule government is to be announced (S)

abstract: JAPAN: Chip Maker To List Shares; JAPAN: Decline In Savings; SOUTH KOREA: Bank Sale Opposed; THAILAND: Growth In Thailand;.

headline: Olympics' Ethics Panel Proposes Disbanding of Iraqi Committee
abstract: International Olympic Committee's ethics commission calls for dissolution of Iraq's Olympic Committee, which Iraqi athletes have accused of employing torture; IOC recommends that exiled Iraqis and those not associated with torture and other crimes form new Olympic committee; IOC was acting on complaint filed Dec 6 on behalf of two Iraqi athletes by Indict, London-based human rights organization; Indict accused Iraq's Olympic Committee and its president, Saddam Hussein's son Uday, of beatings, torture and harassment of athletes (M)

headline: Utilities Rebound by Going Back To Basics
abstract: Interview with Merrill Lynch analyst Steven I Fleishman on outlook for investing in electric power generators; photo (M)

headline: Free of Hussein's Rule, Sunnis in North Flaunt A Long-Hidden Piety
abstract: Sunnis in Mosul, Iraq, begin showing signs of devotion, like wearing beards, that might have gotten them in trouble as fundamentalists under Saddam Hussein's rule; political party resurfaces in city calling for establishment of Islamic rule through electoral process, but there is also widespread distrust of any political party that would try to dictate to people how to live, work or worship; American officials have no plans to block Islamist activity, but hope to reduce its allure by providing jobs, stability and free expression; photo (M)

headline: China and India Edge a Bit Closer to a Border Accord
abstract: India and China sign joint declaration in which India emphasizes that Tibet is part of China and China agrees to begin trading with India's northeastern state of Sikkim; Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee says his meeting with Chinese leaders in Beijing will lead to stable, enduring and forward-looking ties of friendship; photo with Pres Hu Jintao (M)

headline: Marathon Oil Is Set For Venture in Qatar
abstract: Qatar Oil Min Abdullah bin Hamad al-Attiyah says Marathon Oil will sign letter of intent to pursue $4.3 billion joint venture with Qatar to process natural gas into naphtha and diesel; project's 120,000 barrel per day of production will be 70 percent diesel and 30 percent naphtha (M)

headline: Fighting in an Urban Area: 'We Choose Targets Carefully to Avoid Civilians'
abstract: At a news conference yesterday at the Pentagon, Victoria Clarke, the Pentagon spokeswoman, and Maj. Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, vice director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, discussed the bombing of a Baghdad neighborhood on Monday, the destruction of the Iraqi command and control structure, and other subjects. Following are excerpts from the session as recorded by Federal Document Clearing House Inc. A complete transcript is online at nytimes.com/iraq.    Ms. Clarke      We continue to make progress in the war with the Iraqi regime, which has less control of the country every day. Our troops are moving at will in Baghdad, including the presidential palaces.

headline: An Electronic Inventory Of Precious Possessions
abstract: Q. I want to make an inventory of my clothing, compact discs, DVD movies, videotapes and books. What kind of software should I get? I have a Dell laptop with Windows 2000 and Office XP.    A. Your choice of software should hinge on how much detail you want to put into your inventory catalog. On the simple end, you can make a straightforward list with tabbed columns in a word-processing program. With a specialized database program, you can design customized forms to record information about your possessions like location in the house, purchase price, genre and details you might need to have for tax or insurance purposes.

headline: Gaming Pros and Cons
abstract: Daniel Asimov letter says video games are not all good or all bad (Jun 5 article)

headline: PENTAGON ASSERTS THE MAIN FIGHTING IS FINISHED IN IRAQ
abstract: Pentagon says major combat operations in Iraq are over after United States forces take control of Tikrit, last bastion of old government; Secretary of State Colin L Powell accuses Syria of harboring fleeing officials of Saddam Hussein's government; threatens Syria with economic or diplomatic sanctions; White House spokesman Ari Fleischer calls Syria 'rogue nation' and others in Bush administration accuse Syria of backing terrorists and amassing chemical and biological weapons; say Hussein's family members have fled Iraq into Syria in recent weeks; Syrian officials deny this, and also deny that they are developing chemical weapons; Pentagon officials say there are no plans to attack Syria; say military focus is to send some troops home, now that major combat has ended in Iraq, and to reposition others for long-term mission of making Iraq stable and secure; it is unclear how many troops will remain in Iraq and for how long; signs of shifting mission are evident, with ground forces increasingly assuming peacekeeping duties even as combat troops root out remnants of Iraqi military and irregular forces; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Exceeds Expected Profit But Stays Cautious
abstract: Microsoft Corp reports net profit of $2.79 billion for fiscal third quarter ended March 31, beating analysts' estimates; profit was $2.74 billion in third quarter year earlier; revenue rose 8 percent, to $7.84 billion from $7.25 billion year ago; chief financial officer John G Connors comments (M)

abstract: Irish reality television program Cabin Fever meets likely end when schooner used as location for show sinks; photo (M)

abstract: David E Rosenbaum column says budget plan adopted by Congress will neither generate all economic growth promised by Republicans nor do grievous harm seen by Democrats (M)

abstract: Thomas Middelhoff was named a partner with Investcorp, a global investment firm known for buying and selling brand names like Tiffany, Gucci and Saks Fifth Avenue.

headline: German Chancellor's Economic Reform Plan Endorsed
abstract: BERLIN, June 1  Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's plan to enact economic reform by reducing Germany's vast network of social protections was approved today by 90 percent of the delegates at a politically crucial meeting of his Social Democratic Party.

abstract: Taiwan may have suffered another hospital outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, the disappointed leader of its fight against the epidemic said today.

Salsbury, WorldCom's general counsel, and Susan Mayer, the treasurer, resigned, a day after a bankruptcy court examiner's report raised questions about their roles in the company's collapse.    The report suggested that the two executives had contributed to a breakdown in acceptable corporate behavior. [Page C5.]

headline: Investing; Bond Funds' Yields Are Moving Targets
abstract: Morningstar Inc study suggests advertised bond fund yields give very poor indication of fund's future yield, but could provide investors with important clues about riskiness of funds; all funds that list yields in ads must report annualized yield for previous 30 days, minus fund expenses, figure that often has little relationship to full-year yield; Morningstar analyst Bradley Sweeney notes funds with higher-than-average yields usually hold riskier bonds (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Judge Approves Dice's Plan To Exit Bankruptcy
abstract: Dice Inc, Internet job-search service, wins Bankruptcy Judge Burton R Lifland's approval of its plan to exit bankruptcy as private company and hand over ownership to creditors and shareholders; company's recovery plan is supported by hedge fund Elliott Associates and its international affiliate, which holds about $33.6 million, or 48 percent, of notes; Elliott, Dice's largest creditor, will receive 46 percent of new shares (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: SK Rescue Urged
abstract: SK Group chairman Son Kil Seung urges SK companies to provide funds needed to rescue SK Global, group's scandal-ridden trading firm (S)

abstract: Cirio Finanziaria, Italian producer of canned foods, approves plan to convert 1.3 billion euros of debt into shares in effort to avoid bankruptcy (S)

headline: PeopleSoft Won't Go to Court To Stop Takeover Bid After All
abstract: PeopleSoft Inc, target of hostile takeover by Oracle Corp, reverses plans to sue Oracle after having threatened to do so only day earlier (M)

headline: ANOTHER G.I. DIES IN LATEST ATTACKS
abstract: Two American soldiers are missing and one is killed in series of ambushes in and around Baghdad; reports of scattered attacks on troops stream in throughout day; trailer in US military convoy is reported hit by rocket-propelled grenade in town of Najaf and truck is set afire by local residents protesting American presence in Iraq; attacks come as Baghdad suffers through fourth straight day with little or no electricity because of continued acts of sabotage; American administrator L Paul Bremer 3d says saboteurs are rogue Baathist elements trying to hinder coalition efforts; Pentagon is reluctant to speculate on whether two missing troops were abducted, got lost or left their assigned location for some other reason; photo; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Industrial Output Falls
abstract: Japan's industrial output fell worse-than-expected 1.7 percent in February compared with previous month (S)

headline: John Vause: Divisions Over New Government
abstract: NASIRIYA, Iraq (CNN) -- The United States invited handpicked Iraqi opposition leaders to Nasiriya on Tuesday for the first of a series of talks on shaping a new government, but thousands of protesting Shiite Muslims want to make sure their voices are heard.

headline: South Africa to Pay $3,900 to Each Family of Apartheid Victims
abstract: Pres Thabo Mbeki of South Africa says his government will pay reparations totaling $85 million to more than 19,000 victims of apartheid crimes who testified about their suffering before Truth and Reconciliation Commission; family of each victim will receive about $3,900, which compares with average annual salary in South Africa of about $3,000 (M)

headline: Cathay Pacific and Singapore Air Cut Back on Asian Service Because of Deadly Virus
abstract: Cathay Pacific Airways says it will operate 37 percent fewer flights than planned and Singapore Airlines sets 19.7 percent cutback through end of May because passengers have been scared off by emergence of severe acute respiratory syndrome; Cathay Pacific warns its first half financial results will be materially affected by sudden and unexpected collapse in passenger demand caused by SARS and Iraq war; neither carrier sets large-scale layoffs (M)

headline: A Scanner Skips the ID Card and Zeroes In on the Iris
abstract: How It Works column explains eye-scanning systems, used for identification and security; drawings illustrate how systems work (M)

headline: U.N. Official Criticizes Israeli Travel Restrictions in Gaza
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, May 19 — Stepped-up Israeli travel restrictions have been preventing dozens of international workers and managers for United Nations refugee programs in the Gaza Strip from getting into and out of Gaza for the last week, the United Nations special coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process told the Security Council today.

headline: A Chief Against the War
abstract: John S Koppel letter praises AkPharma chief executive Alan Kligerman, in April 6 article, for having courage as corporate executive to oppose war in Iraq

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Special Olympics Are On
abstract: Mary Davies, Special Olympics Chief Executive, reports games scheduled for Dublin (Ireland) this June will proceed, in spite of concerns over spread of SARS; fewer than 200 of 7,000 people participating hail from countries hardest hit by SARS (S)

headline: On Tape, a Discussion of HealthSouth's Finances

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DOW JONES & CO., New York, said its Ottaway Newspapers unit had agreed to buy The Stockton Record in California from Omaha World-Herald Co., Omaha, a publisher, for $144 million.

abstract: Crispin, Porter & Bogusky takes top honors in commercials category at annual International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France; other winners noted (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Deadline In Israel Terror Case
abstract: British court rules that six people, held by Scotland Yard in possible connection with last week's suicide bombing in Tel Aviv, must either be charged or released today; five of six are thought to be friends or relatives of Omar Khan Sharif, who fled bomb scene when his suicide bomb failed to detonate (S)

headline: Earnings Decline at Pixar
abstract: Pixar Animation Studios says first-quarter profit declined 48 percent; net income fell to $8.18 million from $15.6 million year earlier; sales declined 50 percent, to $18.7 million (S)

headline: British Minister Defends Assessment of Risks From Hussein
abstract: British Foreign Sec Jack Straw, addressing House of Commons Select Committee on Foreign Affairs, defends claim in intelligence dossier that Saddam Hussein could unleash unconventional attack within 15 minutes; denies allegations that claim was added to document to embellish findings and support Prime Min Tony Blair's argument that Iraq represented imminent threat (M)

abstract: International Academy of Digital Arts and Sciences' Webby Awards will be scaled back to a virtual event this year, announced on Internet; ceremony two years ago drew 3,000 people to War Memorial Opera House in San Francisco (S)

abstract: India's Reserve Bank cuts its bank rate by 0.25 percentage point, to 6 percent, lowest since 1971; cuts cash reserve ratio of banks by 0.25 percentage point, to 4.50 percent (S)

headline: Amnesty Calls World Less Safe
abstract: Human rights group Amnesty International, in its annual report, says world has become more dangerous, and governments more repressive, since effort to fight terrorism began after Sept 11 attacks on United States (M)

abstract: Chubb Corp says second-quarter profit will be reduced by $17 million as result of losing arbitration decision on 1995 fire claim (S)

headline: How Much Is Enough?
abstract: The Bush administration is learning a simple if unwelcome lesson: it will take more troops to police and secure Iraq than it did to destroy the Saddam Hussein regime.

headline: U.S.-Saudi Ties Frayed Over Mideast Tensions
abstract: Anti-American sentiment, pervasive in Mideast, is now common in Saudi Arabia, where elite have long had close ties with US; prominent figures inside and outside government discuss tensions over role of Saudis in Sept 11 terrorist attacks, US pressure for political reform and resentment on behalf of Palestinians; photos (M)

headline: Putting A Price on Immigration Backlogs
abstract: Daniel Altman column warns slowdown in approval of new immigrants because of security concerns is bad for economy; holds premium processing program that lets businesses speed visa approvals for certain workers by paying $1,000 fee may be major cause of system's huge backlog in routine cases; graph of pending applications (M)

headline: Planned Job Cuts Declined in May, Survey Says
abstract: Challenger, Gray & Christmas reports employers in United States announced plans in May to cut 68,623 jobs, smallest number of intended layoffs in 30 months and down 53.1 percent from April (S)

headline: Bush Visit Is Viewed as Hopeful Sign for Ulster Impasse
abstract: Pres Bush's principal concern during visit to Belfast will be his talks with Prime Min Tony Blair about war in Iraq, but his presence is expected to give added impetus to new push for resolution of long-term conflict in Northern Ireland; his visit comes at most critical moment for province's peace plan since accord was signed five years ago this week; Blair and his Irish counterpart Bertie Ahern had already planned to mark anniversary by instituting public emergency formula that they hope will break impasse that has put self-government there on hold (M)
