abstract: If an emerging Palestinian government makes an effort to halt violence, Israel is willing to pull back troops and release Palestinian prisoners and ease travel restrictions.

headline: As Hancock's Profit Declined, Chief's Pay Rose to $21 Million
abstract: John Hancock Financial Services comes under criticism for raising pay package of its chief executive, David F D'Alessandro, to $21.7 million in 2002, up from $8.2 million year before, even though company's stock price fell 32.4 percent in 2002 and its earnings dropped 15.4 percent; stock analysts and executive compensation experts say D'Alessandro's pay is not in keeping with concept that chief executive's pay should reflect his contribution to company's earnings and share price; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES REPORTS NARROWER NET LOSS; I.B.M. ACQUIRES THINK DYNAMICS;.

headline: Bush Says Evidence of Iraq Weapons Efforts Will Be Found
abstract: President Bush said today that he was convinced that Iraq had programs to make weapons of mass destruction.

headline: U.S. Finds Barrels That May Hold Chemical Weapons
abstract: U.S. soldiers in the Karbala area have found oil drums that, according to preliminary tests, may contain nerve gas and mustard gas.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pharmacy Names Executive
abstract: Boots Group names R

headline: Criticism Takes Toll on South Korean Leader
abstract: Pres Roh Moo Hyun of South Korea is fighting for his political life barely three months into his five-year term; faces daunting list of woes, including corruption investigations involving some longtime associates and his older brother; calls news conference to fend off accusations of corruption, but news media coverage is strongly skeptical, saying there are still many unanswered questions; his recent visit to Washington, during which he met with Pres Bush and strongly reaffirmed country's attachment to its 50-year alliance with US, was supposed to be victory for him; it turned into political debacle at home, after leftist student groups and others accused him of caving in to Washington after campaigning on theme of greater independence; photo (M)

headline: Across Iraq, the Dark Shadow Of Hussein Still Looms Large
abstract: Specter of Saddam Hussein still lays across land in Iraq, two months on; despite presence of 140,000 American troops, many Iraqis of assorted political outlooks feel no sense of consolidated victory; they see no power emerging that is capable of stamping out vestige of once all-powerful Hussein; many Iraqis presume Hussein prepared hiding places long in advance of American and British invasion; they imagine him protected by loyal aides, image that radiates sense of power over Iraqis; one Iraqi man says only remedy that would rid country of Hussein's shadow is new Iraqi government that would project itself clearly and forcefully across unruly land of ethnic and religious division (M)

headline: Consumer Pullback: Retail Sales Fell 0.1% in April
abstract: Commerce Department reports overall consumer spending fell by 0.1 percent in April on seasonally adjusted basis, though sales were still up 2.2 percent since February; says retail spending, less 2.5 percent rise in sales of autos and parts, fell 0.9 percent; holds lower gasoline prices accounted for more than half decline, dragging down spending at filling stations by 5.9 percent; says consumers spent less at clothing stores, where sales fell 3.2 percent, and at department stores, which posted 1.4 percent decline; graph; photo (M)

headline: DataBank; Technology Shares Rally as Earnings Shine
abstract: Stock market performance in week of Apr 14-17 reviewed; graphs; tables (S)0

headline: Online and in the Dark About Privacy Issues
abstract: Annenberg Public Policy Center study finds many adult Internet users know little about how dot-com companies track their online movements and use data gathered (M)

headline: Japan Steps Up Efforts to Counter the Faltering Economy
abstract: Japanese policy makers stepped up efforts today to counter the slowing economy and to calm investors unnerved by the first major bank bailout in four years.

headline: Broadband Use Has Its Risks, Study Finds
abstract: National Cyber Security Alliance study shows that advantages of broadband Internet connections are counterbalanced by far greater risks broadband users are exposed to because their computers are always on (M)

headline: Indians Pursue Portuguese Passports as an Entree to Europe
abstract: Young Indians in Goa, colonized by Portugal five centuries ago, are taking advantage of Portuguese law granting them citizenship to obtain passports that also get them into European Union countries; Portugal gave up colony in 1961 (M)

headline: PARK PLACE SAYS EARNINGS WILL DROP LESS THAN FORECAST
abstract: Park Place Entertainment Corp says second-quarter earnings might fall less than forecast because business improved in May and first half of June (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: AT&T Unit Shifts On Bankruptcy
abstract: The AT&T Latin America Corporation, an unprofitable data-transmission unit of AT&T, said it converted its bankruptcy case into a voluntary one. The company, which was forced into bankruptcy last week by a creditor, MatlinPatterson Global Advisors, said it filed a request to convert its bankruptcy to Chapter 11 in Miami. The company said it planned to continue seeking a new owner or investor. AT&T cut off financing to the unit in October, creating a $40 million gap.

headline: Photo Shops Find the Bright Side of Digital Technology
abstract: Photo shops, which many observers thought would go under with advent of digital photography, are finding niches in which they can survive, principally by persuading users of digitital cameras to have their prints done professionally; clunkiness of much photo-related software and rising use of digital cameras by women are among factors favoring photo shops; photo; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BANKER CAUTIOUS ON RATE CUT; BRITAIN: Barings Auditor Faulted; BRITAIN: Takeover Backing Withdrawn;.

headline: Interstate Bakeries Seeks New Loan Terms
abstract: By Bloomberg News.

headline: Market for Chinese-American Delicacy Plummets
abstract: Sale of squab, delicacy favored by Chinese-Americans, has dropped because of SARS epidemic; squab farmers in Modesto, Calif, are packing birds away in cold storage because fear of SARS has emptied most restaurants in San Francisco's Chinatown; photo (M)

headline: Executives Named To New Positions
abstract: Craig Middleton, chief marketing officer, is named to added post of chairman at Young & Rubicam Inc; Eddie Snyder is named executive vice president and chief creative officer at Fitzgerald & Co (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Ex-Minister Jailed
abstract: Former Egyptian Finance Minister Moheiddin el-Gharib is sentenced to eight years in prison for misuse of public funds (S)

headline: BILLIONAIRE'S BID FOR CIRCUIT CITY IS REJECTED
abstract: Telefonos de Mexico chairman Carlos Slim Helu makes $8-a-share offer to buy Circuit City Stores, but bid is rejected (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Interest Rate Cut
abstract: Norway's central bank cuts its benchmark deposit rate to five-year low of 4 percent from 5 percent (S)

headline: KB Home Reports 27% Rise in Profit
abstract: KB Home says second-quarter profit rose 27 percent, to $81.4 million; revenue rose 26 percent, to $1.44 billion (S)

headline: Former Executive at HealthSouth Pleads Guilty
abstract: Former HealthSouth chief financial officer Aaron Beam pleads guilty to bank fraud; becomes fifth chief financial officer to admit he conspired with Richard M Scrushy, who was fired as chief executive, in accounting fraud that prosecutors say inflated earnings by as much as $2.5 billion (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telephone Profit
abstract: Deutsche Telekom says first-quarter net profit was 850 million euros ($977 million), reversing loss of 1.8 billion euros year earlier; graph (S)

headline: Voyager to a Strange Planet
abstract: Article profiles Richard L Stenlund, who plays main character in multiplayer computer game Anarchy-Online; Stenlund explains attraction of participating in virtual world filled with intricate relationships; photos (M)

headline: 2 Towers Rise in Chicago Despite Weak Market
abstract: Hyatt Center in Chicago is being developed b partnership consisting of Pritzker family and Higgins Development Partners and 111 South Wacker building in Chicago is being constructed by John Buck Co despite weak office-building market; both buildings broke ground in last six months with Hyatt Center expected to be finished in late 2004 and 111 South Wacker in mid-2005; developer Hines Interests of Houston has announced tentative starting date later this year for third high-rise; map; photos (M)

headline: Editor Is Leaving Us Weekly to Try Her Hand at Tabloids
abstract: Bonnie Fuller resigns as editor in chief of Us Weekly and accepts post of editorial director of American Media, company that publishes supermarket tabloids like National Enquirer and that recently acquired group of health and fitness magazines; agrees to package worth more than $1 million, equity stake in company and bonuses for overall company performance on newsstands; American Media chief David J Pecker says his company's three tabloids lost million readers while Fuller was at Us Weekly; graph; photos (M)

headline: Proposal for 'Final and Comprehensive Settlement' to Middle East Conflict
abstract: Text of peace plan for Middle East offered by United States, European Union, Russia and United Nations (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen declines against dollar as US says North Korea acknowledges it has nuclear weapons; dollar settles at 120.35 yen, up from 119.95 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: Reebok and N.B.A. in Deal
abstract: Reebok International will manufacture and sell NBA jerseys, shorts and caps in Asia under five-year contract; financial terms undisclosed; some of clothing will be available in stores in China and Hong Kong this week and distribution will gradually be extended to other Asian markets like Japan and Taiwan (S)

headline: LONGTIME CHIEF AT APPLIED MATERIALS STEPS DOWN
abstract: Jim Morgan to retire as Applied Materials Inc chief executive and remain chairman; will be succeeded by Mike Splinter, who will also become president and join board (S)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: CONGO: New Constitution; KENYA: Moi Lets Go; MOROCCO: Sentences Cut For Metal Rockers;.

headline: House Adopts Global Plan Of $15 Billion Against AIDS
abstract: House adopts $15 billion initiative to combat AIDS worldwide after conservatives win requirement that at least one-third of money promotes sexual abstinence before marriage; vote is 375 to 41; proposal would almost triple federal spending over five years for fighting AIDS overseas, particularly in Africa; it received surprise endorsement from Pres Bush in his State of Union speech; Senate officials say they will consider similar proposal as early as next week (M)

headline: SARS Spreads in Taiwan; W.H.O. Plans Trip There
abstract: SARS appears to be spreading in Taiwan as fast or faster than anywhere except mainland China, prompting World Health Organization to prepare to send team there despite risk of creating diplomatic tensions with Beijing; Taiwan announces that it has 11 more confirmed cases, number that has more than tripled in last 10 days; five people die of SARS in Taiwan, raising its death toll to eight; chart shows outbreak in Taiwan; photo (M)

headline: International Speedway Trims Its Outlook
abstract: International Speedway Corp cuts its profit forecast fo rits current quarter (S)/

headline: Mobil Is Under Scrutiny in Bribe Inquiry
abstract: US attorney Peter Neiman says US government is investigating role of Mobil Oil, unit of Exxon Mobil, in what he says was scheme to bribe leaders of Kazakhstan for country's oil rights; Neiman's remarks come during court proceeding where oil consultant James Giffen pleads not guilty to charges he violated Foreign Corrupt Act by paying $78 million in bribes to Kazakh officials; prosecutors say Giffen made illegal payments to two senior government officials in six oil deals, including Mobil's purchase of stake in Tengiz field in Kazakhstan; Exxon denies any wrongdoing; J Bryan Williams, former Mobil executive who played important role in $1.05 billion Tengiz deal, was indicted April 2 on charges of tax evasion; is accused of concealing $2 million kickback that prosecutors say he received from Giffen; photo (M)

headline: Out of Argentina's Chaos, a Familiar Face Returns
abstract: Carlos Saul Menem, Argentina's former president, emerges as focal point of country's new presidential election and leads field in latest poll; promises to stabilize country, even though most independent economists see him as principal architect of Argentina's economic disaster; he is also putting himself forward as law and order candidate despite brush with law that got him put under house arrest in 2001; photos (M)

headline: MEDI-HUT HIRES AUDITOR TO REVIEW FINANCIAL REPORTS
abstract: Medi-Hut, maker of medical supplies whose headquarters were raided by federal agents in November, hires Eisner LLP as its auditor to review past financial reports; Eisner will audit Medi-Hut's full-year reports for 2001 and 2002, first- and second-quarter filings for last three years, and third-quarter results for 2002 and 2001; company was delisted from Nasdaq in March (S)

headline: Afghans Kill 40 Taliban Militants in Fierce Border Fights
abstract: Afghan government soldiers kill 40 Taliban fighters in three southern border villages; officials say this is one of deadliest instances of increased rebel activity this year; battle and high casualties are reminders of how serious threat of Taliban remains in Afghanistan; photo; map (M)

headline: Dell Names Agencies for Marketing
abstract: Dell has named agencies to handle direct-marketing duties on its account with billings estimated at $50 million.

headline: In Tough Venture Capital Climate, Women Feel the Chill
abstract: VentureOne study finds total vA

headline: For Late Taxpayers, Sooner Is Still Better
abstract: Internal Revenue Service is advising taxpayers who missed Apr 15 tax deadline to file as soon as possible and not become too upset; late filers who owe no taxes face no penalties; those who did not file because they lack money to pay back taxes can request installment plan (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: GLOBAL CHIP SALES ROSE IN FEBRUARY; ADVANCED MICRO AND FUJITSU WILL FORM COMPANY;.

headline: Beijing Journal; Sadly, There Goes the Neighborhood. There's No Stopping 'Urban Renewal.'
abstract: Residents of Beijing's Nanyingfang neighborhood, poor enclave near city's center that is to be razed to make way for luxury offices, apartments and malls, know that 'urban renewal' altering city landscape is unstoppable; worry about their compensation, where they will find new homes, and changesin social texture of their lives; photos (M)

headline: North Korea's Motives
abstract: North Korea said for the first time that it was seeking to develop nuclear weapons so it could reduce the size of a million-man army it can no longer afford.    Article, Page A10.

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: CISCO WILL SUPPLY GEAR TO BELLSOUTH; QWEST MAY INCREASE LOAN TO $1.5 BILLION;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer's Shares Surge
abstract: Shares of British reinsurer Benfield rise on first day of trading from 250 pence to as high as 298 pence, valuing company at $1.15 billion (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: More Runways Urged
abstract: BAA, which runs London's three biggest airports, urges authorities to build three new runways in southeast London to keep pace with expansion in air travel; government, which has forecast that number of people flying in and out of London area will almost triple to 300 million per year by 2030, is considering how to cope with increase (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Bailout Approved
abstract: Japanese government approves restructuring plan of Resona Holdings and Resona Bank, submitted as part of $16.7 billion bailout (S)

headline: Murdoch Cleared to Buy Italian TV Venture
abstract: European Commission says Rupert Murdoch can go ahead with his first major television venture in Continental Europe, takeover of Italian satellite broadcaster Telepiu; imposes what analysts call extremely tough conditions; News Corp, controlled by Murdoch, agreed last fall to buy Telepiu for $970 million from Vivendi Universal and merge it with Stream, rival Italian channel run as 50-50 joint venture of News Corp and Telecom Italia, dominant phone company in Italy; Stream and Telepiu will have virtually entire market for satellite pay TV in Italy; commission says new company, to be called Sky Italia, will have to sell its nonsatellite TV interests in Italy, and its ability to dictate both prices it pays for rights to movies and sports programming and rates it charges subscribers will be limited; conditions will remain in effect through 2011; Sky Italia will be prohibited from expanding its digital TV presence in Italy, and it must sell some broadcast frequencies to rival companies that are willing to provide pay TV services; photo (M)

headline: Nations Fail to Agree on Farm Subsidies
abstract: Negotiators fail to meet their deadline for figuring out how wealthy nations can reduce their huge agriculture subsidies, issue at heart of current round of talks at World Trade Organization; poorer nations were promised that this round of talks would especially benefit them and require first major reductions in what amounts to $300 billion a year in subsidies paid by world's richest nations to their farmers; Supachai Panitchpakdi, director general of WTO, Robert B Zoellick, US trade representative, and Franz Fischler, agriculture commissioner for European Union, are disappointed (M)

headline: Business; Crate and Barrel Handles Its Offshoot With Care
abstract: Crate and Barrel chief executive Gordon Segal discusses houseware retail chain's CB2 offspring, which has only one store, in Chicago, and focuses on younger customers, interview; views store as laboratory; privately-held Crate and Barrel has grown steadily, if not spectacularly, even during economic slumps; sales graph; photos (M)

headline: Afghan Authorities Arrest 5 Planning Bombing
abstract: The arrest underlined the continuing threat that the Taliban and their Al Qaeda connections remain to the fragile state of Afghanistan.

headline: Hong Kong to Set Up a Center To Conduct SARS Research
abstract: Hong Kong will establish regional medical surveillance and research center to study SARS and spot future illnesses before they can turn into epidemics, and will ask neighboring Guangdong Province to cooperate; Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, will ask Legislative Council for $64 million for research into infectious diseases; has been in detailed talks about SARS with Pres Hu Jintao and Prime Min Wen Jiabao of China and with Guangdong provincial leaders; World Health Orgn welcomes research initiative because Pearl River delta, which encompasses Hong Kong, Macao and much of Guangdong, has history of producing many of world's biggest pandemics; SARS is thought to have started in Guangdong; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Judges Move On Basque Party
abstract: Spanish Supreme Court moves to dissolve Sozialista Abertzaleak, party accused of links to Basque separatist group ETA, after Basque parliament refuses to act against party (S)

headline: On Baghdad TV, Images of Hussein Urging Iraqis to Fight
abstract: The White House said it did not matter if the footage was genuine or not, because the Iraqi leader will soon be history.

headline: Palestinian Doctor, Held by Israelis, Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: Prominent Palestinian psychologist Dr Fadel Abu Hein pleads not guilty to charges of weapons possession and incitement following destruction of family home in Gaza City and killing of three of his brothers by Israeli troops; Israel says he was linked to activities of his brothers, who were Hamas militants accused of smuggling arms (M)

headline: Employees of Baltimore Sun Approve a Labor Contract
abstract: Editorial and business employees of Baltimore Sun vote to accept four-year contract despite earlier announcement from Washington-Baltimore Newspaper Guild's bargaining committee that it could not recommend pact; pact goes into effect June 25 with one-time $1,500 signing bonus and 'pay for performance' raises partly replacing across-the-board pay increases for all employees; contract negotiations are first to take place in Baltimore since Tribune Co bought Sun and other Times Mirror newspapers across country in 2000; union members approve by acclamation resolution that harshly criticizes Tribune Co for its tactics during talks after voting for contract (M)

headline: Battlefield Aid for Soldiers' Battered Psyches
abstract: US military is undertaking its most aggressive effort ever to recognize and address combat-related stress among soldiers fighting in Iraq; it remains to be seen how many soldiers will ultimately suffer from protracted psychological problems, including post-traumatic stress disorder; Private Christopher Labier, who began experiencing symptoms of combat stress day after fighting stopped and is being treated in field, and others comment; photo (M)

headline: Winnie Mandela Guilty of Theft and Fraud; Faces Years in Jail
abstract: The former wife of Nelson Mandela fell to scandal today when she and a business associate were convicted of dozens of charges of theft and fraud.

headline: BUNGE SELLS A BUSINESS TO ITS DUPONT PARTNERSHIP
abstract: Bunge Ltd sells Brazilian business for $256 million to joint venture called Solae Co with DuPont Co, which sells soybean-based food ingredients; Bunge expects net gain of $111 million (S)

headline: Owner of Private Discipline Academy in Costa Rica Is Arrested
abstract: Narvin Lichfield, owner of American behavior modification program in Costa Rica housing nearly 200 American youths, is jailed on charges that students have been deprived of their civil liberties; lawyer charges Academy at Dundee Ranch holds children against their will and physically abuses them; girl, 14, who fled academy and returned home says staff members beat and physically restrain children who try to leave, phone interview; ranch and similar program in Jamaica, Tranquility Bay, are affiliated with World Wide Association of Specialty Programs and Schools, founded by Lichfield's brother, Robert; about 30 children were sent from Costa Rica to Jamaica this week after child welfare official visited ranch and told youths they could leave; previous probes have led to closings of association-affiliated programs in Mexico and Czech Republic (M)

headline: Martha Stewart Living Says Revenue Fell 14% in the Quarter
abstract: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia reports first-quarter loss of 9 cents a share, down from earnings of 8 cents a share in 2002 period, as probes into Imclone stock sales by chairman Martha Stewart continue; predicts continued losses in second quarter; total revenue fell 14.6 percent, to $58 million (M)

headline: Idec to Merge With Biogen in $6.8 Billion Deal
abstract: Idec Pharmaceuticals will acquire Biogen in stock swap valued at $6.8 billion; merged company would be third-largest biotechnology company with annual rvenue of $1.55 billion based on 2002 results and research budget of $550 million (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: A Mixed Report From Sega
abstract: Sega Corp eearned 3.05 billion yen ($26 million) in year ended March 31, rebounding from loss year earlier; sales fell 4.4 percent and pretax profits fell 38 percent; president Hideki Sato comments; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Puma Stake Sold
abstract: Monarch Enterprise Holdings sells its 40 percent ownership, worth more than $600 million, of German sporting goods maker Puma; graph of Puma share price (S)

headline: Takeover Turmoil in Business Software Has Users Concerned
abstract: Business software customers are concerned about possibility that Oracle Corp will attempt hostile takeover of PeopleSoft, putting J D Edwards merger in doubt; Oracle's chief executive Lawrence J Ellison has not made any definite statements about whether he wants to acquire J D Edwards along with PeopleSoft; has said that Oracle would eliminate PeopleSoft product line; some corporate managers hope they are not left owning orphaned software; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: John Lennon's Modest Beginnings, Now on Show in Liverpool
abstract: The National Trust has John Lennon's childhood home in Liverpool, to the public for the first time.

headline: Marsh Arabs Cling to Memories of a Culture Nearly Crushed by Hussein
abstract: Marsh Arabs, Iraqis who live where Tigris and Euphrates rivers merge, saw their culture destroyed by Saddam Hussein; he systematically set about exterminating them in his effort to crush any opposition to his rule and to punish Shiite Muslims for rising up against his government in 1991; drained wetlands, set reeds on fire and executed thousands of residents; now, with Hussein's government toppled, people of this part of Iraq are left with only memories and fear that their way of life has been lost forever; photo; map (M)

headline: India Announces Steps in Effort To End Its Conflict With Pakistan
abstract: Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee says India will restore diplomatic and air links with Pakistan in his last effort at peace; hints moves could be first steps of more ambitious effort; breaks 16-month stalemate that began after Dec 2001 attack on Indian Parliament that India blamed on Pakistani support for Islamic insurgency in Kashmir; Min Mian Khursheed Mehmood Kasuri says Pakistan will also upgrade diplomatic ties and is ready to start talks on all outstanding issues, including that of Jammu and Kashmir; State Sec Colin L Powell hails Vajpayee's move; photo (M)

headline: Casualties
abstract: Tally of US, British and Iraqi casualties as of April 3

headline: 11th-Hour Union Vote Keeps American Afloat
abstract: American Airlines avoid bankruptcy filing after flight attendants' union agrees to $340 million in wage and benefit cuts; agreement comes one day after American's former chairman-chief executive Donald J Carty resigned because of criticism over executive benefits; Transporation Department files complaint against airline, accusing it of discriminating against passengers thought to be Muslims or of Middle East or Southeast Asian descent in three and half months after Sept 11, 2001 terrorist attacks; airline denies charges and says its crew members are trying to be vigilant; wage and benefit cuts from unions go into effect on May 1; Association of Professional Flight Attendants president John Ward comments; photos (M)

headline: MONSANTO SAYS FIRST-QUARTER PROFIT TOPPED FORECAST
abstract: Monsanto Co says first-quarter profit is higher than forecast (S)0

headline: Bremer Says U.S. Is Tackling Security Problem in Baghdad
abstract: About 300 violent criminals have been arrested in the last 48 hours as part of a security clampdown, the new American administrator for Iraq said today.

headline: Chrysler Ends Plan to Build Canada Plant
abstract: DaimlerChrysler cancels plans to build $1.5 billion assembly plant in Windsor, Ontario, that would have produced new line of small pickups under innovative manufacturing arrangement with suppliers; Canadian Auto Workers Union says Canadian government and province of Ontario did not provide enough financial support for project; photo (M)

headline: W.H.O. Scientists Say Tactics To Fight Virus Are Working
abstract: Scientists brought together by World Health Organization to review data on SARS say existing public health measures have been effective in containing it in many countries and should work in China and Taiwan, where virus is concentrated; detection and treatment of suspected cases as soon as they are identified and then quarantining contacts is essential; message from meeting is hopeful; there is no evidence that animals or insects are spreading disease; information at meeting about super-spreaders discussed; photo (M)

headline: Coaster With a Message: Your Table Is Ready
abstract: IT'S early on a Wednesday night and the wait for a table at Jaleo, a popular Washington tapas restaurant, is 20 minutes and growing. Along the bar, customers line up three deep for pitchers of sangria.      Almost to the beat of the flamenco music in the background, red lights flash on top of the bar. It's not a light show, but rather a signal that the next table is ready for the lucky person holding the pulsating light.

headline: Earnings More Than Triple at Travelers
abstract: Travelers Property Casualty Corp's first-quarter profits more than triple results from year-earlier quarter; net income was $340 milion compared with $102.1 million (S)

headline: W.H.O. Expected to Gain Broader Powers
abstract: World Health Organization's 192 member nations are expected to grant it sweeping new powers to respond to international health threats such as SARS and bioterrorist attacks; new powers including setting up communications network, tapping reliable unofficial sources of information and sending own teams to see how countries are responding to outbreaks (S)

headline: Wave of Strikes Leaves Much of Western Europe Crippled
abstract: Protesting workers in France and Austria shut down subway systems, ports, trains, toll roads, and airlines.

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: BOLIVIA: Hopes Fade For Mudslide Victims; MEXICO: Suspected Drug Kingpin Held;.

headline: Mass Grave in Iraq May Hold Kuwaitis Missing Since 1991
abstract: Bodies being unearthed from mass grave at abandoned Iraqi military camp in Habbaniya, Iraq, may be corpses of Kuwaitis missing since end of 1991 Persian Gulf War; for past 12 years, Kuwait has demanded to know fate of nearly 600 prisoners taken by Saddam Hussein's security forces after country was invaded by Iraq in 1990; photo (M)

headline: In the Army, Wallets Are Thin
abstract: Challenger, Gray & Christmas study finds military personnel earn far less than most people in private sector; military pay graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Orders Boeings
abstract: Boeing Co beats rival Airbus for order worth as much as $2.25 billion for 45 single-aisle jetliners from All Nippon Airways; planes will replace third of carrier's fleet (S)

headline: Signs of Slower Growth In Consumer Spending
abstract: Deloitte Research April consumer spending index indicates consumers are planning to increase their spending at 5.8 percent annual rate, down from 6.2 percent in March and 7 percent in Feb (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: I.B.M. Beats Oracle In 2002 Database Sales
abstract: Gartner Inc says IBM beat Oracle as top seller of database software last year; IBM's share of $6.63 billion market for relational database programs rose to 36 percent in 2002 from 34 percent in 2001; Oracle's portion slipped to 34 percent from 40 percent; Microsoft Corp's share grew to 18 percent from 14 percent; total market fell by 6.9 percent (S)

headline: Royal Ahold to Sell Its South American Businesses
abstract: Royal Ahold plans to sell its South American businesses, including Argentine store chain Disco where some of its financial problems arose, to raise cash and reduce debt; will sell 429 supermarkets in Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Peru; is already in talks to sell its Chilean stores to Cencosud, local group, where accounting scandal at company became public Feb 24; market interest so far is focusing on units that are seen as crown jewels in Ahold's Latin crown--Bom Preco and G Barbosa chains in Brazil and Disco; photo (M)

headline: What Drove 2 Britons to Bomb a Club in Tel Aviv?
abstract: In Derby, Eng, where many Pakistanis live, older Pakistani population cannot begin to fathom what changed Omar Khan Sharif, well-educated, thoroughly Westernized young man who went from Derby to Tel Aviv to carry out suicide bombing in nightclub on Apr 30; younger Pakistanis, by way of explaining Sharif's possible motives, say some people take Islam more seriously than others; say killing is wrong, but if it is done for God, then it is fair; those who knew Sharif recall that in recent years he began spending more time with local representatives of Al Muhajiroun, group that in 2000 held rally through streets of Normanton, Eng, with placards urging killing of Jews; photos; map; graph (L)

headline: U.S. Struggles to Transform A Tainted Iraqi Police Force
abstract: United States is endeavoring to rebuild Iraq's police force, effort led by former New York City police commissioner Bernard B Kerik amid growing security concerns; even as they start trying to teach democratic policing, Americans are confronting both basic problems like how to set pay levels and get the money, and larger ones like how to identify and purge former Baath Party members from force; superiors are grappling with insubordination in ranks, while officers on street are facing defiance from public; hastily assembled effort and broad administrative problems seem to reflect sketchiness of planning for postwar Iraq; photos (M)

headline: Business; A Deft (Some Say Heavy) Hand in the Kitchen
abstract: Profile of Sysco Corp, No. 1 food service company in America, distributing more than 300,000 products -- from haricot beans to hairnets -- to restaurants, hospitals, hotels and motels, schools and colleges; discusses impressive growth, largely favorable standing among securities analysts and complaints from restaurateurs about its heavy-handed sales and collection practices; says chief potential threat to continued growth would be if Wal-Mart were to undertake major expansion of its McLane Foodservice unit; photos (M)

headline: CONTEMPORARY ART:A SPECIAL REPORT : An expansion of museums in U.S.
abstract: NEW YORK—  Despite drastic cutbacks in government and private funding for nonprofit institutions, Contemporary art aficionados have reason to celebrate with the opening or expansion of several Contemporary art museums in the United States.

headline: Bush's Smooth Landing Is Followed by Turbulence
abstract: White House spokesman Ari Fleischer spends much of morning with reporters attempting to refute acccusations that Pres Bush delayed arrival of aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln and added to government's projected deficit so he could land on carrier deck to declare end of military action in Iraq; claims that ship arrived exactly on schedule; Democrats accuse Bush administration of seeking to use occasion as photo opportunity that will be used during Bush's re-election campaign; excerpts from encounter with reporters; photo (M)

headline: 2 Russian Oil Companies Said to Be Near Merger Deal
abstract: Owners of Russia's largest oil company Yukos and fifth-biggest Russian oil producer Sibneft are close to merger deal that would create one of world's largest petroleum companies (M)

headline: Indonesia Willing to Reopen Aceh Talks, but Sets Tough Terms
abstract: The Indonesian government said today that it was willing to resume peace talks with Aceh Province separatists that broke down late last week.

headline: Israelis and Palestinians Pressed To Compromise in Mideast Talks
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell joins with top European, Arab and United Nations diplomats to press for concessions in peace talks between Israel and Palestinians even as violence in Gaza Strip leaves four Palestinians dead; frustrated diplomats say that prior to latest deaths in Gaza, negotiators had made some progress in their talks over transferring security in most of Gaza Strip from Israel to Palestinian Authority; Powell, attending World Economic Forum at Shuneh, Jordan, expresses mild but unmistakable criticism of Israel's killing of top Hamas leader Abdullah Qawasmeh, saying it could be 'impediment to progress'; his terse remark comes two weeks after Pres Bush rebukes Israel for attempt to kill another Hamas leader, saying it undercut peace talks; Powell and others exhort Palestinians to take action to stop attacks on Israeli soldiers and citizens; Powell makes emotional appeal for restraint by both Palestinians and Israelis (M)

headline: Marriott Wins Round in Suit Filed by Hotels In New Orleans
abstract: Civil District Court Judge Roland L Belsome declines to issue temporary restraining order against Marriott International to prevent it from managing luxury property in New Orleans; ruling is setback for owners of three nearby luxury hotels that have accused Marriott competing unfairly; Whitehouse Hotel Limited Partnership and related entity W H Holdings filed lawsuit in April against Marriott and its unit Ritz-Carlton Hotel Co LLC; contended that Marriott's management of former New Orleans Grand Hotel under its luxury J W Marriott flag would financially imperil their own properties, Maison Orleans, Ritz-Carlton New Orleans and Iberville Suites (M)

headline: Barclays Agrees to Buy Spanish Bank In Cash Deal
abstract: Barclays Bank will pay 1.143 billion euros ($1.31 billion) in cash for Spain's Banco Zaragozano (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Internet
abstract: STAMPS.COM FILES BREACH OF CONTRACT SUIT AGAINST EBAY; GATES SEEKS MEASURES TO FIGHT SPAM;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: U.S. Accuses Hynix Of Being Unfairly Subsidized
abstract: Commerce Department says Hynix Semiconductor is unfairly subsidized by South Korean government; rules in favor of claim by Micron Technology that Hynix received loans and guarantees from government-backed lenders that allowed company to undercut foreign rivals (S)

headline: Bush Plans to Ask U.N. to Lift Penalties Against Iraq in Phases
abstract: Bush administration officials say United States will ask United Nations to lift international penalties against Iraq in phases, retaining UN supervision of Iraq's oil sales for now but gradually transferring other parts of its economy to new Iraqi authority assembled with US guidance; say US will seek three or four Security Council resolutions over several months to lift sanctions; seek to counter efforts by France, Russia and other Council members to link lifting of sanctions to broader role for UN (M)

headline: In London, a Low-Key Celebration of Queen's 50-Year Reign
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II returned today to Westminster Abbey, the shrine where she received her crown five decades ago.

headline: Thousands Riot in Rural Chinese Town Over SARS
abstract: Residents of Chagugang ransacked a building because they believed that it would be turned into a ward for SARS patients.

headline: Writer of 'The West Wing' Is Resigning From the Show
abstract: Aaron Sorkin, head writer and executive producer of NBC series The West Wing, announces he is quitting show; program's leader director and executive producer Thomas Schlamme is also leaving; series will be taken over by another executive producer John Wells (M)

headline: Bush Proposes Free Trade Zone for Middle East
abstract: President Bush, continuing to wield diplomatic leverage gained from a decisive victory in Iraq, proposed a new free trade zone for the Middle East.

headline: No Room in Iraq's Government for Baath Leaders, Pentagon Says
abstract: The Pentagon emphasized today that high-ranking officials of Saddam Hussein's ruling party will not be allowed any role in governing the new Iraq.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Whitbread'S Profit Rises; GERMANY: Ex-Executive Wins Civil Case; DRUG MAKER'S PROFIT FALLS;.

headline: Number of Cases in Taiwan May Be More Than Reported
abstract: World Health Orgn officials say outbreak of SARS in Taiwan is being inaccurately counted and is probably much bigger than reported; official Taiwan tally is 264 cases with 34 deaths; Dr Lee Ming-liang, former health minister leading fight against epidemic, says Taiwan would conform to WHO standards in reporting outbreak, and that when it does, there may be many more probable cases; disease has spread to another major hospital in Taipei, infecting 7 doctors and nurses said to be wearing full infection gear, and ambulance drivers, one of whom dies (M)

headline: British Soldiers' Long Battle for a Southern City's Trust Requires Bullets and Handshakes
abstract: British troops in Iraq move only about two miles closer to Basra after more than week of fighting along highway south of city; are content to stay outside city proper to avoid costly street-by-street fighting; appear to be gaining trust of people of Basra; photo (M)

headline: Affirmative Action: A Corporate Diary
abstract: In the wake of last week's Supreme Court decision, seven executives talked about the role of affirmative action in their careers.

headline: G.I.'s Move in Strength Against Afghan Rebels
abstract: American forces begin large-scale operation in Shahikot Mountains in southeastern Afghanistan to flush out Al Qaeda fighters; photo (S)

headline: Assessment of Iraq War Will Emphasize Joint Operations
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld gives Adm Edmund P Giambastiano, who leads Joint Forces Command based in Norfolk, Va, task of compiling 'lessons learned' from war in Iraq; this is departure from usual practice of having four military services assess what went well and what did not; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toyota To Increase Output
abstract: Toyota Motor Co will increase production capacity in France and Britain to expand its sales in Europe; move will create 1,500 new jobs and expand output by 26 percent at two plants (S)

headline: STARBUCKS AGREES TO ACQUIRE SEATTLE COFFEE COMPANY
abstract: Starbucks to acquire Seattle Coffee Co from AFC Enterprises Inc for $72 million in cash and stock; would own Seattle's Best and Torrefazione Italia Coffee brands, 129 Seattle's Best coffee shops and 21 Torrefazione coffee shops (S)

headline: Israeli Trial of a Leading Palestinian Opens With Defiance
abstract: Trial of Marwan Barghouti, most prominent Palestinian politician in Israeli custody, begins in Jerusalem with defendant refusing to address murder charges against him and Palestinian witnesses refusing to testify; Israel accuse him of masterminding attacks that killed 26 Israelis; he claims he is politician being tried illegally; he is member of Palestinian parliament and leader in West Bank of Yasir Arafat's Fatah movement; Israeli officials say they can prove his involvement in terrorism, and through him, directly link Arafat to such violence; photo (M)

headline: Cable Operator Near Terms To Accept Chairman's Loan
abstract: Charter Communications is close to announcing that it has arranged mechanism for accepting $300 million loan from chairman Paul G Allen; agreement would let Charter create special holding company to borrow from Allen (M)

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: U.S. Military Releases 927 Prisoners Captured in Iraq
abstract: Most of those released were civilians who were somehow caught up in the fighting, not members of the Iraqi military. There are 6,850 Iraqis still in custody.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Cuts For Carmaker
abstract: Volkswagen AG chief executive Bernd Pischetsrieder says cost reductions are needed at company as economic growth in company's main markets stagnates; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Holding Company Regroups
abstract: South Korea's SK Group will disband central office through which its jailed chairman Chey Tae Won has long controlled his holdings; also pledges to reorganize conglomerate around two central companies, SK Corp and SK Telecom; SK Corp's chief financial officer Yu Jeong Jun says company expects net pretax loss of more than $400 million after exchanging for equity more than $700 million debt owed by SK Global (S)

headline: 2 Newsday Journalists Missing Since March 24 Say They Are Safe
abstract: Two Newsday journalists who had been missing from their hotel in Baghdad since March 24 called the newspaper early this afternoon to say that they were safe and about to travel into Jordan from Iraq, a spokesman for the newspaper said.

headline: Private Sector; A Former Nurse Is on the Case
abstract: Profile of United States Atty Alice H Martin, former nurse who is prosecuting case against HealthSouth, chain of rehabilitation hospitals and surgery centers; she has rapidly wrested guilty pleas from 11 top HealthSouth employees; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: GUATEMALA: Mayor Arrested In Political Killing; GUATEMALA: Colonel Freed In Activist'S Death; BRAZIL: First Black Supreme Court Judge; CANADA: High Court;.

headline: A Saudi Editor Who Offended Clerics Is Ousted From His Post
abstract: Saudi Arabia, in first sign that it has already wearied of public debate that followed May 12 suicide bombings, orders removal of Jamal A Kashoggi as editor in chief of Al Watan, newspaper that has spoken out against Islamic militancy; move dismays those who believe religious institutions propagate extremist ideas; members of religious establishment feel vindicated; paper, partly owned by prominent descendants of late King Faisal, has been leading voice calling for openness and reform in kingdom; opened unprecedented petition on its Web site asking rulers to curb extremist religious discourse (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: AOL Sues Five Over Unsolicited E-Mail
abstract: America Online files suit agi

headline: Heavy Fighting For Desert Base At Syria Border
abstract: Military officials say some of heaviest fighting in Iraq is in Qaim, on Syrian border, where American Green Berets and British commandos have been attacking units of Iraq's Special Republican Guard and Special Security Services for last three weeks; say Iraqi forces are defending large compound that includes phosphate fertilizer and water treatment plants; say sheer tenacity of Iraqi fighters has led them to suspect that they may be defending Scud missiles or other illicit weapons, or members of Iraqi leadership trying to flee to Syria; Qaim area was launching point for Iraqi ballistic missile attacks during Persian Gulf war; it was also home to plant used by Iraq in 1980's for uranium processing, and has been identified by American officials as possible site for any effort to revive Iraq's nuclear weapons program; Pentagon officials report making contact with one Iraqi commander in Qaim area in effort to negotiate surrender, but that attempt has failed (M)

headline: DOW CHEMICAL SECURES GAS DEAL WITH ENERGY COMPANY
abstract: Dow Chemical reaches agreement to gain access in 2007 to one-third capacity of liquefied natural gas terminal under development by Freeport LNG Development on Quintana Island, Tex (S)

headline: U.S. Suggests a Qaeda Cell in Iran Directed Saudi Bombings
abstract: US intercepts communications strongly suggesting that small cell of Al Qaeda leaders in Iran directed recent terrorist attacks in Saudi Arabia, and US lodges strong protest with Iran; US is said to have hard intelligence that at least dozen Qaeda figures are in Iran, including Saif al-Adel and Osama bin Laden's son, Saad bin Laden; Sec Donald Rumsfeld comments; photos (M)

headline: Group Says Iran Has 2 Undisclosed Nuclear Laboratories
abstract: Iranian opposition group says it has evidence of two previously undisclosed uranium enrichment facilities west of Tehran; claim, if proven, might add to Bush administration's argument that Iran is violating its commitment not to produce nuclear weapons; group, National Council of Resistance of Iran, is umbrella for Iranian opposition organizations; it says facilities were discovered by People's Mujahedeen, resistance group that brought larger nuclear facility in Natanz to attention of international weapons inspectors; in gesture toward Iran, Bush administration has classified People's Mujahedeen as terrorist group; but American military officials have also signed cease-fire with People's Mujahedeen fighters based in Iraq (M)

headline: W.H.O. Team Visits Hospital in Beijing to Investigate Disease
abstract: World Health Organization team visits Beijing hospital in effort to clear up swirl of questions and rumors about prevalence of respiratory illness SARS in city; only 22 cases of disease and 4 deaths from it have been publicly recorded in city, but figures for Beijing and several other Chinese cities have been widely questioned, and WHO officials describe uncertainty about course of SARS in China as major global worry (M)

headline: More Violence On Both Sides As Cease-Fire Is Awaited
abstract: Palestinian officials say they are finishing details of three-month suspension of all violence against Israelis; Palestinian militant groups increase their attacks and Israeli forces kill three members of militant group Hamas in Gaza City; Palestinian youth shoots and kills telephone company technician on job in Israeli Arab village of Baka el Gharbiya; Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades claims responsibility; group is linked to mainstream Fatah faction of Yasir Arafat, and of Palestinian Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas, who is pressing for cease-fire; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Disease Outbreak Confirmed
abstract: Japanese encephalitis outbreak in Guangdong Province (China) is confirmed as regional authorities announce 18 deaths and 211 cases of disease; secrecy about outbreak, reminiscent of regional confusion regarding SARS outbreak, has caused Hong Kong officials to be concerned (S)

headline: Coca-Cola to Expand College Sports Ties
abstract: Coca-Cola Co, in effort to expand its marketing presence in college sports programming, tentatively agrees to invest in and form marketing partnership with College Sports Television, new cable network; agreement includes $10 million ownership stake in company for Coca-Cola and $5 million marketing package that could include activities like advertising, special events and other entertainment; Coca-Cola will also sponsor network's Sunday night lineup of Notre Dame sports programming, scheduled for fall (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Mercury Shares Plunge On Earnings Forecast
abstract: Technology Briefing: Mercury Shares Plunge on Earnings Forecast**n

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HIGH RIVER LP, the investment company controlled by Carl C. Icahn, extended its $100-per-unit cash offer for Hallwood Realty Partners LP, Dallas, owner of 5.1 million square feet of office and industrial properties, to June 12.    GREKA ENERGY CORP., New York, an oil and natural gas producer, said its chief executive, Randeep S. Grewal, had agreed to buy the 86 percent of the company he did not already own for about $26.1 million.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Retail Sales Fall
abstract: Hong Kong government reports retail sales in April declined 15.2 percent from year earlier, steepest decline in four years (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cordiant Holder Near 25%
abstract: Active Value Fund Managers, lar

headline: E-Commerce Report; Nonprofit groups are slowly learning the benefits -- to services and fund-raising -- of being wired.
abstract: Vast majority of nonprofit groups remain unwired despite cost efficiencies that Internet and other technologies can deliver; only 5 percent of 200,000 largest nonprofits in US use World Wide Web to solicit donations; emergence of affordable technology assistance for second- and third-tier organizations is seen as key to increasing level of technology usage; photo (M)

headline: Large airlines, faced with their worst of times, have stepped up advertising despite the war.
abstract: Airlines are slowly beginning to step up advertising despite war in Iraq, because war may be least of their problems; industry is suffering through what is widely considered worst time in its history; advance domestic bookings have fallen 20 percent from year ago (M)

headline: American Airlines Unions Vote Today on Concessions
abstract: Three major unions at American Airlines will conclude voting on concessions by morning of April 15 and try to get results to company before 11 am in Texas, deadline that American has set to get vote tally; company will file bankruptcy protection 'very soon' if votes are not counted by then, or if any labor group votes down concessions; photo of chief executive Donald J Carty (M)

headline: Beijing and Caspian Oil Fields
abstract: China's bid to join in development of rich oil and gas fields in Kazakhstan stands good chance of being thwarted by existing partners in project; rather than allow two Chinese state-controlled oil companies to buy one-sixth interest held by BG Group of Britain in North Caspian Sea oil development project, BG's partners will probably exercise their first-refusal rights and buy stake themselves; CNOOC Ltd agreed on March 7 to pay $615 million for half of BG Group's stake, or one-twelfth of total; Sinpoec Group agreed to same terms for other half on March 11; both are controlled by Chinese government, though CNOOC Ltd is publicly traded; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Telecom Shares Sold
abstract: Taiwan sells 21 percent of total shares on offer on fifth and final day of auction of stake in Chunghwa Telecom, island's former telephone monopoly, after it lowers its minimum acceptable bid by 2 percent (S)

headline: $1.6 Billion Deal Creates Area's 2nd-Biggest S.&L.
abstract: New York Community Bancorp will acquire Roslyn Bancorp for $1.6 billion; deal will create second-largest savings and loan associations in New York area (M)

headline: U.S. Left Out of Emissions Trading
abstract: US is being left out of emissions trading; US preached importance of market solution to reduce greenhouse gas emissions during negotiations over Kyoto Protocol; Canada ratified treaty in December, meaning plan to reduce greenhouse gases is one nation shy of becoming law in more than 100 countries; heart of treaty is emissions-trading plan that closely resembles what US originally proposed; Steve Drummond, managing director of greenhouse gas brokerage in London calls CO2e.com, says Europe can dominate emissions trading market now that Americans are out; David Doniger, former Kyoto treaty negotiator under Pres Bill Clinton, says when Pres Bush pulled out in cavalier way he did, he galvanized everyone around world to make it work; photo (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Shopping sites are offering plans that automatically send customers the routine purchases of life.
abstract: Small but growing number of online retailers are introducing so-called auto-replenishment programs, in which customers sign up for periodic shipments of goods they use routinely; programs require finesse on part of retailers, who must accurately determine customers' needs and decide whether to give them option of skipping shipment; programs offer retailers both revenue stream and customers who become less likely to return products; operations of HSN.com's program described; photos (M)

headline: Interrupting a Web Search to Take a Quick Call
abstract: Not long ago, you had to choose between access to the Internet or the telephone if you didn{+rsquo}t want to shell out extra cash for a second phone line. Then D.S.L. allowed you to have both voice and data on one line, though for a price. Next came subscription call-waiting services for Internet users. Now a small device called Catch-A-Call offers an inexpensive alternative. Four models ranging in price from $49.99 to $89.99 are available at www.catch-a.

headline: 'Mr. Cartier' Retiring From Swiss Parent Group
abstract: Richemont chief exï

headline: Tales of Iraqis' Silent Suffering Now Find Voices
abstract: Cemetery in Najaf, Iraq, expanded to eight times its previous size in one decade to accommodate casualties of war and repression during Saddam Hussein's rule; people of Najaf are only now able to recount events of those years to outsiders, about bloodshed they witnessed and bullet-torn bodies they helped bury in unmarked graves; one keeper of graveyard describes 'days of chaos' in 1991, when Shiite Muslims launched rebellion against Hussein and Iraqi soldiers pursued them into cemetery, taking 15 days to find them and shoot them to death; photos; map (M)

headline: Loss Widens as Softbank Spends Heavily
abstract: Softbank Corp, Japanes telecommunications and Internet holding company, reports net loss of 100 billion yen ($833 million) for fiscal year ended Mar 31, up from loss of 88.7 billion yen a year ago; photo (M)

headline: F.D.A. Approves Over-Counter Sales Of Top Ulcer Drug
abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves over-the-counter sales of Prilosec, top-selling prescription medicine for ulcers and heartburn; Prilosec, made by AstraZeneca, is expected to sell for less than $1 a pill this fall, compared with $4 a pill now; few consumers with health insurance will see any savings since plans do not cover over-the-counter drugs; people without insurance or on Medicare, which does not cover prescription drugs, stand to save hundreds of dollars a year; health insurers may respond by making similar prescription drugs, like Nexium, Prevacid, Protonix and Aciphex, more expensive or harder to obtain; Prilosec and similar drugs, known as proton-pump inhibitors, had $13 billion in sales last year, more than any other class of drugs; photo; chart (L)

headline: Lehman's Earnings Top Analysts' Predictions
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc says profit increased 48 percent in second quarter, to $437 million; revenue rose 38 percent, to record $2.3 billion (M)

headline: South Africa Faces Test As Zimbabwe Deteriorates
abstract: Situation in Zimbabwe continues to deteriorate, yet South Africa has done little to defuse situation despite having much to lose if its neighbor descends into chaos; South African Pres Thabo Mbeki has been largely silent, engaging in quiet and polite diplomacy with Zimbabwean Pres Robert Mugabe and predicting solution to crisis will somehow emerge (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Export Decline Forecast
abstract: Australian government predicts commodity exports will decline about 5 percent in 2003-4; says farm and mineral exports are expected to decline to 82.8 billion Australian dollars ($55.3 billion) from 87 billion Australian dollars last year; value of agricultural shipments are expected to drop 5.3 percent with similar decline in exports by mineral sector (S)

headline: U.S. Returns Five Captured Border Guards to Syria
abstract: The failure to return the men quickly, even though some were wounded in a raid last week, came to be a diplomatic irritant.

headline: Marines Met Little Resistance From Republican Guard
abstract: American marines advanced to the Baghdad city limits today, meeting scant resistance, and stopped at the brink of entry, awaiting orders.

headline: At 10,000 Feet, Can a Fire-Spotting Camera Discriminate?
abstract: Finding fire that is still in formative stage is considered crucial to limiting its damage; current fire-spotting cameras have tendency to generate false alarms; Donald McKeown and Michael Richardson of Rochester Institute of Technology introduce airborne array of four digital cameras that they plan to begin testing this summer; they say array will overcome several significant problems with current aerial camera systems and distinguish fires as small as one foot across from height of 10,000 feet; diagram (M)

headline: An Electronic Tag for the Peripatetic Pet
abstract: Microchip implants are effective in tracing lost pets but many owners are resistant to having procedure done; humane societies and animal shelters have embraced chips as effective alternative to other identification devices; photos; chip makers and registries noted (M)

headline: Iran Is Said to Have New Nuclear Plans
abstract: A report from the International Atomic Energy Agency says Iran is planning nuclear facilities that could give it new options for producing nuclear arms.    The report concludes in part that ''Iran has failed to meet its obligations'' to fully declare the extent of its nuclear program. That could give the Bush administration more ammunition in its efforts to elicit international condemnation for Iran, which insists that its nuclear program is for energy only.

headline: WorldCom Files Plans For Next Life
abstract: WorldCom Inc, which filed for bankruptcy-protection in July, files reorganization plan that envisions it emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection this year; also plans to change its name to MCI, name of residential long-distance company it purchased in 1998; names Robert Blakely as chief financial officer; will move its headquarters to Ashburn, Va, from Clinton, Miss; chief executive Michael D Capellas comments (M)

headline: Film Rentals Via the Web: A Studio Cut
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on drawbacks of downloading and watching movies on PC; discusses pros and cons of movielink.com and cinemanow.com, sites that offer downloadable movies; drawing (M)

headline: Casualties
abstract: Daily tally of those killed, captured or missing in Iraq war (S)

headline: Iraqi Politicians to Issue a Protest of Occupation Rule
abstract: Iraq's main political groups draft document protesting to US and British over plans to declare occupation authority that would delay turnover of sovereignty to interim Iraqi government; British envoy David Manning promises to take written protests to Prime Min Tony Blair and emphasizes that allies want to leave as soon as possible (M)

headline: Reported Asian SARS Cases Continue to Fall
abstract: Fewer than two dozen new cases of SARS were reported in Asia today as the disease appeared to recede further in the region.

headline: New Orleans Hotel Owners Sue Ritz-Carlton and Marriott
abstract: Owners of three hotels in New Orleans by Ritz-Carlton sue Ritz-Carlton and its owner Marriott International, accusing them of financial mismanagement and deceptive business practices; suit, filed by Whitehouse Hotel Limited Partnerhips and related entity W H Holdings, also seeks temporary restraining order against Marriott to prevent it from taking over management of New Orleans Grand Hotel, which is separately owned; Marriott in coming weeks plans to operate hotel under its luxury J W Marriott; Whitehouse Hotel and W H Holdings own Iberville Suites and Maison Orleans hotels in area; Ritz-Carlton Hotel Co also manages those two hotels, although Ibervile Suites does not use Ritz brand name; W H and Whitehouse Hotel accuse companies of mismanaging their properties to increase Marriott's profits, and not their own, as they say Ritz-Carlton has fiduciary responsibility to do under its management contracts (M)

headline: Personal Business; Slowing Down the Treadmill, With Help
abstract: Increasin

headline: Strike in Zimbabwe Shuts Businesses, Imperiling the Economy
abstract: Most major businesses in Zimbabwe shut down in support of three-day strike called to protest government's decision to triple price of gasoline; strike is latest blow to already imperiled economy and latest political challenge to beleaguered Pres Robert Mugabe (M)

headline: Hollywood Defections Leave Agency Low on Tinsel
abstract: Julia Robert's decision to move to Creative Artists Agency from International Creative Management, which has represented her since 1991, is big blow for ICM, particularly because it comes on heels of other defections, including moves by actresses Cameron Diaz and Lucy Liu to Creative Artists and by director Neil Jordan to Wlliam Morris Agency; ICM remains a top talent agency, but some Hollywood executives say it has not been same since its former co-chairman, James Wiatt, left in 1999 to head William Morris and took several agents with him; economic pressures are making talent agency business trickier than ever; photos (M)

headline: Mad Cow Disease Is Found in Canada; U.S. Imposes a Ban
abstract: The Canadian government announced today that an 8-year-old cow in Alberta had tested positive for mad cow disease.

headline: Paraguay's Election Features Novel Issue: Reform
abstract: Pedro Fadul, successful businessman and leading opposition candidate in Paraguay's presidential election, is running on anti-corruption, pro-reform ticket, contrary to trend in most of Latin America; his Beloved Homeland movement is so new it lacks status as political party; poor, landlocked country has been ruled by Colorado Party since 1947, world record for single party, and Fadul says it is 'most entrenched and corrupt' anywhere (M)

headline: Our Entertainment Diet
abstract: Cellphone makers are spurring consumers to use more sophisticated devices. Plus: the most popular movies, CD's, magazines and software.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Synopsys Posts 2nd-Quarter Profit
abstract: Synopsys Inc says earnings rose 4.3 percent in its second quarter ended May 3; net income increased to $22.3 million from $21.4 million year earlier; sales rose 57 percent, to $292 million from $185.6 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: A Takeover Offer
abstract: French engineering company Alstom says it received takeover offer from unknown Dutch investor called MJ Global Acquisition valued at $763.5 million; spokesman says offer could be joke (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sirius Satellite Names Financial Chief
abstract: Sirius Satellite Radio appoints David J Frear chief financial officer, succeeding John Scelfo, who resigned in April (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Grocer Names Executive
abstract: Former IKEA executive Hannu Ryopponen is named chief financial officer of Royal Ahold, succeeding Michael Meurs; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Korean Rail Links Planned
abstract: Two rail lines, one between Seoul (South Korea) and industrial park near Gaesong (North Korea) and one on eastern coast linking countries, are set to open this Saturday; new rail service marks first train travel between North and South in more than fifty years (S)

headline: Killed in Iraq
abstract: Defense Dept issues name of latest American confirmed dead in Iraq (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Economic Growth Slows
abstract: India's economic growth slowed in fiscal third quarter ended in December as result of decline in agriculture; economy grew 2.6 percent compared with 6.3 percent year earlier; growth in farm sector dropped to 5.9 percent from 7.9 percent year ago; industrial sector grew at 6.3 percent (S)

headline: Investing; Whole Foods' Run May Slow
abstract: Willingness of

headline: Slate Sets a Web Magazine First: Making Money
abstract: Online magazine Slate, founded by Michael Kinsley and funded by Microsoft, becomes first-ever digital media service to post profit; its Internet traffic has doubled in last year, to six million visitors monthly, amid growing ad revenue; photos (M)

headline: Star Data Lights Their Way
abstract: Twenty-five students from five New Jersey high schools study stars with help of Rutgers University professors and Ftools, open-surce software program available from NASA that provides real data from real NASA satellites; photos (M)

headline: Health Officials Wield a Big Stick, Carefully, Against SARS
abstract: ''Public health generally doesn't go swinging the heavy hand of the law,'' Dr. Colin D'Cunha, the chief medical officer of Ontario, said recently, after asking an estimated 10,000 Canadians to put themselves in voluntary quarantine to stop the spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS. ''By nature, we're not police persons. We believe in being reasonable. But we'll take steps if we need to.''    Despite his mild words, extraordinary powers are available to Dr. D'Cunha, as they are to public health officials around the world. The authority to declare quarantines to stop the spread of disease is no less sweeping today than it was for Dr. Cyrus Hudson, the New York City health commissioner during the cholera outbreak of 1892, who told a Congressional committee, ''If we see fit, we may take possession of the City Hall forcibly and turn it into a contagious-disease hospital.''

headline: WPP Creates Division to Unite Agencies
abstract: WPP Creates Division To Unite Agencies The WPP Group in London is making changes affecting several large agencies.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chip Tariffs Sought
abstract: World Business Briefing: South Korea: Chip Tariffs Sought

headline: Ahead of Crucial Meeting, Israel Frees Detainees, Including a Long-Jailed Bomber
abstract: Israel releases almost 100 Arab prisoners and slighly eases punitive measures imposed on Palestinians during current fighting, as good-will gesture on eve of summit meeting with Pres Bush and Palestinian Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas; photos; those freed include Ahmed Jubarah, imprisoned for 28 years for 1975 Jerusalem bombing that killed 13 people (M)
