headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cisco Names Chief Financial Officer
abstract: Cisco Systems says Dennis Powell has been chosen to succeed retiring Larry Carter as chief financial officer (S)

headline: Bush Promises More U.S. Troops to Philippines Leader
abstract: President Bush gave a warm welcome today to President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo of the Philippines and pledged more American support.

headline: Military Hardware Is Adapted to Fight SARS
abstract: Singapore authorities have adapted thermal imaging scanners developed for military purposes to help combat SARS spread; use infrared sensing system to screen arriving airline passengers for fever, SARS symptom, as they walk past special camera; Singapore Technologies Electronics, which worked with nation's defense agency to adapt its scanners, has formed partnership with Solectron Corp to produce commercial versions; photo (M)

headline: Iraqi Missile Hits Army Base
abstract: At least two soldiers and two journalists were killed today by an Iraqi rocket that exploded in an Army headquarters south of Baghdad.

headline: No One Standout and Few Big Risks in the Fall Lineup
abstract: ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox television networks preview their new programming lineups for next fall; fail to stir much excitement among potential advertisers; no single show attracts particular attention from advertising industry; traditional-looking sitcoms and crime dramas dominate networks' offerings; photos (M)

headline: Private Sector; Thinking Outside the Box Factory
abstract: Leonard Riggio, chairman of Barnes & Noble and of Dia Art Foundation board, says his experience as retailer helped him find museum's home in old box-printing factory in Beacon, NY (S)

headline: Defiant Iraqis Say U.S. Advance Has Been Broken
abstract: On a day when American units probed within miles of central Baghdad, the official Iraqi response was mocking and triumphalist.

headline: Russia Pausing on Iran Nuclear Deal, Blair Says; Denial Follows
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair says Russia has pledged to suspend shipment of nuclear fuel to Iran until Iranian government accepts new international controls on its nuclear program; but Aleksandr Y Rumyantsev, Russia's atomic energy commissioner, says no such promise has been made (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: King Is Ailing
abstract: Cambodian King Norodom Sihanouk, receiving medical treatment in Beijing (China), sends letter telling of his mounting health problems and attaches his medical reports for Cambodian doctors (S)

headline: A New SARS Riddle: How to Know It's Beaten
abstract: Lawrence K Altman analysis of SARS epidemic discusses new WHO assurances that outbreak is over in Vietnam and waning in Hong Kong and question of how much confidence experts can express about little-understood new disease (M)

headline: Briefly Noted
abstract: KOREAS SPAR OVER NUCLEAR ARMS South Korea demanded that North Korea abandon any atomic weapons development, but negotiators from the North stonewalled the nuclear discussion, calling it a matter between North Korea and the United States. The chief North Korean delegate, Kim Ryong Song, refused to confirm a claim made during talks last week with American and Chinese officials in Beijing that North Korea was making nuclear weapons, and instead sought to steer the talks in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, toward inter-Korean economic projects, South Korean officials said.

headline: U.S. Detains 3 Top Iraqi Officials, Including Arms Adviser
abstract: Three more Iraqi officials on the American most-wanted list have been placed in custody, military officials announced today, including another of Saddam Hussein's chief weapons advisers.

headline: NBC Said to Seek Alliance With Vivendi Units, Not a Purchase
abstract: NBC is intent on joining bidding for nonmusic entertainment assets of Vivendi Universal, but wants to form alliance with Vivendi rather than buy it out; NBC, which would need approval of its corporate parent, General Electric, before making formal offer, wants to combine its broadcast and cable television operations with Vivendi Universal's entertainment assets in arrangement that would give it majority control; Vivendi Universal is said to be eager to have NBC in bidding, in part to put pressure on Liberty Media, which is considered most aggressive of all companies that are pursuing Vivendi's media businesses (M)

headline: American Overseer in Iraq Returns to a Kurdish Zone
abstract: Jay Garner, American overseer in Iraq, makes emotional return to northern Iraq 12 years after commanding relief mission that saved lives of thousands of Kurds who had broken with Saddam Hussein's government; receives friendly welcome in Sulaimaniya; hails Kurdish self-rule in northern Iraq as example for rest of Iraq; plays down reports of hundreds of Arabs being expelled from their homes by Kurds and frustration some American military commanders have expressed with conduct of some Kurdish forces; map (M)

headline: Compressed Data; An AOL Service Allows Friends and Relatives To Follow the Troops
abstract: American Online feature called US Forces Alerts allows AOL subscribers to receive instant alerts to help them keep tabs on up to 76 specific military units in Iraq (S)

headline: China Cautions Officials Not to Hide SARS Cases
abstract: China's top leaders issued their strongest warning yet about severe acute respiratory syndrome and explicitly cautioned officials not to cover up the spread of the disease.

headline: Turkey, Spared a War, Still Pays a Heavy Price
abstract: Turkish refusal to allow US to use bases to launch Iraq war has cost Turkish military longstanding special bond with US, forfeited chance to secure bridgehead in Kurdish Iraq, cost country $5 billion in economic aid and dealt Turkey out of regional decision-making; Turkish analysts comment (M)

headline: Maker Admits It Hid Problems In Artery Device
abstract: Division of Guidant Corp, one of country's largest makers of medical devices, pleads guilty to 10 felonies, admitting it lied to government and hid thousands of serious health problems, including 12 deaths, caused by one of its products; case against division, Endovascular Technologies, results in $92.4 million in criminal and civil penalties, largest ever imposed against maker of medical devices for failing to report problems to government; company developed stent-grafts that could be used to treat abdominal aortic aneurysms without major surgery; problem was with device used to insert stent-graft; equipment could become lodged, potentially requiring emergency surgery to remove it; in some cases, it was broken into pieces before being removed; Guidant hid results that its product failed to work properly about one of every three times it was used; as part of plea, Endovascular Technologies agrees to cooperate in investigations against executives who might have been involved in wrongdoing; company also faces lawsuits from individuals; photos; diagram (L)

headline: Toronto Dash To Gay Unions
abstract: Toronto's City Hall extends its hours in anticipation of high demand for marriage licenses for same-sex couples during Gay Pride Week (S)

headline: Appointment at Gap
abstract: Gap Inc names Patricia Johnson as chief financial officer of its Old Navy division, succeeding Lee Bird, who is named chief operating officer of Gap; Bird succeeds Ron Beegle, who is leaving (S)

headline: North Korea Calls Missile Production an 'Indisputable Right'
abstract: North Korea defied United States sanctions today on exports of missile technology that American officials fear could be a prelude to sale of nuclear warheads to rogue nations worldwide.

headline: Gingrich Assails State Department and Calls for Overhaul
abstract: Newt Gingrich, the former speaker of the House of Representatives, today called for a sweeping overhaul of the State Department to enable it to explain Washington's policies more effectively.

headline: Pentagon Delays Releasing 5 Syrians Hurt in U.S. Raid
abstract: Defense Department, despite formal protest by Syria and over objections of State Department and American military officers in Iraq, reportedly delays release of five Syrian border guards wounded in US attack on June 18 on Iraqi convoy near Syrian border; Bush administration officials attribute delay to civilians at Pentagon who want guards to be questioned more extensively; Pentagon spokesman Larry Di Rita declines to say how Syrians were wounded or whether American troops crossed into Syrian territory during attack (M)

headline: La-Z-Boy Talks of Possible Plant Closings
abstract: La-Z-Boy, home furniture maker, says it might close plants and extend vacation shutdowns after its quarterly sales fell amid declining demand; net income rose about 1 percent, to $25.1 million in fiscal fourth quarter ended April 26, from $24.9 million year earlier; sales declined to $540 million from $596 million; chief executive Jerry Kiser comments (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Supermarket Sales Fall
abstract: Argentina's supermarket sales volume fell to 1.3 billion pesos ($460 million) in April, compared with 1.1 million pesos year earlier as inflation pushed prices higher (S)

headline: IDT UNIT IS BUYING MAJORITY STAKE IN ANIMATION COMPANY
abstract: IDT is buying 51 percent stake in Film Roman, animator of TV programs The Simpsons and King of the Hill, for $900,000 in cash and credit line of about $2.1 million (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: China Advertising Association cancels plans to send 90 people to International Advertising Festival, to be held June 15-21 in Cannes, France, because of travel restrictions imposed by Chinese government to help control SARS; Absolut Co signs agreement with CBS MarketWatch to be exclusive advertiser on home page of CBS Marketwatch.com each Friday afternoon through end of year, taking time slot occupied for two years by Budweiser ads from Anheuser-Busch; financial terms undisclosed; Malone Advertising opens office in Rogers, Ark, to be near headquarters of Wal-Mart Stores, which sells 25 brands made by Malone clients (S)

headline: Owner of Miller Beer to Buy Most of Big Italian Brewer
abstract: Owner of Miller Beer to Buy Most of Big Italian Breï

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fujitsu Wins Verizon Order
abstract: Fujitsu Network Communications wins ma5

headline: SUNNIS AND SHIITES UNITE TO PROTEST U.S. AND HUSSEIN
abstract: Sunni and Shiite Muslims put aside differences to demonstrate against United States and Saddam Hussein and for Islamic state after prayer service at Sunni mosque, Baghdad; Ahmad Chalabi, scion of wealthy Shiite clan who returned to his native Baghdad this week for first time in 45 years, emerges from well-guarded seclusion to claim role in Iraq's future, news conference; over 100 Shiite clerics meet in Baghdad's vast Shiite slum to discuss security and aid for city's Shiites; meeting quickly becomes power play by radical faction that hopes to gain control over divided Shiites; map; photos (M)

headline: Officials in India Divided On Sending Troops to Iraq
abstract: Indian officials have been debating for more than month whether to send more than 17,000 troops to help American forces stabilize Iraq; Indians would free sizable chunk of 145,000 American soldiers now there to return home; they would also allow Bush administration to claim broader international support for American occupation of Iraq; New Delhi has adopted go-slow approach and asked US to issue several 'clarifications' of American policy in Iraq; Indian officials say their soldiers will not serve under direct American military command and have asked for creation of joint command structure; they have cited concerns that Iraqis will view them as occupiers, and asked US for specific timetable outlining when independent Iraqi government will be formed; government of Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee is divided on issue and opposition Congress Party so far has not taken position; final decision rests with Vajpayee (M)

headline: Australian Official Awaits Court Ruling
abstract: Governor General Peter Hollingworth, former Anglican archbishop who represents British Crown in Australia, says he is stepping aside while court deals with allegation that he committed rape in 1960's; has already come under pressure to resign after church probe concluded that he permitted priest who had sex with minor to continue working, and had promoted church official found to have protected offender (S)

headline: Gaming Pros and Cons
abstract: Herbert Lin letter suggests parents who are concerned with children's exposure to video games consider whether games are consistent with their values and perhaps consider alternative means of developing skills (Jun 5 article)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Oil And Gas Fields For Sale
abstract: ChevronTexaco Corp says it will sell oil and natural gas fields in Papua New Guinea, resulting in its exit from $3.5 billion Exxon Mobil Corp project (S)

headline: FORMER COMPUTER EXECUTIVE IS NEW KODAK PRESIDENT
abstract: Former

headline: To Broad Support, Hong Kong Police Take On an Expanded Role in Fighting SARS
abstract: Government of Hong Kong is assigning broad and expanding role to police in effort to fight spread of infectious disease SARS; officers are taking computer software designed for major criminal investigations and instead entering information on family members and other close contacts of people with SARS; other officers pay three visits daily to homes of people ordered not to go out because someone in their household has confirmed case of disease; new confinement orders are issued for household members of suspected SARS patients as well; tougher measures appear to have broad support in populace terrified of disease that is still infecting 200 more people and killing two dozen each week; photo (M)

headline: Israel Approves Bush's Road Map to New Palestine
abstract: The Israeli government for the first time officially accepted a Palestinian claim to eventual statehood today.

headline: Shares Decline as Fed Eases Rate Less Than Anticipated
abstract: Stocks decline after Federal Reserve cuts its benchmark interest rate by less than some economists expected; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 8.13 points, to 975.32; Dow Jones industrial average drops 98.32 points, to 9,011.53; Nasdaq composite index loses 2.95 points, to 1,602.66; graph; chart (M)

headline: A Digital Camera Attuned To Its Mix-and-Match Lenses
abstract: Olympus introduces digital camera that offers flexibility of single-lens reflex and relies on first interchangeable-lens system to be shared by several manufacturers; photo (M)

headline: IRAN DISPUTES U.S. ON ACTIONS IN IRAQ
abstract: Iran's Foreign Min Kamal Kharrazi rejects American accusations of Iranian meddling in Iraq, calling charges diversion from US failure to establish order; suggests chaos in Iraq will end after Iraqis choose their own government; statement comes at end of meeting of Organization of the Islamic Conference and is tempered by concern that Iran could be next target of Bush administration; Iran denied at meeting that it is developing nuclear weapons or other weapons of mass destruction; US has also suggested that Iran is harboring militants who played role in May 12 suicide bombings against Westerners in Saudi Arabia; photo (M)

headline: Quizno's Evaluates Aspects of Its Account
abstract: Quizno's, chain of sandwich shops, places in review various assignments, including advertising, which has been handled by Cliff Freeman & Partners since 1999; billings estimated at $25 million (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Peril For Banks
abstract: China Banking Regulatory Commission chairman Liu Mingkang says time is running out for lenders to reduce bad loans, improvement management and raise capital, prompting him to consider bailing out banking industry for second time in six years; commission estimates 24.1 percent of loans at China's four biggest state-owned lenders were nonperforming at end of first quarter; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SINGAPORE: Telecom Unit Sold; SOUTH KOREA: A New Sk Proposal;.

headline: Fallout From Hong Kong SARS Will Hit Far and Wide
abstract: While SARS infections have ebbed across east Asia, the economic consequences may continue to be felt for months to come.

headline: Full Text of Bush and Blair's Joint News Conference
abstract: The full text of remarks by President Bush and British Prime Minister Tony Blair at Hillsborough Castle outside Belfast, Northern Ireland:

headline: Private Sector; An Economic Indicator Sings, and Dances
abstract: Producer Anita Waxman says ticket sales to Broadway shows are strong (M)0

headline: Defense Chief's Car In Minor Collision
abstract: Car driven by Maria Chirinos-Medina spins out of control and hits vehicle carrying Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, Washington, DC; Rumsfeld is not hurt; Chirinos-Medina, taken to hospital with minor injuries, gets ticket (S)

headline: Stress Is Up. So Why Are Mental Health Benefits Down?
abstract: Michelle Andrews column on moves by employers to end or cut mental health benefits at time of increasing stress; drawing (M)

headline: TiVo Plans to Sell Information On Customers' Viewing Habits
abstract: TiVo, the maker of digital video recorders, plans today to begin selling information about the viewing patterns of its customers to advertisers and programmers. The company says the reports offer far more precise data than traditional rating methods.    Because TiVo's are essentially computer hard drives connected to a central server, the company can monitor viewers' second-by-second behavior. It can tell how many viewers in a certain ZIP code clicked away at what moment in a commercial, for instance, or when a particular character appeared on a show.

headline: Calpers Raises Health Care Premiums
abstract: California Public Employees' Retirement System approves 17 percent increase in health maintenance organizations' premiums, about half what was being sought by HMO's; Calpers board approves 17 to 18.4 percent increase for Blue Shield of California and 16 percent to 18.2 percent for Kaiser Permanente (S)

headline: Taking a Holiday From Tariffs, Too
abstract: Alexandra W Ballantine letter oú

headline: CHIRON SAYS CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER WILL RESIGN
abstract: The Chiron Corporation, a leading biotechnology company, said yesterday that its chief financial officer, James Sulat, would resign. David Smith, 43, the vice president for finance, will take the post for an interim, it said. Mr. Sulat, 55, will leave next month ''to pursue other opportunities,'' a company spokesman, John Gallagher, said. Chiron, which sells vaccines, blood tests and drugs, hired a GlaxoSmithKline executive, Howard Pien, last month to take over as chief executive, succeeding Sean P. Lance, who remains chairman. Mr. Sulat, who has been at Chiron since 1998, declined to comment. Chiron is based in Emeryville, Calif.

headline: Who Knew? A Shangri-La Within Driving Distance
abstract: TripAdvisor and its new Weekend Getaway Guide offer suggestions for trips to places that are within specified distance from given location; guide is in form of e-mail newsletter; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: A Surprise Second Day Of Strikes; BELGIUM: War Crimes Complaint Against Franks; NORTHERN IRELAND: Man Says He'S Not A Mole; CZECH REPUBLIC: Threat To Poison Hospital Food;.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of picture caption with Apr 20 article on two doctors who developed new nasal wash0

headline: Patents; Tracking termites by monitoring their digestive problems and using hot chili peppers to kill them.
abstract: Terry Clark patents method of detecting and killing termites outside home by monitoring methane they expel; Robert H Neumann patents use of capsaicin, substance that makes chili peppers hot, to kill termites; Donald Sutherland (who is not related to actor of same name) patents method for killing gophers and other rodents by filling their burrows with foam containing ground-up mustard seeds; photo (M)

headline: Report Raises Questions on Success of Immigrant Interviews
abstract: Congressional report finds that Justice Department, which says interviews with more than 3,000 Muslim and Arab immigrants were key component in war on terrorism, has yet to conduct thorough assessment of program, which was hampered by unreliable information; says fewer than 20 were arrested, mostly for immigration violations (S)

headline: U.S. Officials Believe Hussein's Son Qusay Is Still Alive
abstract: Overheard conversations among Iraqi officers indicate that Saddam Hussein's heir apparent has been giving orders.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Shoppers' Bonus
abstract: German Parliament approves longer retail shopping hours to take effect in June; stores can now remain open until 8 pm on Saturday (S)

headline: As Kurds Move Into Kirkuk, Arabs Fear Revenge
abstract: Arabs and Americans brace for revenge attacks as thousands of Kurds pour into Kirkuk, but few killings are reported; Saddam Hussein's campaign of forced demographic change has left Kurds and Arabs with competing claims, situation likely to be one of largest challenges American officials administering Iraq will face (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: VIETNAM: Meeting With Dissident; CHINA: Hitting Back;.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: CENTRAL BANKER EXTENDS TERM; FRANCE: Executive'S Ouster Urged;.

headline: Fed Statement On Decision To Cut Rate
abstract: Text of statement released by Federal Reserve after Fed's monetary policy panel Federal Open Market Committee reduces its benchmark interest rate by quarter of percentage point

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Surge In Shipbuilding Orders
abstract: South Korea's Hyundai Heavy Industries says it tripled value of shipbuilding contracts in first quarter compared with year earlier; contracts signed from Jan 1 to March 31 were worth $2.4 billion, while those signed year earlier were worth $762 million (S)l

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Grocer Rejects Bid
abstract: Somerfield, owner of Kwik Save and Somerfield food chains, rejects $965 million takeover approach from group of investors led by John Lovering, chairman of Peacock Group (S)

headline: MediaTalk; On the Cover: Just Another Pretty Face?
abstract: Lucky, only leading fashion and beauty magazine without celebrities on its cover, succumbs to industry normalcy; Conde Nast publication will feature singer and actress Mandy Moore on its July cover (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Bid For Bank Stake; JAPAN: Economic Assessment Unchanged;.

headline: National Ties To Airlines Weakening In Europe
abstract: If Loyola de Palacio, the European commissioner for transportation, gets her way on Thursday, the special relationships between European nations and their airlines are doomed.     The actual event, which is expected on Thursday, may seem like a bit of routine bureaucratic procedure. The transportation ministers of the 15 European Union members, meeting in Luxembourg, are expected to give officials of the union the authority to negotiate a single air transportation treaty, known as an open skies agreement, with the United States. The agreement would cover all 15 countries.

headline: Politics and Religion Join the Fray in Shiite Slum
abstract: Saddam City is one of most dangerous parts of Baghdad week after Americans' arrival; 80-block wasteland has descended into lawlessness, filled with gunfire by day, which becomes even fiercer at night; Shiite residents of neighborhood, which deteriorated into slum under rule of Saddam Hussein, say they are being attacked by jealous and revengeful Sunnis, or by Saddam loyalists trying to create instability to make it harder for Americans to govern; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: President's Rival Still In Jail
abstract: Morgan Tsvangirai, Movement for Democratic Change leader, appears for bail hearing on charges of treason levied after his party backed national strike in attempt to force Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe to resign; bail hearing is adjourned (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Health Product Ban Widens
abstract: Federal regulators in Australia who recalled 668 nonprescription health products say final sales ban could apply to almost 1,000 items; Pan Pharmaceuticals Ltd has been barred from production and sales for initial six months by Therapeutics Goods Administration, which has been investigating Pan's quality controls and test systems for four months (S)

headline: How Microsoft Warded Off Rival Software
abstract: Orlando Ayala, former head of Microsoft Corp's worldwide sales, sent e-mail message last summer titled Microsoft Confidential to senior managers laying out company strategy to dissuade governments across globe from choosing cheaper alternatives to Windows computer software systems; Ayala's message told executives that if deal involving governments or large institutions looked doomed, they were authorized to draw from special fund to offer software at steeper discount or even free if necessary; Microsoft's chief executive Steven A Ballmer was sent copy of e-mail message; memo written by Ayala on protecting sales of Windows and other desktop software mentioned Linux and stated that under no circumstances lose against Linux; memo, as wel as other e-mail messages and internal Microsoft documents obtained from recipient of Microsoft e-mail, offers rare glimpse into inner workings of Microsoft; spell out program of tactics that were implemented in recent years, ranging from steep price discounts to Microsoft employees lying about their identities at trade shows; chart; photos (M)

headline: Vatican Traveler in Croatia, Reaching 100, Trips, That Is
abstract: Pope John Paul II's visit to Croatia marks 100th time he has left Vatican City for foreign visit, reminder of extent to which travel has defined his papacy and he has used travel to redefine papacy itself; since beginning of his papacy in 1978, he has traveled to more than 125 countries, many of them more than once; his frequent trips, coupled with news coverage it generates, has given him enhanced stature on international stage; Vatican officials say he considers travel integral part of his mission; photo of Pope with Croation Pres Stjepan Mesic (M)

headline: Emirates to Buy 41 Planes In Huge Deal with Airbus
abstract: The order, valued at $12.5 billion, is the single largest ever for wide-body aircraft, both in numbers and dollar value.

headline: Threat to China's Elite
abstract: Report on SARS as threat to China's Communist party elite noted

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Law firm of Ropes & Gray, Boston, acquires Reboul, MacMurray, Hewitt & Maynard, New York (S)

headline: The Next War
abstract: American commanders hope to consolidate their victory in Baghdad by hunting the die-hards from the old regime.

headline: Early Returns in Nigeria Indicate President Will Remain
abstract: Nigerian Pres Olusegun Obasanjo captures 75 percent of vote in early returns; opposition forces and some election monitors in southern Nigeria claim vote fraud; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Trade Gap; JAPAN: Brokers Expect Losses; JAPAN: Chip Maker Forecasts Loss;.

headline: Zimbabwean Urges U.S. to Act Cautiously Against Mugabe
abstract: Opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai, responding to Pres Bush's call for change in Zimbabwean leadership, says his Movement for Democratic Change is developing plan it hopes will lead to peaceful transition of power; cautions that US should not overreach in southern Africa as it pressures Pres Robert Mugabe to step down, apparent acknowledgment that his party is vulnerable to Mugabe's charge that it is British and US puppet; photo (M)

headline: KANSAS CITY LIFE IS ACQUIRING GUIDEONE LIFE
abstract: The Kansas City Life Insurance Company, which had $440.2 million in revenue last year, is buying the GuideOne Life Insurance Company for about $78 million in cash, increasing its number of customers, the company said yesterday. GuideOne Life, based in West Des Moines, Iowa, is owned by the GuideOne Financial Group and has 75,000 policyholders, Kansas City's general counsel, William Schalekamp, said. Kansas City, which was founded in 1895 and is based in Kansas City, Mo., had $3.9 billion in assets as of the end of last year.

headline: In Baghdad, Reflections on the Past and Hopes for the Future
abstract: Iraqis, poised agonizingly between past and future, are grateful to US for ending Saddam Hussein's brutal dictatorship, although sentiment is not always easy to hear through cacophony of voices, but also want some semblance of order to return to their neighborhoods and daily life; photo (S)

headline: American Reporter Is Killed in Drive on Baghdad
abstract: Michael Kelly, the editor at large of the Atlantic Monthly and a columnist for The Washington Post, was killed in Iraq.

headline: British Soldier Accused of Mistreating Iraqi Prisoner
abstract: The soldier left a roll of film at a photo store in Staffordshire that appeared to show an Iraqi prisoner being tortured, the Defense Ministry said today.

headline: Blair Aide Says Presentation of Iraqi Arms Dossier Was Mishandled
abstract: A top aide to Prime Minister Tony Blair promised that "far greater care" would be taken with files in the future.

headline: Fitch Rating Service Is Denied Journalistic Privilege in a Suit
abstract: US Appeals Court rules that credit rating service Fitch Inc cannot invoke journalistic privilege to avoid turning over information and testifying in civil case that involves securities it considered rating; issue involves suit filed by American Savings Bank against UBS Paine Webber; Paine Webber had designed derivative securities for bank to buy that were supposed to gain investment-grade ratings, thus satisfying bank regulators, while giving bank equity-like returns that it could not otherwise obtain; bank regulators ruled deal illegal, and bank sued Paine Webber after it refused to buy back securities; court says that there is evidence that Fitch helped to design securities, even though in end it did not rate them, and that bank could seek information from Fitch regarding structuring of transactions; contends that while Fitch competitor Standard & Poor's had previously been found entitled to limited privilege of journalists under New York's shield law to avoid being forced to provide evidence, Fitch is not entitled in this case (M)

headline: NATIONAL STEEL ACCEPTS BID FROM U.S. STEEL
abstract: National Steel agrees to sell its assets ta

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Laos: Diplomats See Imprisoned Journalists
abstract: Western diplomats are allowed to meet with two European journalists and an American who were imprisoned June 4 in Laos after visiting insurgents from Hmong minority and accused of involvement in killing of village guard; Laotian foreign minister says charges will be filed soon (S)

headline: For EchoStar, the Real Challenge From DirecTV Begins
abstract: EchoStar will be hard put to continue to outperform DirecTV way it has for last 18 months in wake of Rupert Murdoch's News Corp's decision to acquire General Motors' Hughes Electronics and control of DirecTV satellite-television company; as cable television industry finally begins to deliver on promise of its long-lamanted digital upgrades and as DirecTV finally appears to be in hands of aggressive and capable media operators, EchoStar and its chairman Charles W Ergen appear to face biggest challenges in years; photo (M)

headline: A NATION AT WAR: IN THE FIELD | 75th EXPLOITATION TASK FORCE; Smoking Gun Still Proves To Be Elusive for Searchers
abstract: Mobile Exploitation Team Bravo, charged with hunting for weapons of mass destruction, finds thousands of round of ammunition and tons of weapons on its first foray into southern Iraq, but not smoking gun it was seeking; spokesman says amount of ordnance Iraq had amassed is sobering; unit also finds protective suits and gas masks, as have been found at other storage sites (M)

headline: Bush's Trip to Belfast Coming at Crucial Moment
abstract: The visit of President Bush to Northern Ireland on Monday comes at the most critical moment for the province's peace plan.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Takeover Backing Withdrawn
abstract: Germany's state-owned WestLB bank withdraws its offer to finance $1.6 billion bid for AWG, British water and sewage company, after AWG says offer is too low; big was being prepared by Bream Investments, group set up for takeover by Robin Saunders, American-born banker who is head of WestLB's finance unit (S)

headline: Internet Access for the Cost of a Cup of Coffee
abstract: Wi-Fi, for 'wireless fidelity,' which allows fast wireless connections with Internet using protocol called 802.11, is finding its way into airports, hotels, universities, truck stops and cafes; all that is needed is laptop or mobile device equipped with Wi-Fi or retrofitted with Wi-Fi card, and proximity to Wi-Fi beacon known as hot spot; it remains to be seen how many users will be willing to pay $30 a month charged for Wi-Fi access at various sites, given monthly communications feels many people already shoulder; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Cheaper Air Fares
abstract: The Irish low-fare airline Ryanair Holdings will cut ticket prices by about 5 percent annually over the next five years, the airline's chief executive told Handelsblatt, a German daily. ''While many airlines will hike prices due to cost problems, we will cut our average price of 49 euros by another 5 percent annually,'' the chief executive of Ryanair, Michael O'Leary, said, according to an advance copy of an interview to be published today.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Truckers Persist In Strike
abstract: World Business Briefing: South Korea: Truª

headline: Surprise! The Fed Isn't Just Greenspan
abstract: Federal Reserve committee that sets interest rates is unusually divided over risk of deflation and outlook for imminent economic recovery; cracks in Fed's usual unanimity are adding to uncertainty hanging over economy; Chmn Alan Greenspan is Fed's most important optimist, marveling at economy's ability to avoid deep recession despite series of economic shocks; some observers wonder whether he engineered part of debate so Fed can present nuanced view of economy without unnerving investors; graph of dissenting votes at Fed meetings; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Amgen Posts 45% Rise In Profit
abstract: Amgen Inc says profit in first quarter rose 45 percent; net income increased to $493.3 million from $340.9 million year earlier (S)

headline: Leader's Collapse Raises Concern for Azerbaijan's Health
abstract: The 79-year-old president of Azerbaijan collapsed twice during a nationally televised speech there today, prompting fresh questions about the health of a leader considered integral to the stability of his oil-rich country.

headline: Researchers Raise Estimate on Defoliant Use in Vietnam War
abstract: Researchers at Columbia Univ double accepted estimate of chemical dioxin contained in defoliants sprayed by Americans during Vietnam war; study, to be published in journal Nature, is intended to help assess health of Vietnam veterans; re-examination of military documents led to conclusion that additional 1.8 million gallons of herbicides--commonly called Agent Orange--were sprayed by US forces (M)

headline: A Company Man, Spurned, Fights For His Name
abstract: Interview with former Prudential Securities stock broker Robert J Ostrowski, who is suing company holding it tries to make him scapegoat for its regulatory problems over mutual fund marketing; company says it dismissed small-town broker for what it calls unauthorized 2001 trade; big brokerage houses have been shutting down offices in small cities and towns for years, with practice even more common since stock market collapse; photos (M)

headline: Germany's Social Democratic Party Endorses Schröder Proposal to Reduce Worker Benefits
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's plan to enact economic reform by reducing Germany's vast network of social protections is approved by 90 percent of delegates at politically crucial meeting of his Social Democratic Party; so-called Agenda 2010 would reduce unemployment benefits and give added flexibility to employers to hire and fire workers; it has prompted fierce debate and been denounced by leftist members of Schroder's government coalition as pro-business and unfair to working-class and poor people; it must still be voted on by Parliament, and some members of Schroder's slim governing majority could vote against it; photo (M)

headline: Argentina Agrees to Talk Reform With I.M.F.
abstract: Argentina and IMF agree to begin negotiating multiyear agreement that will force new government to make political unpopular decisions the country has been avoiding for nearly two years; Horst Kohler, fund's managing director, offers apology of sorts for having misread nature of Argentine crisis early last year and best way to solve it (M)

headline: Virus Imperils Commerce And Economy In Asian Hub
abstract: Hong Kong's economic setbacks in years since transition back to China are dwarfed by explosive outbreak of severe respiratory disease that is spreading panic and undermining confidence in future of one of world's most dynamic cities; government appeals for calm (M)

headline: SCHERING-PLOUGH RESCINDS EARNINGS ESTIMATE
abstract: Schering-Plough Corp retracts its estimate for annual profit and says its first-quarter earnings dropped 71 percent; says net income fell to $173 million from $600 million year earlier; sales decreased 19 percent, to $2.07 billion from $2.56 billion (S)

headline: Rumsfeld's Design for War Criticized on the Battlefield
abstract: Long-simmering tensions between Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld and Army commanders erupt in series of complaints from officers on Iraqi battlefield that Pentagon has not sent enough troops to wage war as they want to fight it; angry remarks from battlefield opened with comment from Lt Gen William S Wallace last week that military faces likelihood of longer war than many strategists had anticipated; underlying strains between Rumsfeld and Army are questions challenging his preference for emphasizing long-range precision weapons to putting boots on the ground; at present there are 100,000 coalition troops inside Iraq, part of more than 300,000 on land, at sea and in air throughout region for war; 100,000 more troops stand ready for possible deployment; Rumsfeld argues that he adopted approach for flowing forces to region to prepare for war without upsetting Bush administration's diplomatic efforts; even some of Rumsfeld's advisers now acknowledge that they misjudged scope and intensity of resistance from Iraqi paramilitaries in south, and forced commanders to divert troops already stretched thin to protect supply convoys and root out Hussein loyalists in Basra, Nasiriya and Najaf (L)

headline: Sales of Commercials Are Strong So Far
abstract: Sales of Commercials Are Strong So Far Demand for commercial time bought ahead of the start of the 2003-4 season on the broadcast television networks is a bit more robust than had been expected as the big media agencies agree to buy spots at rate increases about as high as forecast.

headline: Retail Borrowing Slowed in February
abstract: Retail Borrowing Sl

headline: Economy May Be Better Than You Think
abstract: Floyd Norris comment holds US economy may be better than it appears; holds retail sales are growing at tepid pace, but high gasoline prices can be blamed for that; says unemployment insurance figures before seasonal adjustment show 7 percent decline; holds stocks of industries other than computers and telecommunications are performing well; graph (M)

headline: Japanese Official Seeks to Guard Against Korean Missiles
abstract: Japan's defense minister called today for expanding his country's antimissile defenses, placing only cautious hope in arms control talks.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Triton Buys Wireless Licenses From Lafayette
abstract: Triton PCS Holdings, seller of mobile telephone service in southeastern US, acquires 12 wireless licenses from Lafayette Communications to increase capacity in South Carolina, Georgia and Virginia; Triton pays Federal Communications Commission $28.1 million retire debt associated with licenses (S)

headline: Sour Mood Pervades the Economic Front
abstract: Mood among business executives and consumers about economy is sour; every survey of manufacturers over last month has shown sharp increase in pessimism as executives complain about slumping demand for goods and higher prices for materials; Commerce Department reports factory orders dropped 1.5 percent in February, steepest drop in five months; economy has already lost more than 600,000 jobs since November and two million since Pres Bush took office; consumers have slowed spending; trend is even worse in Europe and Japan, where growth has almost stalled entirely; graph; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: TV Merger Examined
abstract: British Compet/

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.75        Discount rate   2.25   2.25   N.A.        Federal funds   1.25   1.27   1.75        3-month T-bills   1.08   1.07   1.75        6-month T-bills   1.11   1.11   1.87        10-yr. T-infl.   1.92   1.92   3.07        10-yr. headline: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Newspaper Halted For 3 Months
abstract: Belarus Information Minister announces suspension of established daily publication Belarusian Business Newspaper for media violations; paper's deputy editor Irina Khalip calls action politically motivated; holds that government wants newspaper to end criticism of President Aleksandr G Lukashenko (S)

headline: FOREIGN FIGHTERS ADD TO RESISTANCE IN IRAQ, U.S. SAYS
abstract: United States military commanders say foreign fighters are being actively recruited by loyalists to Saddam Hussein to join resistance against American forces in Iraq, posing new challenge to efforts to stabilize country; say fighters from Syria, Saudi Arabia, Yemen, Algeria, Lebanon and even Chechnya took up arms against US during American thrust to Baghdad, and significant number remain; say new effort is under way to lure more to Iraq to join fight against Americans; new evidence about role of foreign fighters, including passports and other documents, was gathered after American air and ground attack last week on militant camp at Rawa, 150 miles from Baghdad; American officials say two captured foreigners, from Saudi Arabia and Syria, claim they were offered money to come to Iraq and kill American soldiers; American military officials say it is significant that foreign fighters continue to play active role in Iraq and to be recruited for pay; say effort indicates considerable degree of organization behind resistance against American presence; map (M)

headline: What a Joint Account Means to Marriage
abstract: Judith Z Wind letter disputes Ellyn Spragins' April 6 article urging married couples not to maintain joint checking accounts; says joint accounts are wrong target; holds well-planned joint household budget should provide each spouse with some money that he or she can save or spend without scrutiny from the other

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: CANADA: Energy Concerns Plan Venture; MEXICO: Retail Sales Rise; BRAZIL: Boeing Rejects Bid For Varig; ARGENTINA: Supermarket Sales Fall;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Pacific Crossing May Sell Assets To Pivotal
abstract: Pacific Crossing Ltd, bankrupt former unit of Global Crossing Ltd, may sell its assets and subsidiaries to Pivotal Telecom for $63 million; Pacific Crossing operates fiber optic telecommunications network between Japan and US (S)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYNone.

headline: World Business Briefing | New Zealand/Australia: Australia: Bid For Property Trust
abstract: Australian pú

headline: No Time for EBay? Here Come the Agents
abstract: People who find online auction process daunting can now hire surrogates to sell their items on eBay; charge is generally one-time listing fee plus percentage of selling price; photos (M)

headline: Private Sector; A Diogenes of Wall Street Finds Executives to Reward
abstract: a diogenes of wall

headline: Washer Warns Dryer, 'Careful: It's Delicate'
abstract: General Electric's new Profile Harmony clothes care system is first washer-dryer combination in which washer electronically communicates to dryer about type of fabric and duration of cycle and selects appropriate settings; photo (M)

headline: For Nissan, a New Plant and Ambitious Goals in the U.S.
abstract: Nissan is set to open its $1.43 billion plant in Canton, Miss (M)

headline: Israel to Leave Peace Talks Unless Plan Is Amended
abstract: Dov Weisglass, top aide to Prime Min Ariel Sharon, says Israel will propose more than dozen changes to 'road map' for peace put forward by US, European Union, Russia and United Nations and is prepared to walk away if amendments are rejected; Israeli military reports killing Palestinian militant in gun battle on edge of Kiyrat Arba, West Bank settlement; Israeli soldiers shoot and wound two members of International Solidarity Movement, Brian Avery, American, and Lassel Smith, Dane, in northern West Bank town of Jenin (M)

headline: Research Shows Hazards in Tiny Particles
abstract: Review of research on nanoscale materials suggests that tiny particles are often toxic because of their size and are likely to pose health hazards, especially to workers making them (S)

headline: Health Care Atop the Worry List
abstract: Kaiser Family Foundation survey finds cost of health care or health insurance is top worry for 36 percent of American adults surveyed (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Legato To Dismiss Up To 6% Of Work Force
abstract: Legato Systems Inc, which makes software to manage and protect data-storage systems, will lay off up to 6 percent of its work force by June 30; expects to have 1,480 to 1,500 workers after cuts; total number of jobs to be cut has not yet been determined (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Loan For Steel Maker
abstract: The British steel manufacturer Corus Group said its bankers had agreed to terms of a new loan that will be backed by shares in its Dutch subsidiary. The loan will replace a 1.4 billion euro ($1.6 billion) credit facility that expires in January of 2004. The credit ratings of Corus were cut to below investment grade last year.   Heather Timmons (NYT)

headline: Behind Media Rule and Its End, One Man
abstract: Interview with Richard E Wiley, lead lobbyist for big media conglomerates pushing for removal of curbs to their expansion in radio, television and newspapers; Wiley discusses why he now opposes curbs he helped institute when he was Federal Communications Commission chairman; liberal and conservative elements, as well as some very prominent media executives, fear broad consolidations in news and entertainment businesses that Wiley currently espouses; photo (M)

headline: CALPINE SELLS STAKE IN CALIFORNIA POWER PLANT UNIT
abstract: Calpine Corp sells 60 percent stake in unit that leases and operates King City Power Plant, California, to GE Structured Finance for $82 million to help complete plants under construction (S)

headline: European Union Votes 14-1 to Reform Agricultural Policy
abstract: Fourteen of the European Union's 15 governments vote to overhaul their $49 billion common agricultural policy and challenge United States to match what they call their 'historic' reforms; only Portugal votes against new rules, which include new system that would reduce subsidies to wealthy farmers and impose stricter environmental standards; food production would also be cut back; Franz Fischler, chief architect of reforms, recalls American criticism of Europe's farm subsidy program even as Bush administration decided to increase farm spending by $170 billion over next decade; experts and activists say that even with EU reforms, farmers in poor countries will find it difficult to compete with cheap products from Europe as well as US (M)

headline: Economic Scene; The pundits were wrong: Using the Internet to buy cars does save consumers money.
abstract: Economic Scene: The pundits were wrong: Using the Internet to buy cars does save consumers mo

headline: Bush Meets With Blair to Discuss Postwar Iraq
abstract: The two leaders, who held a news conference today, will continue to discuss plans for a postwar Iraq.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Liberia: Swiss Freeze Leader's Assets
abstract: Swiss Federal Office of Justice approves request by United Nations war crimes tribunal and freezes Liberian President Charles Taylor's Swiss bank accounts; Taylor is accused of crimes against humanity during Sierra Leone civil war; photo (S)

headline: Saudis Re-Examine an Islamic Doctrine Cited by Militants to Condone Jihad
abstract: Saudi newspaper columnist Mansour al-Nogaidan drops philosophical bombshell with column charging that Wahhabi doctrine of Islam is root cause of violence fomented in name of Islam in Saudi Arabia and around the world; terrorist attacks in heart of Riyadh transform discussion about religious roots of Islamic militancy and how it spreads through mosques, schools, state television and other official institutions; religious establishment is thrown on defensive by repeated accusations that denigrating anything they do not like as 'infidel' has helped breed generation of Saudis whose radical fringe thinks it is acceptable to kill Westerners and even Muslims who get in way; photo of Nogaidan (M)

headline: Fiat to Eliminate Jobs and Close Plants
abstract: Fiat announces four-year plan that includes 12,300 layoffs, 1.84-billion-euro capital increase and return to profit in 2006; says capital increase and cost cuts will provide enough cash to finance plan, sale of new bonds will be considered if terms are favorable; will close 12 'non-Italian factories'; chairman Umberto Agnelli and chief executive Giuseppe Morchio comment; photo (M)

headline: Management Practice Enabled Huge Fraud, 2 Investigations Find
abstract: Reports by Securities and Exchange Commission's former director William Lucas and former US Atty Gen Dick Thornburgh show WorldCom's former chairman-chief executive Bernard J Ebbers ran company in manner that fostered long and extensive fraud executive by other senior executives; reports, filed with bankruptcy and federal district courts in New York, provide extensive new details of how Ebbers and others in top management led WorldCom into financial and accounting morass; lawyers who have followed case say it is still not clear from documents whether Ebbers will eventually face criminal and civil fraud charges (M)

headline: A Top Partner Quits Law Firm After 38 Years
abstract: Stephen Fraidin, top partner at New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, defects to Kirkland & Ellis in surprising move; departure of Fraidin may complicate merger talks that have last months between Fried, Frank and London-based Ashurst Morris Crisp (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Apr 27 article on bypass trusts: $1 million will be exempt from federal estate tax in 2011 in absence of new Congressional action; article also mistated given name of lawyer who commented

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Economy Slows
abstract: Taiwan's economy grows at rate of 3.2 percent in first quarter of 2003 after expanding 4.2 percent in fourth quarter (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: NASDAQ EUROPE CLOSING; GERMANY: Changes At Utility;.

headline: Chip Tester Prices I.P.O. At High End
abstract: FormFactor, maker of computer-chip testing equipment, increases its initial public offering to as much as $84 million from $60.5 million; plans to sell 6 million shares at $14 each; Morgan Stanley is underwriter (S)

headline: At Meetings Abroad, Raucousness and Hoopla
abstract: Annual shareholder meetings in the United States can be perfunctory affairs, but those abroad are often far different.

headline: Genzyme Gets Approval to Sell Enzyme Drug
abstract: Genzyme Corp wins Food and Drug Administration approval to sell Fabrazyme, drug that treats rare enzyme-deficiency disorder called Fabry disease (M)

headline: As Companies Reduce Costs, Pay Is Falling Top to Bottom
abstract: Analysis of government data by Economic Policy Institute shows average pay of workers at all income levels is falling for first time since 1980's; finds weekly salary of workers at 90th percentile of earners fell 1.4 percent over last year, to $1,439; Labor Department says inflation-adjusted weekly pay of median worker fell 1.5 percent from early last year to early this year; many companies are turning to pay of employees as they try to stay profitable during economic downturn after more than two years of canceling investments in new equipment and laying off workers; some companies that have frozen or cut wages noted; graph; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Financial Revision Advances
abstract: Lower house of Brazil's Congress passes bill that could pave way for increased autonomy for central bank in vote markets see as barometer of left-leaning government's capacity to push through tax and pension changes later this year; proposal would alter legal framework for Brazil's financial system in Constitution, which would allow government to grant more independence to central bank; vote shows Pres Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva can successfully mobilize support from his coalition allies and opposition lawmakers; photo (M)

headline: Proposal on Pension Conversion Attacked
abstract: Proposed regulations to govern way companies change to controvesial type of pension plan are assailed by workes and corporate officials at hearing by Treasury Department; employees say proposals will not prevent companies from reneging on pension promises and stripping workers of benefits they had been led to expect; company officials say rules fail to give employers enough flexibility to change their compensation practices as economic climate changes; regulations under discussion try to address conversions of traditional pension plans to what are called cash-balance plans (M)

headline: In Brazil, All May Not Be as Relaxed as It Seems
abstract: Article on what foreign executives encounter when doing business in Brazil; says foreign executives are often bowled over by Brazilians' spontaneous friendliness and informality, only to be frustrated later by just how long it can take to close deal, thanks to cumbersome bureaucracy or simple delaying tactics; Richard Hayes, American banker and financial consultant in Brazil since 1964, and Peter Stern, New York-born management consultant who has lived in Brazil since 1980, comment; photos (M)

headline: Tests in China Suggest Some With SARS Don't Become Ill
abstract: World Health Orgn reports that blood tests of people who work with exotic animals in markets in southern China show that significant proportion apparently have been infected with SARS virus, suggesting that some people may become infected without becoming ill; findings are from two separate studies of workers in markets in Guangdong Province; they strengthen SARS link between animals and humans (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Casino Deal; THE NETHERLANDS: Cuts At Airline; GERMANY: Business Climate Rises; BELGIUM: Brewer Maintains Forecast; NORWAY: Interest Rate Cut;.

headline: In Karbala, G.I.'s Find Forsaken Iraqi Armor and Pockets of Resistance
abstract: US forces enter Karbala in scorching heat and find herds of tanks abandoned by Iraqi army and pockets of paramilitary fighters who spray troops with grenades and automatic weapons; US now occupies about two-thirds of city holy to Shiite Muslims; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Tyco, Once More, Makes a Change In Its Accounting
abstract: Market Place column holds Tyco's delayed decision to account for acquisitions in its ADT security business in conservative matter shows new management, led by Edward D Breen, remains reluctant to adjust accounting; holds shift was done in confusing way that exaggerates current expenses (M)

headline: A.I.G. Shares Fall as Sales Drop on Fears Over SARS
abstract: Shares of American International Group fall 5 percent after company says severe acute respiratory syndrome is curbing sales in China and some competitors are undercutting its US property rates; net income fell 1 percent, to $1.95 billion; profit from operations rose 11 percent, to $2.37 billion; chairman Maurice R Greenberg comments (M)

headline: Iraqis Confront Memories in a Place of Torture
abstract: Collapse of Saddam Hussein government and unmasking of intelligence and interrogation centers like Al Hakemiya in Baghdad is bringing out some of the thousands of formerly incarcerated Iraqis who want to confront their memories of degradation and torture; Al Hakemiya was apparently used as way station where suspects were worked over and squeezed for information, and sometimes cash, then moved to more permanent facilities; one former detainee describes being held for five months at center, where he was hung from ceiling by his arms and tortured with electric current after being arrested on what he says were trumped-up theft charges; photo (M)

headline: Condé Nast Picks Publisher of New York to Head Men's Shopping Magazine
abstract: Conde Nast Publications hires Alan Katz, publisher of New York magazine, to be publisher of new shopping magazine for men it is developing; magazine is scheduled to appear in 2004; photo (M)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.75       Discount rate   2.25   2.25   N.A. headline: France Works to Limit Damage From U.S. Anger
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell said in recent television interview that France would suffer consequences of its opposition to American-led war, and senior French officials visiting Washington on non-Iraq issues are stunned when their American counterparts inform them of official 'resentment and anger' against France; Pres Jacques Chirac's new policy to address issue is described by followers as 'pragmatic'; this led France to agree unexpectedly to temporary suspension of United Nations-imposed economic penalties against Iraq, apparently without consulting Russia; it also prompted senior French officials to speak about France's 'openness' to possible peacekeeping and reconstruction role for NATO in Iraq; but aides say Chirac will continue to adhere to positions that seem to guarantee confrontation with Washington and to seek to carve out foreign policy for France independent of US (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Semiconductor Forecast Cut
abstract: STMicroelectronics issp

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Uruguay: Bond Exchange Sought
abstract: Uruguay asks bondholders to swap as much as $6.5 billion of debt due through 2027 for new securities that have longer maturities and are worth less (S)1

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: F.C.C. Approves Expansion By Media Conglomerates  The Federal Communications Commission narrowly approved a relaxation of the most significant restrictions on the ability of broadcast and newspaper conglomerates both to expand into new markets and extend their reach in the cities where they have a presence.    The decision will permit a company to own up to three television stations, eight radio stations, a daily newspaper and a cable operator in the largest cities. [Page A1.]

headline: As Order Breaks Down, Allied Forces Pledge to Rebuild Iraqi Police
abstract: American officers in Iraq begin working with local Iraqi officials to try to form nucleus of new police forces; defense officials say effort is unlikely to do much in short term to quell looting and lawlessness now seen in much of country; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, at Pentagon briefing, says situation is 'untidy' but that everything cannot be accomplished instantaneously; defends Bush administration against charges that it has done too little to foresee or to put down outbreak of crime and violence; suggests most of violence would subside on its own after initial explosion of pent-up Iraqi resentment is spent; photo (M)

headline: Nonprofit Institute Gets Contract to Aid Iraqi Civic Agencies
abstract: Research Triangle Institute of North Carolina, nonprofit group, is awarded $7.9 million contract from United States Agency for International Development to help restore local governments in Iraq (S)

headline: PENTAGON EXPECTS LONG-TERM ACCESS TO KEY IRAQ BASES
abstract: US plans long-term military relationship with emerging government of Iraq, one that will grant Pentagon access to perhaps four military bases: those at Baghdad's international airport, at Tallil, at isolated airstrip in western desert and at Bashur in Kurdish north; new American foothold would be felt across border in Syria, and, in combination with continuing US presence in Afghanistan, would virtually surround Iran with new web of American influence; at same time, Pentagon continues withdrawal from Iraq, aware that its presence in Middle East invites charges of empire-building and may create new targets for terrorists; also hopes to ease domestic strains in Turkey and Jordan; map; photo (M)

headline: Iraq's Revived Communists Appeal to the Masses, a Bit Uncertainly
abstract: Iraq Communist Party sets up its headquarters in old army building in Baghdad, emerging from decades of repression that sent many of its members to prison or to gallows; party leaders, with reworked set of principles and renewed sense of hope, are taking their case to Iraqi people once more, in political environment more open than any they have known; photo (M)

headline: Deflation Will Hang Over Bush Talks With Japan Premier
abstract: There will be much friendly talk about Japan's support for American policies from Afghanistan to Iraq, and concerted brow-knitting about a nuclear North Korea.

headline: American Soldiers Find Drums Possibly Storing Chemical Agents
abstract: American soldiers near Karbala found canisters that, according to tests, contain nerve agents and mustard gas.

headline: 17 Tourists Abducted in Sahara Are Freed in Army Raid
abstract: Seventeeen European tourists held captive in Sahara in Algeria are released unharmed after Algerian armed forces raid camp said to be controlled by militant Islamic group; 15 other travelers missing since Mar are still unaccounted for; senior German official terms their situation 'precarious'; freed tourists--10 Austrians, 6 Germans and Swede--were held by members of Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat; group has been fighting guerrilla war against secular Algerian government and is beleived to have ties to Al Qaeda; freed captives appear healthy as they arrive home; it is unclear whether there is any connection between their release and recent visit to Algiers of German Foreign Min Joschka Fischer; photos; map (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: BOSNIA: Top Serb Quits; CHECHNYA: War Crimes Trials Proposed; RUSSIA: St. Petersburg Governor Opts Out; IRELAND: Drinking Laws To Be Tightened;.

headline: Gay Marriage Plan: Sign of Sweeping Social Change in Canada
abstract: News analysis: Canada's decision to allow marriage between same-sex couples is only one of many signs that country is undergoing social change at astonishing rate; changes reflect both a laissez-faire conservatism that goes back to country's founders and a dramatically changing demographics in which 18 percent of population is foreign born (M)

headline: PALESTINIANS URGE SMALLER FACTIONS TO JOIN IN TRUCE
abstract: Palestinian leaders seeking first complete suspension of Palestinian violence against Israelis reach beyond Hamas and Islamic Jihad to persuade other, smaller factions to join in announcement planned with those two groups for June 29; separately, Israeli and Palestinian field commanders plan to renew direct contacts to iron out details for transfer to governing Palestinian Authority of security control over parts of Gaza Strip; in agreeing to temporary truce, Hamas is abandoning its longstanding demand that Israel first halt all its military operations; that demand remains a condition for cease-fire's endurance; truce is seen by both mainstream and militant Palestinian officials as means of focusing international pressure on Israel to restrain its armed forces; Yasir Arafat, who has been shunned by Israel and Bush administration, helped engineer truce; he sent his top adviser Saeb Erekat to meet with Ahmed Saadat, jailed leader of Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, faction responsible for slaying of Israeli minister in Oct 2001; Erekat says after meeting that he expects 'responsible statement' from group; photos (M)

headline: Terror Persists as Congolese Await U.N. Force
abstract: Terrorist attacks continue in Bunia, Congo, where massacre last month killed at least 430 people; photo; map; uncertainty surrounds whether new international force authorized by UN will be able to bring some semblance of security to city bristling with greed and guns, and for how long, given that force does not have explicit mandate to strip Hema militia of weapons (M)

headline: NBC Hires FX Executive to Revamp Its Hit Machine
abstract: Kevin Reilly, program executive from cable channel FX, is named president of prime-time development at NBC, new position; Reilly becomes second-ranking executive to entertainment chief Jeff Zucker; network dismisses Karey Burke, chief development executive, and Ted Herbert, chief in charge of internal production company NBC Studios; Joann Alfano, executive in charge of comedy development, left last week; NBC is making changes at time when its entertainment division, long ratings leader in network television, has lost gound to competitors; photos (M)

headline: Spain Denies War Support Left it Bare To Attacks
abstract: Spanish government seeks to dismiss suggestions by political opponents that its support for American-led war in Iraq led suicide bombers in Casablanca, Morocco, to target Spanish club and restaurant; Julio Anguita, former leader of United Left party, whose son was killed while covering war as journalist for El Mundo, accuses US, Britain and Spain of making world more dangerous and anticipates more attacks (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Brokers Expect Losses
abstract: Japan's Nomura Holdings Inc will book one-time 41.2 billion yen ($349 million) loss on its stock investments in year ended March 31; Daiwa Securities Group also says it will take 37.2 billion yen loss on its stock holdings (S)

headline: Oil Experts Say U.S. Hasn't Come to Grips With Blueprint for Industry
abstract: Oil experts says US is struggling to bring some order to Iraq's oil industry, on which it is counting to finance country's reconstruction; White House promises to reveal its plan for industry in coming days; State Department, reluctant to rely on executives from Hussein-era oil ministry, has been approaching former senior Iraqi oil officials who now live in exile, asking them to serve in crucial posts and as advisers, but several of them have declined because they do not want to be tainted by helping what many Iraqis see as occupation government; senior employees of Iraq's various oil companies scramble to fill power vacuum, in process giving conflicting information about resumption of oil production; photo; map (M)

headline: Private Sector; Out-of-Town Help for New York City
abstract: WPP Group chief executive Sir Martin Sorrell, who lives abroad, is supporting non-profit campaign to raise money to save eight New York City firehouses facing closure because of budget cuts (S)

headline: DENDRITE MAKES OFFER FOR SYNAVANT, TOPPING RIVAL BID
abstract: Dendrite International Inc., which sells marketing and sales software to drug makers, offered to acquire Synavant Inc. for about $38 million in cash, or $2.50 a share. Synavant, which provides customer-relationship management services for pharmaceutical companies, agreed this month to be bought by Cegedim of France for about $35 million, or $2.30 a share. Dendrite, based in Morristown, N.J., filed a lawsuit in the Delaware Chancery Court seeking to have Synavant waive its poison pill, intended to protect the company during a hostile takeover bid, Dendrite said. Synavant is based in Atlanta.

headline: Greece Seizes Boat Loaded With Explosives
abstract: Greek law enforcement officials say they are considering possibility that boat they found and seized off country's western coast with 680 tons of explosives was part of terrorist plot; say it is extremely rare for boats to hold such large quantity of explosives as cargo; note boat was flying flag from Comoros, which is considered flag of convenience, and had crew from Ukraine and Azerbaijan (S)

headline: Putin Writes to Bush, Making an Overture in an Effort to Mend the Rift Over Iraq
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin of Russia writes to Pres Bush seeking cooperation 'on all levels' and also seeking to heal relations bruised by war in Iraq; hopes letter will help set stage for meeting between two presidents in Russian city of St Petersburg; letter is delivered to Bush by Russian Defense Min Sergei B Ivanov, who is at White House for talks with Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld and national security adviser Condoleezza Rice (M)

headline: The War, Not Over, Now Seems Far Away for Some
abstract: Third Infantry Division's engineers clear antitank mines from road leading to airport outside Baghdad; photo; map (M)

headline: Mixed News on Brazil Economy Is Good News for President
abstract: Brazil's economy shrank 0.1 percent in the first quarter compared with the last three months of 2002, but grew by 2 percent compared with the same period last year.

headline: Seeking Calm In the Chaos
abstract: Analysis of dangerous task facing American troops, stretched thin as they seek to restore order and services in Baghdad while combat phase of war continues; troops face attacks from Saddam Hussein loyalists who continue to hide out in small pockets of city (M)i

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Retail Sales Rise
abstract: Retail sales in Mexico rose 3.2 percent in March from year earlier (S)

headline: In Eastern Germany, 1953 Uprising Is Remembered
abstract: Germans commemorate uprising of June 17, 1953, in which hundreds of thousands of workers took to streets in 272 East German towns and cities, demanding both democracy and better conditions for themselves; Soviet troops and East German police put down demonstrations and arrested many of movement's leaders; 25 to 300 people were killed; people in Bitterfeld recall uprising, first of its kind in Eastern Europe; photo; map (M)

headline: Excerpts From Remarks by Bush and Blair: 'Iraq Will Soon Be Liberated'
abstract: Text of statement on Iraq issued by Pres Bush and Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain after their meeting in Northern Ireland and excerpts from joint news conference

headline: Mixed Reaction in Pakistan to U.S. Pledge of $3 Billion in Aid
abstract: The reaction reflects the sharp political opposition to the president and a popular view that American owes Pakistan much more for its perceived loyalty.

headline: 2 Nuclear Weapons Challenges, 2 Different Strategies
abstract: Analysis of different strategies Pres George Bush is using in face of nuclear weapons challenges from Iran and North Korea; while he has given nearly identical warnings to both countries and two are often discussed in tandem as Bush's most urgent proliferation threats; he has declared that US will never abide a nuclear North Korea and is pursuing economic strategy against it; says administration officials hold same strategy would be impossible against Iran, given its oil trade and extensive relationships with Europe and Russia (M)

headline: How the German Postal Service Is Serving the U.S. Army in Iraq
abstract: Americans send about 50 tons of letters and packages every day to the more than 130,000 U.S. soldiers in Iraq. This sensitive cargo is being shipped there by the Deutsche Post (the German Postal Service).

headline: Arafat and Premier Still Split Over New Cabinet List
abstract: New Palestinian Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas remains deadlocked with Yasir Arafat over his proposed ministers for new government; senior members of Fatah movement try to broker compromise; Abbas is coming under fire from establishment Fatah figures who feel slighted in new government, and from upstart reformers who feel he has not sufficiently cleaned house; raucousness of debate illustrates seemingly contradictory nature of Palestinian politics: freedom people feel to speak up and criticize and pre-eminint power Arafat retains (M)

headline: Secret Recording Is Played At a HealthSouth Hearing
abstract: HealthSouth Corp's former chief financial officer William T Owens made secret recording of former chief financial executive Richard M Scrushy at request of FBI in which Scrushy urged Owens to 'fix' company's financial records; recording, played in Federal District Court, shows Scrushy made suggestion in March, day before Securities and Exchange Commission accused him in civil complaint of directing 'massive' accounting fraud that added at least $1.4 billion to earnings; Scrushy has denied wrongdoing and blamed his aides for fraud; no criminal charges have been filed against Scrushy; HealthSouth says its banks, led by Wachovia and J P Morgan, have agreed to wait until May 1 before making any move to force company into bankruptcy; photo (M)

headline: New York Times Co.'s Earnings Rose 26% in First Quarter
abstract: The New York Times Company reported today that its net income rose 26.4 percent in the first quarter from the period a year earlier.

headline: Anthrax Kills Hong Kong Boy, but No Link to Terror Seen
abstract: Officials announced the death of a 2-year-old from anthrax, but said the case did not appear to involve biological terrorism.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Charge For Telecom Concern
abstract: Japan's NTT DoCoMo will take one-time charge related to taxes, cutting its profit for last year by 27 billion yen ($226 million) (S)

headline: Teacher, a Survivor, Fondly Recalls Life in Hussein's Iraq
abstract: Montgomery Malaami, Assyrian Christian teacher in Basra, offers positive recollections of life in Saddam Hussein's Iraq, as long as one kept on good side of Baathists; photo (M)

headline: For $38,000, Get the Cake, and Mickey, Too
abstract: About 2,000 weddings are held yearly at Walt Disney World, Lake Buena Vista, Fla, part of boom in 'destination' weddings; wedding business has become so popular at Disney resorts worldwide that Disney has begun booking ceremonies for its planned Hong Kong park; photos (M)

headline: Court limits forced medication of defendants
abstract: WASHINGTON:—  The Supreme Court ruled Monday that the U.S. government has only a limited right to force mentally ill defendants charged with nonviolent crimes to take medication to make them competent for trial.

headline: Rumsfeld Says Forces Are Nearing Downtown Baghdad
abstract: Coalition forces are meeting little resistance on the way to Baghdad, but Pentagon officials warn that the most dangerous fighting could lie ahead.

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: Kindness of Strangers
abstract: Chris Slaughter, a private, had a question that was part accusation, part invitation. "You didn't bring goggles?" As a matter of fact, the reporter had bought a big pair of painter's goggles at Wal-Mart just before getting on the plane for Kuwait.

headline: Mystery Illness on Wane in City of Outbreak, Chinese Say
abstract: SARS has been brought under "effective control" in Guangzhou, China, where it first emerged in November.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Electronics Job Cuts; FRANCE: Loss At Resort Operator; BRITAIN: Insurer'S Shares Surge; IRELAND: Drug Maker Buys Debt; GERMANY: Bayer Downgraded; BRITAIN: Draft For Europe;.

headline: Casualties
abstract: Tally of reported casualties, missing and captured in Iraq war as of April 14

headline: CHARLES SCHWAB RAISES QUARTERLY PROFIT EXPECTATIONS
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp lifts second-quarter earnings forecast as customers increased their trading 20 percent in May from April; chief financial officer Christopher Dodds comments (S)

headline: Marines Again Kill Iraqis In Exchange of Fire in Mosul
abstract: Marines in Mosul, believing they are being fired upon, open fire in city's main square, killing four Iraqis and wounding 10; is second such incident in as many days; residents say shootings must stop and warn Americans not to squander whatever good will remains; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: VIETNAM: Crime Boss Convicted; NEPAL: New Prime Minister Appointed; TAIWAN: Crash Analysis Issued;.

headline: GLOBALSTAR GETS PERMISSION TO SELL ASSETS TO ICO
abstract: Globalstar wins

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FPL ENERGY, the unregulated wholesale-power business of the FPL Group, Juno Beach, Fla., said it signed three power-sales agreements for wind plants under development and bought wind assets in Pennsylvania.    EXULT INC., Irvine, Calif., a computer-services seller, said it won a $500 million contract to handle payroll, computers and other duties for Bank of Montreal's human resources department.

headline: Private Accounts Don't Have to Disturb Social Security
abstract: Fred Brock column on Rep E Clay Shaw Jr's proposal to partially privatize Social Security by setting up separate, government-funded private accounts for workers to be invested in stocks and high-grade corporate bonds; money in accounts would be used to offset promised Social Security benefits; Shaw holds plan, which would require initial borrowing by government, would repay all its debt and save system almost $5 trillion over next 75 years; photo (M)

headline: Consumer Confidence Was Higher Than Expected This Month
abstract: Conference Board reports consumer confidence index was little changed in June at 83.5 compared with 83.6 in May; separate gauge in report measuring attitudes of consumers about conditions in six months rose to 95.9, highest since September, from 94.5; report shows number of people expecting more jobs to become available six months from now rose to 19 percent in June, highest in year, from 17.9 percent, while number of people expecting business conditions to improve rose to 23.9 percent from 22.8 percent month earlier; report says 5.9 percent of Americans surveyed plan to buy new cars in next six months, down from 7.7 percent last month, and 3 percent say they plan to buy new home, down from 3.8 percent; number of people expecting incomes to rise over next six months falls to 16.9 percent from 17.1 percent in May; graph (M)

headline: On Order From Bush, U.S. Troops in Iraq Begin Disarming Iranian Opposition Group
