abstract: US commanders in Iraq, acting on Pres Bush's decision, begin disarming Iranian opposition group, Mujahedeen Khalq, which was designated terrorist organization in April but was allowed under cease-fire agreement to keep most of its weapons; photo; deal was backed by US commanders as practical way to deal with group without further burdening US forces (M)

headline: People
abstract: Carl Johnson will not return to TBWA Worldwide as planned following sabbatical; Gunnar Wilmot is named to new post of chief operating officer at Lowe Plus Draft; Paul Shearer and James Thornton are appointed executive creative directors at Leo Burnett Worldwide's London office; Andy Madorsky is named executive creative director at Grant, Jacoby, replacing Bernie Pitzel (S)

headline: Private Sector; Women Take On Wall Street, and Lose
abstract: Group of male investment bankers defeats group of college all-stars in charity basketball game at Basketball City, 40-38; game raised $400,000 for Netgain, program run by charity organization Youth I.N.C., which supports New York area high school basketball programs (S)

headline: Networks Try Reality Cure For Summer Rerun Blues
abstract: Broadcast television networks are offering more new series this summer than at any time in their history, hoping to stem summertime loss of viewers to cable channels; 11.3 million more people watched prime-time cable shows during summer of 2002 than watched shows on broadcast networks; cable channels are also rolling out dozens of new shows, frequently their most expensive scripted dramatic series, while broadcast networks will rely instead on cheap reality shows; photos (M)

headline: Pentagon Reports Raising $1.7 Billion to Assist Relief Effort
abstract: Pentagon raises $1.7 billion in financial assistance, food, medicine and other relief products for Iraq from various countries, including Jordan, United Arab Emirates, Britain, Japan, Australia, Netherlands, Canada, Switzerland and Romania (M)

headline: Estate Tax as Retirement Aid
abstract: estate tax as re

headline: Investing; A Storm Watch in the Bond Harbor
abstract: Fund managers, financial advisers and bond traders warn long bond market rally nears end; Robert I Bair III (PSA Financial Center) suggests investors shift from long-duration bond funds to shorter-term ones; graphs of bond fund returns and flows; photo (M)

headline: Turning to Friends for Facts
abstract: Researchers report that people are more likely to seek information from other people, especially people they know, than to search Internet (S)

headline: As Crime and Politics Collide in Rio, City Cowers in Fear
abstract: Criminal gangs in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, are showing greater boldness and strength; residents, increasingly alarmed, complain that political rivalries and bickering between federal and local governments are blocking effective response; in direct defiance of government authority, gangs are attacking government buildings, shopping centers, hotels, buses and even highways linking city to airport; police and intelligence officials say much of violence is work of notorious drug trafficker Luiz Fernando da Costa, who is thought to control gangs from his jail cell; Rio's Gov Rosinha Matheus has fired state public security secretary and replaced him with her husband, former gov Anthony Garotinho; she did this after bus carrying 20 police officiers was attacked because drug trafficker objected to its presence in territory he controlled; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: HBO to Bring 'Sopranos' Back for a Sixth Season  ''The Sopranos,'' the most successful series in the history of cable television, will not end with its fifth season but will instead have one more season, with 10 episodes, according to an executive producer, Brad Grey.    ''Sopranos'' will now end with 75 episodes, enough for a potential sale in syndication, which would likely be the biggest in the history of cable. [Page C2.]

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Long-Distance Service In Minnesota
abstract: Qwest Communications International Inc wins approval from federal regulators to sell long-distance service in Minnesota, where it is biggest local carrier (S)

headline: Iraqi's Road Home, by Way of the Web
abstract: Sam Kareem, who founded Iraq.net in 1995 as hobby, has met with Pres Bush and Iraqi expatriots to work with Defense Dept in planning transitional postwar government; idea has led to creation of Iraqi Forum for Democracy, international group for which Kareem serves as Webmaster; goal is establishment and preservation of democracy in Iraq; photo (M)

headline: American Troops Step Up Efforts to Curb Crime and in Iraqi Capital
abstract: United States military forces embark on their most aggressive police action yet in Baghdad, seeking to arrest thousands of violent criminals who Saddam Hussein released, to jail looters for extended terms, and to run hundreds of night patrols to restore order; L Paul Bremer 3d, new civilian administrator, reports that allied forces arrested 300 criminals in last 48 hours; photos; map (M)

headline: Iran's Chief, in Lebanon, Urges Quick U.S. Exit From Iraq, but Favors Vote
abstract: Iranian Pres Mohammad Khatami, visiting Lebanon, calls on US to leave Iraq quickly but pledges that Iran will support new, inclusive elected government; implicitly lauds Hezbollah, which US considers terrorist group; Khatami speaks to 50,000 people, mostly Shiites, at stadium; photo (M)

headline: Online, All the Time, an All-Seeing Surveillance System
abstract: Surveillance systems no longer depend on analog cameras and banks of video monitors; instead, they use digital images which can be easily stored and manipulated on computer server and monitored from remote location using Internet; illustrations show working of typical surveillance network (M)

headline: Gunmen Kill 2 U.S. Soldiers In a Firefight in Central Iraq
abstract: Gunmen fire machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades at column of US military vehicles near Euphrates River Bridge in Falluja, killing two US soldiers on second day of deadly guerrilla attacks on convoys in Iraq; nine soldiers are wounded; two attackers are reported killed and six captured in hostile town where residents are carrying out organized resistance and avenging dead Iraqis (S)

headline: With All the Little Wars, Big Peace Is Elusive
abstract: Letter From Africa on cruel pattern of endless war in so much of Africa, including Congo fighting that began in 1997 after ouster of dictator Mobudu Seke Seso; analysts explain difference between main conflict, between government and rebel armies, and many smaller wars being waged deep inside Congo's jungles; photos (M)

headline: Sunscreen. Check. Laptop and P.D.A.?
abstract: Survey finds that 40 percent of executives planning on taking vacation this summer also plan to do some office-related work while away (S)

headline: Plan to move troops south of Seoul aims at more mobility : U.S. broadens Pacific focus
abstract: UIJONGBU, South Korea:—  U.S. forces will consolidate at major bases in a two-phase plan that calls for them to withdraw south of Seoul and well beyond North Korean artillery range, according to the Pentagon and South Korea's Defense Ministry.

headline: No Neat Categories for the Casualties of War
abstract: The effort to number the dead on the Iraqi side in the war begins with a conundrum: who is a civilian and who is a combatant?

headline: Palestinians Struggle to Reach Deal on Cabinet as Time Runs Out
abstract: With only three days left to form a new government, the Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, was still struggling today to reach a deal with Yasir Arafat.

headline: For Wal-Mart, New Orleans Is Hardly the Big Easy
abstract: for wal-mart, new orleans is hardly the big easyn

headline: A Blogger's Big-Fish Fantasy
abstract: Bloggers are concerned with increasing readership and appreciate loyal readers and steady rise in traffic; networking with and linking to other blogs can raise number of hits, but blog etiquette notes that publicizing blog without valid link or idea to back it up is considered spamming; odd or unique entries generally attract readers; drawing (M)

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: Planner of Achille Lauro Hijacking Is Reported Captured
abstract: The Palestinian guerrilla leader who masterminded the 1985 hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro was reported to be in American custody in Iraq.

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: Young and Hungry Captives
abstract: Their eyes widened when one of their jailers entered the room in Mahkmoor, Iraq, with a stack of fresh bread. Then, shamelessly, they devoured it, wolfing down chunk after chunk.

headline: People
abstract: Micky Marks resigns as president at New York and San Francisco offices of PHD, Omnicom agency (S)

headline: A Large Pain: Health Coverage
abstract: About forty percent of small-business owners say they cannot afford health insurance coverage, and many who do provide coverage are cutting back and shifting costs to workers; more than half of 41.2 million Americans without insurance are employees of small businesses (special section, Small Business) (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bayer Downgraded
abstract: Moody's Investors Service downgrades credit ratings of Bayer AG (S)

headline: At McDonald's, an Effort to Restore Lost Luster
abstract: McDonald's Corp chief executive James R Cantalupo tells investors that he will bring company back to its glory days by focusing on customer service, clean restaurants and reliable, appealing food; pledges to inject new energy into company by increasing marketing efforts, introducing products and focusing on new demographic groups, particularly women and young adults; says investors could expect to see shift in momentum, which he describes as increases in margins and sales, in 12 to 18 months; photos (M)

headline: Leaders Urge Reconciliation at Summit, but Tension Persists
abstract: Despite efforts to repair relations, diplomatic tension between the Americans and the French hung heavy over the G-8 summit.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Algeria: Hunt For Missing Europeans
abstract: Algerian search in Sahara Desert for 29 missing European tourists receives reinforcements from Germany and Austria; tourists have been missing since February with no clue as to their whereabouts (S)

headline: Former Chairman Of Qwest Agrees To Give Up Gains From Stock Deals
abstract: Qwest Communications' former chairman Philip F Anschutz agrees to give up $4.4 million in personal profits from shares in hot stock offerings that prosecutors say were allotted to him by Citigroup's Salomon Smith Barney brokerage unit that hoped to win additional business from Qwest; Anschutz becomes first corporate official to return gains from practice, known as spinning, through several other former or current top executives have been accused of same practice; agrees to donate to charity profits from his shares; agreement stems from civil lawsuit filed in September by New York State Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer seeking return of spinning gains from shares directed by Citigroup; photo (M)

headline: Michigan Legislation Would Aid Mall Owner
abstract: Takeover battle for A Alfred Taubman's shopping mall empire takes another twist when bill is introduced in Michigan Legislature that, if enacted, would effectively void recent federal court decision and allow Taubman family to block hostile offer; measure, proposed by Rep Bill Huizenga, would help Taubman family in its effort to thwart $1.74 billion hostile takeover of Taubman Centers by Simon Property Group and Westfield America (M)

headline: Aide Denies Shaping Data to Justify War
abstract: Douglas J Feith, Pentagon's under secretary of defense for policy, holds briefing to rebut accusations that senior civilian policy makers politicized intelligence information on Iraq; acknowledges that he created small intelligence team inside his office after 9/11 to search for terrorist links with Iraq and other countries that intelligence agencies elsewhere in government might have missed, but denies shaping data to justify war (M)

headline: Euro Hits New Peak Against Dollar, but It Then Retreats
abstract: The euro's ascent — it is up 12 percent against the dollar this year — is roiling economies in much of Asia.

headline: As I.P.O.'s Go, So Does a Site
abstract: Chief executive David H Roberts disbandÿ

headline: Iraqi Shiites Show Their Fervor in City They Hold Holy
abstract: Iraqi Shiites celebrate newfound political freedom in Karbala, chanting, pounding their chests and lashing their backs with whips to commemorate death of Hussein, grandson of Prophet Muhammad, in struggle that cemented great split in Islam between Shiites and worldwide Sunni majority; observance was banned for 25 years of Saddam Hussein's regime; signs of potential contending forces among Shiites emerge during celebrations (M)

headline: As Industry Shifts, New Chip Seeks Footing
abstract: Intel will face its strongest challenge in more than decade when archrival Advanced Micro Devices formally unveils Opteron 64-bit microprocessor next week; Opteron represents attempt by Advanced Micro to undermine Intel's blueprint for dividing computing universe into two worlds: one represented by its desktop 32-bit Pentium processors and other by its pricier, corporation-oriented Itanium 64-bit chips; many industry executives see Opteron processor and Athlon 64, its companion desktop version to be released in fall, as make-or-break test for Advanced Micro as it tries to carve out secure, profitable position within Intel's shadow; Advanced Micro's chief executive Hector Ruiz comments; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Presses Saudis to Police Accounts Used to Aid Palestinians
abstract: Treasury Department and other federal agencies are pressing Saudi Arabia to monitor closely bank accounts designated for relief aid to Palestinians, so-called Account 98 funds, saying some of accounts may be conduits for terrorist financing; Saudi Arabia insists that money is closely monitored and is not given directly to Palestinian individuals, but rather channeled through major international organizations like United Nations and Red Cross and used to provide food, clothing, shelter and medical care (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Help For Economy
abstract: Thailand has set up 100-billion-baht ($2.4 billion) Phoenix Fund to invest in troubled sectors of economy; Thailand's stock exchange says it will create 700-million-baht fund to invest in shares fund lists (S)

headline: Predictions for TV commercial sales for the fall season are cut because of the war in Iraq.
abstract: Forecasts for record upfront advertising market this spring, when television networks will sell most of their advertising for 2003-4 season, are being tempered as war in Iraq enters its third week; less optimistic predictions, which lower consensus estimates of increases to single digits from 12 percent to 15 percent, are marked change from first few days of war; outlook for upfront market has become cloudy as setbacks in war effort compete for news media attention with successes; original forecasts by analysts and network executives called for broadcast networks to take in as much as $9 billion in upfront market, compared with $8 billion booked in advance of 2002-3 season (M)

headline: Toronto Again Listed as City With Spreading SARS Cases
abstract: World Health Orgn restores Toronto to its list of places where SARS is spreading after Ontario health authorities announce eight new probable cases of disease; United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issues new travel alert for Toronto; total of 27 pepole in Toronto have died of SARS, including 2 of 8 new cases (M)

headline: Hong Kong And China To Sign Pact Easing Trade
abstract: Hong Kong chief executive Tung Chee-hwa say mainland China and Hong Kong are set to sign free trade accord that will end tariffs on many goods and give Hong Kong companies greater access to mainland markets for many services, news conference; foreign business executives note that unless pact excludes Hong Kong subsidiaries of multinational corporations, China would effectively be opening huge back door to its markets (M)

headline: Latest in Series Of Bold Breaks Frees 3 Inmates At French Jail
abstract: In France, third major prison escape in month and fifth since start of year occurs at high-security prison at Luynes, where accomplices descend on prison in helicopter, then use buzz saw to cut through steel security netting and free three inmates; prison breaks have embarrassed Prime Min Jean-Pierre Raffarin government, which has put domestic security at top of its legislative agenda; government is being forced to rethink security in prisons, most of which have severe overcrowding (M)

headline: Merger Creates Russian Oil Giant With Big Dreams
abstract: Russia's largest oil producer Yukos Oil Co will pay $13 billion in cash and stock to buy Sibneft, nation's fifth-largest oil company; Yuko's principal owner Mikhail Khodorkovsky will manage new company, to be called YukosSibneft; Sibneft's principal owners, including enterpreneur Roman Abramovich will hold about 29 percent of new company; company will produce estimated 2.4 million barrels of oil per day and hold estimated 19 billion barrels of oil and gas reserves; Russia's Prime Min Mikhail Kasyanov calls new company 'a flagship for the Russian economy,' and Finance Min Aleksei L Kudrin says deal will help Russian companies strengthen their positions abroad; chart; photo (M)

headline: A Corporate Shadow At Augusta National
abstract: letters: a corporA

headline: State Dept. and U.N. to Inspect Iraq Nuclear Site
abstract: State Dept says it is making arrangements with International Atomic Energy Agency to conduct joint inspections of Iraqi nuclear research center in Tuwaitha, 20 miles from Baghdad, that has been ransacked by looters; center is where Iraqi scientists are thought to have come close to developing nuclear weapon before Persian Gulf war in 1991; Dr Mohamed ElBaradei, director general of IAEA, has repeatedly urged United States to allow UN team to inspect site, citing potential radiological safety and security implications following looting (M)

headline: A Drifter's Oddysey From the Outback to Guantánamo
abstract: David Hicks, 27-year-old Australian who converted to Islam, fought with Taliban in Afghanistan and was captured by Northern Alliance forces in Kandahar in December 2001, is now being held at US naval base in Guantanamo, Cuba, and has become thorny issue in US-Australian relations; US, seeking to reduce number of detainees, wants Australia to take custody of Hicks and prosecute him, but Australian authorities are not pressing US for his release and doubt if he can be prosecuted under Australian law; Hicks has only small support group in Australia, but government is criticized in some quarters for abandoning him; his family describes him as rebel searching for a cause; photo (M)

headline: On Pain of Death, Iraqi Soldier Kept at It
abstract: Nearly all of Saddam Hussein's Republican Guard divisions have been shifted south for defense of Baghdad, leaving estimated 100,000 army conscripts manning front lines in northern Iraq; comments by one of these soldiers, 20-year-old who refuses to give his name for fear of reprisals against his family, gives glimpse of life in Iraq's ill-equipped regular army; soldier, wounded during air attack and recovering in Kurdish-run hospital, recounts his desertion, subsequent arrest by Baath officials and forced reconscription on pain of death; photo (M)

headline: Still Descends on Baghdad After Raging Street Battles
abstract: Raging battles lasted all morning and left the Americans in firm control of an area encompassing the principal seats of governmental power.

headline: National Registry For Blocking Calls Of Telemarketers Begins Today
abstract: National do-not-call registry is set to open for anyone who wants to block sales calls; registry officials also announce new regulations, including requirement that telemarketers transmit their telephone numbers to caller-ID devices and that they have live operator on line within two seconds of consumer's picking up phone; regulations are coordinated effort of Federal Trade Commission and Federal Communications Commission; entire country will be able to register by phone as of July 7 (M)

headline: Relief Agencies Are Forced to Wait as Chaos Reigns
abstract: Red Cross official Vatche Arslanian is killed in crossfire in Baghdad, forcing it and other agencies to suspend relief program; full relief effort will be carried out by United States civilian agencies led by US Agency for International Development and will include agencies from UN and other international and private relief groups; by charter, these agencies are unable to work under authority of any military force, including Pentagon's civilian team headed by retired Gen Jay Garner, which will initially form administration; agencies will coordinate with Garner to ensure programs are as effective as possible; are stockpiling supplies but say they have little idea what they will find when they are able to inspect sanitation and water systems, size of food stocks and medical system; effort will require 480,000 tons of food every month and will cost nearly $2 billion; photo (M)

headline: Chief Executive Resigns At Lowe New York
abstract: Chief Executive Resigns At Lowe New York Paul Hammersley, chief executive of the New York office of Lowe & Partners Worldwide, resigned, the agency said yesterday, four months after another senior manager was named to top posts there.

headline: U.S. Still Critical of Iran Despite Al Qaeda Arrests
abstract: Bush administration reports getting word that Iran recently arrested some Al Qaeda members; says moves fail to ease its concerns that Iran harbors terrorists or to meet its demands that those arrested be handed over to Saudi Arabia or other authorities probing bombings of foreign compounds in Riyadh; says it is unclear how many Al Qaeda members have been arrested, who they are and whether they include any top officials; postpones high-level interagency meeting scheduled to decide new punitive steps against Iran; holds Iran's nuclear program seeks to produce materials for nuclear arms; administration officials say they are split over how to proceed with Iran, with some advocating tough measures; Sec Colin L Powell seeks to play down division; State Department dismisses idea that United States is close to breaking off diplomatic contact (M)

headline: 41 Die in Suicide Bombing in Chechnya
abstract: Truck loaded with explosives blows up near government complex in northern Chechnya, killing at least 41 people and wounding scores more; officials call it suicidal terrorist attack; region has until now escaped worst of Russia's war against Chechen separatists; none of Chechnya's known separatist groups claims responsibilty for attack; it is worst violence there since Russia held constitutional referendum in March as part of Kremlins's efforts to hasten peaceful end to war after 44 months of violence; Pres Vladimir V Putin says attack is intended to disrupt efforts to foster stability in Chechnya under loose political federation with Russia; photo; map (M)

headline: Quirky campaigns vie for the growing market in breath strips, no longer a one-brand novelty.
abstract: Marketers of breath fresheners are developing quirky ad campaigns for growing market; campaigns by Wm Wrigley Jr, which is selling its first product other than gum to carry Wrigley's name, Pfizer's Listerine Pocket Paks and Altoids division of Kraft Foods discussed; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Bank Stake Acquired
abstract: Bank of Nova Scotia to buy 36 percent of Grupo Financiero Scotiabank Inverlat from Mexican government's Bank Savings Protection Institute for $322 million, raising its ownership share to 91 percent (S)

headline: Bomb Kills Police Officer in Chechnya's Capital
abstract: A bomb exploded today outside the main stadium in Grozny killing one police officer and wounding two others, according to Russian news agencies.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: CHINA: Police Blamed For Child Starving To Death; INDIA: President Visits Troubled Kashmir;.

headline: Recording Another Day in America, Aided by Digital Cameras
abstract: Rick Smolan and David Elliot Cohen, best known for creating Day in the Life series of photography books, plan project in which over 1,000 professional photographers and tens of thousands of amateurs and students will begin shooting week in life of nation digitally; expect to get millions of images via Internet and use best from around nation in book America 24/7; will also publish smaller books for each state; HarperCollins, their former publisher, which owns trademark to earlier series, disputes their right to promote photographic time capsules as sequel to series; photo (M)

headline: One Faith, One Political Goal, and Set to Collide
abstract: Iraq's Shiite Muslims emerge from years of official repression and slaughter only to face potentially dangerous new battle between rival clerics competing for political power; Ayatollah Muhammad Bakr al-Hakim arrives in Najaf like triumphant hero to take up its political leadership; speaks at mosque to ecstatic followers; ummistakably hostile demonstration erupts as he departs, by men supporting one of his clerical and political rivals, Moktada al-Sadr; political competition between clerics, and by extension their emotional constituencies, threatens to revive old divisions between Iraq's Shiites that were constantly exploited and encouraged over 35 years by old Iraqi government; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Ice Cream Deal
abstract: World Business

headline: KSL Media Finishes Management Buyout
abstract: Changes are continuing at Interpublic Group of Companies as KSL Media, part of Partnership division, completes management buyout (S)

headline: Wired by a Kindred Spirit, the Disabled Gain Control
abstract: Dr Eamon Doherty, computer scientist who teaches at Fairleigh Dickinson University, develops individualized tools for the severely disabled to help enable them to perform simple functions; photos (M)

headline: Afghan Youth's Death Raises Kabul Bombing Toll to Five
abstract: Afghan teenager wounded in suicide car bomb attack on German peacekeepers dies, bringing to five those killed in attack; is lone Afghan casualty, apart from bomber; four German soldiers are killed and 31 wounded; it is worst attack on international peacekeeping force in 18 months it has been deployed in Kabul and surrounding area; photo (M)

headline: For Two-Way Radios, a Mileage Test
abstract: State of the Art column by David Pogue appraises some new models of two-way radios; finds many do not have nearly the range that manufacturers claim they have; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. Cautiously Begins to Seize Millions in Foreign Banks
abstract: Justice Dept begins using its expanded counterterrorism powers to seize millions of dollars from foreign banks that do business in US, saying tool has proved invaluable in seizing ill-gotten money that criminals hide overseas and that was once out of government's reach; State Dept officials raise concerns over practice, in part because most of seizures involve fraud and money-laundering investigations unrelated to terrorism; worry is that under guise of fighting terrorism, US may be seen as trying to extra-territorially impose its laws; diplomats from several nations, including Switzerland, have voiced private objections; information about seizures has been tightly guarded, and federal judges have sealed records on most of them (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Sinn Fein Is Resolute
abstract: Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams flatly denies claim by Irish and British governments that IRA peace statement lacks clarity; Great Britain and Ireland want IRA to declare end to armed conflict in order to reopen Northern Irish Assembly; photo (S)

headline: Fiat Rating Cut Possible
abstract: Moody's Investors Service reviews Fiat's for possible downgrading of its credit rating after Fiat posts sixth straight quarterly loss (S)

headline: Brazil's Leader Steps Gingerly Onto World Stage
abstract: Brazilian Pres Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, who took office in January, is becoming accustomed to new job and taking first tentative steps on world stage; is preparing to attend Group of 8 meeting and is scheduled to visit Pres George Bush; origins as leftist labor leader are being subsumed as he takes more pragmatic approach to world affairs, although he insists he is not making ideological shift when asked if his party is moving toward center; photos (M)

headline: Top General Denounces Internal Dissent on Iraq
abstract: Gen. Richard B. Myers, the nation's highest-ranking military officer, said complaints about the campaign hurt U.S. troops.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bid For Grocery Chain
abstract: British retailer Tesco agrees to buy C Two-Network grocery chain in Japan for 139 million pounds ($229 million), entering world's second-largest food market as growth in British markets slows (S)

headline: Four Chinese Given Long Prison Terms for Discussing Politics
abstract: Court in Beijing sentences four young men to long prison terms for 'subverting state power'; case involves four friends who met on university campuses to discuss politics and who posted occasional essays on Internet; case has long enraged human-rights advocates, because group's activities seem to be innocuous and because they have been imprisoned for over two years without verdict; although group had no plans to foment change actively, in China such groups are supposed to be registered with state (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar declines against euro on concern that prolonged war in Iraq will slow already sputtering US economy; euro settles at $1.0896, up from $1.0778 in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Trying to Win Iraqi Hearts And Minds on the Battlefield
abstract: Special Operations commanders fight pockets of Iraqi resistance around Basra with carpet-bombing of leaflets urging population not to resist allied forces and advising Iraqi combatants on how to surrender; drawings (M)

headline: Senate Committee Once Again Backs Stringent Penalties for Spam Senders
abstract: Senate Commerce Committee unanimously approves bill to make it illegal for anyone to use fraudulent or deceptive return e-mail addresses, fake e-mail headers or use false subject lines; bill would allow marketers to send initial unsolicited e-mail message, but require that message contain clear way for consumers to opt out of receiving further messages; calls for misdemeanor penalties of up to one year for spammers; co-sponsors, Conrad Burns and Ron Wyden, add number of changes to toughen enforcement; Sen John McCain, committee chairman, adds his own amendment to hold legitimate businsses accountable if they knowingly employ spammers to promote their products (M)

headline: Palestinian Bomber, Freed After 28 Years, Talks of Peace
abstract: Ahmed Jubarah was freed as an Israeli good-will gesture on the eve of a summit meeting with Mideast leaders and President Bush.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank's Profit Rises
abstract: ABN Amro Holding posts 74 percent increase in first-quarter net profit, to 690 million euros ($762 million) (S)

headline: Hong Kong Says Trade Deal Won't Break W.T.O. Rules
abstract: Henry Tang, Hong Kong's secretary of commerce, industry and technology, says upcoming free trade agreement with mainland China will be in compliance with World Trade Organization rules that discourage commercial discrimination based on nationality; hints that agreement will favor companies already doing business in China; agreement is expected to eliminate or reduce sharply tariffs charged by China on goods manufactured in Hong Kong; photo (M)

headline: Pfizer Narrows Field On Big Assignments
abstract: Pfizer narrows review to create direct-to-consumer campaigns for three drugs to seven finalists; assignment had been handled by Deutsch; Pfizer expands its ties with Carat North America, awarding it media planning and buying duties for products sold by its newly acquired Pharmacia unit (M)

headline: Britain Convicts 2 Algerians of Helping Finance Terrorists
abstract: They are the first people in Britain to be found guilty of being part of the Al Qaeda network.

headline: Howard Dean's Remark on Military Draws Fire From Kerry
abstract: Howard Dean, seeking Democratic presidential nomination, tells audience in New Hampshire that United States 'won't always have the strongest military'; this prompts strong rebuke from fellow candidate Sen John Kerry, who claims Dean's remark raises questions about his capacity to serve as commander in chief; Dean claims he was only arguing against Bush administration's emphasis on military action rather than diplomacy; was one of leading Democratic critics of war in Iraq and regulary attacks Kerry for supporting Congressional resolution authorizing Pres Bush to use force there; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Growth Slows
abstract: World Business BrA

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Church Suspends Confessions
abstract: Archbishop Nicholas Chia announces Roman Catholic Church in Singapore will give general absolution this Easter and suspend individual confessions due to SARS in region (S)

headline: Stun Guns Closer for Planes
abstract: Transportation Security Adm says in report to Congress that stun guns may be permitted on airplanes to protect against hijackers; United Airlines and Mesa Air Group has asked agency to consider allowing their pilots to carry such weapons; agency has not issued final decision (S)

headline: KROLL TO BUY FACTUAL DATA FOR $115 MILLION
abstract: Kroll Inc to acquire Factual Data Corp for about $115 million; Factual Data offers mortgage screening services (S)

headline: Remarks by President Bush to the Marines at Camp Lejeune
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Bush's address today at Camp Lejeune, N.C., as recorded by The New York Times:.

headline: INVESTING WITH: David O. Nicholas; Nicholas II Fund
abstract: Investing interview with David O Nicholas, who uses interviews rather than computers to help select 70-90 midcap companies in $416-million Nicholas II fund; photo; fund profile; graph (M)

headline: Hong Kong and China Near Free Trade Accord
abstract: Hong Kong and mainland China expect to conclude by the end of this month a broad agreement, senior officials said today.

headline: Rodgers: Deadly Iraqi missile hits U.S. post
abstract: NEAR BAGHDAD, Iraq (CNN) -- An Iraqi missile slammed into a U.S. Army tactical operations center south of Baghdad on Monday, killing four and injuring more than a dozen.

headline: Playing a Cat-and-Mouse Game
abstract: Northern front in war in Iraq has become cat-and-mouse game between small American Special Operations units and group of Iraqi commanders who are proving to be surprisingly tenacious; American goal is to pin down estimated 100,000 Iraqi soldiers near Dibaga, to prevent them from going to Baghdad; Iraqis are retaliating against Americans with increasingly accurate artillery fire; they have thwarted attempts by Special Operations teams to advance, despite aid of hundreds of Kurdish soldiers and heavy American airstrikes; small, lightly armed American Special Oeprations teams have had several close calls, but they have succeeded in stabilizing area and helping to deter Turkey from dispatching troops into northern Iraq; US is resisting Kurds' plea to launch major offensive there, hoping not to inflame Turkish-Kurdish relations; map (M)

headline: For Europe, Messages Differ on Size and State of the Union
abstract: European leaders gather in Porto Carras, Greece, for special summit meeting devoted to drafting first constitution for European Union; leaders consider different viewpoints about how big European Union should be, whether it should have its own formidable defense force, or maybe confine itself to economic matters; different countries in union feel differently about how much control and autonomy to cede to union--on matters of taxation, foreign policy or even culture--and about how important that surrender is for union to remain coherent and relevant; photo (M)

headline: Webdenda
abstract: Adwalls, Honolulu , and Publicitas North America , New York, signed an agreement giving the Publicitas sales force responsibility for the marketing and sale of advertising on 10,000 billboards controlled by Adwalls. Terms were not disclosed. Publicitas is part of the PubliGroupe. Andy Anderson was named to the new post of senior director for partnership marketing at the American Urban Radio Networks , New York. He had been advertising director at Billboard, New York, published by the VNU Business Publications USA unit of VNU. Barkley Evergreen & Partners , Kansas City, Mo., acquired a majority stake in Three Wide Marketing , Kansas City, a sponsorship and event marketing agency. Dan Fromm and Joe Sciara will continue as co-presidents at Three Wide Marketing. Terms were not disclosed. MaryAnn Bekkedahl , publisher at Men's Health magazine, New York, was named a vice president at the magazine’s parent company, Rodale Inc. Jodi Coppernoll was named director for business development at Euro RSCG Tatham Partners , Chicago, succeeding Alan Reighard, who was named managing director for advertising at the agency's Salt Lake City office. Ms. Coppernoll had been director for business development at Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, New York, part of the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network. Euro RSCG Tatham is part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas. Kevin Cox was named vice president and group account director for technology accounts at the San Francisco office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos , succeeding Patrick Godfrey, who left, the agency said. Mr. Cox had been vice president and director for strategy and integrated marketing at the San Francisco office of Doremus, part of the Omnicom Group. Hill, Holliday is part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Mark Dacey was named senior client partner in the entertainment and media practice at Korn/Ferry International , New York. He had been president at the Marketing-Media and Arts Group at VNU Business Publications USA, New York, part of VNU. D'Arcy Directory Marketing , Chicago, became part of a sibling, the Starcom MediaVest Group , and was renamed SMG Directory Marketing . Kathleen DeCaire-Aden , who had headed D'Arcy Directory Marketing, will also oversee SMG Directory Marketing. The change is part of a reorganization at the Publicis Groupe as it closes D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles. Philip H. Geier Jr. was named to the board at the Intermedia Advertising Group , New York, a television advertising research company. Mr. Geier is chairman emeritus at the Interpublic Group of Companies; he served as chairman and chief executive from 1980 to 2000. Sue R.E. Geramian , director for corporate communications at Gruner & Jahr USA , New York, was named a vice president. Gruner & Jahr is part of Bertelsmann. Kim Hatamiya was named senior vice president for sales and marketing at Sony Pictures Television International , Culver City, Calif., succeeding Annie Morita, who left, the company said. Ms. Hatamiya had been senior vice president and general manager for television and film at the Los Angeles office of Mindrocket Media. Sony Pictures Television is part of the Sony Pictures Entertainment division of the Sony Corporation. Innovation Ads , New York, is selling print advertising inside more than 37,000 taxi cabs in the Boston, Dallas, Phoenix and San Diego areas, effective on June 1. Beverly Kastens , associate vice president for marketing at the American Legacy Foundation , Washington, which sponsors antismoking campaigns aimed at teenagers, was promoted to vice president for marketing. Elizabeth Marks , the senior vice president and director for business development at the Media Planning Group's United States division, New York, was named chief marketing officer, succeeding David Colomer, who is moving to Madrid to take a marketing post at the Media Planning Group Spain. The Media Planning Group is part of Havas. The Northarvest Bean Growers Association , Fargo, N.D., named Gabriel deGrood Bendt , Minneapolis, as agency of record on its account, which had been handled on a project basis. Billings were not disclosed. Octagon Worldwide , New York, promoted two employees. Michael Bucks , executive vice president for corporate development and head of business affairs at Octagon CSI, a television division, was named chief operating officer for marketing for Africa, Australia, Europe, the Middle East and New Zealand. Mr. Bucks, who continues to be based in London, succeeds Tim Moufarrige, who left, the agency said. Also, Curt Curtis , chief marketing officer, was named to the new post of senior executive vice president for marketing, sales and business development; he remains in New York. Octagon is part of the Interpublic Sports and Entertainment Group, a division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Beth Robitaille , advertising director at the Chicago office of Coastal Living magazine, was named to the new post of associate publisher. Coastal Living is part of the Southern Progress Corporation division of Time Inc., part of AOL Time Warner. Sprinks , New York, an online advertising sales division of About Inc. , named the Technology Communications Group at J. Walter Thompson, New York, as agency of record to create its first advertising. Billings were not disclosed. About Inc. is part of Primedia. Sudler & Hennessey , New York, acquired Health Answers Education , North Wales, Pa., which provides training for pharmaceutical and biotechnology sales employees, from Health Answers Inc. Terms were not disclosed. Mark Samuel will continue as president at Health Answers Education, which will operate as an autonomous unit of Sudler & Hennessey, the health care communications unit of Young & Rubicam, part of the WPP Group. Brian Zorn was named senior vice president and management supervisor at Integrated Communications , Parsippany, N.J., working on a new assignment, the Diovan account. Diovan is sold by the Novartis Pharmaceuticals division of Novartis. Mr. Zorn had been senior vice president and management group director at Lally, McFarland & Pantello Euro RSCG, New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas. Integrated Communications is part of the Lowe Healthcare Network, a division of the Lowe & Partners Worldwide unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Executive Pay: A Special Report; The Hunt for Clarity In Proxy Statements
abstract: Article in special report on executive pay notes ways executives become multimillionaries have expanded, leaving investors, regulators and rest of public in dark about much of corporate compensation despite rules requiring companies to report salaries, bonuses and some other forms of executive pay in easy-to-read tables; executives now get generous benefits long after they retire that are rarely spelled out; top executives have been paid enough in form of stock that they own large, hard to calculate, portions of their companies; disclosures recommended by shareholder-rights advocates and management professors noted (M)

headline: Israeli Forces Strike in Gaza
abstract: A helicopter strike in Gaza, which targeted a top Hamas official and killed two, was followed by an attack that killed three.

headline: Ugandan's Key to White House: AIDS
abstract: Pres Bush embraces Uganda Pres Yoweri Museveni at White House for his success in fighting AIDS, but says nothing publicly about what White House views as Uganda's less inspiring role as weapons supplier to militias in Congo civil war; meeting showcases Bush's $15-billion AIDS bill; photo of two with children's choir whose members were orphaned by AIDS; Ugandan program emphasizes abstinence, which pleases Bush's conservative base; officials say Bush was adamant in private that Uganda stop backing militias (M)

headline: It's Boeing Vs. Airbus In Big Battle Over Brazil
abstract: Boeing and Airbus battle over who will supply aircraft to Latin America's largest-by-far airline that will be created by merger of Brazil's two leading carriers, Varig and TAM; Boeing, traditonally dominant in region, supplies ailing Varig, while Airbus supplies TAM (M)

headline: Pentagon Officials Say They See No Organized Iraqi Resistance
abstract: Pentagon officials monitoring attacks on American forces in Iraq say that there are no indications of a centrally organized resistance movement.

headline: Residents Blare Horns, Dance and Empty Government Offices
abstract: Much of Baghdad tumbled into American hands today as Saddam Hussein's image was pulled down from pedestals and portraiture in the city.

headline: 28 Boys Die in Fire at School for Deaf in Russia
abstract: Unable to hear the frantic shouts of adults, 28 deaf boys perished and at least 106 were injured early today after fire consumed their boarding school.

headline: Most Airlines Increase Domestic Fares by $5
abstract: Six major airlines increased domestic air fares $5 each way on almost all tickets over weekend, most significant fare increase in more than year; four low-cost airlines match fare increase; reduction in seats coupled with slight increase in domestic traffic probably influenced decision by airlines to increase fares; Air Transport Assn says domestic traffic rose 0.2 percent for week ended May 4 from year earlier; international traffic was down 16.9 percent compared with year ago, while trans-Pacific traffic was down 36.6 percent (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: CHINA: Auto Venture To Start; HONG KONG: Bus Operator Acquired; TAIWAN: Chip Sales Rise; JAPAN: Broker Posts Profit;.

headline: Nigerian Leader Dismisses Monitors' Criticism of Election
abstract: President Olusegun Obasanjo tonight defended the elections on Saturday and he expressed disappointment with international election monitors who had criticized the process.

headline: Suspect in Plot on U.S. Base Is Convicted of Lesser Charge
abstract: German court convicts Turkish man Osman Petmezci of illegally possessing explosives and illegal drugs but more serious charge that he and American fiancee Astrid Eyzaguirre planned to bomb headquarters of United States Army is dropped (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: HONG KONG: Export Growth; SOUTH KOREA: Bank Sale Reconsidered; TAIWAN: Interest Rate Cut;.

headline: Airlines Fear the Loneliness Will Persist
abstract: Nation's airlines, which blamed war in Iraq for plunge in business that forced layoffs of more than 10,000 employees and elimination of dozens of flights, are not expecting postwar era to be better; weak economy, continued fears of terrorism and complicating factor of mysterious illness SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, are likely to offset any increase in travel that could be expected once conflict in Iraq subsides; United Airlines executive vice president Douglas A Hacker says carrier does not expect any bounce back; Air Transport Association economist John Heimlich says short-term outlook is gloomy; association cites year-over-year 17.4 percent decline in overall travel for week ended April 6; domestic travel fell 14 percent, while Asia-Pacific region is off more than 25 percent; graph; photo (M)

headline: As SARS Outbreak Took Shape, Health Agency Took Fast Action
abstract: Article in Rise of a Virus series says World Health Organization acted as swiftly as it could in face of SARS epidemic, given lack of official candor in China, where disease first erupted in November 2002; notes praise agency has received for showing courage to issue global alert on March 12; photos (L)

headline: FIVE ARAB LEADERS VOW ACTIVE FIGHT AGAINST VIOLENCE
abstract: Leaders of Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Jordan and Bahrain and new Palestinian Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas pledge to Pres Bush that they will actively fight 'culture of extremism and violence' that has undercut Mideast peace efforts for years, promising to curb flow of money that finances suicide bombings against Israel; photo with Bush at Sharm el Sheik; leaders step around hard details and Saudi Arabia resists commmitment to speeding up normalization of relations with Israel; Pres Bush, meeting alone with leaders for 90 minutes, is heard on microphone telling them Israel must deal with its West Bank settlements and ensure Arabs contiguous territory, but also exhorting them to fight terrorist funding; carefully worded official statement is strongest yet on ending aid to Hamas, Hezbollah and other terrorist groups; Bush commits himself and US to helping with hard decisions toward peace; Asst Sec John Wolf to lead US monitoring team (M)

headline: A Top Suspect In '91 Massacre Of Croatians Surrenders
abstract: A former Yugoslav Army commander, charged with directing the 1991 massacre of nearly 300 Croatian civilians during the siege of the Danube port of Vukovar, turned himself in to the Serbian authorities today.    Serbia's government called the surrender of the commander, Capt. Miroslav Radic, a major victory in its crackdown on organized crime and war-crimes suspects after the assassination last month of Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic.

headline: E-Commerce Report; States have become stricter about sales taxes for online transactions. Next in line to collect: Europe.
abstract: Governments wield their tax powers with increasing zeal over commerce conducted via Internet; European Union will soon begin levying value-added tax on digital goods and services imported by consumers, move expected to significantly effect operations and competitive standing of American Internet companies; has been collecting import taxes on physical goods from abroad sold online for last few years; photo (M)

headline: Martin Savidge: Public Might Not Trust Ex-Police
abstract: The chaos in Baghdad continued Saturday, but some stores re-opened and a man came forward claiming to be deposed leader Saddam Hussein's former plastic surgeon.

headline: Private Sector; Cutting Out Middlemen in a Magazine
abstract: Bloomingdale's plans own quarterly lifestyle magazine, B, which will be sold at store and sent free to some customers; John Brown Publishing, joint partner in venture, will finance magazine and handle ad sales (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Computer Horizons' Founder Resigns
abstract: Computer Horizons' founder John Cassese, who is under indictment on insider trading charges, resigns as chief executive and will get severance pay totaling $3.5 million; chief financial officer William Murphy will succeed Cassese as chief executive; Computer Horizons is fighting unsolicited takeover offer from Aquent; sues Aquent, saying Aquent created 'false impression' in proxy material that Computer Horizons is either for sale or subject of 'bona fide acquisition proposal' (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NEW ENGLAND BUSINESS SERVICE , Groton, Mass., a supplier of forms and services to marketing companies, agreed to buy Safeguard Business Systems, Dallas, a maker of checks and business forms, for $72.5 million.    EXXON MOBIL , Irving, Tex., the oil company, is combining its East and West Coast production operations in Houston and cutting about 80 administrative and clerical jobs in New Orleans.

headline: In Pakistan Border Towns, Taliban Has a Resurgence
abstract: Many Taliban who took refuge in border regions of Pakistan after government of Afghanistan collapsed in Dec 2001 are remaining in sprawling Afghan refugee settlements; they are gathering openly, showing growing confidence since alliance of religous parties sympathetic to their movement won provincial elections in Quetta last fall; meet weekly to talk of war and return of Taliban to Afghanistan; photo (M)

headline: New Rules Give Big Media Chance to Get Even Bigger
abstract: As consumer advocates deplored yesterday's changes to media ownership rules as a blow to democracy, investors bought up shares of the biggest media companies.     Both advocates and investors agree that the latest rule changes are likely to let media leviathans like the News Corporation and Viacom fortify their positions while increasing the odds against newcomers and small fry.

headline: Former Captives Recall Horror of Hussein's Prisons
abstract: Prison in Basra, Iraq, is opened to reveal workings of Saddam Hussein's elaborate bureaucracy of terror; people say cells were occupied until just before war, but no inmates are found, and many people believe they were executed and sent to anonymous graves outside city; people swarm over over state security building, its cellblocks and its grounds, poring over scatterd files in search of clues about missing friends and relatives; photos (M)

headline: MCI Investors Learn Promises Can Be Broken
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on WorldCom reorganization plan focuses on provision that grants nothing to retail investors of securities issued in 1996 by MCI Communications, telephone company that was acquired by WorldCom in 1998; securities known as Quips, which were debt, not preferred stock, close in over-the-counter trading at $5.25, or 21 percent of their $25 par value; traders hope that Thomas M Mayer, partner in Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel who is representing holders of MCI Quips, will persuade bankruptcy court to give them better deal; graph (M)

headline: 2nd Suicide Blast in Week Claims New Victims in Chechnya
abstract: At least 14 people were killed at a religious festival in the latest attack, which signaled an intensification of the conflict.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Brewer Names Executive
abstract: Scottish anl

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Touch America To Receive Loan From Qwest
abstract: Qwest Communications International will provide bankruptcy financing to Touch America Holdings Inc as part of agreement that resolves billing and other disputes between phone companies (S)

headline: Some Numbers Only Add To the Fog
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column questions General Electric Co's practice of including gains on asset sales in its overall operating results, instead of highlighting them on separate line; GE holds its financial reports are explicit and give investors needed clarity (M)

headline: U.S. Challenging Gemstar Severance
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission seeks court order to freeze severance payments to Gemstar-TV Guide International's former chief executive Henry C Yuen and former chief financial officer Elsie Ma Leung; Gemstar, which SEC has been investigating for possible securities fruad, said last month that it might pay Yuen $29.5 million in severance after firing him; Leung, who was also fired, might be entitled to $8.17 million (S)

headline: U.S. Repeats North Korea Stance Before Visit From South's Leader
abstract: The White House refused to rule out military force against the North but said again that it hopes for a diplomatic solution to problems with that country.

headline: 3 Qaeda Cells Are Operating In Saudi Arabia, Officials Say
abstract: American and Saudi government officials say Al Qaeda has at least three cells of operatives plotting new attacks in Saudi Arabia or North America; Prince Bandar bin Sultan, Saudi ambassador to Washington, says intelligence monitoring has picked up almost as much chatter about impending attack as was gathered before three simultaneous bombings in Riyadh last week that have been linked to Al Qaeda; Saudi and American officials say renewed threat against both countries would result in closer cooperation; Saudi officials are stunned by bombings in Riyadh and are cooperating more fully with US investigators than they have in previous efforts to track down terrorists in their country (M)

headline: Call to Overthrow Chávez Cost Venezuelan a U.S. Visa
abstract: State Dept announces it revoked visa of former Venezuelan general Enrique Medina in May for advocating overthrow of Pres Hugo Chavez; says American Embassy in Venezuela advocated revocation; political experts say move signals US rejection of radical elements in Venezuela's opposition that favor anthing-goes approach to deposing Chavez; Bush administration has publicly endorsed referendum on Chavez's rule as solution to political tumult (M)

headline: Hamas Halts Truce Talks With Abbas
abstract: The statements by the top Hamas leadership in the Gaza Strip came a day after Israeli troops killed two Hamas members in a shootout in the West Bank.

headline: Lawyers Taking Aim at Ford On Veracity of Expert
abstract: Questions about credibility of expert witness in lawsuits involving rollover accidents are putting Ford Motor Co on defensive, as lawyers for accident victims press claims that Ford covered up evidence that its Bronco II sport utility vehicle was dangerous; South Carolina Supreme Court last week said estate of Ray H Chewning Jr whose leg was crushed in 1990 Bronco II rollover can seek to reopen case he lost decade ago; court cited claims by Chewning's lawyers that Ford paid expert witness, former Ford engineer David Bickerstaff, to testify falsely on its behalf; decision follows 2001 finding by federal judge in West Virginia case that there was evidence of 'conspiracy' between Fod and Bickerstaff to mislead court; Ford settled that case, which involved fatal accident, within two days of judge's finding; photo (M)

headline: Estate planning: Preparing for the worst-case scenario
abstract: PARIS—  When Michael Carter, an American, died this winter in Paris at the age of 45, he left a wife, three small children, a wide circle of friends — and one of the worst nightmares an expatriate family can face.

headline: Early Surge Falters, Leaving Modest Gains at End of Day
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 23.26 points, or 0.3 percent, to 8,300.41; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 1.08 points, or 0.1 percent, to 879.93; Nasdaq composite index rises 6 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,389.51; US dollar rises 0.7 percent against euro, to $1.0659, and 0.3 percent against yen, to 120.23 yen; US bond prices fall; 10-year note falls 7/32, to 99 5/32; yield rises to 3.98 percent from 3.95 percent; 30-year bond falls 2/32, to 106 2/32; yield is unchanged at 4.97 percent; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Serbia to Issue Arrest Warrant for the Wife of Milosevic
abstract: Serbia, as part of sweeping crackdown on organized crime after assassination of Prime Min Zoran Djindjic, plans to issue arrest warrant for Mirjana Markovic, ex-Pres Slobodan Milosevic's wife; Markovic, thought to be hiding in Russia, is political power in own right; is suspected of ordering Aug 2000 killing of ex-Pres Ivan Stambolic, her husband's one-time political rival; Serbia is also expected to ask Russia to arrest and extradite Milosevic's son, Marko; arrests several people linked to both Milosevic government and Zemun clan, organized crime group that allegedly killed Djindjic; seeks Zemun boss Milorad Lukovic; photo (M)

headline: Cordiant Sells Off Main Australia Units
abstract: Cordiant Sells Off Main Australia Units.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Electronic Data Wins Pentagon Contract
abstract: Electronic Data Systems Corp will upgrade Pentagon's computer networks and data-storage systems under two-year contract valued at $258 million (S)4

headline: Deal Seems Near on Israeli Pullout From North Gaza
abstract: A deal that would remove Israeli troops and replace them with Palestinian security forces appeared close despite new violence.

headline: Foreign Envoys Discuss Iraq and Use of Force
abstract: European Union foreign ministers meeting in Greece agree to send diplomatic envoys back to Baghdad; consider new security doctrine that could authorize use of force against 'irresponsible nations' controlling weapons of mass destruction; agree to put differences over Iraq behind them and mandate Javier Solana, European Union foreign policy chief, to draw up new security strategy for the bloc; photo (M)

headline: Visit to Cemetery in Normandy Signals U.S.-French Good Will
abstract: French and American officials visit American military cemetery at Normandy beaches in effort to mend relations between their countries; Treasury Sec John W Snow and France's finance minister Francis Mer are accompanied by Canadian finance min John Manley; Mer makes clear effort in his remarks to overcome anti-French sentiment in US over French opposition to Iraq war; photo (M)

headline: Federal Reserve Lowers Key Rate To 1%, Lowest Level Since 1958
abstract: Federal Reserve, trying halt long economic downturn, cuts short-term interest rates by quarter point, taking them to 1 percent, lowest level since 1958; rejects half-point cut, to disappointment of stock and bond markets; Fed issues statement saying economy appears to be improving but could still benefit from easier credit since it has yet to exhibit sustainable growth; also says concerns about price declines, rather than inflation, are 'likely to predominate for foreseeable future'; some economists say statement is signal that Fed, while still viewing risk of deflation as minor, plans to keep interest rates low for extended period; stocks and bonds fall after announcement, with Standard & Poor's 500 Index closing at 975.32, down 8.13 percent (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: CANADA: Cost Of A Mine Strike; CANADA: Power Contract Error;.

headline: Calculatingly, U.S. Tolerates Dollar's Fall
abstract: Treasury Sec John W Snow becomes latest policy maker to try to talk up sagging economy while stopping short of major policy action against recent decline in dollar's value; Snow calls dollar's 20 percent decline against euro over last year 'fairly modest'; currency traders say they understand remarks to mean that Bush administration, reversing policy adopted by Clinton administration, does not plan to buy dollars on open market to halt decline; dollar ends down 0.6 percent against euro; euro trades at $1.1643 in late afternoon trading, close to four-year high, up from $1.1578; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Battling the spread of SARS, Asian nations escalate travel restrictions
abstract: HONG KONG:—  Asian nations battling the spread of a killer disease across land, sea and air borders imposed dramatic new restrictions Friday on all travelers suspected of infection.

headline: Bush Demands 'Cooperation' From Syrians
abstract: Pres Bush accuses Syria of harboring senior Iraqi military and government officials; demands 'cooperation' in punishing some of them, but stops short of threatening to use military force against Syria; asserts there are chemical weapons in Syria but does not clarify whether they were shipped there during or before war in Iraq; Syrian officials deny allegations that they are taking in Iraqi leaders and accuse Washington of waging 'disinformation campaign' to divert attention from lawlessness in Iraq; Bush also says efforts to get North Korea to bargaining table to discuss nuclear arms may be successful; question remains whether US march to Baghdad will drive North Korea to disarm or to build nuclear arsenal; Gen Tommy Franks says military has samples of Saddam Hussein's DNA and will use them to determine whether he has been killed in airstrikes (M)

headline: Experimental Drug May Fight SARS, Researchers Say
abstract: German researchers say that experimental Pfizer drug AG-7088, which was tested and shelved as common cold remedy, may, with some chemical tinkering, be used to fight SARS virus; Pfizer did not apply for FDA approval and modification would take several years; researcher Dr David Ho says in Hong Kong that he and colleages at Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center in New York have synthesized several peptides that could prevent SARS from entering human cells, but that will also take years of testing (M)

headline: Entertainment Industry Loses in Net Case
abstract: Federal Judge Stephen Wilson rules in favor of online services Grokster and StreamCast Networks that allow people to share music, movies and other digital files freely over Internet; decision puts brakes on momentum entertainment industry has previously enjoyed in its legal efforts to block file-swapping services, which have made it easy for consumers to acquire copyrighted material free; Wilson says Grokster and Streamcast are essentially no different from companies that create videocassette recorders, which also allow consumers to make their own copies (M)

headline: Mr. Murdoch's War
abstract: Global influence of Rupert Murdoch grows as his News Corp adds major additional outlets in various countries to its media empire; editorial policies of most of his English-language news organizations echo Murdoch's stridently hawkish political views about war in Iraq and his belief that resulting lowered oil prices will greatly strengthen world economy; worldwide expansion of Murdoch's reach leads critics to compare him to press barons of decades past and causes governments to invoke regulatory restrictions over media ownership; he says that overseeing News Corp leaves him no time to directly manage editorial content of its global outlets; photos; list of company's major holdings worldwide (M)

headline: Another G.I. Dies in Violence-Prone Iraqi Town
abstract: The attack in Falluja, which also injured five U.S. troops, was the eighth death of an American soldier in the last 10 days.

headline: On Video Games, The Jury Is Out And Confused
abstract: Debate about effects of electronic games on children does not make parents' decisions about allowing games or setting limits easy, as even experts disagree; years of research focusing on negative impact of gaming is not easily mitigated, even though new University of Rochester study shows games can improve visual attention skills; photos; drawing (L)

headline: Gambling on Peace: India's Leader Tries Again
abstract: Analysis of Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee's unexpected offer of willingness to give peace with Pakistan one more chance, and Pakistan's warm response to his olive branch; says American officials have been pushing India to resume dialogue with Pakistan for over year, and toward that end Deputy Sec Richard Armitage is planning visit to region next week; says Vajpayee, with his offer, has managed to pre-empt Armitage, who will now be in position of trying to coax peace process along primarily by looking for concrete commitments from Pres Pervez Musharraf on ending support for Islamic militancy in Kashmir; says Vajpayee has put Pakistan on defensive, in move one diplomat describes as brilliant tactically; map (M)

headline: Willard G. Rouse III, 60, Dies; Shaped Philadelphia Skyline
abstract: Willard Goldsmith Rouse III, scion of family of builders who built his own niche with Liberty Property Trust of Malvern, Pa, real estate business that includes some of most visible peaks of Philadelphia skyline, dies at age 60; photos (M)

headline: Dowry Too High. Lose Bride and Go to Jail.
abstract: Nisha Sharma becomes overnight sensation in India by calling police to her wedding and having groom arrested after free-for-all between their families over his family's last-minute demand for larger dowry; dowries, illegal for many decades in India, are now often disguised by families as gifts to give newlyweds a start in life; more than a media creation, Sharma and her dowry defiance strike chord in nation, whose expanding middle class is rebelling against dowry tradition that is being overfed by new commercialism; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Freddie Mac Fires President Over Accounting Inquiry  Freddie Mac, the mortgage finance company, fired David Glenn, left, its president, contending that he failed to cooperate with an internal investigation into its accounting practices.    The company's two other most senior officials abruptly quit, Freddie Mac said. Leland C. Brendsel, Freddie Mac's chairman and chief executive, retired, and Vaughn Clarke, its chief financial officer, resigned. [Page A1.]

headline: LAIDLAW EMERGES FROM BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS
abstract: Laidlaw International edmerges from bankruptcy court protection (S)

headline: Liverpool Journal; The House That Can't Forget a Boy With a Guitar
abstract: Two-story house in Liverpool, Eng, bears plaque saying John Lennon lived there from 1945 to 1963; National Trust has spent past year restoring interiors to time when Lennon lived there, and now has opened it to public; those taking tour remark on such ordinary setting producing one of 20th century's legendary figures; photos (M)

headline: On the Road to Falluja
abstract: An attempt to end the attacks against American troops became an excursion into the complex politics of postwar Iraq.

headline: Another Defector Joins Lazard
abstract: Lazard, private investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, says Gary W Parr has defected from Morgan Stanley to join firm as its deputy chairman (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.75        Discount rate   2.25   2.25   N.A.        Federal funds   1.25   1.24   1.79        3-month T-bills   1.12   1.11   1.66        6-month T-bills   1.12   1.10   1.90        10-yr. T-infl.   2.09   2.05   3.14        10-yr. T-note   3.95   3.90   5.15        30-yr. T-bond   4.94   4.90   5.64        Telephone bd.   5.85   5.77   7.75        Municipal bds.   4.97   4.99   5.35        (Sources: Citigroup; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Elizabeth Neuffer, 46, Reporter Overseas for The Boston Globe
abstract: Elizabeth Neuffer, award-winning reporter for Boston Globe, is killed in automobile accident in Iraq, where she was covering aftermath of war; she was 46; photo (M)

headline: Big Shareholder Raises Stake in Cordiant, Posing a Threat to WPP's Bid
abstract: Active Value Advisors increases its stake in British advertising firm Cordiant Communications to nearly 24%, casting doubts on WPP Group's plan to acquire Cordiant; British regulations require that acquisition be approved by three quarters of shareholders (M)

headline: Briefly Noted
abstract: 2 British soldiers were held in Syria; Iran urged to allow more inspections; Afghan panel to investigate Massoud's death; Red Cross wants grave sites secured;

headline: Travel Gadgets That Promise Safety and Security Are Selling Briskly
abstract: Travel Gadgets That Promise Safety and Security Are Se

headline: Masks Become a Taiwan Must-Have, With Bootlegging and Price Gouging
abstract: Taiwan, hit hard by SARS epidemic, is mask mad; importers are ordering truckloads of them, and Chinese-Americans are shipping them to relatives on island; public health experts say roaring underground market for N95 masks, which filter out 95 percent of particles, is based largely on misunderstanding; say average person could wear simple paper surgical mask as Pres Chen Shui-bian did when he appeared in public this week; photo (M)

headline: 2 WorldCom Executives, Faulted in Bankruptcy Inquiry Report, Resign
abstract: WorldCom's general counsel Michael H Salsbury and treasurer Susan Mayer resign, one day after bankruptcy court examiner's report by Dick Thornburgh raises questions about their roles in company's collapse (M)

headline: Lebanon Says Arrests Foiled Attack on the U.S. Embassy
abstract: Lebanese government officials say Lebanese Army, helped by Syrian intelligence, arrested nine Islamic militants in northern Lebanon who were plotting attack on United States Embassy in Beirut; say men were also planning to take one or more government officials hostage as bargaining chip in efforts to free 30 militants of Sunni Muslim extremist movement arrested in government crackdown two years ago; Army spokesman says movement, Redemption and Dawn of Islam, adheres to strict Wahhabi branch dominant in Saudi Arabia; says 7 of men are Lebanese and two Palestinians, and that explosives and detonators were also seized during arrests (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Rights Body Approved
abstract: Egyptian Parliament unanimously approves law to set up National Council for Human Rights; some rights activists raise doubts about government's seriousness, noting that security officials recently rejected registrations of two rights groups (S)

headline: Spain Expels 6 Iraqi Diplomats After Arms Cache Is Revealed
abstract: Spain orders six Iraqi diplomats to leave country after reportedly learning of cache of illicit firearms in Iraqi Embassy (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Help For Economy
abstract: Thailand has set up a 100-billion-baht fund ($2.4 billion) to invest in troubled sectors of the economy. As that fund, the Phoenix Fund, was announced, Thailand's stock exchange said it would create a 700-million-baht fund to invest in the shares it lists. The exchange said the investment was part of an effort to increase revenue as interest rates on its bank deposits fall. The Thai government has already announced plans to sell mutual funds to individual investors to raise part of the 100 billion baht it plans to use to invest in local stocks as part of its plan to prop up stock prices.   Wayne Arnold (NYT)

headline: PRESIDENT WILLING TO GIVE GREENSPAN NEW TERM AT FED
abstract: Pres Bush says Alan Greenspan deserves fifth term as Federal Reserve chairman, in effect leaving to Greenspan decision of whether to extend his long tenure, interview with financial journalists; White House officials say Bush will renominate Greenspan before his current four-year term expires in June 2004; Greenspan, 77, has been chairman since 1987; he undergoes prostate surgery; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Grey Executive Pleads Guilty to Charges
abstract: Grey Worldwide's former executive vice president Mitchell E Mosallem unexpectedly pleads guilty in federal court as part of Justice Department's antitrust investigation into print production and advertising industries; Mosallem was first Madison Avenue executive to be indicted, joining executive of Color Whreel, New York company know known as 291 Digital, in what prosecutors called bid-rigging scheme centered on defrauding Grey clients through inflated invoices for production of print ad from 1990 to 2001 (M)

headline: CAPTURED OFFICIAL IS SAID TO TELL U.S. HUSSEIN SURVIVED
abstract: Abid Hamid Mahmoud al-Tikriti, captured top aide to Saddam Hussein, reportedly tells US interrogators that Hussein and sons Uday and Qusay survived war and that he himself fled to Syria with sons after conflict; news reportedly sparks intense burst of clandestine US military activity aimed at capturing Hussein and his sons; American officials say conviction among loyalists that Hussein is still alive is motivating military resistance against US forces; photo (M)

headline: President Plans A June Meeting On the Mideast
abstract: President Bush will meet the Israeli and Palestinian prime ministers and the leaders of some major Arab nations early next month to press for progress in his plan for peace in the Middle East, administration officials said today.    Mr. Bush plans to meet at the resort of Sharm el Sheik on the Sinai Peninsula with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel and Mahmoud Abbas, the new Palestinian prime minister, one official said, although there were indications that the location might still be changed, possibly to a site in Jordan.

headline: EXPRESS SCRIPTS DISCLOSES $2.48 BILLION IN REBATES, FEES
abstract: Express Scripts Inc, which manages prescription benefits for employers and insurers, received $2.48 billion in rebates and fees from pharmaceutical companies in last three years; discloses rebates under change in accounting practices in regulatory filing, accounting for money as decrease to cost of goods sold, rather than increase to revenue; change means Express Scripts' revenue for 2000 through 2002 is reduced by same amount (S)

headline: S.E.C. Looks at Stock Deals Done in Wachovia Merger
abstract: Wachovia Corp says Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating certain stock purchases made after its merger with First Union Corp was announced in April 2001; stock purchases came in middle of battle for control of Wachovia between First Union and SunTrust Banks, which made hostile bid; SunTrust executives asserted at time that Wachovia and First Union wee buying First Union's stock to increase value of First Union's offer; Wachovia says its first-quarter earnings, which will be announced on April 16, will beat analysts' expectations (M)

headline: Dad's Job Was Worse, a Survey Suggests
abstract: DIARY Dad's Job Was Worse, A Survey Suggests.

headline: Iraqis Set to Meet to Pick Transitional Government
abstract: Political gathering of 300 Iraqis from most parts of country and most religious and ethnic factions, sponsored by United States and Britain, decides to call national conference in month's time to select postwar transitional government for Iraq; national conference is to decide whether Iraq wil adopt leadership council or single head of state; Zalmay Khalilzad, Bush administration envoy, is co-chairman of meeting, held in Baghdad; members of Shiite clerical groups are present, as are members of Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq, group with strong ties to Iran that boycotted earlier meeting in Nasiriya; several miles from conference hall, several thousand protesters affiliated with Shiite theological college in Najaf denounce meeting as unrepresentative of religious Shiism; security for Baghdad gathering is extraordinarily tight, partly because large-scale demonstrations are expected to mark Saddam Hussein's 66th birthday; in Tikrit and nearby Awja, Hussein's hometown, demonstrations that members of his family called for are thwarted by stepped-up presence of American troops; two nights earlier, pro-Hussein demonstration in Tikrit left one Iraq man injured and three Iraqi cars crushed by American tanks (M)

headline: Europe Sues Greece Over Airline Subsidy
abstract: European Commission is suing Greek government for refusing to retrieve 194 million euros ($213 million) in statae aid granted to Olympic Airways, assistance that commission has said is illegal; action is latest sign that despite pressure from some European Union nations, including Greece, commission intends to stick to its hard line against state assistance for airlines, regardless of industry's problems; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Internet
abstract: STUDIOS AND DVD COPIER GO TO COURT; KAZAA OPERATOR TOLD TO DISCLOSE INVESTORS;.

headline: A Visitor to Toronto Is Stricken With SARS
abstract: North Carolina man who visited Toronto in May comes down with SARS, apparently contracted while visiting relative at nursing home; health officials in state say case is mild and illness has not spread (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Tepid Economic Growth
abstract: French economy avoided recession in first three months of year, as its growth slowed to rate of 1 percent year over year from 1.5 percent in fourth quarter of 2002; economy grew 0.3 percent in first quarter from fourth (S)

headline: Teach Your Children, Virtually
