abstract: Although there are fewer than two dozen cyberschools serving lower grades nationwide, trend is broadening; charter virtual elementary and middle schools are stand-alone programs and are blossoming because of increasing dissatisfaction with conventional schools and increasing acceptance of cyberlearning; most states have explored so-called distance learning, which is useful for families who favor home schooling, in that they provide complete curriculum; critics lament lack of social interaction; photos (L)

headline: U.S. Civilian Experts Say Bureaucracy and Infighting Jeopardize Search for Weapons
abstract: Civilian scientists and other experts recruited to help find weapons of mass destruction in Iraq characterize American military's search effort so far as superficial and misguided; say bureaucratic infighting and confusion have delayed effort and search itself may be compromised; Defense Department officials, while conceding some missteps, defend military hunt as sound; photo (M)

headline: A High Point in 2 Decades of U.S. Might
abstract: The collapse of government authority in Baghdad constitutes the high-water mark for a new American determination to use the nation's military might.

headline: New Charges Against Ex-WorldCom Executive
abstract: WorldCom Inc's former chief financial officer Scott D Sullivan is indicted on additional federal charges that accuse him of defrauding series of banks out of billions of dollars; new charges increase potential prison time that Sullivan could receive; indictment says in 2001, Sullivan conspired on WorldCom's behalf to defraud several banks, including Bank of America and Chase Manhattan, out of $4.25 billion just weeks before company announced that it misreported billions of dollars in expenses; Sullivan is free on $10 million bond (M)

headline: State Dept., Not the F.B.I., Expelled Cuban Diplomats
abstract: FBI officials say that White House and State Dept officials were behind expulsion of 14 Cuban diplomats from United States for 'inappropriate activities,' including spying; bureau officials say there was no specific espionage event that touched off action, adding credence to Cuba's charge that expulsions are part of new political strategy; administration's move to expel seven diplomats from Cuba's Washington mission and seven from United Nations delegation comes amid growing tensions and increasingly heated rhetoric between countries; American officials are studying series of measures to signal displeasure with Cuba's recent crackdown on government critics (M)

headline: Security Worries May Cut French Host Town's Profits
abstract: French government decides for security reasons to seal off Evian-les-Bains from rest of world for three-day economic summit meeting by Group of 8; Pres Bush has reportedly discussed prospect of demonstrations during summit with Pres Jacques Chirac, who is said to have assured him that all necessary security measures have been taken; restrictions being imposed will sharply cut into profits city's merchants had envisioned; photo (M)

headline: Extended Review of Oracle Bid Is Expected
abstract: Justice Department plans to extend its review of Oracle's $6.3 billion hostile bid for Peoplesoft, adding another roadblock to software maker's attempt to acquire rival (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: NEPAL: Prime Minister Quits Amid Protests; JAPAN: Official Resigns Over Postquake Pinball;.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Voting by Computer.

headline: Putin Proposes Amnesty for Chechen Rebels Who Disarm
abstract: The offer would exclude any accused of murder, rape, kidnapping or other crimes, President Vladimir V. Putin said today.

headline: Two Start-Ups Aim to Take On Cisco and Juniper
abstract: Silicon Valley start-ups Procket Networks and C

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Far West Side; The Final Frontier for Development in Manhattan
abstract: Demand for office space on far West Side of

headline: Suit Says ChevronTexaco Dumped Poisons in Ecuador
abstract: Group of American lawyers representing more than 30,000 indigenous people in Ecuador file $1 billion lawsuit against ChevronTexaco Corp; suit is filed in Ecuador on behalf of 88 plaintiffs in Lago Agrio and asserts that from 1971 to 1992, ChevronTexaco dumped over four million gallons per day of toxic wastewater, contaminated with oil, heavy metals and carcinogens into open pits and rivers; also says company left behind nearly 350 open waste pits that killed people and animals; ChevronTexaco denies any wrongdoing and maintains that its practice was consistent with practices of Ecuador's national oil company Petro Ecuador as well as internationally recognized standards; case, in litigation for almost decade, has been dismissed at four times; Amazon Watch, nonprofit environmental group in San Francisco, plans to bring group of 13 indigenous leaders from Ecuador to ChevronTexaco's headquarters in San Ramon, Calif; Amazon Watch representative Leila Salazar and Chris Jochnick, lawyer and founder of Center for Economic and Social Rights, comment; photo (M)

headline: This Time, He's Riding a Trial Balloon
abstract: Virgin Atlantic founder Sir Richard Branson seeks financial data about possibly reviving Concorde service being abandoned by British Airways; British Airways dismisses move as publicity stunt; Branson's penchant for such stunts noted; photo (M)

headline: Questions Arise on Drafting Blueprint for Governing Iraq
abstract: Question of who should write new Iraqi constitution and how it should be adopted is being discussed in aftermath of war; conference intended as first step toward creation of interim authority is held in Ur and is attended by Kanan Makiya, exile who has relationship with Bush administration, and other prominent expatriots; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: BCE Posts 54% Increase In Net Earnings
abstract: BCE Inc, telecommunications company, reports first-quarter net earnings rose 54 percent, to 458 million Canadian dollars ($319 million) (S)

headline: An Ergonomic Keyboard Has Typists Floating on Air
abstract: TouchStream MacNTouch keyboard from FingerWorks, to be used with Apple laptops, arranges keys in what company says is more ergonomic layout; photo (M)

headline: Freed G.I. to Return To U.S. to Undergo Further Treatment
abstract: Officials at military hospital in Germany say Pfc Jessica D Lynch has recovered enough from her injuries to return to United States, where she will undergo further medical treatment; she was rescued from Iraqi captivity on Apr 1 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: American And New Zealander Held
abstract: Benjamin Lan of San Francisco and Sung Gang of New Zealand, who were born in China, are being held in China for planning alleged terrorist activities linked with dissident group China Federation Foundation, which promotes overthrow of Chinese government and establishment of democracy (S)

headline: Planned Auto Safety Rules Focus on Rollovers and S.U.V.'s
abstract: Senate Commerce Committee approves long list of new regulatory requirements that would pressure automakers to improve safety on several fronts, including making sport utility vehicles and pickups less prone to rolling over and less dangerous to other vehicles in collisions; measures, included in budget authorization for National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, call for stronger roof and tire standards (M)

headline: Armitage 'Optimistic' About Renewed India-Pakistan Dialogue
abstract: Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage said he was "cautiously optimistic" about the renewal of diplomatic relations between India and Pakistan.

headline: New Overseer Arrives in Iraq In U.S. Shuffle
abstract: America's new civilian administrator in Iraq, L Paul Bremer III, arrives in Baghdad as his predecessor Jay Garner and members of Garner's team prepare to leave in coming weeks; sudden overhaul rattles Iraqi political leaders; Massoud Barzani, Iraqi Kurd who will play crucial role in formation of interim government and who has been close to Garner, says United States risks squandering its victory over Saddam Hussein by allowing chaos and anarchy to run unchecked in country; says Garner's departure will have negative effect; voices concern that ideological clashes in Washington over American role in postwar Iraq are hampering policy in Iraq; also voices concern about Bremer's longtime association with Henry A Kissinger, whom Kurds blame for their betrayal in intelligence wars between Iran and Iraq three decades ago; neither Garner nor Bremer, in remarks at airport in Baghdad, address causes of personnel changes ordered by Bush administration officials; Bremer is bringing large contingent of new administrators; he offers no detailed assessment of how he plans to reverse deterioration in security in Iraq; photos (M)

headline: Mobster's Release Brings Criticism of Italian Policy on Informers
abstract: Early release from prison of mobster convicted of murder touches off furious debate in Italy about policies that reward even worst killers if they provide information that helps put other members of Mafia behind bars; Enzo Brusca, whose prison sentence was commuted to house arrest, is one of more than 1,100 criminal informers, called pentiti, who are collaborating with Italian law enforcement officials, and they have become favorite weapons Italian police use against criminal organizations (M)

headline: Soccer Players Describe Torture by Hussein's Son
abstract: Habib Jaafer, star midfielder of Iraqi national soccer team, says he was physically punished by Saddam Hussein's son Uday every time team failed to win; National Olympic Committee headquarters in Baghdad, building now in ruins, contains torture chambers in basement; poor passes could result in player's being punched or slapped in face by Uday; other players were beaten with electric cables; horrors that are tumbling out of American-ruled Iraq exceed worst that human rights organizations had chronicled in years before Hussein was toppled; role of Uday is likely to receive special attention; while Saddam Hussein murdered on mass scale as political tool, to create fear that discouraged challenges to his power, Uday apepars to have inflicted pain and death mostly for pleasure; photos (L)

headline: A Radio Tuner Remembers Which Songs You Loved
abstract: Kenwood KTC-H2A1 Here2Anywhere is radio tuner that is broadcast node for Sirius satellite radio service and remembers particular songs listeners tag; photo (M)

headline: Final Arguments Start in Trial Of 4 Arabs in Terrorism Case
abstract: Closing arguments begin in Detroit in trial of four Arabs arrested after Sept 11, 2001 attacks; prosecutors say four plotted terrorism; defense tries to cast doubt on government's case and its crucial witness Youssef Hmimssa, onetime associate of defendants; they are charged with document fraud, conspiracy and material support of terrorism; they are Farouk ali-Haimoud of Algeria and Abdel-Ilah Elmardoudi, Ahmed Hannan and Karim Koubriti of Morocco (M)

headline: Expected U.S. Plan on Iraq Likely to Face U.N. Dispute
abstract: Diplomats at United Nations predict United States plan that is likely to call for endorsement of allied authority to run Iraq and for end to United Nations' sole control over its oil will prompt dogged opposition from several Security Council members (M)

headline: Fight in Taiwan Is Impeded By Resistance to Isolation
abstract: In contrast to authoritarian Singapore, Taiwan is model of how hard it can be to set up airtight quarantine in a democracy; authorities in Taiwan are struggling to keep 23,000 healthy people in quarantine in effort to contain SARS; Interior Ministry installs video cameras in quarantined homes and may employ satellite tracking devices, or house offenders in military camps; in and around Taipei, where most cases are, unknown number of people have broken quarantine; angry officials threaten large fines; Taiwan's most infamous quarantine violater, unidentified high school student, is now hospitalized with SARS; photo (M)

headline: Bush Asks Nations to Renounce Mideast Violence
abstract: President Bush condemned the latest deadly bus bombing in Israel today and urged "all the free world" to renounce violence between Israelis and Palestinians.

headline: Cable Is Confident of Internet Lead Over Phone Rivals
abstract: Cable industry executives gathered in Chicago for annual trade show face latest attempt by phone companies to win fight for dominance in advanced telecommunications; cable industry's confidence that it can rebuff challenge from its more traditional rivals rests largely on its success in selling high-speed, or broadband, connections to Internet; more than twice as many Americans buy broadband Internet access from cable companies than buy digital subscriber line, or DSL, service from phone companies; Verizon and SBC, major telephone companies, have in recent months reduced their prices for DSL service and undercut cable companies' rates for cable modem service; cable industry executives predict their lead over phone industry competitors will be insurmountable because they invested earlier in Internet access strategy; photo of Microsoft chairman Bill Gates, Viacom chief executive Mel Karmazin, AOL Time Warner chairman Richard D Parsons and Comcast chief executive Brian L Roberts (M)

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: Powell Says 'There Is No War Plan' Against Syria
abstract: The U.S. appeared intent on cooling anxiety in the region caused by recent comments from the Bush administration.

headline: British Activist Is Reported Wounded by Israeli Sniper in Gaza
abstract: british activist is reported woun7

headline: State Department Official to Lead Council on Foreign Relations
abstract: Richard N Haass will leave post as director of policy planning at State Department to become president of Council on Foreign Relations, replacing Leslie H Gelb (M)

headline: Executive Life; His Quest: A Safe (and Efficient) Airport
abstract: Profile of Marcus Arroyo, federal security director at Newark Liberty International Airport for last 10 months; says he and 300 other airport security directors or deputy directors with Transportation Security Administration must be part start-up entrepreneur, shaping a new organization, and part turnaround artist, fixing system that many people have regarded as broken; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Focus In Iraq Is on Repairs, Not Building
abstract: United States Agency for International Development administrator Andrew S Natsios says United States will focus on emergency repairs rather than on major reconstruction of Iraq's crumbling infrastructure; says problems are more complicated than were anticipatED, and he does not expect increase in $2.4 billion aid package approved for this year; comments suggest that Bush administration may be at odds with British officials, who are overseeing reconstructin efforts in southern Iraq and who favor more ambitious effort; Bechtel Group, American contractor overseeing repairs, is also proposing more comprehensive and expensive series of projects in next several years (M)

headline: Subway Restaurants In Agency Review
abstract: Subway Restaurants is beginning review for creative and strategic-planning duties on its ad account, which has been handled by Euro RSCG MVBMS Partners since March 2000 (S)

headline: Hospital Supplier Says Auditor Has Quit
abstract: Neoforma, which operates Web site where hospitals can order supplies, says its accounting firm Deloitte & Touche has resigned after less than year on job and months after company restated its revenue for 2000, 2001 and part of 2002; company says it is not aware of any disagreement with Deloitte over accounting principles or practices, financial statement disclosure or auditing scope or procedure; Deloitte declines comment; Neoforma is designated electronic commerce company for Novation, large private company that negotiates contracts for hospitals to buy their supplies (M)

headline: 15 New Cases Of Pneumonia Near Toronto May Be SARS
abstract: Ontario health officials say they are concerned over new cluster of suspected SARS cases in hospital in Whitby, hour's drive east of Toronto, where 15 people receiving dialysis have contracted pneumonia; say there is no obvious connection to any previous patient with SARS, but they are assuming it is SARS and taking appropriate precautions; authorities are scrambling to find epidemiological link to possible new cluster, to contain broader possible outbreak (M)

headline: Consulting Company Acquired by Omnicom
abstract: Omnicom Group acquires corporate identity consulting company Siegelgale; will rename acquisition Siegel & Gale (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: METROLOGIC RAISES EARNINGS ESTIMATE; HEWLETT SHAREHOLDERS BACK POISON PILL PROPOSAL;.

headline: Private Judge to Resolve 'Spider-Man' Case
abstract: Sony Corp wins its bid to have private judge resolve dispute with Marvel Enterprises over licensing rights to movie Spider-Man, which generated more than $820 million in worldwide box office sales; Marvel, publisher of Spider-Man comics, seeks $50 million and termination of its licensing agreement with Sony after completion of Spider-Man 2, scheduled for release next May (S)

headline: Treasury Chief's Comments Weigh on Dollar as Euro Jumps
abstract: The dollar's decline accelerated today, pushing the euro within striking distance of its all-time high.

headline: Israel Is Criticized for Restricting U.N. Access in Gaza
abstract: United Nations Middle East envoy Terje Roed-Larsen tells Security Council that stringent Israeli travel restrictions are preventing dozens of international workers and managers for UN refugee programs from getting in and out of Gaza Strip; says this violates privileges and immunities afforded UN workers, and runs counter to Israel's international humanitarian law obligations as occupying power; Israeli envoy to UN Dan Gillerman says new measures are necessitated by tragic escalation in terrorist attacks and suicide bombings by Palestinians; photo (M)

headline: China Admits to Having More of Mystery Illness
abstract: China bows to international pressure and admits that it has more cases of mysterious SARS illness, in more provinces, than it said before; it also agrees for first time to let international health investigators visit Guangdong Province, where illness is believed to have sprung up late last year; there have also been serious outbreaks in Hong Kong, Singapore, Vietnam and Canada; photo (M)

headline: If You Behave Yourself, I'll Print You a Toy
abstract: How It Works column explains three-dimensional printing; such printers are being used by industrial designers to create prototypes of parts and other objects, by arranging stream of chemical or laser light to bind powdery material, layer by layer, into object; technology is currently very expensive, but some companies are considering possibility of producing lower-priced version that could generate everyday items; series of illustrations shows how it works (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Venice Landmark Damaged By Fire
abstract: Mulino Stucky, Venice landmark, is damaged by fire; 19th-century mill, located on Giudecca island across from Venice, is being renovated and converted into hotel and housing development (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Huey/Paprocki is named agency of record for Jerzees brand of apparel made by Russell Corp (S)

headline: Fall of a Northern City, Suicide Bombing on Marines, Killing of a Cleric
abstract: As Kirkuk fell in the north, American and British troops made important advances. But they also encountered heavy resistance and uncovered worrisome signs that the war was far from over. An important Muslim cleric was killed in Najaf, a suicide bomber wounded four marines in Baghdad and President Bush went on Iraqi television to reassure the Iraqi people of America's intentions. About two-thirds of Iraq has come under American and British control but coalition forces have not found Mr. Hussein or the weapons of mass destructions he was believed to possess.

headline: A Top Qaeda Member, Tied to 9/11, Is Captured
abstract: American officials report capture in Pakistan of Walid Ba'Attash, top operative of Al Qaeda who is suspected of playing crucial roles in both bombing of American destroyer Cole in 2000 and Sept 11 terrorist attacks; he is Saudi citizen of Yemeni descent; he has been identified as important lieutenant of Osama bin Laden, and deeply involved in many of Al Qaeda's most deadly plots; his reported aliases include Tawfiq al-Atasha and Tawfiq bin Atash; once Pakistani authorities turn him over to United States for questioning, he will be only person in American custody who attended critical meeting of Qaeda operatives in Malaysia in Jan 2000 that may have been called to plan Sept 11 attacks; two of 19 hijackers involved in Sept 11 also attended that meeting; he may be able to provide CIA and FBI fresh insight into inner workings of Sept 11 plot; five other suspects captured with him say they are Pakistanis, but American officials say they have not verified their identities; 10 other suspects in Cole bombing escaped from jail in Yemen last month, raising questions about whether they received help from inside Yemeni government, which faces allegations that it knew more about Cole plot than it has acknowledged; American officials say they know of no connection between jail break in Yemen and capture of Ba'Attash in Pakistan (L)

headline: Canada Increases Pressure on World Health Organization to Lift Travel Advisory
abstract: Prime Min Jean Chretien protests World Health Organization's advistory for travelers to avoid Toronto because of outbreak of highly contagious respiratory disease known as SARS; will spend evening at hotel in city to show how safe he feels it is; Canadian officials express optimism about controlling disease; photos (M)

headline: I Want My Rebate
abstract: Edwin Hustead letter suggests consumers wait to send for rebate until they are sure they are satisfied with product or they may face difficulty returning it in box that has been stripped of bar code (Apr 17 article)

headline: United and 2 Unions Reach Tentative Agreements
abstract: United Airlines reaches tentative agreements with flight attendants and dispatchers on new six-year contracts that will grant contract concessions sought by airline, which is under bankruptcy protection; terms of agreement with Association of Flight Attendants are undisclosed; union for flight dispatchers says proposed contract will yield savings of $4.5 million per year from 170 flight controllers; United will focus on its last major labor group, International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents 37,500 workers at airline (M)

headline: AOL Is Seen In Deal to Sell Comedy Central Stake to Viacom
abstract: Viacom is poised to double its laughs.    AOL Time Warner is close to a deal to sell its half of a joint venture in the Comedy Central cable channel to Viacom, its partner, for about $1.2 billion, an executive briefed on the talks said last night.

headline: Goodyear's Rating Reduced as Debt Rises
abstract: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co's credit rating on $1.9 billion in unsecured debt, already below investment grade, is cut one level by Standard & Poor's because of increase in secured debt (S)

headline: How to Deal With Spam
abstract: Ma

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Read-Rite Files For Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: Read-Rite Corp, which makes components used in computer disk drives, asks for bankruptcy court protection while its assets are liquidated (S)

headline: The Evelyn Wood of Digitized Book Scanners
abstract: New book-scanning robots are proving boon to libraries and nonprofit groups working to digitize books into computer databases; robots, introduced by 4DigitalBooks and Kirtas Technologies, can rapidly turn pages and scan them; can be located close to book collections and offer speed and quality control unattainable by manual systems; high cost makes them cost-effective only on larger projects; photos (M)

headline: Hunt for Etiquette Among Unwired
abstract: Speakers and panelists at recent Vortex Conference in Dana Point, Calif, face annoyance and distraction from audience members who use laptops to constantly check email and run other wireless applications; lack of audience etiquette is seen as wave of future as wireless technologies grow in popularity (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Stolen Frescoes Found
abstract: Italian police find two frescoes stolen from Pompeii villa hidden in nearby outbuilding; 2,000-year-old treasures were cut from walls of House of Chaste Lovers and found packaged and ready to be shipped; no one is under arrest for theft; photo (S)

headline: WPP Reaches Deal to Acquire Cordiant
abstract: WPP Group and Cordiant Communications Group agree to takeover deal that values Cordiant at just 10 million pounds ($16.8 million); WPP will also purchase 177 million pounds of Cordiant debt, paying holders 100 percent of its face value (M)

headline: War Tests a German Niche Industry
abstract: German companies have profited from American-led war in Iraq by selling various supplies for British and American soldiers; Hasso von Blucher's company Blucher GmbH produces carbon-laced fabric that goes into protective suits worn by soldiers and marines in Iraq; von Blucher comments; photo (M);

headline: Giving Troops The Tool Of Language
abstract: Marine Acoustics has adapted phrase-translation software to hand-held computer called Phraselator that can change English into Arabic--or just about any other language--for US troops in Iraq; VoxTec is device's marketer; vice president Ace J Sarich comments; photos (SM)

headline: France Urging U.N. to Suspend Iraq Penalties
abstract: French Amb Jean Marc de la Sabliere urges United Nations to immediate suspend most of its sanctions against Iraq, allowing unrestricted nonmilitary trade to resume; seeks to avert new Security Council showdown over UN role; could also be seeking to prevent France from being shut out of plans for postwar Iraq; proposal falls short of Pres Bush's call for Security Council to lift all sanctions; signals that France seeks to shed its image as leading antagonist of United States on Iraq war; Bush administration offers lukewarm response; Bush says he has no plans for another war, interview with Newsweek reporters; administration officals adamantly oppose quick return of UN arms inspectors to Iraq; say military team of American, British and Australian officials search for biological and chemical arms; insist return of UN team lead by Hans Blix would be hindrance; Blix credits competence of current inspectors, noting some used to work for UN, interview; holds UN team is more independent and thus has more credibility with international community; photo (M)

headline: MCDONALD'S U.S. SALES ROSE 6.3% IN MAY
abstract: McDonald's Corp reports US sales rose 6.3 percent in May, largest monthly gain in four years (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: H.I.V. Drug Cleared
abstract: World Business Briefing: Switzerland: H.I.V. Drug Cle

headline: A Blast Kills 2 Mothers, And Bewilders 2 Sons
abstract: Two elderly Israeli women killed in suicide bombing of bus in Jerusalem had much in common--including mentally disabled sons who are devastated at their loss; women met each other while visiting their sons at group home in suburban Jerusalem (M)

headline: Saudis Seek 19 Suspected of Terrorist Plot
abstract: Saudi authorities pursue 19 Islamic militants with Al Qaeda ties who apparently planned major terrorist attack; militants are still at large three days after raid, prompting unusual public disclosure of names and photos (M)

headline: JOHNSON & JOHNSON REACHES AGREEMENT TO BUY LINK SPINE
abstract: Johnson & Johnson buys Link Spine Group for $325 million and future payments, gaining instrument for treating spinal disorders (S)

headline: Jewish Donors To Democrats Urge Support Of Road Map
abstract: Group of prominent Democratic Jewish donors sends letter to Democratic presidential candidates urging them to support, or at least not to oppose, Bush administration's 'road map' for peace in Middle East, even after latest wave of violence; letter asks that candidates not put obstacles in way of Bush's Mideast peacemaking policies as long as adminstration remains actively engaged in that effort; says they should 'speak out' if administration makes Middle East a low priority; signers are organized in part by Israel Policy Forum; officials at several Democratic campaigns will not commit themselves to letter's request; privately, officials at some of campaigns express annoyance at what they perceive as unstated threat that donors might shut their wallets (M)

headline: Faxes vs. E-Mail
abstract: H Z Bornstein letter argues that fax has better chance of being read by recipient than e-mail, which is often deleted after user scans name of sender and subject line (Mar 13 article)

headline: 2 Drug Makers Lose Appeals Court Ruling
abstract: Aventis and Andrx improperly conspired to keep generic forms of a blood pressure drug off the market, an appeals court ruled.

headline: 2 Afghan Soldiers Slain in Heavy New Outbreak of Clashes
abstract: Two Afghan government soldiers were killed in a new burst of heavy fighting in southeast Afghanistan on Wednesday.

headline: Nepal's Maoist Guerrillas Let the Revolution Rest, for Now
abstract: Nepal's Maoist guerrillas come to Katmandu under cease-fire that has virtually stopped political violence since it took effect four months ago; civil war that had festered out of sight of Katmandu exploded tenfold last year, claiming 4,655 lives and prompting King Gyanendra to fire his prime minister and make secret feelers to Maoists; Krishna Bahadur Mahara, Maoist leader, says there is now strategic equilibrium of military power; Maoists say they control 80 percent of countryside, while king oversees 50 percent increase in Royal Nepal Army, with new military aid arriving from India, Britain and United States; major question is whether Maoists are serious about talking peace or merely using time to gain military strength for new phase of war; photo (M)

headline: DataBank; Stock Indexes Take a Pre-Holiday Dip
abstract: Major stock indexes fall last week, after weeks of gains; tables; graphs (M)

headline: Jardín Journal; A Bird-Watcher's Heaven (if War Wasn't Hell)
abstract: Jardin Journal on bird-watching expeditions in Colombia that continue despite ever-present threat of rebel kidnappings; country has 1,865 bird species, most in world, with nearly 250 found around Jardin forested Andean foothills; efforts are under way there to protect Yelloweared Parrot; photo of British ornithologist Paul Salaman, who works with Conservation International, along with Salaman's photo of parrot; map (M)

headline: Oil Minister Reappointed
abstract: Saudi Arabia reappoints Oil Min Ali al-Naimi in cabinet reshuffle (S)

headline: Russia's Economy Seems to Be Starting to Bloom
abstract: Moscow is home to most of Russia's wealth, but figures indicate that all Russia is on economic roll; domestic output grew by 4.3 percent in 2002; some private experts say true number is above 5 percent; this is country's third year of robust growth, making it second-fastest-growing nation among emerging economies after dozen years of capitalism; one big caveat is that growth has been driven far more by high oil prices than by manufacturing, base of most rebounds; glossiest of optimists say Russian economy is on track to triple by 2010 to trillion dollars a year; photos; map; chart (M)

headline: France Claims U.S. Is Engaging in Disinformation Campaign
abstract: France took the highly unusual step today of complaining formally that it had been victimized by a campaign of "repeated disinformation," allegedly fed by the Bush administration.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: S.E.C. Chairman Troubled By Remarks From Purcell  Morgan Stanley's efforts to play down the firm's role in the Wall Street research scandal appeared to backfire, as William H. Donaldson, left, the chairman of the S.E.C., released a blistering letter addressed to the firm's chief executive.    Mr. Donaldson said he was ''deeply troubled'' by comments by Philip J. Purcell of Morgan Stanley. He warned that Morgan could face further legal action if it continued to deny having acted badly in the research scandal. [Page A1.]

headline: Bush in Europe
abstract: President Bush arrived in a Europe hopeful that the trans-Atlantic rift could be healed but skeptical about the administration's willingness to rebuild the European-American partnership.    Article, Page A9.

headline: JetBlue Posts 34% Increase in First-Quarter Profit
abstract: JetBlue Airways says first-quarter profit rose 34 percent as it added flights and carried 70 percent more passengers; net income rose to $17.4 million from $13 million year ago; sales increased 63 percent, to $217.1 million from $133.4 million; company announces it will buy 65 Airbus A320 aircraft, with options on 50 more; new planes will start arriving in 2004 and deliveries will run through 2011 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Asset Sale Planned
abstract: World Busir

headline: Washington Asks, How Firm Are Saudis on Extremists?
abstract: Suicide bombings in Riyadh revive sharp debate in Washington over whether Saudi Arabia has moved firmly enough to fight Islamic militancy within its borders and to stanch flow of money to terrorist groups overseas; critics say Saudi royal family remains ambivalent about cracking down on militant clerics and sympathizers who aid Al Qaeda; Sen Charle Schumer says those who carried out latest attack were likely educated at extremist Saudi-funded schools (M)

headline: New Agency Sets Ethics Rules To Avoid Conflicts of Interest
abstract: Homeland Security Dept is establishing ethics rules to ensure that lobbyists with personal connections to Sec Tom Ridge and other senior officials will not receive special favors from agency; officials say rules will be similar to conflict-of-interest rules at other federal agencies (M)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYNone.

headline: Police in Canada Search 13 Brokerage Firms
abstract: Royal Canadian Mounted Police search 13 brokerage firms in Toronto area as part of probe into illegal activity in speculative over-the-counter stocks; investigation centers on small part of stock market involving high-risk, highly speculative stocks; Ontario Securities Commission spokesman Frank Switzer says stocks at center of probe are not what average people have in their mutual funds (S)

headline: Menem, Polls Slipping, Quits Argentine Race
abstract: Carlos Saul Menem withdraws from presidential race in Argentina; faced prospect of humiliating defeat in runoff vote scheduled for May 18; decision clears way for Nestor Kirchner to be sworn in as president on May 25; Kirchner accuses Menem of 'running away' from electoral debacle in order to weaken mandate of new government; Menem tells reporters he is pulling out because of 'fraud' in electoral process by Pres Eduardo Duhalde, who supports Kirchner; Menem, who governed country from 1989 to 1999, is extremely unpopular with majority of voters, who blame him for economic crisis of past four years; photo (M)

headline: Arab Leaders Skeptical, but Hope for Results
abstract: When President Bush opens a new Middle East peace quest on Tuesday in Egypt, he will confront a region still trying to absorb America's occupation of Iraq.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Extradition In Americans' Deaths
abstract: US State Department announces that Colombia will extradite Nelson Vargas Rueda, Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia guerrilla, to stand trial in US for 1999 killing of American human rights workers Ingrid Washinawatok, Terence Freitas and Lahe'ena'e Gay (S)

headline: Bush Signs Trade Pact With Singapore, a Wartime Ally
abstract: Pres Bush signs free trade agreement with Singapore, his first since Congress granted him trade-promotion authority last summer; Singapore's Prime Min Goh Chok Tong joins Bush for signing ceremony at White House in display of what US Ambassador to Singapore Franklin L Lavin says is administration's policy, after war in Iraq, of 'working with friends'; Chile had expected to be first country to sign such agreement after completing negotiations in December, but lost honor by refusing to support US in its call for war at United Nations Security Council; US trade representative Robert B Zoellick says he is disappointed with Chile; dignitaries attending treaty signing include State Sec Colin L Powell, national security adviser Condoleezza Rice, Commerce Sec Donald L Evans and Zoellick; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Jobless Rate Rises to 6.1%, Reaching a Nine-Year High  The unemployment rate rose to 6.1 percent in May, its highest level in nine years, the Labor Department reported, as the worst jobs slump since the early 1980's continued to spread.    Still, the pace of layoffs has slowed over the last two months, suggesting that the economy might have stabilized and could begin adding jobs this summer, forecasters said. The economy has lost almost 2.5 million jobs since February 2001. [Page A1.]

headline: SUITORS PROTEST IN FIGHT FOR TAUBMAN CENTERS
abstract: Simon Property Group and Westfield America Inc, seeking to amend suit they filed in connection with their hostile bid for Taubman Centers Inc, charge Taubman improperly uses share repurchase program to thwart bid (S)

headline: Israeli and Palestinian Envoys Meet With Bush Aides
abstract: Senior Israeli and Palestinian envoys hold separate meetings with top aides to Pres Bush, trying to forge agreement on actions to reduce tensions in next few weeks and start talks; administration officials focus on their plea for Prime Min Ariel Sharon of Israel to drop his refusal to endorse administration's peace plan; Sharon wants plan to make clear that Palestinian actions to disarm violent groups must precede any Israeli action to pull back forces or even dismantle Jewish settlements in West Bank and Gaza; administration said to be looking for some artful language that would allow Sharon to endorse plan (M)

headline: NEXT LEVEL AGREES TO SETTLE SUIT OVER MOTOROLA BID
abstract: Next Level Communications agrees to settle its lawsuit seeking to block bid from Motorola Inc for remaining 26 percent of Next Level after Motorola raises its offer (S)

headline: U.S. Raises Some Fuel Economy Rules
abstract: Bush administration will raise fuel economy regulations for light trucks by 1.5 miles a gallon, or about 4.5 percent, by 2007 model year; environmental groups criticize administration's plan as minuscule step at time when gas consumption is national security issue (S)

headline: A Soldier's Story
abstract: The death of Pvt. Kelley Prewitt was a small episode in a big war. But it reveals a lot about the nature of that war.

headline: Lawmakers Want to Expand Inquiry on U.S. Efforts in Iraq
abstract: The move was another sign of Congressional displeasure with the White House's plans for rebuilding Iraq.

headline: 4 Journalists Are Safe in Jordan After a Week in an Iraqi Jail
abstract: Four journalists who have been missing for week arrive safely in Jordan after being held prisoner in Iraqi jail; say they were not physically harmed and acknowledge international efforts to gain their release; journalists are Newsday reporter Matthew McAllester, Newsday photographer Moises Saman, and freelance photographers Molly Bingham and Johann Spanner (S)

headline: Terror Groups May Be Planning New Attacks, State Dept. Says
abstract: It was a calibrated caution to Americans traveling or living abroad that the risks of terrorism have not vanished.

headline: Stealing a Signature
abstract: M Lypka letter holds biometric signature data is encoded in binary form and can be stolen as easily as credit card data (Mar 13 article)

headline: Canadian Bank Posts Higher Net
abstract: National Bank of Canada says profit rose 13 percent in its fiscal second quarter ended April 30; net income rose 138 million dollars ($99.6 million) from 122 million Canadian dollars year earlier; revenue fell 5 percent to 773 million Canadian dollars (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Party Drops Support
abstract: Brazil's Democratic Labor Party, led by Leonel Brizola, splits with President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva and invites others within president's own party to join them; photo (S)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for ROBERT A. KAPP; Tracking the Impact of SARS on Business With China
abstract: Robert A Kapp, president of US-China Business Council in Washington, answers questions on short-term and potential long-term effects of SARS on American business involvement in China; photo (M)

headline: Russia's Latest Oil and Gas Oasis
abstract: Aggressive investments by world's three largest oil producers--Exxon Mobil, Royal Dutch/Shell and BP--illustrate how Chayvo Bay on shore of Sakhalin Island is on track to surpass Moscow this year as top destination for foreign investment in Russia; Sakhalin's Mayor Igor P Farkhutdinov says volume of foreign investments is expected to double this year to about $1.3 billion; much of oil giants' work is concentrated on modernizing Sakhalin Island's infrastructure to make it easier to support oil field development to follow; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Demands That Iran Turn Over Qaeda Agents And Join Saudi Inquiry
abstract: Bush administration officials say US is pressing Iran to cooperate with investigation into recent bombings in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and to hand over operatives of Al Qaeda believed to have been working in Iranian territory; administration has held series of secret meetings with Iranian officials, who continue to deny any involvement with Al Qaeda; UN Amb Javad Zarif says Tehran is cooperating in attempts to control Al Qaeda and has arrested members of network but would not respond to 'language of pressure'; dispute in intelligence community about Iran-Al Qaeda connection discussed; some in administration believe terrorists could be in Iran but not necessarily with sanction of government; there is also concern that Iran is supporting Shiite groups in Iraq seeking to destabilize American occupation; possible acceleration by Iran of its nuclear weapons program discussed; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Cameron Day is named Chrysler brand creative director at Troy, Mich, office of BBDO Worldwide that had been handled by Bill Morden, vice chairman and chief creative officer; Evelyn Neill is named to new post of president for creative at Doremus (S)

headline: Inquiry on Energy Trading
abstract: By Bloomberg News.

headline: Kurds Oppose U.S. Proposal On Oil Money
abstract: Two main Kurdish political leaders, Jalal Talabani and Massoud Barzani, send letter to Iraqi civilian administrator L Paul Bremer 3d sharply criticizing American proposal for new United Nations resolution on Iraq, saying it would take away $4 billion that righfully belongs to Kurds; at issue is plan to redistribute unspent money from UN's oil-for-food program; $4 billion amount is 13 percent of sales of oil that accumulated for Kurds in separate bank account; US wants to combine all oil revenues into internationally monitored Iraqi Development Fund (S)

headline: South Korea Moves to Rescue Its 9 Credit Card Companies
abstract: South Korea's biggest companies and banks begin putting about $4 billion into their credit card companies as part of government-driven plan to rescue them from bankruptcy and stave off another economic crisis; Samsung Electronics pledges to invest another $100 million in Samsung Credit Co by end of June; Financial Supervisory Service calls for financial institutions to cover more than $8 billion in debts that are falling due this quarter on bonds issued by credit card companies (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Flextronics Will Close Some Plants
abstract: Flextronics International, world's largest maker of electronics for other companies, will close more circuit-board plants because they are losing money (S)

headline: Airbus and Boeing Vie Aggressively for Big AirTran Order
abstract: AirTran is expected to make an order for 100 planes, valued at several billion dollars, from either Airbus or Boeing.

headline: STATE STREET SAYS IT WILL ELIMINATE 1,800 MORE JOBS
abstract: State Street Corp will cut as many as 1,800 more jobs, bringing total to 13 percent of its work force this year (S)4

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Soldier's Life For Harry
abstract: Prince Harry, youngest son of Prince Charles and Diana, late Princess of Wales, completes course of study at Eton and royal family announces his application to Sandhurst Royal Military Academy to begin army career; like his older brother William, he plans to spend year abroad before school; photo (S)

headline: CHUBB TO SELL SHARES AND EQUITY UNITS FOR $1.2 BILLION
abstract: Chubb Corp, property and casualty insurer, to sell $1.2 billion worth of new equity (S)

headline: U.S. Analysts Link Iraq Labs To Germ Arms
abstract: US intelligence agencies conclude that two mysterious trailers found in Iraq were mobile units to produce germs for weapons, but have not found biological agents or evidence of such use; trailers were thoroughly decontaminated with unidentified caustic agent but experts can come up with no other plausible explanation; US reportedly will invite international experts to examine mobile units; photos; diagram; Iraqi scientists claim 2,000-liter vessel in each unit was used to mix chemicals to produce hydrogen gas, but evidence suggests vessels, made in 2002 and 2003, are fermenters used to multiply seed germs into deadly swarms (M)

headline: Amid Rows of Bundles, the Saddest of Searches
abstract: Sabeeha Muhammad's brother was 20 when last seen in 1991. Now, he has been seen again — dissolved and disassembled by time into pieces of a skeleton.

headline: U.S. Agrees to Redeploy Troops Far From North Korea Border
abstract: After weeks of tense discussions, the U.S. and South Korea agreed today to redeploy American troops far away from the demilitarized zone that separates North and South Korea.

headline: Minsk Journal; On Destined Way to Dallas, Oswald Tarried Here
abstract: Minsk, Belarus, remains much as it was when Pres John F Kennedy's assassin, Lee Harvey Oswald, lived and worked there from 1960 to 1962; most historians support then-Soviet Union's claim that it had no role in assassination; there are no exhibits or tours in Minsk related to Owwald, but his presence lingers in minds of those who knew him there and in places he frequented; photos; map (M)

headline: MAF BANCORP TO BUY ST. FRANCIS CAPITAL FOR $264 MILLION
abstract: MAF Bancorp Inc acquires St Francis Capital Corp in all-stock transaction valued at about $264 million (S)

headline: Top Bush Aide Calls On Europe to Ban All Parts
abstract: Condoleezza Rice said today that the political wing of Hamas should be added to the European Union's list of terrorist organizations.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Meeting With Dissident
abstract: Vietnam Prime Minister Phan Van Khai meets with monk Thich Huyen Quang, confined leader of banned Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam, to discuss religious freedom; monk has been held prisoner in his own temple since 1982 (S)

headline: British Envoy Sees Allies Running Iraq In Near Term
abstract: John Sawers, Britain's representative to American administration in Baghdad, says occupying powers intend to run country for foreseeable future, with Iraqis restricted to advisory role; plan he outlines draws sharp criticism from Iraqi political groups that supported American-led invasion and had expected to help govern country, or at least appoint their own consultative council, once Saddam Hussein was deposed; Sawers notes that Iraqis who are beginning to chafe at American and British occupation would also object to transitional government chosen exclusively by former exile groups; says Iraqis who do take part in interim administration must be generally representative of Iraq as a whole; photo (M)

headline: New Warnings on Cigarettes?
abstract: At its annual meeting last week, the American Medical Association voted to seek stronger health warnings on tobacco products. The group wants cigarette packs to contain antismoking images that are similar to those used in other countries. People who buy cigarettes in Canada, for example, see pictures of a diseased mouth, a lung tumor, a damaged heart and a limp cigarette that accompanies a warning on male impotence.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Trade Pact Threatened
abstract: European Union spokesman holds that Cuba's recent crackdown on opposition, evidenced by execution of 3 men for hijacking and imprisonment of 75 dissidents, jeopardizes potential trade relations with European Union; holds that damaged relationship is not irreparable as union foreign ministers will not vote on deal with Cuba until June (S)

headline: Hints of a Bid Forming for Vivendi Units
abstract: Edgar Bronfman Jr is trying to put together group to buy back many of entertainment properties his family sold to Vivendi in deal that turned sour; among those considering whether to join Bronfman in bidding for Vivendi assets are Cablevision Systems and several private equity firms, including Quadrangle, led by Steven Rattner, member of Cablevision board; among other private equity firms that Bronfman has approached are Providence Equity, Kohlberg Kravis Robers and Blackstone Group; no firm group is aligned with Bronfman; Bronfman remains on Vivendi's board; photo (M)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYNone.

headline: Canada Extends Cattle Ranch Quarantine to British Columbia
abstract: Canadian inspectors extend quarantine of cattle ranches to three British Columbia ranches in effort to trace path of feed eaten by single cow infected with mad cow disease and to find where its remains were distributed after it was butchered in Alberta in Jan; probe whether feed sold illegally in British Columbia caused illness; face challenge because of incomplete cattle records; say cow may have been born in Saskatchewan Province; officials say it is too soon to suggest disease poses threat to Canada's food supply (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: *Fruit of the Loom, Bowling Green, Ky, makes Grupo Gallegos its first agency of record for advertising aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers (S)

headline: U.S. Forces Take Control of Baghdad
abstract: Much of Baghdad tumbled into American hands as Saddam Hussein's image was pulled down from pedestals and portraiture in the city.

headline: Chairman Resigns At Tierney DeGregorio
abstract: Tony DeGregorio resigns as Tierney DeGregorio Advertising chairman and chief creative officer; Kelly Simmons will assume some of his duties as executive vice president and chief creative officer; agency will revert back to its previous name, Tierney Advertising (S)

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Man of Internet Fraud
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commissino files fraud charges against K C Smith who reportedly took money from would-be investors by creating fictitious federal agency; lawsuit charges Smith with raising $102,554 through bogus Web sites and about nine million unsolicited e-mail messages; Smith used SEC seal to convince investors scheme was legitimate; Smith does not admit to nor deny accusations, but agrees to settlement requiring him to return $107,510 of gains and interest, and barring him from future violations; Smith ran Web site for Kryer Financial, bogus investment company offering double-digit monthly returns said to be insured by 'United States Deposit Insurance Corp,' another entity he invented (S)

headline: W.H.O. Adds Toronto to List of Cities to Avoid Because of SARS
abstract: With the disease spreading every day and a 15th person in Toronto dying of the ailment today, what once looked like a model plan appears to have been shattered.

headline: Some Work Is Shifted For Cigarette Brands
abstract: British American Tobacco shuffles worl

headline: Bush's Warning to Syria, and Words From the Deputy Syrian Ambassador
abstract: Excerpts from Pres Bush's news conference regarding possibility of military action in Syria; excerpts from appearance by Syrian Amb Imad Moustapha on television program Meet the Press

headline: Cleric Assumes a Bully Pulpit
abstract: Shiite Muslim cleric Sayed Abbas has declared himself mayor of Kut and taken up residence in ornate city hall, surrounded by legions of zealous Iraqi followers; US military commanders, who dismiss him as clown and sham, are embarrassed and frustrated by spectacle of cleric receiving homage from followers as he calls for resistance to 'dividers,' oblique reference to Americans (M)

headline: ENTREMED SHARES SOAR AFTER REPORT ON CANCER DRUG
abstract: Shares of EntreMed Inc soaB

headline: Morgan Vice Chairwoman to Join Buyout Firm
abstract: Julie G Richardson, vice chairwoman of J P Morgan Chase, is leaving to join Providence Equity Partners as managing director (M)

headline: Some Doubts About Logic Of Senate Plan For Drug Aid
abstract: Analysis of prescription drug benefit plan recently approved by Senate Finance Committee concludes that bill is largely political act without clear benefits to any large segment of elderly population; fewer than half of current Medicare recipients would benefit from plan, which would not offer comprehensive benefits to those members with highest prescription costs; overall cost of plan is estimated at $400 billion over ten years, although lower-than-expected rate of participation could result in higher average costs per patient; graphs (M)

headline: 2 Senior Managers Leaving Interpublic
abstract: Larry Weber, chairman-chief executive at Advanced Marketing Services, division of Interpublic Group of Cos, is resigning as division is dismantled; Weber will become consultant to David Bell, chairman and chief executive at Interpublic, and Weber Shandwick, public relations agency he helped found; Mark Shapiro, chairman-chief executive for North American operations at Momentum, part of McCann-Erickson World Group division of Interpublic, is leaving because his job is being eliminated (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Texas Instruments Increases Chip Speed
abstract: Texas Instruments breaks one-gigahertz barrier for digital signal processing chips, increasing top speed for such chips by nearly 40 percent (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Trade Surplus Grows; SINGAPORE: Economic Growth Slows; SOUTH KOREA: Fund Raises Industrial Stake; JAPAN: Bank Sale;.

headline: After Turkish Quake, Rush Is On to Save 90 Students Trapped Under Wreckage
abstract: Rescue teams in Bingol, Turkey, work feverishly to free 90 or more pupils trapped underneath rubble after powerful earthquake levels their boarding school; bodies of 14 children and teacher have been recovered, and more than 90 children have already been hauled out alive; Prime Min Recep Tayyip Erdogan visits scene; vows to hold responsible those who built school in what he says was shoddy manner as well as people who failed to inspect it; photos; map (M)

headline: Kenya Urges U.S. and Britain to Lift East Africa Terror Alert
abstract: Foreign Minister Stephen K. Musyoka said his country had "nipped in the bud" potential terrorist operations in Somalia and Kenya.

headline: New York's Olympic Promoters Recruit a 9-Iron Fund-Raiser
abstract: New York's Olympic Promoters Recruit a 9-Iron Fund-Raiser.

headline: Forgive, Pope Says, But Croats Find It Hard
abstract: Croatians of Vukovar, where Serbs killed 5,000 people in siege nearly twelve years ago, find it difficult to heed Pope John Paul II's call for forgiveness; photo of pope in Osijek; map (M)

headline: Webdenda
abstract: Bev Andal was named to the new post of chief operating officer at CMR , New York, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres. She continues as president and chief operating officer at Evaliant, New York, which was acquired by CMR last year. Sylvia Auton , managing director for the Country and Leisure Media group at IPC Media , London, was named chief executive, succeeding Sly Bailey, who left to become chief executive at Trinity Mirror, London. IPC is part of the Time Inc. unit of AOL Time Warner. Bob Costabile was named director at 30FPS , Glen Cove, N.Y., a production company. He had been an art director at Young & Rubicam Advertising, New York, part of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group. Evins Communications , New York, and the It Management Global Corporation , New York, formed a strategic partnership to work together on accounts, though the agencies do not plan to merge. Terms were not disclosed. The Hartford Financial Services Group , Hartford, Conn., was named ``Company of the Year'' by the Financial Services Council of the Direct Marketing Association at an April 3 ceremony in Clearwater Beach, Fla. The Hispanic Public Relations Association , Los Angeles, elected Laura Hernandez as secretary, a vacant post. Ms. Hernandez is an assistant account executive at Rogers & Associates, Los Angeles. Integrated Entertainment Partners , Beverly Hills, Calif., is being opened by several longtime advertising, marketing and entertainment executives. Among them are Mitch Kanner , who had led his own company, Idea Bridge; Rich Frank, former chairman at Walt Disney Television, part of the Walt Disney Company; and entertainment lawyer Skip Brittenham . Stacey Lynn Koerner , senior vice president and director for broadcast research at Initiative Media North America , New York, was promoted to the new post of director for global research integration. Initiative Media North America is part of Initiative Media Worldwide, a unit of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. The Lead Dog Marketing Group , New York, an event management and sports marketing agency, acquired the event marketing division of the National Media Group , New York. Terms were not disclosed. Laura Molen was named to the new post of vice president and director for ad sales at TNN , New York, the cable network that is part of the MTV Networks division of Viacom. She had been senior vice president and general sales manager at Paramount Advertiser Services, New York, also part of Viacom. The New Jersey Advertising Club named four executives to its Hall of Fame at a ceremony in West Orange. They are: Deb Di Gregorio , president at Camarès Communications, Cedar Knolls; Arden Davis Melick , a communications consultant; John P. Manos , president and chief executive at DKB & Partners, Morristown; and Philip H. Roberts , executive director at the New Jersey Broadcasters Association, Monroe Township. Mervyn's , Hayward, Calif., which operates more than 260 department stores in 14 states, named Castells & Asociados , Los Angeles, to handle a television campaign aimed at Hispanic consumers. Spending was not disclosed. Mervyn's, a division of the Target Corporation, assigns advertising on a project-by-project basis. The campaign is based on the theme ``La ropa lo hace todo,'' or ``The clothes say it all.'' Duncan Marshall and Howard Willmott were named to the new posts of executive creative directors at Publicis in the U.S., New York, part of the Publicis Worldwide division of the Publicis Groupe . They had been group heads and associate creative directors at a sibling agency, Saatchi & Saatchi, London, and will report to Peter Nicholson, chief creative officer. PSA-Dong Feng Motors , Beijing, a joint venture between PSA Peugeot Citroën and Dong Feng Motors, named Star East , Beijing, to handle advertising and communications in support of the introduction of the Peugeot brand in China. Billings were not disclosed. Star East is part of Havas. The Christopher Reeve Paralysis Foundation , Springfield, N.J., named the Crossbow Group, Westport , Conn., to handle direct-mail campaigns, which had been handled by Craver, Mathews, Smith & Co., Arlington, Va. Billings were not disclosed. Rubio's Fresh Mexican Grill , Carlsbad, Calif., a chain of 144 restaurants in six states, named two agencies to handle duties on its account. Siltanen/Keehn , El Segundo, Calif., will handle the creative duties for television and radio commercials, and Tesser , San Francisco, will handle brand, graphics and design assignments. The television duties had been handled by the Los Angeles office of Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group; the other assignments are new or had been handled internally. Spending was estimated at $3 million. The Schadler Kramer Group , Las Vegas, hired three employees. Jessica Cipolla was named account executive; she had been account executive at Shonkwiler Marcoux Advertising, Las Vegas. Greg McFarlane was named copywriter; he had been copywriter at DRGM Advertising and Public Relations, Las Vegas. And David Sadowski was named graphic designer; he had been a freelance graphic designer. Scott D. Schulman was named senior vice president for sales and marketing at The Wall Street Journal , New York, part of Dow Jones & Company, succeeding Paul C. Atkinson, who left to pursue other interests, the company said. Mr. Schulman had been president at the Dow Jones Consumer Electronic Publishing division; succeeding him there is Todd Larsen, who had been vice president and general manager at the division. John Shea , senior vice president for strategic programming at MTV: Music Television , New York, part of the MTV Networks division of Viacom, was promoted to the new post of executive vice president for sponsorship development and integrated marketing for the MTV Networks Music Group. The group is composed of the CMT, MTV, MTV2 and VH1 cable channels. Tim Wallace was named managing director and senior entertainment and broadcasting analyst at UBS Warburg , New York, assuming duties that had been handled by Christopher Dixon and Lee Westerfield, analysts, who left, the company said. Mr. Wallace had been a managing director and senior research analyst at Banc of America Securities, New York, part of Bank of America. UBS is part of UBS A.G.

headline: Iraqis Evaporate: 'I Just Think They Saw Us Coming and Ran'
abstract: Marine units that make up Task Force Tarawa move to engage Iraqi Army's 10th Armored Division at Amara, but Iraqi fighters appear to have fled, leaving vehicles scattered across countryside; marines encircle city, firing only two shots; Iraqi division at full strength had 219 tanks, 260 armored personnel carriers, more than 60 artillery pieces and more than 5,000 soldiers, but those numbers are thought to have been reduced by as much as 75 percent by allied airstrikes; photo; map (M)

headline: Dutch Court Sentences Killer Of Politician to 18-Year Term
abstract: Volkert van der Graaf is sentenced to 18 years in prison for assassination of Pim Fortuyn, right-wing Dutch politician whose death continues to disturb Netherlands; tells court he killed Fortuyn because he felt he was dangerous man 'who abused democracy by picking on vulnerable groups' and who had 'awful ideas' about immigrants, asylum seekers, Muslims and other issues; photo (M)

headline: Goodyear Found Liable
abstract: Denver jury finds Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co liable for $4 million for defective rubber hoses used in home heating systems, third such verdict against company in last 18 months (S)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Some Resilience in a Shaky World
abstract: Average diversified equity mutual fund fell only 3.2 percent in first quarter despite bad news weighing on financial markets; loses in all domestic equity funds averaged 2.9 percent; many analysts and portfolio managers credit resilience to fact markets have already corrected sharply over last three years; investors continued to pull money out of equity funds, with $6.8 billion outflows in quarter; taxable bond funds attracted record inflows of $43.5 billion; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Advert

headline: U.N. Official Gains Key Support to Be Representative in Iraq
abstract: Sergio Vieira de Mello is Secretary General Kofi Annan's choice as the United Nations special representative in Iraq.

headline: Using the Web to Pay Up
abstract: IRS estimates that 53 million Americans will file their taxes online this year and that almost all of them will use software on one of many tax-related Web sites; photo; graph (S)

headline: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- Paris; A City of Good Food, Fashion and Corporate Drama
abstract: Profile of Paris as business destination; photo (M)

headline: Ill Doctor Is Back in U.S.
abstract: Dr Chesley L Richards Jr, American doctor suspected of having SARS, and three colleagues who advised Taiwan, arrive in Atlanta from Taipei; Richards is epidemiologist for Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (S)

headline: Greenspan Says Fed Is on Guard Against Deflation
abstract: The Fed chairman said today that he remained confident that economic conditions were poised for a turnaround.

headline: Cairo, Once 'the Scene,' Cracks Down on Gays
abstract: Most Egyptians view homosexuality as heretical, but in late 1990's Cairo was site of rapidly expanding gay scene; for several years gay life flourished there, either largely unnoticed amid more pressing issues, or tacitly tolerated; there were bars and discos and public meeting places where gays could socialize; in May 2001, police raided disco known as gay-friendly hangout, arresting 52 men; Cairo court has just convicted 23 of them of 'debauchery' and sentenced each to three years in jail after two highly publicized trials that have been widely criticized by human rights groups and Western governments; gay Egyptians say raid on disco was only beginning of harsh crackdown that has quietly intensified (M)

headline: Spring Cleaning for My Brain
abstract: It's Spring Cleaning time again…for my brain. Below, a cluster of random follow-ups, postscripts and observations to tide you over until the spring weather actually turns springlike.

headline: Coaster With a Message: Your Table Is Ready
abstract: Wireless paging devices developed by Long Range Systems and JTech Communications allow restaurant patrons freedom to move about instead of gathering around hostess waiting for names to be called as tables become available; other systems that use customers' cellphones are also being used; photos; drawing (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Says Iran Is Developing Nuclear Arms Under Guise of Civilian Program
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld warns about Iran's nuclear activities, which Washington says is being done under guise of civilian nuclear program; Rumsfeld is in Germany to attend 10th-anniversary celebrations of joint institution of German and American military establishments; says American intelligence community currently assesses that Iran does not have nuclear weapons but does have very active program and is likely to have nuclear weapons in relatively short period of time; in Washington, senior US official says Bush administration has asked International Atomic Energy Agency to refer issue of Iran's suspected nuclear arms program to UN Security Council; photo (M)

headline: By Bank of Japan Standards, New Chief Is an Activist
abstract: 100-day tenure of Bank of Japan governor Toshihiko Fukui contrasts sharply with that of predecessor Masaru Hayami, who frequently resisted government efforts to combat deflation; bank's policy board has voted to ease monetary policy in five of six meetings following Fukui's appointment; critics doubt that small steps taken thus far have had meaningful impact on economy; contend that bank will lose credibility if it does not take decisive action to end deflation; graph; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Forecast Cut For Chip Sales
abstract: Semiconductor Industry Association says chip sales will grow only 10.1 percent in 2003, to $154.9 billion, down sharply from its November 2002 forecast of increase of 19.8 percent; says that chip industry will achieve compound annual growth rate of 9.8 percent fron now to 2006 and that in that year will return to 2000 sales levels (S)

headline: Xerox Alters Tack to Win Business Back
abstract: Xerox Corp announces new business copier products, expanded sales channels and strategy shift toward cutting prices to regain market share; analysts say moves will make Xerox competitive with rivals like Canon and Ricoh in market segments where it has been losing ground (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Economy Slows
abstract: Malaysia's gross domestic product expanded 4 percent in first quarter from year earlier, in line with analysts' expectations and slowing from revised 5.4 percent in fourth quarter (S)

headline: Mastering Many Slopes
abstract: James A Champy, chairman of consulting firm, comments on career path; photo (The Boss column) (S)

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: Neighbors of Iraq Express Concern Over U.S. Intentions
abstract: Leaders of the six countries that share a border with Iraq said they expected to conclude the meeting with a unified stance against even a short-term military occupation of Iraq.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: 2 U.N. Observers Abducted
abstract: Two United Nations peacekeepers are kidnapped from Beni (Congo) headquarters; official in capital Kinshasa reports observers, who are both African, are alive (S)

headline: Korea Distiller Is Ordered Into Bankruptcy
abstract: South Korean court orø

headline: U.S. Economy Slows Growth Across Canada
abstract: Finance Min John Manley says Canada's economy is growing more slowly than expected, but government will balance its budget anyway; expects gross domestic product to grow by 2.2 percent in 2003 after adjusting for inflation, down from 3.2 percent forecast in February; says unexpectedly sluggish economy in US and recent outbreaks of SARS in humans and mad cow disease in cattle are holding back Canada's economy (M)

headline: Turkish Leaders Sending Military Observers to Kirkuk
abstract: American officials worked to discourage Turkey from any steps more provocative than that.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Fuel Project Approved
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group and its partners approve $10 billion project to tap deposits off Russia's Pacific coast after finding buyer for fuel; Shell, Mitsui & Co and Mitsubishi Corp will proceed with plans to develop Lunskoye gas field and build liquefied natural gas plant on Sakhalin Island (S)

headline: S.& P. Cuts Ratings for Altria and Kraft
abstract: Credit ratings of Altria Group, along with those of its Philip Morris USA and Kraft Foods units, are lowered by Standard & Poor's, which cites increased risk of litigation for tobacco companies (S)

headline: Hadhrat Mirza Tahir Ahmad, Muslim Spiritual Leader,74
abstract: Hadhrat Mirza Tahir Ahmad, leader of Ahmadiyya Muslim Movement, dies at age 74 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Reuters Rating Lowered
abstract: Long-term credit rating of Reuters Group is lowered one level by Standard & Poor's on concern cost-cutting plan may hurt revenue (S)

headline: A Fund Group Is Fund-Raising
abstract: Calvert Group, mutual fund group that stresses socially responsible investing, is promoting series of investment and philanthropic vehicles aimed at supporting recovery efforts in Iraq and Mideast peace (S)

headline: North Korea's Atomic Bravado Incites a Host of Skeptics
abstract: North Korea apparently announces it is reprocessing nuclear fuel rods, step that would suggest development of atomic weapons; later withdraws statement from its official Web site amid confusion over accuracy of translation; United States, reacting cautiously, says it will consult with Japan, South Korea and China before responding; officials see no strong indication that nation's known plutonium fuel rods are being reprocessed; many analysts see claim as example of North Korea's shrewd and sometimes seemingly reckless negotiating style (M)

headline: Over Protests, Nepal Lets Chinese Force Refugees Back to Tibet
abstract: Nepal allows China to force 18 Tibetan refugees back to Tibet; has long winked at efforts by its ethnic neighbors in Tibet to separate from China, but is now bending more and more to pressure from Beijing, which is increasingly important aid and trade partner (M)

headline: Henry Racamier Dies at 90; Revitalized Louis Vuitton
abstract: Henry Racamier, who expanded leather-goods maker Louis Vuitton into worldwide conglomerate, dies at age 90; photo (M)

headline: The Fog of Peace
abstract: U.S. forces in Iraq are operating in a netherworld between war and peace. One moment they may be restoring power and the next they may be in a firefight.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Airline Cuts Staff
abstract: Scandinavian Ai

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Midtown Manhattan; Club and Hotel to Share More Than the Name
abstract: Nonprofit good-government organization City Club of New York and commercial venture City Club Hotel reach agreement for club to lend some of its memorabilia to hotel to enhance business's image and for hotel to play host to some club events; both are housed in landmark 1904 Manhattan building; photo (M)

headline: In Japan, Smaller Banks Are Outperforming the Giants
abstract: Handful of midsize regional banks in Japan are outperforming industry giants, which remain plagued with investment losses and bad loans five years after $80 billion government bailout; Shizuoka Bank, Bank of Yokohama and Bank of Bukuoka are among successful institutions virtually unknown outside of their own localities; small companies' success is seen as underscoring flaw in government policy encouraging bank mergers; chart (M)

headline: IRAQIS FRUSTRATED BY SHIFT FAVORING U.S.-BRITISH RULE
abstract: The sudden shift in postwar strategy in favor of an American and British occupation authority has visibly deflated the Iraqi political scene, which earlier this month was bustling with grass-roots politicking and high expectations for an all-Iraqi provisional government.    This week Kurdish leaders are clearing out of Baghdad to return to the north to consult with their constituents about a course of action. They have asked the new American civilian administrator in Iraq, L. Paul Bremer III, to visit northern Iraq to confront the popular disenchantment.

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: DIRECTV WINS DISMISSAL OF SUIT ON PIRACY LETTERS; WEBEX LOWERS FORECASTS ON SALES AND PROFITS;.

headline: 3 European Economies Contract, Stirring a Fear of Wider Damage
abstract: European Union says growth stalled across 12-nation euro zone in first quarter, with Germany, Italy and Netherlands reporting unexpected contractions in their economies; Germany's report that its economy contracted 0.2 percent in quarter, after shrinking 0.03 percent in previous quarter, meets textbook definition of recession, its second since 2001; economists caution that latest figures are preliminary; Germany and France are plagued with chronically high unemployment, and with what bankers and industrialists see as calcified labor markets and cradle-to-grave social welfare programs that are increasingly unaffordable in era of big budget deficits; efforts to shake up labor markets and reduce role of state in economy have been met with strikes in France, political feuds in Germany and protests in Austria; Germany and France have already breached EU rules that limit size of budget deficits at 3 percent of gross domestic product; photos; graph (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Greece: Cigarette Maker Acquired
abstract: Philip Morris International, unit of Altria Group, acquires majority stake in Papastratos, Greece's biggest producer of cigarettes, for as much as 371 million euros ($424 million) (S)

headline: Untangle Family Roots With Simple Software
abstract: Q. I would like to create computer records of information about my ancestors. Are there genealogy programs that are appropriate for computer beginners?    A. Genealogy study is a popular pastime, and dozens of software programs and hundreds of Web sites can help you trace your family's history. Much of the software designed for home users is straightforward and easy to learn.

headline: Senate Panel Agrees to Increase Size of Asbestos Trust
abstract: Senate Judiciary Committee agrees to increase to as much as $153 billion proposed trust fund that would end all asbestos lawsuits and instead pay asbestos victims from set schedule based on their diseases; agreement, for additional $45 billion in financing, could help win support from Democratic lawmakers, increasing likelihood that trust will become law; major obstacle to creation of trust is disagreement over size of payments (M)

headline: World's View of U.S. Sours After Iraq War, Poll Finds
abstract: Poll by Pew Research Center finds Iraq war has deepened international skepticism toward US, American global policies and Pres Bush, with even military allies voicing disappointment or suspicion; graph; director Andrew Kohut says war has widened rift between Americans and Western Europeans, further inflamed Muslim world, softened suppport for war against terrorism and weakened global backing for UN and NATO (M)

headline: Some People's Pests Are Others' Meal Tickets
abstract: Profile of highly specialized industry that sells crickets, mealworms, other insects and rodents to zoos, wild-game parks, bait outlets and others as animal feed; sales total $25 million to $50 million a year; photo (M)

headline: Latin Sweatshops Pressed by U.S. Campus Power
abstract: Factory in Villa Altagracia, Dominican Republic, is unionized with help of unlikely coalition of United States college students, labor activists and world-class brands like Nike and Reebok; together they are working to improve labor conditions in factories in developing countries that make caps and clothing emblazoned with university names and mascots; in Villa Altagracia, interventions from abroad started in 2001, after 20 workers who said they were organizing union were fired; stateside groups lobbied brands that have contracts with factory; United Students Against Sweatshops sent thousands of letters to factory, and also sent student volunteer to help union organize; universities and students were able to coax American brands to cooperate, bringing to table reputation of schools whose names are on caps eagerly courted by athletic wear companies; photo (M)

headline: Saul Gellerman, 74, Psychologist And Consultant on Management
abstract: Saul William Gellerman, psychologist, management consultant and author of books and training films in those areas, dies at 74 (S)

headline: Putin Likens Truck Bomb In Chechnya To Saudi Raid
abstract: Pres Vladimir Putin draws direct parallel between truck bombing in Chechnya and attacks in Saudi Arabia hours later, portraying Russia's war in Chechnya as part of global battle against terrorism; tells visiting NATO Sec Gen Lord Robertson that handwriting is identical; at least 55 people were killed and more than 200 injured in bombing outside government compound, deadliest attack in Chechnya since voters approved new constitution that Kremlin portrays as step toward peace (M)

headline: Passengers Tumble Out as Jet's Door Fails Above Africa
