abstract: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, May 9 — The rear ramp of a Russian-made cargo plane crammed with soldiers and their families flew open high above the jungles of the Congo, officials and witnesses said today. Passengers fell from the sky.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ricoh Profit Rises
abstract: Ricoh Co says profit grew 15 percent in its fiscal fourth quarter; earned 21.1 billion yen ($178 million) (S)0

headline: French Workers Strike to Protest Pension-Revision Plan
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of government employees, with the sporadic backing of workers in the private sector, went on strike to challenge the government of Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin.

headline: Bruised Feelings In Health Care; Letters Describe Clash Of Banker and Client
abstract: The low point in the relationship between Benjamin Lorello, Wall Street's most powerful health care banker, and Mark L. Wagar, a longtime client, came in December 2001.     Mr. Wagar's company, Radiologix, was in the middle of a road show trying to market a $150 million bond offering, and he kept hearing from potential investors that UBS Warburg, Mr. Lorello's firm, was spreading misinformation about his company, indicating that he would shortly be fired from his post as chief executive and that Radiologix had some accounting irregularities.

headline: Learn to Play While Your Guitar Gently Prompts
abstract: Yamaha introduces digital guitar that helps teach user how to play; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls on speculation that US economy will not expand fast enough to prompt foreign investors to invest more in US; euro settles at $1.0775, up from $1.0758 in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Private Sector; In the Shadow of Freddie Mac
abstract: Profile of Armando Falcon Jr, who leaves as director of Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight; agency has come under Congressional scrutiny for not being first to make public possible accounting irregularities at Freddie Mac, giant home mortgage company it regulates, and allegedly coddling company and its larger counterpart, Fannie Mae; he holds agency has done its job and that oversight process has worked, interview; photo (M)

headline: MOODY'S LOWERS CREDIT RATINGS ON READER'S DIGEST
abstract: Moody's Investors Service lowers Reader's Digest's senior secured rating and senior unsecured shelf registration rating (S)

headline: U.S. Official Is 'Optimistic' On India-Pakistan Dispute
abstract: Deputy State Sec Richard L Armitage meets with Pres Pervez Musharraf and other Pakistani officials in Islamabad; then says he is 'cautiously optimistic' about prospect for renewed relations between India and Pakistan; says Musharraf has assured him that infiltration by Islamic militants from Pakistan into part of Kashmir controlled by India has stopped, and that any militant camps found in Pakistan will be closed; India and Pakistan have suprised many with their sudden overtures for peace in last two weeks; Armitage says he hopes to encourage dialogue between two countries over Kashmir (M)

headline: ATARI SELLS A MILLION COPIES OF 'MATRIX' GAME IN A WEEK
abstract: Atari sells more than one million units of its computer game Enter the Matrix in first week; game is tied to release of film The Matrix Reloaded (S)

headline: For Egyptian City Where Leaders Meet, Peace Is a Business
abstract: In a town whose fortunes ebb and flow to the rhythms of the region's hostilities, peace brings dollars, war does not.

headline: A Black Model Reaches the Top, A Lonely Spot
abstract: Liya Kebede, model from Ethiopia,

headline: Executive Pay: A Special Report; A Remix in the Grants of Options and Stock
abstract: Article in special report on executive pay notes most companies gave their chief executives more stock in form of restricted shares last year as stock prices remained submerged, but continued to also give them stock options as well; average value of grants fell along with tumbling market, but many companies raised number of options they awarded; graphs of mix of restricted stock and stock options received by some chief executives; photos (M)

headline: At Trial of 'Real I.R.A.' Leader, Testimony on a Grisly Bombing
abstract: David Rupert, FBI informant, testifies before Ireland's special antiterrorist court in Dublin as main prosecution witness against Michael McKevitt, man charged with running Real IRA, which was behind 1998 bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, that killed 29 people and maimed dozens more (M)

headline: Investing; Have Business Service Stocks Fallen Too Far?
abstract: Many securities analysts believe that shares of business services companies, which range from credit card processors to technology consultants, are poised for rebound after declining nearly 28 percent in last 52 weeks; industry's health largely hinges on healthy economy; layoffs throughout economy have meant fewer paychecks to process and fewer credit card transactions to clear, and decline in high-technology spending has dampened demand for technology advisers; photo; graph (M)

headline: Unemployment Rate Rises To a 9-Year High of 6.1%
abstract: Labor Department reports unemployment rate rose to 6.1 percent, May, highest level in nine years; revised data show economy lost almost 2.5 million jobs since Feb 2001; pace of layoffs has slowed over last two months; graphs and tables of employment data (M).

headline: I.B.M.'s Opponent in Suit Criticizes Linux Advocate
abstract: SCO Group, in new court document, criticizes Linus Torvalds, guardian of freely shared Linux operating system; SCO's amended suit against IBM contends Torvalds, who has overseen development of Linux, appears to have casual attitude toward intellectual property rights; Linux is distributed free and improved upon by far-flung network of developers; SCO sued IBM in March, contending that computer company improperly copied Unix code into Linux; SCO bought source code and license rights to Unix in 1995 (M)

headline: ROADWAY CUTS PROFIT OUTLOOK FOR QUARTER AND YEAR
abstract: Roadway, largest trucking company in the nation, cuts its second-quarter and full-year profit forecasts (S)

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: Online Diary column; Project Implicit (implicit.harvard.edu/implicit) is collaboration by researchers at Harvard, University of Virginia and University of Washington offering tests that measure unconscious preferences on variety of topics; acrophobia, classic word game from early days of Internet, is undergoing revival; players create witty phrases that fit randomly generated combinations of three to seven letters and are scored on basis of number of players who select answer as best; Web site wheniwaslittle.com offers display of both baby and recent photos of people; some miscellaneous sites noted; drawings (M)

headline: Lurking Within the Hi-Fi Rack, a Hard Drive That Rips
abstract: TDK's Jukebox with 20-gigabyte hard drive can play and record standard and MP3 audio CD's and is portable; photo (M)

headline: Truck Bomb Leaves Dozens Dead and Injured in Chechnya
abstract: Today's attack near a government complex killed at least 41 people and wounded scores more, many of them gravely.

headline: For a Precious TV, Mr. Fix-It Is Still There
abstract: Television repair in 21st century is odd business--sets are both bigger and smaller than they used to be; common thought is that they have become more disposable as prices have dropped, but Adam Goldman, who repairs sets in New Jersey, finds people are attached to TV sets and have various threshholds for how much they will spend for repairs; photos (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Just because prices are falling, it doesn't mean there's deflation.
abstract: Virginia Postrel Economic Scene column says fact that prices are falling in some industries does not mean there is deflation; says trends are moving in opposite direction; holds falling dollar raises cost of goods, while growing federal budget deficit creates inflationary pressure; photo (M)

headline: STANDARD REGISTER TO CLOSE PLANTS AND CUT 500 JOBS
abstract: Standard Register, which

headline: Mob Kills Islamic Cleric
abstract: Sheikh Abdul Majid al-Khoei was killed by members of a rival Shiite group in an altercation at Najaf's Imam Ali Mosque.

headline: Chief of Tenet-Owned Hospital Is Indicted
abstract: US grand jury indicts Barry Weinbaum, head of Tenet Corp-owned Alvarado Medical Center, on charges of making illegal payments to doctors to gain patient referrals to hospital; indictment is latest in series of regulatory and legal problems faced by Tenet, whose share price has fallen dramatically since 2002; company is being investigated for its Medicare billing practices as well as possible unnecessary surgeries performed at another of its California hospitals (M)

headline: Times Co. Says Quarterly Earnings Rose 26%
abstract: New York Times Co says first-quarter net income rose 26 percent as falling newsprint costs, rising circulation revenue and overall rise in advertising sales helped company withstand sharp drop in advertising last month in early days of war with Iraq; says net income was $68.8 million compared with $54.5 million year earlier; revenue rose 6.3 percent, to $783.7 million from $737.1 million; advertising revenue for newspaper group decreased 1.6 percent; total costs and expenses increased 3.6 percent, to $661.4 million from $638.6 million; circulation revenue, which makes up 28 percent of total revenue, rose 9.8 percent; average daily circulation for The Times fell by 3.4 percent, to 1.1 million, in quarter compared with year earlier; average Sunday circulation fell 2.4 percent, to 1.7 million; chief financial officer Leonard P Forman comments (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Jupitermedia Cancels Planned Trade Show
abstract: Technology Briefing Hardware: Jupitermedia Cancels Planned Trade Show**Jupitermedia calls off technology exhibition it had planned for Las Vegas to rival Key3Media Group's Comdex's trade show; had hoped to take advantage of Key3Media's bankruptcy plight (S)

headline: Of 2,000 Treasures Stolen in Gulf War of 1991, Only 12 Have Been Recovered
abstract: Experts say more than 2,000 objects were stolen from museums in Iraq in wake of Persian Gulf war in 1991, and not more than half dozen of those pieces have been tracked down; many others are presumed to have been traded away through thriving international market in antiquities; poor record of returning artifacts lost after gulf war suggests daunting obstacles that museum officials and police investigators face as they commit to finding items recently sacked from National Museum of Iraq in Baghdad and other sites; photo; map (M)

headline: Images From a Land of Whispers and Fear
abstract: Photos of various scenes of fighting in Iraq captioned by photographer Tyler Hicks, who relates his feeling of being introduced to culture of fear and repression

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Bank'S Income Rises; SOUTH KOREA: Agency To Raise Bank Stake; JAPAN: Production Slips; JAPAN: Nomura Posts Loss; JAPAN: Canon Posts Profit;.

headline: Role Reversal; Volunteers Set the Grading Curve for Report Cards on Teachers
abstract: RateMyTeachers.com relies on 1,000 student volunteers who weed out fake teacher names and check comments about teachers before they become publicly accessible on Web-based bulletin board (S)

headline: Radical Cleric Is Charged With Treason In Indonesia
abstract: Indonesian prosecutors indict radical cleric Abu Bakar Bashir on charges of treason and plotting to overthrow government and establish Islamic state; Bashir is alleged to have been involved in bombings of several churches in Indonesia in December 2000 and in foiled plot to blow up United States Embassy in Singapore in December 2001; indictment signals change in policy by Indonesian government, which long denied that terrorism was problem or that Jemaah Islamiyah, group Bashir leads, even existed (M)

headline: Chirac to Join German and Russian Leaders
abstract: Pres Jacques Chirac of France will join Pres Vladimir V Putin of Russia and Chancellor Gehard Schroder of Germany for meeting in St Petersburg to discuss postwar Iraq; says UN and UN alone should be responsible for administering Iraq's reconstruction and governance; UN denies Russian announcement that Sec Gen Kofi Annan will join three leaders in St Petersburg (M)

headline: Text of Bush's Statment of Mideast Peace Plan
abstract: Following is a statement by President Bush that was issued today by the White House, as posted on whitehouse.gov.

headline: Plan to Hand More Autonomy to Chechnya Has Its Skeptics
abstract: Akhmad Kadyrov, Moscow-appointed head of government in Chechnya, has proposed giving breakaway republic more autonomy, but many Chechens interpret move as way for him to improve his standing ahead of elections slated for October; Kremlin has yet to issue response to proposal, although Pres Vladimir V Putin has called for treaty on division of power; map (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Suggests Iraq Might Have Destroyed Illicit Arms
abstract: The defense secretar suggested publicly for the first time that Iraq might have destroyed its suspected chemical and biological weapons before the start of the war.

headline: Cause of Tank Plunge Under Investigation
abstract: Marines continue investigation of accident involving tank with crew of four that veered off bridge near Nasiriya, Iraq, and plunged into Euphrates River, killing crew; details of incident recounted; photo (M)

headline: Argentina's Chief Is Sworn In and Comes Out Fighting
abstract: Nestor Kirchner is sworn in as Argentina's president; issues strong challenges to foreign creditors, armed forces and political establishment, speech; disputes International Monetary Fund's recipe for economic recovery; demands easing of foreign debt; Jose Pampuro, new defense minister, confirms three-quarters of army generals and over half of air force and navy commanders are being forced into early retirement; Cuban leader Fidel Castro is among dozen Latin American heads of state at inauguration; photos (M)

headline: Bankruptcy Is Changing Air Canada
abstract: Bankrupt Air Canada seeks to overhaul its culture as well as its finances; former government entity, with dominant share of domestic market and heavily unionized work force, is still associated with mediocre food, lost luggage and surly service; wants to change image to win customers back from low-cost rival WestJet; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Court Allows Same-Sex Marriages
abstract: Toronto (Canada) announces it will grant same-sex marriage licenses following decision by Ontario appeals court that limiting marriage to heterosexuals violated constitutional rights of homosexuals (S)

headline: World Briefing | South Pacific: Troops To The Solomons
abstract: Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer announces Australia and New Zealand will answer Solomon Island government request and enter into armed cooperative intervention to quell 3-year-old insurgency on island chain; foreign ministers of South Pacific nations are to meet Monday and discuss details; 2,000 troops are expected to be deployed to Solomon Islands next month; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft To Buy Unix Licenses From Caldera
abstract: Microsoft Corp will buy some rights to use Unix computer operating system from Caldera International Inc, bolstering Caldera's legal challenge to rival Linux software; Microsoft buys licenses to ensure its Windows-based programs will work with Unix software; value of deal undisclosed; Caldera, which is changing its name to SCO Group, is suing IBM and has warned 1,500 other companies (S)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: BRAZIL: Amazon Deforestation Rate Up; ARGENTINA: Chief Justice Leaves; ARGENTINA: Terror Trial To Hear Security Role;.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: ITALY: Law Signed Ending Berlusconi Trial; ITALY: Migrant Boat Sinks Off Tunisia; RUSSIA: Conviction In Theater Hostage-Taking; GERMANY: Immigration Plan Rejected; SPAIN: Basque Leaders Charged;.

headline: Who's Minding the Drugstore?
abstract: Food and Drug Administration, earlier criticized for delays in halting misleading drug advertising, is taking far fewer actions against ads than in past; industry critics cite promotions that illegally market unapproved uses of drug, understate risks, overstate benefits or make claims not backed up by studies; says FDA has become willing to let some problems slip by and let companies go further with their marketing claims; Comr Mark B McClellan defends agency's efforts, interview; holds decline in regulatory letters began in Clinton administration and does not mean FDA has become less aggressive in enforcing marketing rules; says FDA is working with drug companies before ads run to prevent misleading ads; says it is responds to several court rulings that it went to far in trying to rein in promotions; graphs of rising ad spending and waning FDA regulatory letters; photos (M)

headline: F.C.C. Votes to Relax Rules Limiting Media Ownership
abstract: The ruling allows companies to buy more television stations and own a newspaper and a broadcast outlet in the same city.

headline: Business; Amid a Wine Glut, Efforts to Court Black Consumers
abstract: Vision Cellars proprietor Mac McDonald has joined with three other black winemakers to form Association of African-American Vintners, marketing group aimed at black wine drinkers, overlooked marketing niche; association members recently took part in tasting in Harlem run by TenFolks, for-profit wine education group for New York City blacks; photo (M)

headline: American Reining In Frequent-Flier Plan
abstract: American Airlines is raising number of miles that members of its frequent-flier program need to accumulate before miles can be redeemed for certain kinds of tickets; required miles for those tickets will go up as much as 25 percent; mileage increase, to take place on May 1, applies to seven kinds of free ticket that can be used for travel within US and Canada or between North America and Hawaii; American, unit of AMR Corp, has 45 million members in its frequent-flier program, most of any airline (M)

headline: With Virus at Gate, the Drawbridge Is Up
abstract: Many villages surrounding Beijing build makeshift barricades and post sentinels to keep out strangers, in desperate if not always well-informed attempt to fend off contagion of SARS; total number of cases of SARS in Beijing is now 1,114, with 56 deaths; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Another Loss At Hynix
abstract: Hynix Semiconductor posts net loss of 1.05 trillion won ($87 billion) in first quarter of year compared to profit of 3.7 billion won in first quarter of 2002; sales were 682 billion won ($568 million), down from 823 billion won in period last year (S)g

headline: An Art Center Left in Ashes
abstract: Baghdad's cultural elite rage about destruction of city's art treasures, first by American bombs and then by looters; Amal al-Khedairy, whose home is in one of Baghdad's wealthier enclaves, walks amid rubble and shattered windows and ransacked remains of her home and cultural center she ran; war has dragged her from comfortable way of life under Saddam Hussein; she does not speak of compromises involved in running Baghdad's most luminous artistic center that flourished during Hussein's reign; her rage seems emblematic of whole class of people who might be expected to be more sympathetic to American cause; all they can see now is ruins; photo (M)

headline: Kidnappers in Separatist Georgian Region Free 4 U.N. Workers
abstract: Four United Nations employees kidnapped last week in secession-minded region of Georgian Republic are released by their abductors and returned to Tbilisi; are part of UN team that monitors ceasefire agreement struck in 1993 between Georgian government and leaders of breakway region of Abkhazia; kidnappers first demanded $3 million in ransom, then agreed to release hostages in exchange for guarantee that they would not be arrested; hostages--two Germans, Dane and Georgian--are shown on Georgian television, unshaven and dirty but celebrating their release; Georgian officials say no ransom was paid (M)

headline: Miller Brewing finds that women wrestling in wet concrete get attention but don't help it sell beer.
abstract: 'Cat Fight' commercials for Miller Lite beer, among most contentious and talked-about advertising of recent years, come to abrupt end as Miller Brewing realizes that women wrestling in wet concrete gain attention but don't help sell beer; Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide created ad campaign; series is seen as emblematic of trend toward using more frank and provocative sexual imagery to sell products (M)

headline: PEOPLESOFT SHARES FALL WITH MISSED FORECAST
abstract: Shares of PeopleSoft Inc fall 9 percent after company says first-quarter profit and sales declined more than forecast; license sales were as low as $80 million after forecast of $125 million to $135 million; profit fell to 11 cents or 12 cents per share, missing company estimate of as much as 14 cents; total sales dropped to $450 million (S)

headline: Unit of Interpublic Announces Job Cuts
abstract: Mullen Advertising, unit of Interpublic Group of Companies, is laying off about 10 percent of its 554 employees (S)

headline: Hole in a Wall At a Palace Yields Millions In U.S. Cash
abstract: American soldiers find huge cache of US currency in one of Saddam Hussein's palaces that could be as much as $656 million; military officials say money was originally acquired from Bank of Jordan (M)

headline: G.M. to Raise $10 Billion For Pension Gap
abstract: General Motors will sell $10 billion in bonds and other securities in move to reduce its billion pension deficit, which stands at $19.3 billion; company had previously announced that it would contribute about $15 billion to its benefit and retirement plans through 2007 (M)

headline: U.N. Draft: 'to Assist the People of Iraq'
abstract: Excerpts from United States-supported resolution for United Nations Security Council on Iraq (M)

headline: United to Offer E-Mail Access on North American Flights
abstract: The service, which will be available on more than 500 United planes by the end of the year, is the first e-mail system set up on an airline in the United States.

headline: Iraq Arms Report Mishandled, Blair Aide Concedes in Letter
abstract: Alastair Campbell, British Prime Min Tony Blair's director of communications, writes letter to Sir Richard Dearlove, chief of Secret Intelligence Service, conceding that government's presentation of report on Iraqi arms was mishandled and promising that 'far greater care' would be taken with files in future so as not to discredit spy agency's work; news of letter comes as use of intelligence findings to muster support for war on Iraq has increasingly come under questioning; controversy has obliged Blair to reassure Paliament that his government did not embellish spy reports to exaggerate threat of unconventional weapons and justify war (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Tough Target For Carmaker
abstract: DaimlerChrysler chairman Jurgen E Schrempp says it will be difficult to meet profit margin targets for 2003; says Chrysler's sales in US are down 6.2 percent so far this year; photo (S)

headline: Lightning-Quick CD Burner Moonlights as a DVD Player
abstract: Samsung's new compact-disc recorder drive can record DC-R discs at speed of 52x and record data to reusable CD-RW discs at 24x; photo (S)

headline: As Their Leaders Wrangle, Palestinians Look Askance
abstract: As his leaders clashed over what men would hold which seats in a new Palestinian government, Jamal Abu Rumi, college graduate and father of seven, sat at a curbside falafel restaurant here today with less than a dollar in his pocket, places to go and no hope of getting there.    For five days, Mr. Abu Rumi, who studied geography at the University of Beirut, has not been able to get to his home in southern Gaza because Israel closed two checkpoints inside Gaza. He has not been able to get out of Gaza to his job at an Israeli construction site because during the Passover holiday Israel has shut the gates even to legal Palestinian workers like him.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Monsoon Rally
abstract: Bombay Stock Exchange index of 30 stocks rises 45.71 points, or 1.4 percent, as annual monsoon season arrives; graph (S)

headline: Marketer to Lead Division of Big Agency Company
abstract: Marketer to Lead Division of Big Agency Company*** Ann Fudge is named unexpectedly to be chairwoman and chief executive of Young & Rubican Inc, major division of WPP Group; is first black woman to lead large division of global advertising agency company and one of few black female chief executives in US; assumes duties from Michael Dolan, whose departure is being described as resignation; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Jack Griffin is named president of Meredith Magazine Group, division of Meredith Corp (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.75       Discount rate   2.25   2.25   N.A.       Federal funds   1.38   1.30   1.70       3-month T-bills   1.03   1.02   1.71       6-month T-bills   1.07   1.07   1.89       10-yr. T-infl.   1.79   1.79   3.13       10-yr. T-note   3.53   3.52   5.26       30-yr. T-bond   4.48   4.51   5.76       Telephone bd.   5.58   5.65   7.82       Municipal bds.   4.58   4.60   5.45          (Sources: Citigroup; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Market Place; Decreasing Prices Ignite a Sell-Off In Tobacco Bonds
abstract: Recent slide in tobacco bonds issued by states has touched off panic selling among many investors and raised speculation about possible improper trading; many states have sold bonds backed by money they expect to receive over 25 years from tobacco companies, under industry settlement reached in 1998; prices of those bonds have fallen in recent weeks on growing fears that tobacco companies might not complete their payments; California says it might delay sale of tobacco bonds, scheduled for two weeks from now; California is counting on revenue from such sales to help cover its enormous budget deficit; average price of tobacco bond previously issued by California fell 14.4 percent from March 21 through March 27 (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Industrial Use Rises
abstract: Canadian industrial companies worked harder in first quarter, using 82.8 percent of their capacity (S)0

headline: In Abandoned Iraqi Files, Hints of What Might Have Been
abstract: The Iraqi military's defense of this country did not go as planned. But a recent visit to the abandoned headquarters of Iraq's 51st Mechanized Division offered glimpses of what might have been.

headline: Business; With a Stable of Heroes, Marvel Casts a Wide Net
abstract: Marvel Enterprises Inc's comeback from bankruptcy five years ago described; its successful strategy involved rights to hundreds of characters created over years for Marvel's comic books; Marvel has been remade as entertainment company focused on licensing its characters to moviemakers, toymakers, video game makers and television producers; photo of one such character, Spiderman, and of company principals William E Jemas Jr, Allen S Lipson, Avi Arad and Alan Fine; graph (M)

headline: U.N. Gives Cuba Mild Rebuke Over Crackdown on Dissidents
abstract: UN Human Rights Commission passes resolution giving mild rebuke to Cuba, calling for admission of human rights monitor but saying nothing about recent crackdown on dissidents that has touched off international outrage; rejects Costa Rican amendment calling for release of more than 75 dissidents imprisoned in recent weeks; tougher amendment is shunned by other Latin American nations (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Cuts At Airline
abstract: Singapore Airlines will lay off 414 employees who are based in Singapore (S)

headline: BRUKER DALTONICS BUYS BRUKER AXS TO SAVE BOTH MONEY
abstract: Bruker Daltonics, maker of scientific equipment that is controlled by chief executive Frank Laukien and his family, agrees to buy Bruker AXS, also owned by Laukiens, for $103.6 million; combined company will be called Bruker BioSciences Corp (S)

headline: Verizon to Reveal Customers in Piracy Case
abstract: Verizon Communications says it will give Recording Industry of Association of America names of four online subscribers accused of illegally copying music over Internet after federal court rejects its bid for delay; decision is blow to Internet service providers and privacy advocates who argue that subpoena process group used violates rights of Internet users; recording industry executives laud decision (M)

headline: Letter Attributed to Hussein Published in London Paper
abstract: A purported letter from Saddam Hussein published Wednesday in an Arabic-language newspaper in London urges Iraqis to "rise up" against occupation.

headline: Marking Tianamen, Hong Kong Crowd Opposes Security Law
abstract: Thousands of Hong Kong residents hold candlelight vigil to commemorate students who died in Tiananmen Square in 1989 and to oppose stringent internal-security laws that their own government is considering, partly at Beijing's behest; laws would give government broad powers to ban orginizations that have been prohibited in mainland China and would make distribution of publications that incite violent acts of subversion, secession or treason a crime; group of pro-democracy advocates from Hong Kong is also in United States, trying to bring international pressure against legislation; Roman Catholic Church in Hong Kong has also been active in opposing legislation, which it fears could be used to limit religious freedom (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: MICROSOFT CORRECTS SECURITY FLAW IN PASSPORT PROGRAM; I2 TECHNOLOGIES TO BE REMOVED FROM NASDAQ;.

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Life-Cycle Funds Become Popular for Long-Term Goals
abstract: Big mutual fund companies are offering relatively new kind of fund as automatic way to shift money among asset classes; funds, know by names like lifestyle funds, life-cycle funds, life-strategy funds and target-date funds, are gaining popularity; tend to decline less than traditional balanced funds during market downturns, but generally do not ouperform market in good times (M)

headline: Iran Strongly Disputes American Accusations of Interfering in Iraq's Affairs
abstract: Foreign Min Kamal Kharrazi of Iran brushes off American accusations of interference in Iraq at joint news conference in Tehran with French Foreign Min Dominique de Villepin; says US should cooperate with Iran and welcome Iran's positive role; US blames Iran for ferocious anti-American sentiment being voiced by Shiite Muslims and some Sunnis in Iraq; says Iranian agents have crossed into Iraq to promote friendly Shiite clerics in Basra, Karbala and Najaf and advance Iran's interests; de Villepin expresses hope that France can contribute to political, economic and social reconstruction of Iraq; stresses pivotal role of United Nations; photo (M)

headline: Looting at a Border Post: All That's Left Is Regret
abstract: Scene described in Trebil, checkpoint on Iraqi-Jordanian border, as post is picked clean by looters; photo (M)

headline: U.S. to Recruit Iraqi Civilians To Interim Posts
abstract: Bush administration says it will begin to identify civilian leaders to help run Iraq; tensions persist between State and Defense Depts over interim authority that would pave way for elected government in Iraq; Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz says regional public meetings will be held in Iraq beginning next week to seek out candidates for civilian leadership posts and elicit their views; says meetings will include civilians from all ethnic and religious groups, inside and outside Iraq; administration officials say they are appealing to allies for material help, including personnel to help keep order in postwar Iraq; emphasize that American and British military forces would play 'leading role' in setting up Iraqi government, and that United Nations would play 'vital' but decidedly advisory role limited to coordination of food, medicine and other relief supplies; still unresolved is what, if any, role will be played by Ahmad Chalabi, head of Iraqi National Congress; Wolfowitz as well as Vice Pres Dick Cheney and Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld are among his powerful allies; State Dept views him with skepticism because he has been in exile for so long (M)

headline: Health Officials Seek Help From U.S. to Control Virus
abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention team arrives in Canada to help Canadian officials control continued spread of SARS; officials advise health care workers in Toronto area hospitals to wear double sets of gowns and gloves and full face shields when caring for SARS patients; advise hospitals and clinics to clean treatment rooms more stringently and restrict access to rooms; respond to continued spread of illness among health care workers and studies suggesting virus can survive on objects for 24 hours (M)

headline: Iraqi Leader Asks U.S. To Stop Military Sweeps
abstract: Adnan Pachachi, respected elder Iraqi statesman encouraged by Bush administration officials to enter postwar politics in Iraq, criticizes United States military for its increasingly aggressive operations in Iraq and says they should be suspended while interim Iraqi government is formed over next month; asserts that military sweeps through civilian areas with mass arrests, interrogations and gun battles, which are intended to suppress remnants of Saddam Hussein's Baath Party and military command, are inflaming sentiments against American and British occupation; photo (M)

headline: U.S. and Saudis Sensed Attacks Were Imminent
abstract: US and Saudi officials grew increasingly alarmed in two weeks before Riyadh truck bombings about intercepted communications that gave 'strong indications' of imminent attack by Islamic terrorists against Americans in Saudi Arabia; at least 20 people, including seven Americans, were killed in precise, well-coordinated strikes at three civilian housing complexes; US says Al Qaeda is almost certainly responsible and believes attacks were timed to coincide with Sec Colin Powell's visit; photos; Vice Pres Cheney says only way to deal with threat is to destroy it; indications of more attacks also noted (M)

headline: ACCORD REPORTED ON ISRAELI PULLOUT FROM GAZA AREAS
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian leaders reportedly reach agreement on withdrawal of Israeli forces from areas of Gaza Strip and return of security control to Palestinian officers; withdrawal, which could begin on June 29, would be first joint step forward under road map peace plan; Palestinian security officials agree to seek capture of what Israel calls 'ticking bombs'--attackers preparing to strike; Israel promises to permit Palestinians to travel more freely, ease military choke points on main north-south road and to draw back forces in northern Gaza (M)

headline: Calvin Klein Is Seeking Treatment for Substance Abuse
abstract: Fashion designer Calvin Klein is seeking professional help for substance abuse, nearly two weeks after his erratic behavior during Knicks basketball game at Madison Square Garden briefly forced halt to play; incident raised questions about Klein's health and his role in his company; Klein says he will continue his ongoing work at Calvin Klein Inc, which was recently acquired by Phillips-Van Heusen; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank's Profit Falls
abstract: Net income of French bank Credit Agricole fell 5.7 percent in first quarter; net profit dropped to 246 million euros ($285 million) from 261 million euros ($302 million), while gross operating income fell 28.2 percent, to 288 million euros ($334 million) (S)g

headline: The PC Generation, Back to the Board
abstract: People who grew up playing computer and video games are rediscovering board games, not so much stalwarts like Monopoly and Scrabble as more complex games of exploration and trade with names like Settlers of Catan, Puerto Rico and Carcassone; welcome social interaction they cannot get from video games, even playing against others online; photos (M)

headline: Agency Is Selected for Napster Revival
abstract: Agency Is Selected For Napster Revival.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)ÿ

headline: Business; Carrying On When Suits Are in Camouflage
abstract: Many companies are experiencing creativity gaps

headline: Continued Air Assaults on City Follow Attempt to Kill Hussein
abstract: U.S. forces launched another assault on central Baghdad this morning, following an attempt to kill Saddam Hussein.

headline: Hooked Fish Feel Pain, British Scientists Say, Roiling the Waters
abstract: Fishing is Britain's most popular participatory sport; now its 3.8 million anglers are under pressure from dispute arising from study published in Royal Society, independent British scientific research body, establishing for first time that fish do feel pain when hooked; anglers fear that Britain's militant animal rights movement will turn on them; photo; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Casino Deal
abstract: A bingo and casino operator, the Gala Group of London, is teaming up with Harrah's Entertainment to build eight casinos in Britain. Each of the gaming companies will invest $500 million in the 50-50 partnership. Sites for the casinos and time frame for development have not yet been decided.     Heather Timmons (NYT)

headline: Private Sector; Augusta Charity Finds Itself in the Rough
abstract: augusta charity finds itself in the rouï

headline: Suicide Blast Kills 16 in Jerusalem; Israel Strikes Gaza
abstract: A Palestinian bomber disguised as an Orthodox Jew detonated himself on a crowded bus, killing 16 other people and wounding nearly 100.

headline: The Cellphones We Ought to Have
abstract: In last week’s edition of Circuits, I reviewed super-simple cellphones. I gave top honors to the Kyocera 2325, where every useful feature is a single button-press away.

headline: On Dark and Stormy Nights, A Keyboard Lights the Way
abstract: EluminX computer keyboard from Auravision glows in dark (M)

headline: In Their Hummers, Right Beside Uncle Sam
abstract: Some Hummer owners feel especially patriotic when seeing US military use vehicle in Iraq; General Motors sells 3,000 Hummer H2 vehicles per month, best-selling large luxury SUV; International Hummer Owners Group founder Rick Schmidt comments; Sierra Club is planning campaign against Hummer because of its gas consumption; photos (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Phillip H. Perelmuter; Hartford MidCap Fund
abstract: investing4

headline: Irate Members Of Congress Talk of Inquiries Into Freddie Mac
abstract: Members of Congress promise to investigate Freddie Mac, government-chartered buyer of home mortgages, and they gain Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan as ally in their efforts to end company's special exemptions from securities laws; lawmakers announce plans for at least one, and probably more hearings into Freddie Mac, which is conducting internal probe into its accounting practices; members of Congress criticize Freddie Mac for refusing to disclose terms of severance package of departing executives David Glenn, Leland C Brendsel and Vaughn A Clarke; Glenn will not receive any severance pay because he was fired; Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, which monitors Freddie Mac, says company has decided to disclose severance terms and it expects to release information on June 11; Rep Richard H Baker says his House Financial Sevices subcommittee will hold hearing; Sen Richard C Shelby says Senate Banking Committee will be monitoring regulators' probe; possibility of yet another hearing is raised by Rep Cliff Stearns, chairman of House Energy and Commerce subcommittee (M)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Nobel Money To Benefit Staff Children
abstract: United Nations General Assembly agrees to use Nobel Peace Prize awarded to organization and Secretary General Kofi Annan to establish education fund for children of civilian staff members killed in line of duty; Deputy Secretary General Louise Frechette comments (S)

headline: Barrels of Iraqi Oil Exported for the First Time Since the War
abstract: First Iraqi oil to be exported since end of war is loaded onto tanker in Turkish Mediterranean port of Ceyhan; but Iraqi oil officials say steady flow of oil to world markets appears to be at least two weeks away, because of severe looting of oil facilities; first oil exported is part of eight million barrels that had been shipped from vast northern Kirkuk field to storage terminals in Ceyhan during war; photo (M)

headline: Once Dangerous Pilgrimage Is Forbidden No More
abstract: Shiite Muslimsï

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: Online Diary reports on Sam Brown's Web site, where he displays pictures he draws that are inspired by titles submitted by site visitors, on software offered by some Christian-oriented companies that tracks one's Internet use and electronically reports any visits to pornography, gambling or other addictive sites one is trying to avoid to an 'accountability partner,' and new crop of visualization tools that apply network theory to Web browsing; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Growth Forecast
abstract: Thailand's Prime Min Thaksin Shinawatra expects nation's economy to expand average 6 percent a year over next six years; says gross domestic product will probably grow to $200 billion by 2009, from $130 billion; inflation is expected to be 2 percent over next year; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: AMP Shares Fall
abstract: Shares of AMP, Australia's largest financial group, fall 40 percent as market responds to its decision to sell additional stock and spin off money-losing British unit, which runs Henderson Global Investors fund; graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hyundai Strike Planned
abstract: Workers at South Korea's Hyundai Motor vote to strike, seeking 11 percent wage increase and 40-hour workweek, down from 44 hours; Pres Roh Moo Hyun orders crackdowns on illegal strikes as subway workers stage partial walkouts in Pusan and Inchon; photo (S)

headline: German Cause Célèbre: A Teacher's Head Scarf
abstract: Lawsuit brought by Fereshta Ludin over being denied public teaching job because she wears Islamic head scarf comes before Germany's highest court; dispute has divided public opinion and become touchstone for German anxieties about growing Islamic minority (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: HONG KONG: Airline Adds Flights; INDONESIA: Public Offering; JAPAN: Fujitsu Wins Verizon Order; JAPAN: Hotel Operator Seeks Protection; SOUTH KOREA: Hyundai Strike Planned; JAPAN: Seiko Epson Opens Strong;.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Departing Leader Pardons Plotters
abstract: Argentina's interim President Eduardo Duhalde engenders criticism, with his pardoning of political leaders Enrique Daroldo Gorriaran Merlo and Mohamed Ali Seineldin; both are serving life sentences for their part in coups attempted over 10 years ago (S)

headline: Rain Forest Is Losing Ground Faster in Amazon, Photos Show
abstract: New satellite images show that Amazon rain forest is disappearing at increasing rate--with about 10,000 square miles lost mainly to pasture land, plantations and illegal logging in 12-month period ended last August; scientists and environmentalists say about 20 percent of Amazon has already vanished and that rain forest could be wiped out in 80 years; Brazilian Environment Min Marina Silva promises emergency action but does not offer specific proposals (M)

headline: SBC Drops Out Of Bidding For Hughes And TV Unit
abstract: SBC Communications drops out of bidding for Hughes Electronics and its coveted DirecTV satellite television operation; Rupert Murdoch's News Corp is expected to make formal bid for controlling stake in Hughes in complex deal expected to be worth more than $5 billion; only competitor left for control of Hughes appears to be Cablevision Systems (M)

headline: Appointment at Lauren
abstract: Polo Ralph Lauren names Brian Duffy president and chief operating officer of Polo Europe, succeeding Gian Luigi Longinotti-Buitoni, who resigned (S)

headline: Argentina's President Overhauls Federal Police
abstract: Argentine Pres Nestor Kirchner steps up purge of unpopular security forces, dismissing 80 percent of high command of Federal Police and moving to control notoriously corrupt force in Buenos Aires province (S)

headline: J. Hugh Liedtke, 81, Oilman Who Bested Texaco in Court
abstract: J Hugh Liedtke, longtime head of Pennzoil Co, dies at age 81 (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Big Board Says Inquiry Is of Breach Of Lesser Sort
abstract: New York Stock Exchange says contrary to news reports, it is not investigating whether its traders improperly bought stocks in advance of big orders from investors, practice known as front-running; says it is investigating whether handful of specialists failed to match orders from small investors directly, instead making profit by buying from one and selling to another; rules require that specialists directly match orders whenever possible; Edward A Kwalwasser, executive vice president of exchange for regulation, comments (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Offers Are Set This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Alaris Medical Inc., San Diego, 9.1 million shares. Bear, Stearns/CIBC World Markets/UBS.

headline: Midas Begins Review Of Its Creative Work
abstract: Midas Inc beginï

headline: Administration Divided Over North Korea
abstract: Days before Pres Bush approved opening of negotiations with North Korea over its nuclear program, Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld circulated memo urging US to team up with China to exert diplomatic pressure for ouster of North Korea's leadership; situation has become newest subject of internal struggle in administration that is determined to stop spread of nuclear arms and other unconventional weapons; White House officials say regime change in North Korea is not official administration policy and Pentagon spokeswoman Victoria Clarke says Rumsfeld supports Bush; memo, which argues that Washington's goal should be collapse of Kim Jong Il's government, was said to have circulated for discussion among high-level officials; strategy outlined in memo is in stark contrast to State Dept position of assuring North Korea that US is not trying to undermine government; memo's detractors say it is ludicrous to think China would do anything to bring about fall of North Korean government, which would create flood of refugees and put Western allies on its border; Bush and Rumsfeld have carefully avoided ruling out military strike on North Korea, and both have publicly insisted that diplomacy is proper approach; hard-liners insist US should use speedy victory in Iraq to persuade North Korea to disarm or meet similar fate (M)

headline: Smith Barney Hires Merkley Newman
abstract: Smith Barney Hires Merkley Newman The Smith Barney division of Citigroup in New York yesterday named Merkley Newman Harty & Partners in New York to handle creative duties on its account, which had been handled since 1994 by McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York. Billings were estimated at more than $15 million.

headline: Entrepreneurial Spirit Leads Middelhoff to Investcorp
abstract: Thomas Middelhoff, who was ousted from Bertelsmann IN 2002, completes contract to head European corporate investment arm of Investcorp; describes yearlong process that led him to Investcorp as arduous; photo (M)

headline: British Spy in I.R.A. Is Pulled Out
abstract: Alfredo Scappaticci was moved to a safehouse in England after it emerged that newspapers in Ireland and Scotland were about to identify him by name.

headline: Military and C.I.A. Searching Baghdad for Hussein and His Sons or Their Bodies
abstract: Besieged by reports and rumors on the whereabouts of Saddam Hussein, a formerly covert intelligence operation in Baghdad turned into a wide-open manhunt.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Unemployment Rises
abstract: Hong Kong's unemployment rate rose to 8.3 percent in period from March through May, compared with 7.8 percent for February through April; rate of underemployment rose to 3.8 percent from 3.2 percent (S)

headline: People
abstract: *Ami Brophy is named executive director at Clio Awards, New York (S)

headline: Greenspan, Broadly Positive, Spells Out Deflation Worries
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, issues his strongest warning yet about dangers posed by deflation while offering generally optimistic view of economy, testimony before Joint Economic Committee of Congress; says deflation is possibility and Fed is closely monitoring it for ways to combat it if it takes hold; stresses that growth is likely to improve this year; holds Fed could inject money into economy to halt any deflation, which could cripple economy by causing people to reduce their spending in anticipation of future bargains, and by effectively increasing debt load; gives political support to policy makers who have argued for smaller tax cut, reiterating concern that rising federal budget deficit could harm economy by driving up interest rates and raising cost of money for consumers and business; avoids taking positions on specific parts of tax-cut legislation before Congress, instead lamenting lack of discussion about reductions in government spending; offers general praise for elimination of taxes on dividends and capital gains and for unemployment benefits, which Democrats want to extend; photo (M)

headline: France Offers More Talks in Bid to End Union Walkouts
abstract: Trying to end the worst labor unrest in almost a decade, France's government sought to gain the support of labor unions whose views on pension reform are most like its own.

headline: Students Roil Iranian Capital in 3rd Night of Protests
abstract: Students protest outside Tehran Univ for third night, calling for social and political freedom; chant 'Death to Khamenei,' slogan that can bring jail term in Iran, where Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, supreme religious leader, goes unquestioned; protest explodes into surrounding middle-class neighborhoods, with large gangs of students fighting running street battles against vigilantes armed with sticks and chains; protests are erupting as nervous government seeks to forge policy toward United States in face of renewed pressure from Washington; adding to government's unease is fact that opposition-run Persian-language television stations in US are calling for Iranians to pour into streets; Khamenei accuses US of trying to foment disorder in Iran and warns protesters that government would be merciless against those acting in interests of foreign powers; photo (M)

headline: After 2 Years of Gains, Gold Struggles to Keep Its Luster
abstract: Will strong individual investor demand for gold persist, or will it slow, now that the war in Iraq appears nearly over?

headline: In Challenge, Forbes Paid No Money Back
abstract: No advertisers qualify for refunds guaranteed them by Forbes magazine Web site Forbes.com if their ads on site failed to achieve some degree of effectiveness after 60 days (S)

headline: Pilots Ratify Concessions At United
abstract: United Airlines says its pilots have ratified labor concessions that would save it $1.1 billion a year; reaches tentative accord with mechanics on wage cuts and other moves to save $349 million a year over six years; flight dispatchers also approve concessions; UAL Corp chief executive Glenn F Tilton says United needs moves to emerge from bankruptcy and succeed for long term; seeks $2.56 billion a year in labor concessions (M)

headline: 5 Israeli Arabs Accused of Funneling $10 Million to Hamas
abstract: It was a relatively rare instance in which Arab citizens of Israel have been accused of ties to extremist movements.

headline: No Concession From I.B.M. In Linux Fight
abstract: IBM announces it will fight suit brought by SCO Group over allegations that IBM infringed SCO license by copying code from Unix operating system to freely-distributed Linux system; SCO, which has attempted to build its own Linux-based business, has shifted strategy to focus on aggressively enforcing its licensing rights to Unix, acquired in 1995 from Novell; thus far SCO has signed licensing agreements with two companies, one of which is Microsoft (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Internet Security Says Profits May Exceed Predictions
abstract: Shares of Internet Security Systems Inc., whose software protects computer networks from intruders, rose 11 percent on the Nasdaq yesterday after the company said second-quarter profits and sales might exceed analysts' forecasts. Profits, excluding some costs, will be 13 cents to 15 cents a share on sales of $60 million to $64 million, the company said late Thursday. Analysts on average expected earnings of 13 cents a share and sales of $62 million, according to Thomson First Call. First-quarter profits rose 59 percent as costs fell and sales gained 1.8 percent. Internet Security shares, which dropped 43 percent last year and 46 percent in the first quarter, rose $1.30, or 11 percent, to $13.11. Profits, excluding acquisition costs and other items, this year will be 57 cents to 65 cents a share, the company said. On that basis, which does not comply with generally accepted accounting principles, profits are expected to be 56 cents, according to Thomson First Call. Sales this year will be $248 million to $260 million, the company said. That compares with analysts' average forecast of $254.4 million.

headline: Inquiry Into a Deadly Venezuelan Rally Is Stalled
abstract: Investigation into deaths of 18 people when gunfire erupted during April 11, 2002, antigovernment march in Caracas, Venezuela, appears to be in shambles; still, it is increasingly clear that gunfire came from both sides, as did victims; much of blame for lack of progress in bringing those responsible to justice is being placed on office of Atty Gen Isaias Rodriguez, who was once vice president and whose ties to Pres Hugo Chavez, some say, have compromised his independence; photo (M)

headline: American Envoy Rules Out Sanctions on French Trade
abstract: US trade representative Robert B Zoellick reassures French business leaders that 'punishment' Bush administration intends to mete out to France for opposing Iraq war does not include trade sanctions; Zoellick meets with French Economy Min Francis Mer in Paris to attend meeting of Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development; says primary purpose in coming to France is to energize some motion on Doha agenda, referring to current round of talks under World Trade Organization (M)

headline: Egyptian Intellectual Speaks Of the Arab World's Despair
abstract: Ahmed Kamal Aboulmagd, one of Egypt's best-known intellectuals, despairs over path taken by United States and claims America's Arab friends have never before felt so estranged from US: has spent more than 20 years working on projects aimed at promoting dialogue between Western, non-Muslim civilization and Arab-Muslim world; says under present situation, he could not consider defending United States; says its war on Iraq is widely seen in Arab world as attack on all Arabs, meant to serve interests of Israel with no compensating outreach to aggrieved Arabs; says 1991 Persian Gulf war was waged with understanding that US would engage itself in search for peace, but this war was launched without parallel American effort to compel Israel to forge genuine peace with Palestinians; his remarks reflect deep distress that has seized Arab elite, people whose support could help advance Bush administration's professeed mission to bring democracy to Arab world; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Cristian Dobles is named senior vice president and executive creative director at New York office of GlobalHue, assuming duties handled by president-chief creative director Kevyn Lewis, who becomes consultant (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: COURT ASKED TO UPHOLD MICROSOFT SETTLEMENT;.

headline: Rumsfeld Awed and Blunt, And a Rush for the Tarmac
abstract: When Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld arrived in Baghdad on Wednesday at the culmination of a seven-nation tour, his first stop was at one of Saddam Husseins ornate palaces that Army commanders have converted into a headquarters.     Mr. Rumsfeld has seen his share of opulence over the years, and last visited Baghdad in 1983 as President Ronald Reagan's special Middle East envoy. But the secretary looked a bit awe-struck and even disgusted at the extravagance of the gleaming marble and crystal chandeliers.

headline: Powell to Visit Israel to Ask For Looser Reins in Gaza
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell says he will travel this week to Israel to press for transfer of security operations in northern Gaza Strip from Israeli forces to Palestinian forces under direction of security chief Muhammad Dahlan (M)

headline: Blair Denies Britain Distorted Intelligence Reports on Iraq
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair said today a parliamentary committee would investigate the accusations and make public its findings.

headline: 200 in Herd Found Free Of Mad Cow
abstract: Canadian authorities report that nearly 200 cows belonging to same Alberta herd as one infected with mad cow diseases were found to be free of disease after they were slaughtered and tested; say they will kill at least 140 and perhaps hundreds more cattle in coming days in western Canada to test them and assure consumers and international importers of Canadian cattle that livestock there is safe to eat; United States, Mexico, Japan and many other major importers of Canadian beef suspended purchases early last week after single cow slaughtered in Jan tested positive; nation's export-dependent cattle industry, representing $7 billion a year in sales, remains paralyzed (M)

headline: Europe Asks Compromise On Auditors
abstract: European Union warns of retaliation if US requires European audit firms to register with its new accounting oversight board; Frits Bolkestein, European commissioner in charge of market reform, says in letter to Securities and Exchange Commission chairman William H Donaldson that proposed rules will cause major problems for European audit firms; says US audit firms will be required to register with all 15 member nations of European Union if compromise cannot be reached and US does not narrow scope of new rules (M)

headline: It's a Feast. Now See if Wall Street Can Resist.
abstract: WHEN Wall Street's biggest brokerage firms coughed up $1.4 billion to settle regulators' accusations that they had misled investors with compromised research, this question was on everyone's lips: Would the firms truly change their practices?     A definitive answer seemed unknowable, at least until another bull market began. Testing brokerage firms' commitment to change would be impossible until the issuance of securities -- and their attendant fees -- boomed again.

headline: Two Executives Step Into a Void At Credit Suisse
abstract: John J Mack and Jeffrey M Peek, leading executives at Credit Suisse First Boston, were forced to assume new roles to help troubled bank survive even before arrest of Frank P Quattrone; Mack is co-chief executive of parent company Credit Suisse Group; Peek was brought on to expand firm's asset management business, but with recent sale of large part of his division, he is helping investment bankers find new business; photos (M)

headline: Of Good Fences and Good Nannies
abstract: Ellyn Spragins column on her difficulty viewing nannies and au pairs who cared for her children over years as employees while they performed most important job in household; notes member-of-the-family approach sometimes offers more comfort to employer than nanny; drawing (M)

headline: IPO.com Web Site Closes
abstract: IPO.com, Web site that tracked equity sales for six years, closes (S)

headline: In a Battle of the Bands, Musicians Are the Judges
abstract: Web site garageband.com offers more than 325,000 musicians opportunity to post their music and have it heard by new-music hunters and other musicians who review original songs in ongoing round-robin, giving comments and reactions; other similar sites have disappeared, leaving garageband as sole haven for amateur musicians in search of feedback; drawing; photo (L)

headline: AMERICANS ARREST WOULD-BE LEADER OF IRAQ'S CAPITAL
abstract: American forces arrest Baghdad's self-appointed mayor Muhammad Mohsen Zobeidi along with seven of his top aides after he defies warnings to stop acting as city's chief administrator; United States appears to be sending message that it will not tolerate challenges to its authority in Iraq, although Army is giving wide berth to more threatening figures, including Shiite clerics who have taken over administration of large swaths of Baghdad and other Iraqi cities; contradiction between cautious stance with clerics and Zobeidi's arrest highlights growing confusion over who is running Iraq in absence of strong, visible central authority; Jay Garner, retired general heading American interim adminsitration, has so far been all but invisible to Iraqi public; this has left field open for many to claim authority, including Ahmad Chalabi, who is head of Iraqi National Congress exile group and who initially supported Zobeidi's role in Baghdad; most notable among influences insinuating themselves in Iraq is that of Iran, ruled by clerics of same Shiite Muslim sect as majority of Iraqis; Iran's potential to shape Iraq is source of anxiety for Bush administration,which hopes to end up with pro-American government in Baghdad; photos (M)

headline: Spam: The Next Frontier In Booking Your Trip
abstract: Forrester Research travel analyst Henry H Harte

headline: Bush Condemns Saudi Blasts; 7 Americans Are Dead
abstract: At least 20 people, including seven Americans, are killed in synchronized truck bombings in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; Pres Bush vows to hunt down killers; nine additional bodies appear to be those of bombers; explosions blast apart buildings in three residential compounds populated by Westerners; photos; map; about 200 people are wounded, most not seriously; Crown Prince Abdullah, in address to Saudis, swears to confront murderers; US orders nonessential diplomatic employees home; FBI joins probe; Sec Colin Powell tours complex that has front of building blown off and ten-foot crater in front, and says attack has Al Qaeda fingerprints; Saudis last week raided Islamic militant cell but 19 suspects escaped (M)

headline: Fuel Economy Hit 22-Year Low in 2002
abstract: Environmental Protection Agency reports that average fuel efficiency of nation's cars and trucks fell to its lowest level in 22 years in 2002 model year; technological and engineering leaps of last two decades have been poured into everything but fuel economy; since 1981, average vehicle has 93 percent more horsepower and is 29 percent faster in going from 0 to 60 miles per hour; it is also 24 percent heavier, reflecting surging sales of sport utility vehicles; over same period, fuel economy has stagnated, contributing heavily to nation's rising oil consumption; cars and light trucks--SUV's, pickups and minivans--account for about 40 percent of nation's oil consumption and fifth of its carbon dioxide emissions; EPA report exasperates environmentalists, who are already frustrated by years of legislative defeats and recent retreat by Ford Motor Co on pledge that it would improve fuel economy of SUV's; in 2002 model year, fuel economy averaged 20.4 miles per gallon, lowest since fleet averaged 19.2 miles per gallon in 1980; fuel economy peaked at 22.1 miles a gallon in 1988 but has mostly fallen since; photos (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Greenspan Says Tax Cut Is Not Needed for Growth  Alan Greenspan suggested to Congress that a large tax cut like the one favored by President Bush was not necessary to generate growth and that the budget deficits resulting from lower taxes without offsetting reductions in spending could be damaging.    Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said with the end of the uncertainties associated with the war in Iraq, the economy was in a position for strong growth. But if that does not occur, he said, the Fed was prepared to lower rates further. [Page A32.]

headline: U.S. Declares Major Combat in Afghanistan to Be Over
abstract: United States declres that major combat operations are over in Afghanistan; hopes this will encourage more nations to join international reconstruction effort there; announcement is made by Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld and Afghan Pres Hamid Karzai at news conference in Kabul; photos; map (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Judge Considering Options for Philip Morris Bond
abstract: Illinois Judge Nicholas Byron says he will consider options that will not require Philip Morris USA to put up $12 billion bond while it appeals recent judgement he issued against it, saying he does not want to put company out of business; Byron awarded $12 billion in compensatory and punitive damages and lawyers' fees last month after he found company liable for failing to inform consumers that its 'light' cigarettes were not less harmful than full-tar cigarettes; Judge James Henry issues temporary restraining order that prevents Illinois from collecting $3 billion in punitive damages for 10 days; Illinois lawmakers are expected to introduce proposal that would limit appeal bond that company would have to put up to no more than 10 percent of judgment against it (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Focus Shifts to Northern Iraq, U.S. Says Baghdad 'Still an Ugly Place'
abstract: Several hundred Kurdish fighters under the command of 100 American special force fighters took control of the oil town.

headline: While Many Islamic Fighters Surrender, Kurds Remain Wary of New Terrorist Attacks
abstract: Scores upon scores of fighters with Ansar al-Islam, militant Islamic group expelled from its mountain stronghold in northeastern Iraq by American and Kurdish forces, return to Iraq after brief period of refuge in Iran, where they were disarmed, and are trying to negotiate surrender to Kurdistan Social Democratic Party; Kurdish officials worry that risk of Ansar activity continues because so many Ansar fighters are at large; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T To Sell Services From Former Division
abstract: AT&T will start selling package of services that includes mobile calling from AT&T Wireless Services (S)

headline: Crude Oil Prices Increase 4% On Surprising Fall in Inventories
abstract: Price of crude oil traded in New York has its biggest gain in six weeks after Energy Department report shows that inventories declined unexpectedly last week; graph (M)

headline: Personal Business; Testing the Deflation Zone
abstract: Concerns about deflation risk discussed; graphs and map of how prices are behaving differently across sectors and geographical areas in United States (S)

headline: Karzai Announces Pakistani Pledge to Stop Cross-Border Attacks
abstract: Taliban and other rebels have been launching attacks against Afghanistan from Pakistan in recent months.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Supreme Court Approves Maine's Prescription Plan  Maine's effort to cut prescription drug costs for uninsured state residents by pressuring manufacturers to grant price rebates received the Supreme Court's qualified approval.    The 6-to-3 decision lifted an injunction that has kept the Maine Rx Program from taking effect since the State Legislature enacted it in 2000. The court's action is likely to shift the drug pricing debate back to the executive branch and to the states. [Page A1.]

headline: 2 New Funds Will Track Nasdaq Composite Index
abstract: Fidelity Investments plans to start first exchange-traded fund that tracks Nasdaq composite stock index; fund will be its first exchange-traded fund of any type, traded and priced continuously like stocks; Fidelity also plans traditional mutual fund that will track index (M)

headline: SCHLUMBERGER TO SELL SEMICONDUCTOR-TESTING UNIT
abstract: Schlumberger Ltd sells its NPTest semiconductor-testing unit to group led by Francisco Partners and Shah Management for $220 million in cash (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Higher Rating For Telephone Concern
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp raises short- and long-term credit ratings of France Telecom after announcing plan to reduce its 68 billion euro ($78 billion) debt (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Gates Seeks Measures To Fight Spam
abstract: Microsoft Corp chairman Bill Gates calls on technology industry to develop strategy of self-regulation to deal with problem of unsolicited commercial e-mail; cites some measures Microsoft has taken against spam (S)

headline: Is There Life After Silicon Valley's Fast Lane?
abstract: Some computer industry experts warn that Moore's Law, 1965 observation by Intel co-founder Gordon E Moore that number of transistors on silicon chip would double about every 18 months, dictating pace of product obsolescene and innovation, may soon reach its theoretical limits, with dire consequences for technology industry's economic engine; influential cadre of heretics is arguing that seeing end to slavish demands of Moore's Law could be best thing to happen to culture of Silicon Valley and maybe even to future of technological innovation that is afected by that culture; eBay founder Michael S Malone, Po Bronson, author of book What Should I Do With My Life?, National Semiconductor chairman-chief executive Brian L Halla and Randy Komisar, longtime Silicon Valley executive and author of book The Monk and the Riddle: The Art of Creating a Life While Making a Living, comment; graph; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Acclaim's Chief Executive Resigns
abstract: Acclaim Entertainment co-founder Gregory E Fischbach resigns as chief executive and is succeeded by president and chief operating officer Rodney Cousens; remains co-chairman (S)

headline: HUMAN RIGHTS GROUP SUES OCCIDENTAL OVER '98 BOMBING
abstract: Occidental Petroleum is being sued by human rights group that contends company participated in 1998 bombing of Santo Domingo, Colombia, that killed 19 civilians; suit, in Federal District Court, Los Angeles, is filed under Alien Tort Claims Act, which allows corporations to be liable in US court for their conduct abroad; Occidental is accused of providing money and intelligence for Colombian Air Force's raid on village (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Plan For A Rights Body
abstract: Information Minister Safwat al-Sharif announces that Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak along with Justice and Interior Ministers plan to form National Council for Human Rights; disbanding of state security courts, which have been highly criticized for their alleged unfair treatment of individuals, is also being discussed (S)

headline: Virginia Law Makes Spam, With Fraud, A Felony
abstract: Virginia enacts law imposing harsh felony penalties for sending unsolicited commercial e-mail to computer users through deceptive means; law would be enforced against those who use fraudulent practices to send bulk e-mail, commonly known as spam, to or from Virginia; new statute adds criminal penalties for fraudulent, high-volume spammers; outlaws practices like forging return address line of e-mail message or hacking computer to send spam surreptitiously; those found guilty of sending more than 10,000 such deceptive e-mail messages in one day would be subject to prison term of one to five years and forfeiture of profits and assets connected with these activities; Virginia's Gov Mark R Warner says new law could have significant effect on spam because half of all Internet traffic flows through Viriginia; map; photo (M)

headline: Dominican Painter Helps To Unearth True Fakes
abstract: Alberto Ulloa, Dominican artist whose paintings are found in collections and museums in Europe and Americas, becomes first artist in his country's history to demand and secure criminal convictions for two people who trafficked in crude fakes that were sold for high prices; increasing popularity of Latin American art has spawned growing underground industry of forged copies of paintings sold to would-be collectors and unsuspecting tourists; Dominican authorities, fearful of trade penalties by US, have begun to protect intellectual property more aggressively, bringing almost 600 cases under ambitious law passed in 2000; photos (M)

headline: OfficeMax Makes Sudden Shop Change
abstract: OfficeMax Makes Sudden Shop Change.

headline: Near the Border With Iran, Memories of War Blend With Hope for Better Relations
abstract: Residents of Basra are tearing down larger-than-life metal sculptures of soldiers on border with Iran; initial hesitancy to touch statues and their ultimate destruction is emblematic of complicated and changing relationship between Iraqis in southern part of country and Iran (M)

headline: Earnings Reports Released Tuesday, April 22
abstract: Schwab Profit Drops Sharply, Trading Down

headline: AUTO AIR BAG MANUFACTURER TO CUT 3,500 JOBS BY 2005
abstract: Breed Technologies, maker of automotive air bags, will cut 3,500 jobs by end of 2004 in bid to restore profitability after being bought in April by Carlyle Group (S)

headline: In war's wake, hostility and mistrust
abstract: PARIS:—  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED Thursday, June 5, 2003:

headline: Most Israeli Settlers Oppose 'Road Map'
abstract: MASUOT OUTPOST, West Bank, May 25 — Uria Tal's hillside caravan, which serves both as his bedroom and as a blues bar stocked with an impressive range of whiskeys, offers both a link to Jewish history and a soothing view of a valley filled with pine trees.

headline: $1 Billion Offered to Settle Suit on I.P.O.'s
abstract: Some 300 companies that sold new shares to public during late 1990's agree to pay $1 billion to settle investor lawsuit contending that stock offerings' prices were artificially inflated; will pay nothing if investors also win settlement of at least $1 billion from brokerage firms that underwrote stock offerings and are also being sued; lawyers for investors have contended that firms sold shares to favored clients who agreed to purchase additional shares in open market, driving up prices; settlement provides guarantee that investors who bought initial public offerings from 1998 through 2000 will receive at least $1 billion, before legal fees; companies that issued shares are hoping investors' lawyers will prevail against 55 brokerage firms; any payment to investors will be delayed until securities lawsuits against brokerage firms are resolved (M)

headline: In Kuwait, Lost Items And a Blackened Museum Are Effects of Earlier War
abstract: Recent looting and burning of Iraqi cultural institutions have been painful reminders of Iraqis did to Kuwait National Museum in 1991; museum remains closed, its main galleries still black from fires set by retreating Iraqi forces; Sheika Hussah Sabah al-Salim al-Sabah and her husband have art collection that they hope can return to a Kuwait museum; photo (M)

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: 'Just Shoot Me'
abstract: Aweek into the air war in Iraq, as the upper decks of the carrier Abraham Lincoln bustled in preparation for a heavy night of strike fighter missions, a petty officer, Naveed Muhammad, quietly took off his shoes and laid out a green prayer rug on the floor of the ship's chapel.

headline: The Boeing State Fights to Build the Next Jet
abstract: Puget Sound area and state of Washington are facing one of their worst nightmares--possibility that Boeing Co, its biggest employer, will move final assembly of its next wide-body jet, 7E7, to another state; government officials and business leaders in Washington are scrambling to put together proposal loaded with financial incentives; state legislators say they will try to work out favorable tax code revisions and tax relief before session adjourns June 10; workers have begun staging rallies next to Boeing plant in Everett; Gov Gary Locke's office says keeping Boeing's future production in Washington is state's top priority; critics say Boeing's threat is form of corporate blackmail, blatant attempt to spur pork-barrel legislation; photo (M)

headline: Bank Official Says Hussein's Son Took $1 Billion in Cash
abstract: American and Iraqi officials say Pres Saddam Hussein's son Qusay and close adviser carried off nearly $1 billion in cash from Iraq's Central Bank in hours before American bombs began falling on Baghdad; say removal of money was performed under direct orders of Saddam Hussein; unidentified Iraqi official with knowledge of incident says no financial rationale was offered for removing money from bank's vaults, and no one was told where money would be taken; says it was $900 million in American $100 bills and $100 million worth of euros, and that sheer volume of cash was so great that three tractor-trailers were needed to cart it off; seizure of money is confirmed by United States Treasury official; seizure of cash provides glimpse into final days of Hussein's rule and perhaps clue about how he intended to finance his escape and survive out of power; Iraqi officials say money removed amounted to quarter of Central Bank's hard currency reserves; say they are uncertain of effect it will have on Iraqi economy; photo (M)

headline: A New Doctrine's Test
abstract: Military Analysis: critics say Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld's principles of military engagement have been applied and found wanting in Iraq; skeptics, including some leading former Army commanders from last war with Iraq, say force United States has deployed is not large enough to begin decisive battle in Baghdad while simultaneously guarding ever-lengthening supply lines and establishing control throughout Iraq; paradigm being pushed by Rumsfeld is one that touts striking force of American air power and agility of special forces, but sees less of role for Army's heavy armored divisions; final assessment of strategy will have to await battle for Baghdad; Rumsfeld's defenders say he is determined to stimulate change and challenge long-entrenched patterns of military thinking, even at risk of offending retired and active duty generals; everyone agrees that American force fighting in Iraq is fundamentally different from one used during Persian Gulf war, when doctrine applied was one of overwhelming force and when Pentagon sent Gen H Norman Schwarzkopf forces he did not even request; premium was placed on holding risks to absolute minimum; two campaigns compared and contrasted; chart (L)

headline: Oil Companies Reap Rewards Of Higher Prices for Crude
