abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell and ChevronTexaco say their first-quarter earnings more than doubled, capping series of strong results for oil industry as price of crude oil rose; Shell says net income jumped to $5.3 billion from $2.26 billion a year ago; ChevronTexaco profit rises to $1.92 billion from $725 million (S)

headline: JOHNSON CONTROLS TO BUY GERMAN ELECTRONICS COMPANY
abstract: Johnson Controls Inc, maker of automotive interiors, will buy German automotive-components maker Borg Instruments (S)

headline: US Airways Makes Cuts And Leaves Bankruptcy
abstract: US Airways emerges from bankruptcy protection with federally backed $1 billion loan and new $240 million equity investment; labor agreements make up $1 billion of $1.9 billion in annual cost savings and are good until Dec 31, 2008; nonmanagement employees, in exchange for concessions, will get 31.2 perent stake and four board seats; Air Transportation Board will get 10 percent stake (M)

headline: Market Place; Did Fed Let Expectations Get Out of Hand?
abstract: Market Place column suggests that Federal Reserve let expectations of interest rate cut get out of hand; says many people concluded that cut was going to bigger than quarter-point reduction, and result was falling stock and bond prices; graphs; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Bank Merger Advances
abstract: Malaysia's EON Bank and AMMB Holdings begin talks on potential merger after winning approval of central bank (S)

headline: The Undermining of the House of Stewart
abstract: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia announces that Stewart expects to be indicted on charges that she disposed of her shares of ImClone Systems stock based on non-public 'insider' information; sales of company's wares have fared well during controversy about her stock-trading ethics; fortunes of her media properties are floundering; Martha Stewart Living magazineadvertising revenues are down, while imitators copy its graphic design and her lifestyle fantasies in new publications; Stewart's company's share price has lost half its value since revelation about her trading in ImClone stock; photos; share price graph (M)

headline: Mad Cow Case Raises Worries in United States
abstract: Discovery of case of mad cow disease in Canadian cow raises anxiety in US food industry, which buys about three-fourths of Canada's beef exports; shares of fast-food companies fall as chains like McDonald's and Burger King reassure public about safety of their meat (S)

headline: Canada Parts With U.S. on Drugs
abstract: So-called injection site in Vancouver, British Columbia, offers drug users place to shoot heroin and cocaine into their veins under supervision of registered nurse who dispenses fresh needles, swabs, sterile water and advice on how to maintain veins; operation is technically illegal but it is condoned by new mayor, Larry W Campbell, who was elected by landslide on platform of more treatment for addicts, more thorough law enforcement and regulated injection sites; there are similar facilities in Australia, Germany, Switzerland and Netherlands; this is only one to operate openly in North America; its presence is lateset sign that Canada's drug policies are moving in direction that diverges sharply from those in United States--to treat addiction more as medical issue and less as one of law enforcement; photo (M)

headline: Bush Sees Limited Role for U.N. in Postwar Iraq
abstract: President Bush described the U.N.'s role as largely humanitarian and advisory rather than one central to overseeing postwar Iraq.

headline: A Media Campaign Is Intended to Speed End of War
abstract: Pres George Bush and Prime Min Tony Blair use newly seized Iraqi state television facilities to send message to Iraqi people promising to help build 'government that protects the rights of all citizens'; message is opening salvo in Pentagon-devised media campaign intended to shape messages sent to Iraqi people and speed end of war; it is unclear how many people received broadcast because of widespread power failures; both governments also intend to publish newspapers; details of other information dissemination campaigns noted, including broadcast of American nightly news programs; photos (M)

headline: Israelis Kill a Hamas Leader
abstract: Israeli forces killed a leader of Hamas a day after Secretary of State Colin L. Powell tried to conclude a cease-fire agreement with Israeli and Palestinian leaders. Page 4.

headline: New Economy; Businesses are starting to toy with the wiki, an off-beat technology for fostering Web interaction.
abstract: Businesses are starting to experiment with 'wiki,' offbeat software technology that makes it simple for anyone to publish on Internet; wiki lets anyone in group of collaborating authors edit, modify or even delete material on pages; future of wiki in business world is uncertain; illustration of wiki page (M)

headline: Cases Thought to Be Relapses Now Seen as Other Conditions
abstract: Health officials in Hong Kong say dozen former SARS patients there who were initially thought to have suffered relapses actually had other medical problems; initial report caused international alarm; rate of new SARS cases being reported around world slows somewhat; several governments announce lower daily totals for new cases; Beijing reports 69 new cases, down from 114 day earlier and lowest daily total in last two weeks; Taiwan, which has been posting 8 or 10 new cases a day, has only 2 new cases on May 3 but 14 more on May 4; photo (M)

headline: Costa Rica Intervenes at Troubled U.S.-Owned Academy
abstract: Costa Rican authorities move to seize American-owned behavior-modification academy for children after hearing allegations of physical and emotional abuse; Academy at Dundee Ranch has 200 children, ages 11 to 17, almost all of them Americans, living under strict regimen; parents and program officials say 30 to 50 children fled on foot or into custody of Costa Rican officials after being told they could not be held at academy against their will; Costa Rican authorities claim academy's punishments include physical and emotional abuse, isolation and physical restraints; say it lacks trained personnel; academy is one of four foreign-based programs under banner of World Wide Assn of Specialty Programs and Schools; its highly profitable programs, aimed at troubled teenagers, face licensing and legal challenges in US and abroad; map (M)

headline: Shares of Corporate Nice Guys Can Finish First
abstract: STUPEFYING, is it not, how selfish behavior in the executive suite continues even as managers claim to care deeply about corporate governance issues? The ham-handed attempt by Donald J. Carty, the just-defenestrated chief of the AMR Corporation, to hide special executive pay perks while he cut workers' pay is only the latest indication that some powerful people still think the do-as-I-say, not-as-I-do approach is acceptable.    It is puzzling that these people cannot or will not see that doing right by shareholders, employees and customers is good business. Part of the problem may be that the payoff from tending to corporate governance issues is nowhere near as immediate as the payback from self-serving moves.

headline: Leighton Rees, 63, of Wales, Who Threw Darts, Deftly
abstract: Leighton Rees, world's first professional dart-throwing champion, dies at age 63; photo (M)

headline: Yahoo Plans Improvements in Effort to Regain Lost Ground
abstract: Yahoo introduces series of improvements to its World Wide Web search service in attempt to reclaim premier search engine position usurped by Google in 2002 (M)

headline: S.E.C. Says Ex-Gemstar Officials Used Deception to Inflate Revenue
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission sues Henry C Yuen, contending that he engaged in widespread scheme to inflate revenue of Gemstar-TV Guide International, company he founded and ran; accuses Gemstar's former chief financial officer Elsie M Leung of participating in same scheme; suit seeks monetary penalties and return of gains from suspected fraud; also seeks to permanently ban Yuen and Leung from serving as officers in public company; lawyer for Yuen and Leung says they acted properly and openly; SEC says Yuen and Leung deceived auditors KPMG; photo (M)

headline: Basra's Defenders Are Said to Be Desperate and Fearful
abstract: Sheik Muhammad al-Bouslimi, Shiite cleric, brings message to British-held border post from besieged city of Basra; says Baath party officials there are desperate and ready to surrender but fear mob violence; says they have no support among Iraqi people; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Discloses Development With Nanotubes
abstract: IBM says it has generated electrically controlled infrared light from carbon nanotubes; says output from single-molecule devices suggest that such nanotubes could become important materials in optical communications, sensing and other light-based applications; chip researchers have focused on nanotubes as potential replacements for silicon transistors in semiconductors as microchips shrink and, in other forms, as molecular-sized wiring (S)

headline: Taubman Centers Reports a Quarterly Loss
abstract: Taubman Centers Inc, real estate investment trust, posts first-quarter net loss of $2.98 million, compared with $1.87 million net income in 2002 period (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Regulators Seek E.D.S. Papers On Navy Deal
abstract: Electronic Data Systems Corp says Securities and Exchange Commission has requested documents about $6.9 billion Navy contract after company reports $334 million pretax loss on seven-year contract to build computer network linking Navy and Marine Corps at more than 300 bases in US and Caribbean (S)

headline: Former Bosnian Serb Officer Admits Guilt in '95 Massacre
abstract: Momir Nikolic, former Bosnian Serb army commander, agrees to plead guilty to crimes against humanity in 1995 Srebrenica massacre of over 7,000 Muslim men and boys; agrees to testify against other Bosnian Serb commanders charged with roles in massacre, Vidoje Blagojevic, Dragan Obrenovic and Dragan Jokic, at war crimes tribunal in Hague; other charges against him will be dropped (M)

headline: Proposals on Generic Drugs
abstract: President Bush plans to announce measures today to speed the availability of generic drugs. A Senate panel passed a similar bill. Page C1.

headline: Monster Escapes Monitor; 3-D Glasses Under Suspicion
abstract: X3D Technologies introduces glasses that add depth to flat video games and movies, using timed electronic shutters that send slightly different image to each eye giving 3-dimensional effect; photo (M)

headline: Grundig, the Radio Maker, Is Insolvent
abstract: Grundig, the Radio Maker,

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Chicago Economist Wins Prize for Studies on Crime  Steven D. Levitt, a professor at the University of Chicago, was awarded the John Bates Clark medal by the American Economic Association. The prize, given every two years, recognizes him as the leading economist under age 40.    Professor Levitt has studied the economics of crime and urban areas for most of his career. His methods for isolating cause-and-effect relationships have also won wide admiration in his field. [Page C5.]

headline: $6.5 Million Being Invested In a Venture On Solar Cells
abstract: NanoSolar that is working to develop and produce cheaper solar cells will announce it has raised $6.5 million from Benchmark Capital and US Venture Partners; investment is one of latest signs that alternative energy companies are attracting serious financial interest in high-technology circles (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Hostage Freed
abstract: Philippine troops rescue last remaining hostage out of three Indonesian seamen orginally kidnapped last June by Abu Sayyaf Muslim group; one hostage had escaped and one died while being held on Jolo, group's home island; terrorists still hold five Filipino women (S)

headline: France Clamps Down on Shipping Pollution
abstract: France creates new maritime ecological zone in Mediterranean, reaching up to 90 miles from its coast, to clamp down on pollution from shipping; France is alarmed by series of oil tanker disasters; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Says Quarterly Loss Narrows
abstract: Palm Inc says net loss narrowed to $15 million in its fourth quarter ended May 31 from $27.5 million year ago; sales fell 3.2 percent, to $225.8 million from $233.3 million; chief executive Eric Benhamou comments (S)

headline: . . . And Cause More Stress
abstract: Parson Consulting survey of 100 senior finance executives finds that complying with accounting and securities regulations of Sarbanes-Oxley law is costing them time, money and peace of mind (S)

headline: For the Press, a Case That Is an Irresistible Draw
abstract: Heavy media coverage of Martha Stewart's indictment in Imclone stock trading case is expected to further harm Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia (M)

headline: FAO REACHES DEAL WITH INVESTORS; STORES TO STAY OPEN
abstract: FAO Reaches Deal With Investors; Stores To Stay Op

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: Syria's Foreign Minister Calls U.S. Charges 'Baseless'
abstract: Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa said that the U.S. seemed to be trying to start another conflict even before stabilizing either Iraq or Afghanistan.

headline: P&O PRINCESS CRUISES APPROVES ACQUISITION BY CARNIVAL
abstract: P&O Princess Cruises says shareholders approved Carnival Corp's $7.8 billion purchase of company (S)2

headline: Canada Fills U.S. Prescriptions Under the Counter
abstract: Discount RX Connection, tiny storefront operation in Boca Raton, is one of many such stores around US that, for small commissions, arrange orders and deliveries of prescription drugs from Canada, saving US customers thousands of dollars; photo; drug companies start limiting shipments to Canadian suppliers; health regulators begin crackdowns now that discount buying has moved from Web sites to retail outlets (M)

headline: Delay Seen in U.S.-Philippine Joint Mission
abstract: In a setback to the campaign against terrorism in the Philippines, the commander of American forces in the Pacific said today that a joint mission with Philippine troops to combat Muslim rebels will likely be postponed for six months.    Military officials said the delay was needed to allow the United States to train several hundred additional Philippine troops in counterterrorism, and to buy time to break a months-long impasse over rules for the operation that would conform with the Philippine Constitution.

headline: African Mission to Investigate Tensions in Zimbabwe
abstract: Southern African Development Community forms task force to probe intensifying political tensions that threaten to push Zimbabwe toward further unrest and economic ruin; at issue is dispute between Pres Robert Mugabe and political opponents who charge his authoritarian rule has undermined democracy and devastated economy; Zimbabweans fleeing hunger and unemployment are becoming drain on South Africa; Western governments are pressing South African Pres Thabo Mbeki to take stronger stand against Mugabe's human-rights violations (M)

headline: Fraud and Fear Mar Election in Nigeria, Monitors Say
abstract: Even as they commended the patience and fortitude of Nigerian voters, two groups of election observers from the United States expressed concern today about fraud and intimidation in some parts of the country on Election Day, and called on the government to improve confidence in the democratic process.    President Olusegun Obasanjo seemed on his way to victory, with roughly 60 percent of states reporting results to the Independent National Electoral Commission headquarters here in the capital. Mr. Obasanjo, a southerner from the Yoruba ethnic group, had about 62 percent of the vote.

headline: Banker Cleared, Easing Way to Head European Bank
abstract: Bank of France governor Jean-Claude Trichet is acquitted by Paris court of charges he helped French bank Credit Lyonnais manipulate its accounts before it collapsed in early 1990's, when he was director of French treasury; verdict clears way for Trichet to become next president of European Central Bank; French Finance Ministry says France will reaffirm Trichet's candidacy at meeting of European government leaders in Salonika, Greece, that is scheduled to begin June 26; photo (M)

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: For 7 Families, Relief After Weeks of Waiting
abstract: Seven families across the nation wept, laughed and celebrated at word that their children and spouses had been released.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Online Schools Drain Funds.

headline: A conservative forecaster shows a bit more optimism on ad spending for this year and next.
abstract: ZenithOptimedia increases its estimate for 2003 and 2004 United States advertising spending; several major advertisers describe plans to augment their ad budgets in coming months (M)

headline: Jerusalem Suicide Bomber Kills 6 and Wounds More Than a Dozen
abstract: A suicide bomber attacked a city bus just hours after Israeli and Palestinian leaders held their highest-level talks in more than two years.

headline: Ads That Registered
abstract: Intermedia Advertising Group compiles list of ten most-remembered advertisements that ran during May's television season program finales; photo; list of ads (S)

headline: U.S. to Back Heart Device In More Cases
abstract: Federal Government will expand number of Medicare patients permitted to receive defibrillators, device implanted in chest and designed to protect against fatal heart rhythms; 45,000 Mediare patients currently receive devices each year, and under latest decision 10,000 more will be added; defibrillators cost $25,000 each, and operation along with follow-up care can come to $40,000 per patient; total cost to Medicare is expected to increase by as much as $400 million over current level of $1 billion (M)

headline: '85 Hijacker Is Captured In Baghdad
abstract: American Special Forces in Baghdad capture Abu Abbas, leader of Palestinian terrorist group responsible for 1985 attack on Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro; Abbas led faction of Palestine Liberation Front in 1980's and 1990's and has been living unhindered in Baghdad since leaving his home in Gaza Strip in 2000; is first major terrorist figure found in Iraq by US forces since fall of Saddam Hussein's government; American officials say they have not made connection between his Palestinian group and Al Qaeda and have no evidence to tie him to terrorist acts in recent years; Abbas faces life sentence in Italy in connection with Achille Lauro hijacking and death of Leon Klinghoffer, American passenger who was pushed overboard in his wheelchair; Abbas's organization later began series of attacks against Israeli targets, but he subsequently renounced terrorism and was given amnesty by Israel in 1996 following Oslo accords; prior to US war in Iraq, Abbas publicly denounced Sept 11 attacks and Osama bin Laden, and asserted that Palestinian cause was completely separate from fanatical terrorism of Al Qaeda; in separate intelligence-related development, Central Intelligence Agency officials say their analysts believe that Saddam Hussein's government collapsed so rapidly because top aides were convinced that he was dead; Abbas photo (M)

headline: Report of Profit by AT&T Sends Stock Soaring 23%
abstract: Investors send AT&T shares up 23 percent after company reports first-quarter profit and says it will meet or exceed its earlier projections for year; says net income was $571 million compared with loss of $975 million year earlier; earnings from continuing operations rose to $529 million from $446 million year ago; sales fell 5.9 percent, to $9 billion, from $9.5 billion year earlier; revenue from business customers was $6.4 billion, down 1.4 percent from year ago, while consumer sales, including residential long-distance service, were $2.5 billion, down 17.8 percent; chief financial officer Thomas W Horton comments (M)

headline: Lost in the Shuffle, a Sign of Strength for Social Security
abstract: Trustees of Social Security issued annual report on March 17 showing that projected point at which tax revenues will fall below expenses, forcing system to dip into its trust fund to pay benefits, is moved to 2018 from 2017; report also finds that point at which trust fund will be exhausted is put at 2042, instead of 2041, as cited in last year's report (M)

headline: In Grip of AIDS, South African Cries for Equity
abstract: Profile of Abdurrazack Achmat, ethnic Malayan South African AIDS activist who has disease but refuses to take antiretroviral drugs until government makes them available to all; photo; five million people are believed infected in South Africa; Achmat, diagnosed in 1990, founded national coalition to fight discrimination (M)

headline: Warning of Doom, Edgy Iraqi Leaders Put On Brave Front
abstract: Iraqi leadership puts on show of redoubled defiance and promises American troops 'death in the desert,' even as American forces advance toward Baghdad and Saddam Hussein's presidential compound once again comes under remorseless aerial attack; Iraqi government ministers, holding news conference at Palestine Hotel, affect not to notice sharp booms of bombs striking nearby and shaking hotel building; their demeanor is more strudent, more polemical, more pugnacious and more edgy than in past; there is virtually no reference to Saddam Hussein, although ministers stand beside large, flatteringly youthful portrait of him; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: MRO Shares Drop On News Of License Sales
abstract: Technolog4

headline: Back From Iraq, High-Tech Fighter Pilots Recount Exploits
abstract: Lt Col David Toomey and seven other F-117 pilots from Eighth Fighter Squadron recount new details of Mar 19 attack against Saddam Hussein's bunker on first night of Iraq war, and their other missions, days after they return to home base at Holloman Air Force Base in NM; say that in Iraq war, stealth fighters adapted new tactics to hit fiercely defended targets on short notice; Air Force introduced new 'bunker buster' bombs; about one-third of their missions came in first three days, when allied commanders sought to destroy Iraq's remaining air defenses; photo; chart (L)

headline: Inquiry Into Currency Trading Ends
abstract: Justice Dept drops three-year investigation of foreign exchange trading practices of FXall, electronic currency trading system whose investors include Bank of America and Goldman Sachs Group (S)

headline: An Opulent and Pugnacious Champion of India's Outcasts
abstract: Mayawati, chief minister of Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, has become chief champion of people on bottom of Hinduism's caste hierarchy, once known as untouchables and now as Dalit, or downtrodden; her oppulent lifestyle as been seized on by critics, but seems less to offend her supporters than to affirm new political power she has helped them achieve; she denounces upper castes, but has three times formed coalition with largely upper caste Bharatiya Janata Party to become chief minister; photo; map (M)

headline: WELLS FARGO TO BUY PACIFIC NORTHWEST BANCORP
abstract: Wells Fargo & Co agrees to buy Pacific Northwest Bancorp for about $623 million in stock to expand in Washington and Oregon (S)

headline: TECUMSEH TO MOVE PRODUCTION OUT OF U.S.
abstract: Tecumseh Products Co, leading maker of engines for lawn mowers, will close its plant in Douglas, Ga, and lay off 550 employees as it moves production to plants in India, Brazil and Czech Republic; job cuts, to begin June 6, represent 2.4 percent of company's global work force (S)

headline: France Tries to Limit Ship Pollution in Mediterranean
abstract: France has created a maritime ecological zone in the Mediterranean reaching up to 90 miles from its coast.

headline: NAVISTAR SAYS IT WILL RAISE OUTPUT BY 17% AT OHIO PLANT
abstract: Navistar International Corp plans to increase Springfield, Ohio, factory's daily production of medium-duty trucks and school buses 17 percent starting in July; plant will begin building 167 of trucks and buses on July 21, up from 143 (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.75       Discount rate   2.25   2.25   N.A.       Federal funds   1.25   1.27   1.71       3-month T-bills   1.08   1.09   1.73       6-month T-bills   1.08   1.13   1.85       10-yr. T-infl.   2.10   2.06   3.06       10-yr. T-note   3.78   3.89   5.17       30-yr. T-bond   4.75   4.80   5.67       Telephone bd.   5.62   5.75   7.73       Municipal bds.   4.83   4.84   5.33          (Sources: Citigroup; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Palestinian Premier Faces Competing Demands Over Cabinet
abstract: New Palestinian Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas tries to form government in face of competing demands; reportedly wants to bring in technocrats and root out endemic corruption, but major shake-up would oust longtime loyalists of Yasir Arafat, who wants only minor adjustments to cabinet he formed less than year ago; Abbas photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Prilosec to Be Available Without a Prescription  The Food and Drug Administration approved over-the-counter sales of Prilosec, the ulcer and heartburn pill that not long ago was the top-selling prescription medicine in the world. The decision benefits those who pay for the drug -- health insurers and people with no insurance -- and could roil the pharmaceutical industry.    Prilosec is expected to sell for less than $1 a pill when it becomes available without a prescription this fall, compared with $4 a pill now. But health care executives said that few consumers who have health insurance would see any savings. [Page A1.]

headline: Bids Due for British Department Stores
abstract: Selfridges & Co, nearly 100-year-old London department store, may soon be at center of bidding war; Selfridges' shares rise to 52-week high as investors expect bids from Scottish retailing enterpreneur Tom Hunter and from Selfridges management and others; Selfridges' banker Merrill Lynch sets May 6 as deadline to submit bids; consortium formed by Goldman Sachs is also reported to be submitting bid; company as whole had $718 million in sales last year; photo (M)

headline: Money for Start-Ups: Tight, Getting Tighter
abstract: Technology entrepreneurs describe huge difficulties finding venture capital money even for most promising ideas; photo (special section, Small Business) (M)

headline: Music Lasts Longer on a Hybrid Player
abstract: Sony offers new line of Net MD Walkman music players that link to PC to copy files from computer's MP3 library and compress five hours of music into single 80-minute disc; can also handle WAV files; photo (M)

headline: Lender to Poor Credit Risks Expects Loss for This Quarter
abstract: American Business Financial Services says it will report loss of more than $4.2 million for quarter ending June 30 (S)

headline: Foreign Fighters, Not Taliban, Are the Danger, Karzai Says
abstract: Pres Hamid Karzai says there is no Taliban resurgence in Afghanistan, but that threats remain from foreign terrorists; blames them for recent attack on bus full of German peacekeepers; Interior Min Ali Ahmad Jalali blames Pakistan for its part in continuing security problem in south and southeast of Afghanistan, saying Taliban forces that attacked Afghan forces are using Pakistan as refuge; Karzai says Afghan forces together with international security force and American-led coalition task force are taking measures against terrorist threat (M)

headline: Antiwar Cause Offers Utne a Second Act
abstract: Utne magazine chief executive Nina Rothschild Utne capitalizes on Code Pink protests against Iraq war and her own arrest at protest to provide marketing opportunity for magazine and its liberal political message; group's buttons and bumper stickers list magazine's Web site; struggling magazine's embrace of movement is emblematic of its quest to find new readers; photos (M)

headline: Istanbul Journal; Europe's on Notice: Don't Mess With Our Lunch
abstract: Turks rally round kokorec, traditional sandwich of toasted bread and fried lamb intestine, as country's push to enter European Union brings it closer to EU's restrictions on sale of animal organs, part of its response to outbreak of mad cow disease; photo (M)

headline: Bush Says It Will Take Time to Find Iraq's Banned Arms
abstract: Pres Bush says weapons of mass destruction will be found in Iraq but it will take time because Saddam Hussein spent so many years hiding his stockpile; remarks reflect growing concern in administration that opponents of war will claim that US exaggerated evidence against Iraq in order to justify attack that was intended to depose Hussein; Bush's senior aides have begun backing away from prewar claims that Hussein had arsenal that was loaded and ready to fire, saying that instead he developed 'just in time' production strategy for his weapons, hiding chemical precursors that could be quickly loaded into empty artillery shells or short-range missiles; no evidence has been found that he did so; photo of Bush in Crawford, Tex, with Prime Min John Howard of Australia (M)

headline: Heady Days for Kuwait Stock Exchange
abstract: Kuwait's stock market is soaring; main index has shot up by 26 percent since start of hositilities in Iraq, and has nearly doubled since October; Kuwaitis have poured as much as 12 billion Kuwaiti dinars ($40 billion) in savings into Kuwait Stock Exchange, whose total market capitalization is about $100 billion; graph; photo (M)

headline: Israeli Soldiers Kill 5 Palestinians, Including a Journalist
abstract: Israeli raid directed at Palestinian militants in southern Gaza Strip ends with at least 5 Palestinians killed, including 15-year-old boy, and more than 35 injured in heavy exchanges of fire; Palestinian cameraman is shot dead by Israeli soldiers while filming violence in West Bank city of Nablus; Yasir Arafat remains at odds with his handpicked prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, over formation of new government; photo; map (M)

headline: Fears in Turkey That Its Cyprus Problem Is Alienating Europe
abstract: Many Turkish leaders are frustrated over divided status of Cyprus and over degree to which it may hamper Turkey's bid to join European Union; Pres Ahmet Necdet Sezer has lashed out at European Union officials for repeatedly suggesting that Turkey would never get into union until negotiations to reunite Turkish and Greek sectors of Cyprus succeed (M)

headline: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; GERMANY: SEPT. 11 INDICTMENT
abstract: German prosecutors indict Abdelghani Mzoudi, Moroccan Al Qaeda suspect, on 3,066 counts of accessory to murder in connection with Sept 11 attacks, for allegedly providing logistical support to hijackers (S)

headline: 2 WPP Divisions to Merge
abstract: 2 Media Divisions Of WPP Will Merge.

headline: Documents Show Urgent Iraqi Push to Recruit and Control Troops
abstract: Documents found in Baath Party bureau in Zubayr show effort during summer of 2002 to mobilize cadres across country; efforts included emptying prisons in attempt to spark loyalty and recruit troops; party collected declarations from Iraqis professing willingness to make suicide attacks; documents represent important record of Baath Party culture and tactics it used to galvanize and control its security forces; what is impossible to convey in documents, however, is fear that existed between party leaders and soldiers whose lives, and lives of their families, depended on absolute obedience; documents illustrate patterns of coercion and redundancy showing conformity and discipline (M)

headline: American Dies in a Land Whose Faith Called Him
abstract: One of eight Americans killed in bombing of compounds for foreigners in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, is Obadiah Y Abdullah, United States Army veteran who was working for Defense Dept contractor in Saudi Arabia and, as convert to Islam, was thrilled to be there (M)

headline: PENN NATIONAL OFFERS MIXED OUTLOOK ON EARNINGS
abstract: Penn National Gaming Inc raises its second-quarter profit estimate, but lowers its outlook for year; Penn National is laying off workers and trimming marketing in Illinois after state approved casino tax increase starting in July (S)

headline: The War Goes Well. So Where's the Dividend?
abstract: Business executives and economists say that while progress of troops in Iraq is unquestionably good news for economy, it remains to be seen whether military success will prove to have been turning point; still unclear is whether consumer confidence and business investment will not only revive from their war-jitter depths but also begin more sustained recovery; General Motors Corp chief executive Rick Wagoner says Bush administration's recovery plan increases chance economy can get back on more rapid growth pace; photo (M)

headline: Word That U.S. Doubted Iraq Would Use Deadly Gas
abstract: American intelligence analysts reported to Bush administration last year that Saddam Hussein was deploying chemical weapons but would almost certainly not use them unless regime's survival was at stake; wide-ranging report by Defense Intelligence Agency last November found it unlikely that Iraq would use unconventional weapons as long as there were UN sanctions because use would confirm Iraq's evasion of restrictions; other findings quoted (M)

headline: Journalists Tell of a Prison Filled With Screams
abstract: Four Western journalists released from Iraqi custody speak publicly for first time about their incarceration in prison near Baghdad; say they were not harmed by their captors, but other prisoners were beaten in front of them and they often heard screams (S)

headline: Can Meetings Restore Trust?
abstract: Large corporations continue to treat annual shareholder meetings as necessary evil, not chance to ease high level of distrust fostered by recent scandals; current meeting season may be most contentious in recent years, with shareholder proposals to limit executive pay getting more support; rising tide of resentment has widened gulf in how investors and corporate officials view events; more companies reportedly are leaving out independent directors when shareholders meet, eliminating only opportunity for investors to question their supposed representatives; graphs of shareholder resolutions and director attendance at annual meetings; map of meetings held far from corporate headquarters; photos (M)

headline: 6 Iraqi Officials Offer To Surrender to U.S.
abstract: Lt Gen Tahaseen Rafan and five midlevel Iraqi military and intelligence officials arrive at makeshift United States military base in Mosul to negotiate their surrender and seek protection from revenge attacks; none are on list of 55 senior Iraqi officials wanted on war crimes charges, but group hints that their surrender is being closely watched by more senior officials now in hiding; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: CANADA: Washington To Hear Marijuana Plan; HONDURAS: Guards Killed Most Prison Rioters;.

headline: Accounts and People of Note
abstract: Accounts • Gold's Gym International, Venice, Calif., the chain of 650 gyms in 34 countries, to Henderson Advertising, Greenville, S.C., as the agency of record for the company and its franchisees. The assignment, with billings that were estimated at $15 million to $18 million, had been previously handled internally and on a project basis. Miscellany • Issuers of credit cards sent 4.89 billion solicitations to consumers through direct mail in 2002, down 2.4 percent from a record of 5.01 billion solicitations in 2001, according to research by the financial services practice of the Tarrytown, N.Y., office of Synovate. The decline in mailings was attributed to the uncertain national economy and world situation.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Landfill Company To Be Acquired; BRITAIN: Advertising Unit Sold;.

headline: Patents; A series of inventions to help soothe the cries of a baby, and perhaps even the cries of the parents, too.
abstract: Devices recently patented to serve needs of infants and their parents described; drawing (M)

headline: Bush Takes No-Budge Stand In Talks With North Korea
abstract: Pres Bush instructs team that will negotiate with North Korea that United States will not settle for another freeze on country's nuclear program, but will insist that North dismantle both of its major nuclear weapons projects as part of any larger bargain with US: tells Secretary of State Colin L Powell that he is not ready to discuss any kind of treaties with North Korea--something that country has demanded--until nuclear threat is dismantled; it was China's intervention that created compromise leading to trilateral meeting; photo (M)

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: Criticism Mounts in Ontario Over High Rate of SARS Cases
abstract: The second-guessing is now blooming faster than the disease and it is beginning to jeopardize business confidence and become a rancorous political issue.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Grabbing for a Patch of Moral High Ground
abstract: Morgan Stanley chief executive Philip J Purcell says he does not see anything in industrywide settlement to concern his firm's retail investors; contradicts regulators' findings that Morgan failed to disclose to investors that it paid $2.7 million to other Wall Street firms to publish research on companies whose shares Morgan Stanley had underwritten; Purcell's comments come as surprise to New York State Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer, whose office investigated Morgan; says allegations set forth in Morgan Stanley document establish record that should deeply retail investors because document reflects that supposedly neutral analytical work was indeed subservient to investment banking needs of company; Morgan Stanley spokesman Ray O'Rourke comments on Purcell's apparent discrepancy; Morgan is proud that its top analyst Mary Meeker, who still covers Internet companies, was not singled out by regulators in settlement as were some other analysts at other firms; photos (Market Place column) (M)

headline: BUSH SHIFTS FOCUS TO NUCLEAR SALES BY NORTH KOREA
abstract: Pres Bush seeks to marshal international support for preventing North Korea from exporting plutonium for nuclear weapons, in tacit acknowledgment that North may not be deterred from producing such material; this is shift in decade-long United States policy that North Korea would be prevented, by any means necessary, from producing plutonium or highly enriched uranium; in 1994, Pres Clinton ordered Pentagon to draw up plans for military strike when North threatened to begin production, but nuclear freeze agreement was reached; Bush's new focus on blocking sale of nuclear material reflects intelligence officials' conclusion that they cannot ascertain whether North Korea is bluffing when it claimed last month that it has already reprocessed enough spent nuclear fuel to make many weapons; Secretary of State Colin L Powell insists that administration's long-term goal is to force North Korea to dismantle all its nuclear weapons programs; vows that it will get no international aid unless its government changes course; Bush's new approach is seen as major gamble that will depend on superb intelligence about North Korea's efforts to sell its weapons (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Guidant Unit Pleads Guilty To Hiding Device's Flaws  A division of Guidant pleaded guilty to 10 felonies, admitting that it lied to the government and hid serious health problems, including 12 deaths, caused by one of its products.     The company agreed to pay $92.4 million in criminal and civil penalties, the largest ever imposed against a maker of medical devices for failing to report the problems. [Page A1.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Bank Stake Sold
abstract: Indonesia sells 51 percent stake in B

headline: MIDWAY GAMES HIRES CHIEF EXECUTIVE FROM PLAYBOY
abstract: Midway Games Inc replaces chief executive Neil D Nicastro with Playboy Enterprises' president-chief operating officer David F Zucker (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Truckers Strike Ends
abstract: Truckers' strike that has paralyzed port of Pusan, South Korea, for week is settled (S)

headline: U.S. Envoy in West Bank Urges Steps by Palestinians and Israel
abstract: American envoy William J Burns says Palestinians must halt violence and Israel must ease tough security measures to nudge new Middle East peace initiative forward; violence continues; Israeli man is killed and two others are injured when their car comes under gunfire near Jewish settlement in West Bank; Prime Minister Mahmoud Abbas claims Palestinians are 'well on our way' to implementing road map, while Israel has expressed more than dozen reservations about plan; Prime Min Ariel Sharon says security measures will not be scaled back until Israel is confident that Abbas is committed to halting attacks on Israel; Sharon refuses to meet with Yasir Arafat, but has expressed willingness to see Abbas (M)

headline: Top Executives at ImClone Step Down Under Pressure
abstract: ImClone Systems president-chief executive Dr Harlan W Waksal resigns from those posts but will become company's chief scientific officer; Waksal took over as chief executive year ago after his brother Samuel D Waksal resigned before being arrrested on charges of insider trading; Samuel Waksal has since pleaded guilty to securities fraud and other charges and is awaiting sentencing; Robert F Goldhammer resigns as chairman and will leave ImClone board when his term expires at next annual meeting; chief financial officer Daniel S Lynch will be acting chief executive while board searches for permanent chief (M)

headline: Roving Instant-Message Pad Supplants the Portable Phone
abstract: Motorola introduces IMFree, wireless hand-held 'Web pad' that permits users to send and receive instant messages from anywhere in home; device requires base station tethered to personal computer that is connected to Internet but it does not tie up family PC; photo (S)

headline: Intelligence on Iraq Defended
abstract: President Bush's top foreign policy advisers insisted that all evidence indicated that Saddam Hussein was reviving his illegal weapons programs. Page A14.

headline: Bush Affirms U.S. Is Ready to Send Troops to the Philippines
abstract: Pres Bush, meeting with Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo of Philippines at White House, reaffirms Washington's commitment to send American troops to help root out Muslim militants in southern Philippines, but does not provide details of how or when they would be sent; statement appears to be public gesture to Arroyo, whose state visit is most recent in series of public thank yous by Bush to loyal supporters during war in Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Iran Is Trying to Curb Porn and Politics on Web
abstract: Iran attempts to restrict Internet access, officially labeling as depraved some sites that mock Islamic Republic's puritanism, and host of other political, social and truly pornographic online destinations; limitations put on newspapers and other mass media lead people to look for news on Internet; line between what is acceptable and degenerate, legal and illegal, remains fluid, so crackdown has prompted cat-and-mouse game between conservative hierarchy and Iran's younger generation, which is growing ever more technically proficient in gaining access to Western Web sites; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: PAKISTAN: Restoring Links To India; MYANMAR: Freedom Anniversary;.

headline: Youth and Fitness Offer Little Defense Against Disease
abstract: Health officials in Hong Kong report that new respiratory disease known as SARS is beginning to kill younger and healthier adults as well as older people, as medical treatments are proving somewhat less effective than originally hoped; efforts to harvest serum from patients who have recovered from disease and inject it into those still suffering, in hope that serum will contain antibodies, have run into safety problems; World Health Orgn says SARS has hit Hong Kong harder than anywhere else, for reasons that remain unclear; it has three-fifths of world's current SARS patients, although questions have been raised about veracity of mainland China's figures; photo (M)

headline: A Role for the U.N., or Not; the Iraqi Leaders' Whereabouts
abstract: Overview of reports on Iraqe

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: KOREAN RAIL LINKS PLANNED; PAKISTAN: 18 Held In Attack On Police;.

headline: Boldly Defending Their Options in a Penitent Age
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column on move by TIAA-CREF, big public pension fund, to reform executive pay practices by requiring that top executives get stock options only if their companies clear certain performance hurdles and that they hold most of shares for substantial period; SBC Communications and Siebel Systems are only companies of 50 approached by fund who fight proposal; face shareholders votes; SBC stock price graph (M)

headline: SAKS BUYS 12% OF FAO, THE TOY RETAILER
abstract: Saks Inc bought equivalent of 12 percent stake in toy retailer FAO Inc, which emerged from bankruptcy protection last month; purchased 5,000 FAO preferred shares for $5 million (S)

headline: Finding the Perfect Fit: A Cat's-Eye View
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on Web sources for eyeglasses; drawing (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CITADEL BROADCASTING CORP., a unit of Forstman Little & Co., New York, said it would buy 11 radio stations from Wilks Broadcasting, a unit of the Wicks Group of Cos., for $133 million.    WILLIAMS COS., Tulsa, Okla., owner of a leading natural gas pipeline system, said it would sell natural gas deposits in Colorado to Petroleum Development Corp., Bridgeport, W. Va., for $28 million to raise cash and help avert bankruptcy.

headline: In Searching the Web, Google Finds Riches
abstract: Article on financial success of Google information service; Google does not disclose revenue or profit, but it says it has been profitable for nine consecutive quarters; its executives have privately told board that revenue will soar from less than $300 million in 2002 to $750 million or more this year, with gross profit margins of 30 percent; Yahoo, Microsoft and others are discovering it will not be easy to unseat Google; Google employs 800 people, yet it handles 200 million searches of Web each day; is leading Internet movement to offer advertising related exclusively to individual user's interests; co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin comment; photos (M)

headline: An Investment Adviser Urges That El Paso Board Be Ousted
abstract: Influential investment adviser Institutional Shareholder Services recommends that El Paso Corp stockholders elect board of directors being proposed by dissident shareholders; company's stock has plunged in year; photo (M)

headline: Executives See Weak U.S. Economy Over Next 6 Months
abstract: Chief executives of large companies expect the American economy to remain weak over the next six months but to avoid a new recession, according to a new survey.

headline: American Air's Parent Reports Huge Loss
abstract: AMR, parent of American Airlines, reports first-quarter loss of $1.04 billion; company lost $1.56 billion in year-earlier quarter; revenue was $4.12 billion, 1 percent drop from year ago; chief executive Donald J Carty calls results 'truly dreadful' (M)

headline: G.I.'s Will Gradually Leave Korea DMZ to Cut War Risk
abstract: United States and South Korea agree to reposition American troops far away from demilitarized zone that separates North and South Korea to make them less vulnerable to attack by North; 14,000 American troops are considered strategic 'tripwire' on Korean peninsula, ensuring that American troops would be drawn into any war started by North; redeployment, which will occur over period of years, is negotiated at time of high tensions beetween US and North Korea over North's suspected development of nuclear weapons; it comes after months of strained relations between US and South Korea, where Pres Roh Moo Hyun won election in December amid large-scale protest movement against American military presence in country; most of 37,000 American troops in South Korea are based in northern tier of country, in and around Seoul; some South Korean officials feared that repositioning of troops would leave US free to make pre-emptive attack against North Korea's nuclear sites without fear of retaliation against American soldiers; their fears are eased when US pledges that some American troops will remain presence in northern part of country, near demilitarized zone; photo (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Convertibles Gain A Bigger Following
abstract: Purchases of mutual funds made up of fixed-income securities that can be converted to common stock have surged recently, as individual investors look for ways to limit losses in volatile stock market; funds give investors some income and less exposure to falling stock prices than stock funds; got $846 million in net cash in 2002, ending year with $8.1 billion in total assets, and gained added $339 million in 2003 first quarter; table of performance results; photos (M)

headline: Israelis and Palestinians Press Points Ahead of Key Meetings
abstract: The outcome of the crucial talks will set the tone for a planned three-way summit meeting with President Bush.

headline: Webdenda
abstract: Art Directors Club, New York, will present Pixar Animation Studios, Emeryville, Calif., with the 2003 Vision Award, honoring what the club calls Pixar's commitment to design throughout the creative process. The award will be presented at the club's 82nd annual awards ceremony on June 5.

headline: CAPITAL HAS LOOK OF A BATTLEFIELD
abstract: Gunfire erupts on grounds of Republican Palace in Baghdad, almost 24 hours after arrival of US tank column; explosions thunder over city that now resembles battlefield, with Iraqi special forces and militia taking up positions on streets and bridges; photos; US units appear to make forays from palace compound to take control of surrounding areas in heart of government district; Iraqis fire from around Palestine Hotel, apparently betting they will not take return fire because foreign journalists are there; semblance of normality persists on east bank of Tigris, with cafes crowded, although city is without electricity, water or much telephone service and buses are scarce for crowds trying to leave; Information Minister Muhammad Said al-Sahhaf insists to reporters that they are not really seeing American troops in city (M)

headline: A Warning on Health Claims
abstract: Federal Trade Commission and Food and Drug Administration are sending letters to retail and Internet marketers of coral calcium products warning them to cease any false or deceptive advertising; say many health claims go far beyond scientific evidence (S)

headline: WorldCom to Exit Bankruptcy and Change Name to MCI
abstract: WorldCom Inc., which last year had both the biggest bankruptcy filing and the biggest accounting fraud in corporate history, is getting a makeover.

headline: Syria Fears the Unknown: What's Behind U.S. Threats
abstract: Syria, which has been burnishing its pan-Arab credentials by criticizing America, faces new reality of barrage of threats from United States, whose military is virtually on its doorstep in neighboring Iraq; warnings by Pres Bush, Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld and other senior advisors, mostly seem to reflect American concerns that Iraqi leadership might escape to Syria; but Bush administration, while asserting that it is not contemplating military action against Syria, is also warning Damascus, in terms once reserved for Baghdad, against providing place where terrorist groups can obtain weapons of mass destruction; Syria denies that any senior Iraqis have crossed border, saying they would not be welcome; two countries have long been ruled by bitterly competitive branches of Baath Party, and there has also been marked public backlash against the tens of thousands of Iraqis living in Syria; officials also deny facilitating travel of volunteer fighters or delivery of weapons across border; governments in Middle East and beyond say they are at loss to explain why United States is so vociferously comparing Syria to Iraq; brewing crisis has already alarmed moderate Arab states worried about regional instability; they say that Syria's sole objective is to get back territory occupied by Israel since 1967; photos (M)

headline: Are Toxins Astir? Release the Hounds
abstract: JESSE ARNOLD took his dog to the park on Saturday, hovering over it with an umbrella to shield it from the rain. Water would kill it, or at least short it out.     That's because the dog is a robot. It is also part of a multidisciplinary research project at Yale University that upgrades low-end robotic toys to sniff out environmental toxins.

headline: As AIDS Ravages Caribbean, Governments Confront Denial
abstract: AIDS is imperiling many Caribbean countries as it spreads into population; infection rate there is highest outside Africa; health experts and political leaders warn of potential for devastation in region of small, image-conscious countries that depend on limited pool of labor and resources, as well as tourism; 40,000 adults and children in Caribbean are believed to have died of disease in 2001 alone; it is leading cause of death among young men; epidemic's full extent is obscured by fear, denial, limited treatment and lack of public health resources; estimated 2.4 percent of Caribbean's adult population is thought to be infected with HIV; migration between islands--and United States--is common and helps spread disease; medications remain unavailable in many places, and on many islands hospitals and doctors lack will or resources to treat HIV-positive patients, bouncing them from clinic to clinic; photos; map; chart (L)

headline: Electronic Data Systems Posts a Loss
abstract: Electronic Data Systems posts loss for first quarter; net loss was $126 million compared with net income of $354 million year earlier; total revenue rose 1.9 percent, to $5.37 billion; company is under investigation for its accounting practices (M)

headline: Syria and Jordan Suspected of Being Conduits for Funds Drained From Iraq
abstract: Federal authorities and investigators searching for $1 billion in currency stolen from Iraq's central bank by relatives of Saddam Hussein are focusing on Syria and Jordan; say two countries have long been conduits for government funds that Hussein moved secretly out of Iraq; note they have had extensvie business dealings with Iraq, particularly in oil trading, which provided ample opportunities for Hussein to cloak funds; charge both countries turned blind eye to transfer of money by Hussein's government, which violated United Nations Security Council sanctions; say they doubt that political leaders and financiers in both nations will cooperate with them now in search for funds (M)

headline: A SHOW OF FORCE
abstract: Armored force of 60 American tanks and other vehicles enters center of Baghdad from south and then loops out to city's international airport, taking city's defenders by surprise and starting rolling firefight along boulevards lined with some people waving and others shooting; one American tank gunner dies, and hundreds of Iraqi fighters are killed; military officials say that of six Iraqi divisions ringing Baghdad before allied attack began, just three are left and that only 92 of 2,500 tanks thought to have been at disposal of Republican Guard troops remain; swing into Baghdad is intended to show people there, who had just seen Pres Saddam Hussein on television, walking city's streets amid cheering crowd of supporters, that American forces now encamped at city's edges can attack at will; photos; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: MICROCHIP TECHNOLOGY TO CUT 140 JOBS; BROADCOM WILL HAVE 2ND-QUARTER EXPENSE; SOUTH KOREA SEEKS REVERSAL OF CHIP TARIFF;.

headline: To Get Broadband Cable, Install a Modem Yourself
abstract: Q. How can I install a cable modem for Internet broadband service with a kit supplied by the cable company?    A. If you have cable television service, adding a cable modem for high-speed Internet access is not difficult.

headline: Recent Suicide Bombers Could Have Been Working in Concert
abstract: The two bombers struck 12 hours apart, lived a block apart in Hebron, belonged to Hamas and carried out their attacks disguised as religiously observant Jews.

headline: Twee Rivieren Journal; Bushmen Squeeze Money From a Humble Cactus
abstract: Pfizer is working on appetite suppressant from cactus plant used by African Bushmen for generations, principally to raise their energy and fight hunger during long hunting trips; now one of world's oldest and least developed peoples hopes to enjoy its first taste of prosperity, thanks to desert weed known as hoodia; Pfizer, with British-based research partner, has spent millions working to develop drug from active chemical in hoodia plant; San Bushmen of South Africa have already received $30,000; under agreement reached between them and government; about 100,000 Bushmen in South Africa, Botswana, Namibia and Angola will receive at least three more payments during clinical testing of drug; South African government will pay San Bushmen 6 percent of royalties it receives once drug goes on market; San trace their history back 150,000 years, to world's first humans; photo; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Promoting Secularism
abstract: France's Education Minister Luc Ferry wants new law for state schools that would eliminate all religious elements from learning environment; head scarves and crucifixes are already banned, but restrictions are not always enforced; Ferry contends that renewed emphasis on secular surroundings is effort to keep national rise in racism and anti-semitism out of schools (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: A Chase Saga Dominated by Its Cinematic Cousin
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory colum reviews game Enter the Matrix, based on Matrix movies; photos (M)

headline: NPS PHARMACEUTICALS CANCELS ENZON BID
abstract: NPS Pharmaceuticals Inc, which agreed to buy rival Enzon Pharmaceuticals Inc, says companies have called off deal (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: New Sars Case
abstract: China reports new case of SARS in Guangdong Province one day after World Health Organization lifts ban on travel to Beijing and declares country to have effectively controlled disease; patient was already under quarantine as suspected SARS case (S)

headline: What's on the Menu?
abstract: Command Shortcuts    Q.What is a contextual menu? How does it differ from the regular menu bar at the top of the computer screen?    A.Menus -- lists of options, commands and controls -- are a common part of operating systems, like Microsoft Windows and Apple Computer's Mac OS, that use a graphical interface and a pointing device like a mouse.

headline: Tony Blair, Visiting Basra, Tells of Challenges Ahead
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain, first foreign leader to visit postwar Iraq, makes quick stop in Basra to praises British soldiers there; came under fierce political attack at home for joining American-led war; is portraying his visit not as victory tour but as tribute to British forces, especially those who died in fighting; later meets with L Paul Bremer 3d, new American civilian administrator, and is briefed on security and challenge of forming new government (M)

headline: Iran Hunger Striker Allowed to Stay in Britain as Refugee
abstract: The Iranian political poet who sewed up his lips, eyes, and ears in protest at what he says are injustices in the way Britain treats asylum seekers is to be granted refugee status.

headline: Apparel Chain Plans Multicultural Theme
abstract: Apparel Chain Plans Multicultural Theme.

headline: British Cabinet Minister Quits, Accusing Blair of Betrayal
abstract: Britain's secretary for international development, Clare Short, becomes second person to resign from cabinet over Iraq; makes angry speech to House of Commons, accusing Prime Min Tony Blair of 'betrayal' of his promise to work for United Nations involvement in postwar Iraq; scores what she sees as his cooperation in American campaign to 'bully' UN; Short squandered much of her standing with Labor dissidents in Parliament in March when she reneged on pledge to resign if Britain joined US-led war without UN approval; Downing Street announces that Baroness Amos will replace Short in British cabinet; photo (M)

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: Bush Urges U.N. to Lift Economic Sanctions Against Iraq
abstract: President Bush's call was a challenge to members to recognize the coalition's military success despite strong opposition.

headline: Bush's Next Role: Mediator in Disputes Over Running Postwar Iraq
abstract: President Bush is moving to end arguments between the U.S. and Europe and between his own State and Defense Departments.

headline: Earnings Off 13% At Williams-Sonoma
abstract: Williams-Sonoma says earnings fell 13 percent in its first quarter ended May 4; net income dropped to $13.4 million from $15.4 million year earlier; sales increased 12 percent, to $536.8 million (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Consumer Borrowing: Feb.    TUESDAY  None

headline: Kurdish Group Takes Autonomous Role in Iraq Oil Projects
abstract: Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, Kurdish political party working with United States to shape interim government in Iraq, pushes ahead quietly on three oil development projects, acting autonomously as local government; party has signed production-sharing contracts with two Turkish companies to develop and survey oilfields in northeast Iraq, and has agreed to allow Australian company to do surveying work in eastern Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Ethics Lacking in Business School Curriculum, Students Say in Survey
abstract: Aspen Intitute survey shows ethical conduct in workplace has become increasingly important to students at leading business schools but students are concerned that their study progams might teach questionable value that may later contribute to mismanagement and corporate fraud; study finds that 73.9 percent of respondents consider meeting customers' needs to be top priority of company, while 70.6 percent of those polled believe maximizing shareholder value is second most important priority; participants in poll include Columbia Business School, Yale School of Management, Wharton School at University of Pennsylvania and London Business School (M)

headline: Shares Move Higher on Earnings Vigor
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 19.36 points, increase of 2.2 percent, to 911.37; Dow Jones industrial average adds 156.09 points, or 1.9 percent, ending at 8,484.99; Nasdaq composite index gains 26.99 points, or 1.9 percent, closing at 1,451.36; US bond prices rise; 10-year note gains 5/32, to price of 99 8/32; yield falls to 3.97 percent from 3.99 percent; 30-year bond rises 3/32, to 107 10/32; yield drops to 4.89 percent from 4.90 percent; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Israelis and Palestinians Prepare for New Peace Initiative
abstract: Israel and Palestnians gear up for new Middle East peace effort that would require both sides to take steps they have long resisted; international peace plan, known as road map, is most ambitious one in 31 months of Middle East bloodshed; there is no guarantee plan will fare any better than previous proposals abandoned amid almost daily violence; plan has backing of United States, United Nations, European Union and Russia; Palestinians are urging adoption of three-phase plan according to timetable that envisions comprehensive peace agreement and Palestinian statehood by 2005; Israeli cabinet stresses that any progress is contingent on Palestinians' halting violence; Israel wants United States alone to be responsible for monitoring security issues, and insists that Palestinians drop demand for 'right of return' of Palestinians who fled or were forced from their homes in Middle East wars; first phase of plan calls for Palestinian leadership and security forces to crack down on violence, although Palestinian militants are pledging to press ahead (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: General Says He May Surrender
abstract: Ante Gotovina, former Croatian army general and third most-wanted war crimes suspect at Hague tribunal, offers possibility of his surrender in interview with Nacional Croation weekly; was indicted for 1995 crimes against Serbs in Krajina region (Bosnia) (S)

headline: Publicis Combines Health Care Units
abstract: Publicis Groupe is reorganizing its many units specializing in health care advertising and marketing into new division led by Publicis president and chief operating officer Roger Haupt; division will be called Publicis Healthcare Group (S)

headline: May Day in Beijing: Not Everything Is Changed by SARS
abstract: Revelries in Beijing were badly crimped by the pervasive fear of disease and the city's stringent new controls on public events and touring. But some things remained the same.

headline: Not Snow Nor Gloom of Night, but Other Factors Slow Troops' Mail
abstract: Delivering letters is complicated by soldiers' need for supplies which always trumps letters, photographs and care packages.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Executive Leaves Reuters
abstract: Reuters Group says chief operating officer Philip Green will leave on June 30 and it will eliminate position to reduce costs; photo (S)

headline: Personal Business; Some Memorial Stones Need Not Be Made From Granite
abstract: LifeGem Memorials makes diamonds for mourners from carbon in cremated remains of people and pets; customers comment; photo (M)

headline: New Economy; As regulators become more stringent, data storage companies prepare for a wave of demand.
abstract: Increasingly-stringent government regulations concerning companies' need to retain data such as internal memos and e-mail benefit data storage companies that package high-margin data management software with their storage hardware offerings (M)

headline: Kurds and Displaced Arabs Compete for Land
abstract: Hundreds of Arab families in Iraq's north are being displaced by Kurds, who themselves were driven from area during Iraq's most sweeping ethnic cleansing campaign over 30 years ago; since war, Kurds are returning to their original homes and farmland, and Arabs are migrating back to lands in center, south and west of Iraq; some Arab families have no home or land to go back to; land disputes in north were foreseen by relief organizations long before war (M)

headline: Sniper Kills U.S. Soldier as Violence Goes On in Iraq
abstract: Sniper kills American soldier on patrol in northwestern neighborhood of Baghdad, 11th US military death in guerrilla assaults in last three weeks; soldier is shot in back in his vehicle; large-scale military raids continue in capital and across broad arc north and west of city; more than 100 people arrested; photos; US administrator L Paul Bremer says reconstruction work is proceeding, but is slowed where military operations are under way; announces special Iraqi court to try senior Baath Party members trying to destabilize situation (M)

headline: McDonald's Seeking Cut In Antibiotics In Its Meat
abstract: McDonald's Corp says it will ask its meat suppliers around world to reduce their dependence on antibiotics; expects its suppliers to phase out use of some antibiotics that promote growth in healthy animals and to significantly reduce use of other antibiotics that typically protect animals against disease; is responding to growing evidence that use of antibiotics in farm animals is creating antibiotic resistance in animals and in bacteria that cause diseases in humans; industry officials say McDonald's decision will likely help alter way animals are raise around world because McDonald's is world's largest restaurant chain and one of world's biggest purchasers of meat; other major restaurant chains and food companies are expected to follow McDonald's lead and force suppliers to cut back antibiotic use; photos (M)

headline: In Land of Sake, Brewers Suffer as a New Generation Sniffs Disdainfully
abstract: Sake brewers of Japan's Shimane Prefecture, which produces some of country's finest sake, seek ways to interest younger Japanese in sake, which they are spurning for beer and wine; number of sake breweries in Japan has halved since 1955, and domestic consumption plummeted by 30 percent since between 1989 and 2001; success of sake in US market is only hope for brewers; photos; map (M)

headline: Wieden Leads Honors At Commercials Show
abstract: Offices of Wieden & Kennedy wins 12 honors in agency category at annual show sponsored by Association of Independent Commercial Producers, recognizing work on television commercials; other winners noted (S)

headline: Orange County to Use Merrill Again
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company wins right to work for Orange County, California, nine years after county filed for bankruptcy caused by bad bet on derivatives sold to it by Merrill; Merrill paid county $400 million in 1998 to settle allegations against firm; county's Board of Supervisors voted 3 to 2 to again use Merrill as an investment broker (S)

headline: Arab Media Portray War as Killing Field
abstract: Rage against United States in Arab countries is fed by steady diet of close-up color photographs in Arab newspapers and television footage of dead and wounded Iraqis; some papers are blending images of Iraqi war with coverage of Palestinians, superimposing Israeli flag on American flag, to give impression that what is happening in Iraq is part of one continuous brutal assault by America and its allies on defenseless Arabs, wherever they are; Arab leaders and moderates had hoped for short war with minimum of inflammatory pictures of Iraqi civilian casualties; instead, war has become political crisis of street protests, militant call for holy war and bitter public criticism of ties to US; biggest influence on coverage comes from satellite news channel Al Jazeera; prominent Islamist writer Fahmi Howeidy says people feel frustrated and humiliated; predicts chaos in Arab world if war continues much longer; photos (M)

headline: In Ancient Skulls From Ethiopia, Familiar Faces
abstract: Scientists think they see for first time faces of immediate ancestors of modern humans in 160,000-year-old fossilized skulls of two adults and child found in Ethiopia; except for few archaic characteristics, skulls are readily recognizable; they are longer than their Neanderthal contemporaries from Eurasia or earlier ancestors; discovery of oldest near-modern human remains is considered major step in establishing time and place for emergence of anatomically modern Homo sapiens, probably 150,000 years ago in Africa, as previous genetic studies suggest; Dr Tim D White, paleoanthropologist who lead international team that excavated and analyzed skulls, reports findings in journal Nature; findings are thought to fill frustrating gap in fossil evidence between 100,000 and 300,000 years ago, when transition from prehumans to modern humans is thought to have taken place; fossils, found in 1997, were so fragmented that it took years of cleaning, re-assembling and analyzing before discoverers felt they could report their findings; photos; map (L)

headline: Calpers to Invest $200 Million in Japan Turnaround Fund
abstract: California Public Employees' Retirement System is expected to put $200 million in fund managed by W L Ross & Co that will invest in small Japanese companies; Ross hopes to raise another $800 million in private equity for fund (M)

headline: George Kozmetsky, 89, Dean And a Co-Founder of Teledyne
abstract: Dr George Kozmetsky, co-founder of conglomerate Teledyne and lifelong educator who sought to bring industry and academia closer together, dies at age 85; photo (M)

headline: The tortured review for the prized California Lottery account heads to a third round.
abstract: WHAT may well be the wildest Western account review ever has taken another wacky turn as the California Lottery Commission has asked agencies to compete for the lucrative assignment for the third time in 18 months.    Lottery executives, in a decision made on Friday, in effect tossed out the results of two previous lengthy and lawsuit-generating reviews for the account, which had been handled for the last five years by the Los Angeles office of Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group.

headline: Filipino Journalists Find Death Threats Are Part of Job
abstract: Many journalists in Philippines arm themselves and hired bodyguards out of fear for their lives; Committee to Protect Journalists ranks Philippines among most dangerous countries outside war zones for journalists, along with Algeria, Pakistan, Colombia, Cuba and Russia; says that since Pres Ferdinand E Marcos was driven from office in 1986, 40 journalists have been killed; none of cases has been solved; photo of Hernan dela Cruz, editor of Zamboanga Scribe, who now carries pistol and moves about with two armed bodyguards (M)

headline: British and French to Halt Concorde Flights
abstract: Concorde, the needle-nosed jet that flies across the Atlantic at supersonic speeds, will be retired this year due to falling passenger demand and rising maintenance costs.

type: Money and Business/Financial DeskMoney and Bus
headline: Private Sector; A Car Guy Runs Into Some Critics
abstract: General Motors Corp vice chairman Robert A Lutz shares his passion for automobiles with art and design students at Pratt Institute; during question-and-answer session, students pressed him--at times aggressively--on environmental consequences of 16-cylinder Cadillac Sixteen, imtimidating size of Hummer H2 and power of corporations to influence consumer taste (S)/

headline: Drug Makers to Expand Panel On Joint Research on Cancer
abstract: Pharmaceutical executives will broaden task force formed to consider ways for industry to collaborate on cancer research; possible area of cooperating is in research into mechanisms by which tumors form and grow; group's chairman is Robert Ingram of GlaxoSmithKline (M)

headline: Heinz's Earnings Decrease 54%
abstract: H J Heinz Co says earnings dropped 54 percent in its fourth quarter ended April 30; net income fell to $102.6 million from $223.5 million; sales rose 6 percent, to $2.19 billion (S)

headline: Walter Cronkite Backs Away From Sponsored Video Deal
abstract: Former CBS News anchor Walter Cronkite sends letter ending his agreement with production company WJMK to serve as host for series of corporate-sponsored videos, resembling news reports, that are broadcast on public television stations; WJMK recently hired Cronkite and Aaron Brown of CNN to replace Morley Safer as hosts of series called American Medical Review; Safer also sends letter to WJMK, demanding that it stop using videotape of him appearing on news-style set as host of series; tape was made several years ago, but has been used in hundreds of videos since; drug makers and other health care companies pay WJMK about $15,000 to have their products featured in American Medical Review videos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Jobless Rate Rises
abstract: Japan's unemployment rate rose to 5.4 percent in March, from 5.2 percent in February, and number of new jobs slipped (S)

headline: Bush and Blair Will Meet In Belfast Early Next Week On Iraq, Mideast and Ulster
abstract: Pres Bush will meet with Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain in Belfast beginning April 6 to discuss war in Iraq and peace efforts in Northern Ireland and Israel; meeting will focus on when to declare existence of new Iraqi government, event that American officials now say could come even before government of Saddam Hussein is toppled or Baghdad is secured; Bush meets at White House with dozen Iraqi exiles, who speak in unified voice of their support for Bush and war to overthrow Hussein, whom they accuse of human rights abuses and atrocities; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDIA: Industrial Output Rises; SOUTH KOREA: Help For Credit Unit;.

headline: Vanguard Closes a Bond Fund
abstract: Vanguard Group closes its High-Yield Corporate Bond fund to new investors for at least three months and will limit existing sharehoulders to $100,000 in added investments this year; chairman John J Brennan cites effort to protect long-term shareholders from costs of increased transaction activity caused by investors soley focused on past performance and high yields (S)

headline: Shaky Ground Is Ahead And Behind in the North
abstract: Allied ground war advancing in northern Iraq faces two principal challenges: risks of armed resistance on lonely approaches to expected battle for Tikrit, Saddam Hussein's ancestral home and power base, and risk of escalating civil unrest in regions that have already changed hands; Kirkuk, which fell into American control on Apr 10, remains rife with disorder and uncertainty; city has been left largely to its own drift and disorder after fighting stopped, just like other cities where American fighters have broken Baath Party's hold on government; Fairadoon Abdulkader, interior minister for eastern Kurdish zone, arrives in Kirkuk with fledgling police force; he is angry about looting of past two days, and upset that it was given chance to occur; says American forces are making mistake by not thinking beyond what happens after fighting stops; photo (M)

headline: Bush Is Said to Accept a U.N. Role in Postwar Iraq
abstract: The Australian foreign minister said in remarks broadcast that President Bush seemed disposed to having a special U.N. representative working in a postwar Iraq.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Martha Stewart Is Indicted And Vows to Fight Charges  Martha Stewart was indicted on charges of conspiracy, obstruction of justice and securities fraud for a personal stock trade she made in 2001. She pleaded not guilty and vowed to fight the charges.     Hours after her arraignment in federal court, the media and merchandising company she founded, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, announced that she was stepping down as chairwoman and chief executive. She will continue as a director and be the company's chief creative director. [Page A1.]

headline: 2 Promoters of Worker Protests in China Get Prison Sentences
abstract: Yao Fuxin and Xiao Yunliang, who promoted large worker protests in northeastern China last year, are given stiff prison sentences on charges of subverting the state (S)

headline: That Championship Season, in Code
abstract: Scene described at annual finals of International Collegiate Programming Contest, where teams of students from around world compete for top prize of $10,000 and laptop computer for each member of three-person team; teams are given real-life problems that require automated solutions; photos (L)

headline: Hussein's Top Science Adviser Surrenders to U.S. Marines
