abstract: Gen Amir al-Saadi, Saddam Hussein's top science adviser, turns himself in to United States marines in downtown Baghdad after telling German journalist that Iraq had no chemical or biological weapons (M)

headline: Commercial Time Is Selling Quickly For Cable, Too
abstract: Robust demand for commercial time on broadcast television networks before start of 2003-4 season is carrying over to their cable counterparts as both look to set records for revenue in 'upfront' market; upfront market for broadcasters is likely to total $9.2 billion to $9.3 billion, compared with $8.1 billion last spring; revenue in cable market could reach $5.4 billion to $5.6 billion compared with $4.6 billion last spring (M)

headline: Iraq Shows Casualties In Hospital
abstract: Hospital in Hilla, about 30 miles south of Baghdad, becomes showcase of what Saddam Hussein's government wants world to believe about American way of war; hospital reports scores of dead and hundreds of wounded from incident in which civilians came under attack from US tank that fired on a bus and from US aircraft that dropped cluster bombs on impoverished neighborhood; photo (M)

headline: Bush's Commitment to Mideast Peace Plan Gives Rise to Optimism in the Arab World
abstract: Pres Bush's promise to concentrate on resolving Israeli-Palestinian conflict encourages Arab world and makes US, for now, focus of hope rather than rage, despite long tradition of mistrusting US motives; photo of Palestinian Prme Min Mahmoud Abbas (M)

headline: CYTEC INDUSTRIES SAYS IT IS BUYING AVECIA BUSINESS
abstract: Cytec Industries, which makes chemicals and materials for aerospace and auto industries, acquires metal and stabilizers business of Avecia Investments for $97 million (S)

headline: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; AIRPORT CONTRACT FOR IRAQ
abstract: Bush administration awards contract to SkyLink Air and Logistic Support Inc to manage Iraq's international airports in Baghdad, Basra and Mosul; contract could be worth $10.2 million over 18 months (S)

headline: Head to Head; For $2,000 or More, 4 Smooth Operators
abstract: Ratings of high-end video gaming systems from Voodoo, Alienware, Falcon and Hypersonic noted (S)

headline: 2 Ex-Ministers Accuse Blair of Distorting Intelligence
abstract: Robin Cook and Clare Short, two members of Prime Min Tony Blair's cabinet who resigned over Iraq war, tell House of Commons committee that Britain made selective use of intelligence to make case that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction; say they were told by security officials before war that Iraqi weapons did not pose immediate threat; Cook says he does not question Blair's good faith, but Short accuses Blair of misleading public; both question 'thin' dossier Blair cited (M)

headline: Dead in Iraq
abstract: Defense Dept releases name of American confirmed dead in Iraq

headline: North Korea, Protesting New Ship Inspections, Suspends Its Passenger Ferry Link With Japan
abstract: North Korea suspends service on its lone passenger ferry link with Japan, in response to new Japanese and American policy of subjecting all North Korean shipping to intensive inspections; without provoking North Korea with formal penalties or naval blockade, North Korea's neighbors are seeking to pressure it to drop its clandestine nuclear weapons program; on two occasions in last week, South Korea's navy has fired warning shots at North Korean crab boats that ventured south of sea border claimed by South Korea; North Korea notes that new maritime policies followed two meetings Pres Bush had in United States in May, with Japanese Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi and South Korean Pres Roh Moo Hyun; photo (M)

headline: British Assault Captures Half Of City in South
abstract: Two British battle groups push into Basra, taking at least half of city in storm of artillery shells and tank fire; thrust comes after more than two weeks on outskirts of city; it appears to be part of coordinated effort to take down what is left of Iraqi resistance; Iraqi government's isolation will be sharply accentuated if Basra falls, and it could deal psychological blow to Baathist holdouts in Baghdad, hastening that city's fall; three British soldiers are killed; Iraqi casualties are unable to be confirmed, but hundreds are believed to have died; British tanks surround local headquarters of Pres Saddam Hussein's Baath Party, and British troops set up base at former college inside city's western limits; fighting is fierce, but British officers say Iraqi resistance is less than they feared; British advance is met with delight by some residents and alarm by others as chaotic looting takes place in streets; photos (M)

headline: Baghdad Residents Begin a Long Climb To an Ordered City
abstract: Baghdad shows tentative signs of its determination to begin long climb back toward order after five days of chaos; American troops' entry into city week ago set loose demons of popular revenge among people long repressed under Hussein and his ruling coterie; nightmarish lawlessness and violence abounded; now Iraqi volunteers are venturing out into what had been free-fire zones to recover bodies of dead and some bus service in city center has been revived; for first time in week, looters are outnumbered by taxis, buses carrying passengers rather than plunder, street stalls selling food and enough casual motorists and pedestrians to create distant facsimile of normal Sunday in Baghdad; clear manifestation of tightening American grip comes with appearance of first American military helicopters to venture over city center; American forces seek to convey message to would-be looters and hard-core remnants of Hussein's government that US is nearly unchallenged power in Baghdad, and that time is running out for those intent on score-settling over brutalities of Hussein or striking out against American forces that toppled him; photos (M)

headline: Zookeepers' New Task: Getting Animals Back
abstract: Wild Aid, conservation group from San Francisco, is helping to manage what are left of zoo animals in Baghdad and elsewhere in Iraq; American soldiers are helping; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Summit Meeting Charges
abstract: Park Jie Won and Lim Dong Won, advisers to former South Korean President Kim Dae Jung, are indicted for allegedly giving $100 million to North Korea as payment for participation in 2000 summit meeting between presidents; charges have created skepticism about motives and success of Kim Dae Jung's sunshine policy, although he was cleared of involvement in payoff; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Energy Profit Rises
abstract: Statoil, Norway's largest oil and gas producer, reported that net income rose 20 percent increase on the first quarter, to 3.59 billion Norwegian kroner ($508 million). High oil prices and increased output were offset partly by a weak dollar exchange rate and lower gas prices. For the period, Norsk Hydro, which ranks second in Norway to Statoil, earned 2.48 billion kroner ($351 million), an increase of 16 percent.   Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Currencies: Do

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Negotiators Fail to Agree On Agriculture Subsidies  Negotiators failed to meet their deadline for determining how wealthy nations would reduce their huge agriculture subsidies, the issue at the heart of the current round of trade negotiations at the World Trade Organization.    The poorer nations were promised that this round of trade talks would be of special benefit to them and require the first substantial reductions in what amounts to $300 billion of subsidies paid by the world's richest nations each year to their farmers. [Page C2.]

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Micro's New Chip To Be Used By I.B.M.
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices Inc says its new Opteron chip will be used in some server computers made by IBM (S)

headline: Once Feared, a Southern Iraqi Clan Finds Itself Hunted
abstract: Once powerful Sadun tribe, Saddam Hussein's primary supporters in southern Iraq, now beg British and American occupation forces to protect them from wrath of their neighbors; photo; map (M)

headline: Debt Sale Schedule For Coming Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes the regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills today; a four-week bill and a three-year note on Tuesday; a five-year note on Wednesday; and a 10-year note on Thursday.    By the close of the New York cash market Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.10 percent, the six-month bill was 1.12 percent and the four-week bill 1.05 percent. In when-issued trading, the three-year note was offered at a price to yield 2.01 percent, the five-year note at 2.92 percent and the 10-year note at 3.94 percent.

headline: Moving in : Reading the fine print of lease can prevent misunderstandings
abstract: PARIS—  Finding an acceptable apartment in a pleasant neighborhood abroad can be challenging enough for an expat who wants to hit the ground running in a foreign assignment. And while signing a lease may bring a sigh of relief, expats should take extra care to study local real estate customs and read the fine print of their lease if they want to prevent misunderstandings, unforeseen obligations or even the surprise of a sudden eviction.

headline: Former Mobil Oil Executive Pleads Guilty to Tax Evasion
abstract: Mobil Oil Co's former executive J Bryan William pleads guilty to evading taxes on more than $7 million in unreported income, including $2 million kickback in connection with Mobil's oil business in Kazakhstan; was charged in April with failing to report $2 million kickback he received for negotiating Mobil's purchase in 1996 of 25 percent stake in Tengiz oil field in Kazakhstan for $1.05 billion; field produces 261,000 barrel a day; money was deposited in secret bank account Williams maintained in Switzerland in name of Alqi Holdings, company in Virgin Islands that he controlled; photo (M)

headline: Flatiron Bistro Held Together By Family Ties
abstract: Profile of Cyril Renaud, owner of Fleur de Sel restaurant in New York City's Flatiron district; photo (special section, Small Business) (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil rises after OPEC members including Iran, Algeria, Qatar and Indonesia say group should reduce output; crude oil for May delivery rises $1.37, or 4.7 percent, to $30.55 per barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: DuPont Photomasks Names New Chairman
abstract: Peter S Kirlin resigns as chairman and chief executive of DuPont Photomasks; Marshall C Turner is named to succeed him (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Brewer Maintains Forecast
abstract: Belgian brewer Interbrew sticks to its earnings forecast of organic sales and profit growth this year; graph (S)

headline: As Iraqis' Disaffection Grows, U.S. Offers Them a Greater Political Role
abstract: The imam at one of Baghdad's largest mosques urged more than a thousand listeners today to wage a jihad, or religious war, against American occupying forces in Iraq.    Speaking at Friday Prayers, Imam Mouaid al-Ubaidi denounced the Americans as invaders and aggressors and implicitly praised recent guerrilla attacks against United States soldiers as self-defense by people who are being ''strangled.''

headline: Ahead of Harvest, Farm Fears Grow
abstract: Farmers in Iraq worry that harvest of their barley crops will face serious difficulties with no government in Baghdad, looted central bank, fuel in short supply and ethnic land disputes flaring; timing is crucial: one week of delays would cause barley to rot in fields; farmers will meet with Amerian officers to discuss problems; Mosul region produces half of country's wheat and barley; photo (M)

headline: Beijing Hurries to Build Hospital Complex For Increasing Number of SARS Patients
abstract: Some 4,000 construction workers, working around clock, rush to erect sprawling hospital complex in Beijing suburb to house at least thousand people who have highly infectious respiratory illness as number of reported SARS cases rises sharply in city; new hospital is latest example of how China has geared up to fight SARS, sealing off entire neighborhoods or factories where infected people live and work, closing public buildings and filling airwaves with advice about hygiene and pleas for calm; disease's growing reach has rattled even some experts; photo (M)

headline: Driving Along a Virtual Road to Recovery
abstract: Virtual Reality Medical Center in San Diego, Calif, helps people who have been in serious car accidents conquer anxieties associated with driving; photo (M)

headline: ADVICE TO PUT OFF TRIPS TO TORONTO IS LIFTED BY W.H.O.
abstract: World Health Organization lifts week-old advisory against nonessential visits to Toronto, citing ebb in SARS outbreak there; decision is welcomed by Canadian officials, who disputed contention that city became source of outbreaks outside Canada, but reversal raises question of whether WHO yielded to intense pressure from influential country; 21 people have died in Toronto but no new cases have been reported since April 9 in general community or since April 20 in hospital system; city still has 39 active cases and 398 people in quarantine; WHO chief Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland defends original advisory and shift, warning decision could be changed again; photo; China reports 389 new cases; Dr Julie L Gerberding of Centers for Disease Control tells Senate panel US has 52 probable cases, nearly all involving travel to affected countries; Canada agrees to use infrared temperature machines to screen departing international passengers at Toronto and Vancouver airports; setback to Canadian economy and Prime Min Jean Chretien's personal lobbying of Brundtland noted (M)

type: A Nation at War / A Nation at War
headline: Syria's Foreign Minister Calls U.S. Charges 'Baseless'
abstract: Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa said that the U.S. seemed to be trying to start another conflict even before stabilizing either Iraq or Afghanistan.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Drug Maker's Profit Falls
abstract: Drug maker AstraZeneca reports first-quarter pretax profit fell to $1.29 billion from $1.32 billion in 2002 period (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept list of latest Americans to die in Iraq (S)

headline: Chinese Capital Closes Schools for at Least Two Weeks
abstract: Beijing, in strongest action yet against SARS outbreak, closes all primary and secondary schools until at least May 7 and tells students to study at home, using newly improvised online educational service; orders teachers to report to schools to assist students who choose to come and study on own and to use Internet to post assignments and review materials; officials say entrance exams may have to be postponed; fearful parents in many parts of city have kept children home since disclosure that respiratory disease outbreak is larger than previously announced; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Inquiry Over Tv Trial Coverage
abstract: Government requested internal investigation into state-controlled television network RAI's broadcast of protester's derogatory comments at Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's trial draws disapproval from Italian journalists; Berlusconi, on trial for corruption, is often accused of unfair media control (S)

headline: STAGECOACH AGREES TO SELL NEW ENGLAND BUS DIVISIONS
abstract: Stagecoach Group reaches tentative agreement to sell five Coach USA units in New England to Peter Pan Bus Lines (S)4

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Extortionist Wants A.T.M. Cards
abstract: Czech Republic blackmailer, threatening to poison food in state hospitals, demands $10 million ransom be paid through elaborate ATM scheme involving 100,000 cards distributed in free newspapers; police would then supply blackmailer with PIN; Interior Minister Stanislav Gross says plan is unworkable, but is willing to negotiate another solution (S)

headline: Alienating Customers Can Involve Nickels and Dimes as Well as Dollars
abstract: Article on how some hotels and airlines can alienate loyal customers by attempting to gouge them; cites case of Diane Hansen and her husband Leslie Hendrickson who were penalized $2,400 by Continental Airlines for trip they canceled to Hong Kong in wake of mysterious virus that is spreading throughout Hong Kong; say Continental refused to offer refund despite clause in travel agreement that allowed for refund and that Visa did refund full cost, $3,800; also cites $2.75 fee that is charged at conference-center coatcheck room in Hilton New York; Hilton says it contracts out coatcheck service for conventions and organizing group has option of paying for service itself; drawing (M)

headline: Market Place; Goldman Bought Questions Along With Spear, Leeds
abstract: When the Goldman Sachs Group paid more than $6 billion in stock for the trading firm Spear, Leeds & Kellogg in 2000, even its chairman knew the price was high.    ''There is no such thing as a real bargain,'' Goldman's chairman, Henry M. Paulson, said unapologetically on the day the deal was announced.

headline: Case Re-elected To AOL Board; Margin Is Called Underwhelming
abstract: Some large shareholders of AOL Time Warner deliver open rebuke to Stephen M Case, former chairman, and two of his close associates by withholding their votes in their re-election as directors at company's annual meeting; Case and his colleagues Miles Gilburne and Kenneth Novack are re-elected to board, but with far fewer votes than rest of directors; Richard D Parsons, AOL chief executive, is battered with criticisms about ethics and performance; photo (M)

headline: Freed Soldier Undergoes Several Operations in Germany
abstract: Pfc. Jessica Lynch is undergoing a battery of operations at a military hospital here to treat wounds that include a fractured right arm, two broken legs and a spinal injury.

headline: Sears Promotes Executive
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co names Mindy Meads, executive at Lands' End, to head its clothing and home fashion business; Meads succeeds Kathryn Bufano as executive vice president for soft lines and will continue to hold that title at company's Lands' End unit; Bill White is appointed vice president of store operations, succeeding Mary Conway (S)

headline: The Test for Rumsfeld: Will Strategy Work?
abstract: Critics charged that Donald H. Rumsfeld's principles of a new American military have been applied in Iraq and found wanting.

headline: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; U.N. SENDS TEAM TO IRAQ
abstract: UN sends first team of human rights investigators to Iraq for long-term missionto help distribute aid and handle rights complaints (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: *Direct Marketing Association, New York, expels member, Infolink Technogies, for fax abuse; Interactive Edge completes management buyout from Cordiant Communications Group (S)

headline: Iraqi Documents on Israel Surface on a Cultural Hunt
abstract: American soldiers from special mobile exploitation team work with members of opposition Iraqi National Congress to search secret police headquarters, Baghdad, for seventh century copy of Jewish Talmud, one of most ancient copies in existence; fail to unearth text, but instead find trove of Iraqi intelligence documents and maps relating to Israel and data on offer by 'holy warrior' to sell uranium and other nuclear materials to Iraq; photo (M)

headline: British Department Store Reviews Bids for Buyout
abstract: Board of Selfridges & Co, London department store, meets to discuss rival buyout offers from Galen Weston, Canadian supermarket magnate who heads George Weston Ltd, and Scottish retail entrepreneur Tom Hunter (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurance Unit Spinoff
abstract: World Business Briefing: Britain: Insurance Unit Spiÿ

headline: Japan to Spend $16.5 Billion to Save Bank
abstract: Japan to Spend $16.5 Billion to Save B

headline: Europe Extends Deadline on G.E.'s Finnish Deal
abstract: European Commission stops clock in its probe into planned acquisition by General Electric of Finnish medical equipment company Instrumentarium, pushing back Aug 18 deadline for ruling on deal; GE says it still expects to close deal by end of September; deal is also under examination in US (M)
